description:
Really great first visit for lunch! Got on the Yelp Waitlist while we looked for parking and by the time we walked over, our table was ready. We ordered 6 dishes for about $60 not including tip. 

1. Savory soy milk with Chinese donut
2. Pea sprouts with garlic
3. Spicy pork and chive dumplings 
4. XLB Shanghai pork dumplings 
5. Dry fried chicken wings 
6. Pan fried pork buns 

Food impressions
1. Rich and savory soy milk with bits of pickle and pork sung at the bottom. The donut was also nice and crispy.
2. Fresh and generous portion with whole sautéed garlic cloves. Not too salty with a good crunch. 
3. Thick skin (too thick for my preference), but good pork/leek flavor, and very garlicky vinegar sauce, which I liked. 
4. Again, thick skin, but pork flavor was super savory. 
5. Five-spice forward and crisp skin. 
6. My favorite dish! Small delicate crispy and chewy with a juicy pork flavor. There was a hint of sweetness in the dough, too. I enjoyed pouring the spicy dumpling sauce on the pan-fried pork buns.

Service impressions
Fast, competent, and efficient wait-staff. 
Debit or cash only.

Would come back!!
author: Leah H.

description:
I'm only giving 3 stars because the service was fast. 

Idk if it's because I've had some delicious dumplings/xiao long baos in the past and I'm just expecting consistent quality...but this was definitely THE WORST dumplings I've ever had. The dough/wrapper was too thick and has weird texture like it was stretched out enough. 

We ordered:
- crab & pork xiao long bao (this was ok - weird texture)
- pork dumplings in chili oil (this was BAD!!!! It didn't even taste like chili oil, wrapper was too thick, and there were chunks of garlic?)
- shrimp fried rice (this was as expected)
author: Nikka C.

description:
Dumpling and noodle craving satisfied!! Came here on Sunday around 12PM and was already super packed, I joined the waitlist though so thankfully skipped the wait. Ordered the XLB, spicy wontons, beef stew, and green onion pancake. 

-XLBs were sooooo good!! The skin was thicker than others I've had but I think this helped hold the broth inside of the dumplings better, very flavorful. Ask for the red vinegar w/ ginger with this, so delicious! 
-Spicy wontons IMO could be better, the chili oil wasn't that flavorful and not that spicy. But I loved the wonton skins and the filling inside.
-Beef in the beef stew was SO tender and the noodles were perfect!! Only complaint was that the broth itself though was very bland, but I'd order again for the meat because it was cooked perfectly which I find a lot of restaurants always tend to over cook.
-The green onion pancake was a last minute decision, my boyfriend and I saw it on another party's table and decided we needed that in our life. Best decision ever, the green onion pancake was sooo flaky on the inside and soft on the inside. Definitely a must try!

Everything was reasonably priced and portions were just right. The food we got were definitely I feel meant for a party of 4, don't know how we managed to eat everything between us two lol! Total came to be 42 with tip. Parking can be a hassle, so make sure to join that waitlist! Seems like this place is the busiest during lunch time.
author: Erica L.

description:
Solid place for dumplings and Chinese food. This place has become so popular over the years! There is rarely a time when people are not queued out front in anxious anticipation. 

Two of us came for a late lunch and enjoyed the Shanghai  soup dumplings, pan-fried pork dumplings,and stir fried pea sprouts. Those veggies were off the hook delicious! Just the right amount of garlic and perfectly prepared! We loved dousing the dumplings with black vinegar before devouring each delectable bite.

We will happily return. Also, pro-tip: definitely join the waitlist via Yelp! We did then walked right in to our waiting table upon arrival.
author: Bella L.

description:
I love dumplings! And Xiao Long Bao (soup dumplings) are my favorite kind. 

This place has been in my bookmarks for a while and since I was in the area, I decided to give them a shot. 

*CASH OR DEBIT CARD ONLY*

Service is kind, fast, efficient. Since I came during a late afternoon (on a weekday) business was slow and I was quickly seated. 

I only had their xiao long baos (~$9 for 10 pieces). 

This is probably one of the most judged about dishes in Chinese culture (from personal experience and from article/videos by food journalists). 

Traditionally, a xlb should have no less than 18 folds which was not the case throughout my experience. I don't mind the lack of folds, but I was disappointed to see that some skin/wrapping was inflated(swelled)/doughier. The same dumplings had less soup inside. Each dumpling lacked consistency with the next. The soup was okay and the meat was fine - nothing out of the ordinary and tastes like a normal dumpling. 

I don't really see the value since that's nearly a dollar per dumpling and the execution is inferior to the ones I order frozen from a company in LA. 

It's a decent option if you're in the area and want something super causal to each for lunch but otherwise I would look for other options.
author: Ida H.

description:
**MY GO TO PLACE** Yes, find me here every week! I'll be here... ordering the same thing... same thing... super consistent and everything excellent!

SERVICE: all I have to say about service is... "BEST SERVICE EVER" - seated right away (note: place gets busy, so come around 5pm, there's no line). Tea served and I'm ready to order!

FOOD:
(1) HOT & SOUR SOUP: yes, must get.... for all starters... this is the best hot and sour soup ever made! Everything is well balanced and lots ingredients - bamboo, fungus, tofu (*drools*), everything is great!
(2) Shanghai Steamed Soup Dumpling, #1: comes 10 pieces! Dip it in vinegar, make a tiny bite, suck the soup - be careful! Will burn you! So fresh, so good!
(3)  Shanghai Fried Pork Buns, #5: if you're into the soup dumpling (what's wrong with you?) Have no fear... this is excellent also
(4) Honey Walnut Shrimp: is like nothing I ever had... very not your typical, basic Chinese honey walnut shrimp... this give you a kick of zest! Give it a try - but don't be expecting something else. Very different and I love it!
(5) Green bean: fresh, crispy and well made - never over cooked, and has a very nice crunch!
(6) Pea Sprouts in garlic - OMG... lots of flavors! Very well made again!

And... I always over order cause I get excited every time I eat here... even 3 days after... still in my fridge and it's still so good!

**OVERALL: everyone has to try to place!
author: Mindy Y.

description:
*500th review!*

I wanted to save a special place for this milestone review, and Dumpling Kitchen is definitely very special to me. I live in a city thriving with plenty of great restaurants, but unfortunately we don't have any places to get soup dumplings (xiao long bao), or XLB for short. XLB are filled with pork and a gelatinous sheet that turns into liquid when steamed. I've wanted to try them ever since learning about them on some travel food show, so I researched for all the places to get them in SF. Finding and eating XLB and going to Alcatraz were the only two things I knew I HAD to do on my trip! 

My boyfriend and I took a long Uber ride to Taraval to check out two different places for XLB. Dumpling Kitchen was up first. The dining room is decently sized and was full of people enjoying bamboo baskets full of steaming dumplings. We were seated right away at one of the last open tables. Of course we wanted to order the XLB but we also got chicken with black bean sauce as we were pretty hungry. After a short wait, the soup dumplings came out and I could tell they were going to be delicious! The wrappers were so thin and delicate, yet held up to the poking of my chopsticks. I had done research on the "right" way to eat XLB but it took a lot of willpower for me to not just shovel them into my mouth. You have to be careful as they're pretty hot! I bit a small hole into one to let the steam escape, slid it onto my spoon with a little sauce, and slurped it all up. Immediately the flavorful soup burst into my mouth and I could taste the salty pork - it was seriously one of the best food experiences I've had. The waiting and the buildup was totally worth it and I was not let down! I wanted to order more but had to stop myself. The texture of the dumpling and the warmth of the soup was so comforting and I couldn't stop smiling. I told my boyfriend - don't like this too much, we can't get these at home!

The chicken with black bean sauce was also excellent - wonderful flavor without being overly salty, and perfectly cooked. Service was prompt and pretty much silent but I didn't care, I could barely focus on anything beyond the XLB in front of me. SO GOOD. I wish I could eat them every day.

500 stars, Dumpling Kitchen. I love you and your xiao long bao.
author: Katy C.

description:
I love dumplings, and Dumpling Kitchen delivers.

An eager party of two, we shared the pork dumplings in chili oil, Shanghai style pan fried buns, Taiwanese rice rolls, and garlic pea shoots. Everything was delicious, and I loved the homemade chili oil at the table--reminded me of the one my own Chinese mother makes.

Next time I'm 1) definitely bringing more friends and 2) trying the braised pork belly and rice cakes!
author: Kelly R.

description:
Dish: Salt and Pepper Chicken Wings
Cost: $10.95
Rating: 4.25/5
Review: Not sure if you could ever go wrong with salt and pepper chicken wings :p I love that the wings here have meat and aren't just skin and bones. Also love that they have garlic with it! I just wish it was a little spicy and then it would make this perfect! I like this spot cause it's close to home and has Asian comfort food (dumplings)  

Dish: Pan-fried Potstickers
Cost: $9.50 for 10 pieces
Rating: 4.25/5
Review: I love their potstickers here. It's pan fried and nice and juicy inside and I also like the sauce it comes with. It's a vinegary soy sauce and it complements it very well :p I always order this whenever I eat here!

Dish: Green onion pancake
Cost: $6.25
Rating: 3.5/5
Review: This pancake was just meh. I barely tasted a green onion flavor. I felt like I was just eating a salty piece of crispy floured pancake. I had to dip it in sauce to make it taste better but I did like the texture. It wasn't too thick or too thin or too crispy.

Came here for lunch at 12pm on a weekday and surprisingly pretty busy! I swear people don't even work anymore! Located on Taraval and 30th so parking can be scarce but the L bus/train runs by there!
author: Valerie T.

description:
A little bit of a wait but worth it. Place is quite big for a dumpling kitchen!

A great find for some good asian fare in the neighborhood on a colder night. It's pretty hot and stuffy inside so don't come here on a hot day ! It's perfect though for this area that rarely gets warm (sunset/parkside).

Staff is friendly and service is quick. We ordered the following. Beware that if you order dessert dishes, they'll come out at the same time as the entrees.

Green beans- what a big portion!! They are deliciously cooked and didn't taste greasy. Plenty of bite, and I found myself going for seconds and thirds... of a vegetable!

Shanghai dumpling - very good! Chewy skin, tender meat, but not enough soup! Easy to eat. Perfect temperature (not scalding !).

Beef chow mein- typical but delicious. I like these "smaller" noodles than the Shanghai noodles they serve here

Dry fried chicken wings - soooo delicious!!! I wanted more and more. The wings are a good size, seasoned well, not too spicy but full of spice-flavor and sticky too. 

I would order the same meal over again. Def worth the visit.

Oh and parking is horrible. Beware!
author: Karen H.

description: Favorite place for comfort food on a sad rainy foggy day. The first time my friend and I came here, we literally came back the next week because it was that good. The pork XLB is a classic, and the skin is more doughy because they make it themselves. I personally loved the crab and pork XLB because they were so flavorful. Would recommend the chicken corn soup and not the sizzling rice soup.
author: Emily C.

description:
Being able to check in on Yelp and drive over is great, because around popular times you best believe there will be a line, and it won't move fast. 

Very limited seating, but a fast kitchen gets oodles of good dumplings out in quick fashion. The walnut shrimp, and pork based dumplings were great. The fried chicken was just okay as there was not a ton of chicken on the bones, and some of the dumplings had much more dough then I'm used to. Not bad per say, but different.
author: Joey T.

description:
I'ma be real about this place. I gained 10 pounds living in San Francisco for a year and a half due to this specific place. I ain't even joking but EVERY SINGLE POUND WAS WORTH IT. 

Damn it's so good. This place has the best dumplings on Taraval hands down. My boyfriend and I always try to come back to this place when we are near Irving St. or 19th Street. The line can get long however, it's not really that long and usually incredibly worth it! The Xiao Long Bao always has the perfect amount of soup and meat ratio. I'm not really sure how this place does it but it's so freaking good. Also, a BUNCH of their other foods are really really good as well. 

If I moved back to Sunset area... I more or less likely will put on another 10 pounds for each year I stay. And you know what it's worth it.
author: Ann N.

description:
It sure felt like a kitchen when I was eating! It was so hot and stuffy in the restaurant probably because we were seated in the back. 

Soup dumplings were decent, but I thought the skin was a little thick giving it a doughy texture. Very juicy and almost burned my tongue when it came out of the bamboo basket. 

Pan fried pork buns had a nice crispy bottom, but like the soup dumplings, the bun itself was too thick in flour. 

Tofu salad was actually very enjoyable because it was light and refreshing to offset all the heat in the restaurant. 

Overall, decent dumplings and sides with good service if only they could turn up the AC.
author: Ronald M.

description:
Having been in Boston for a few years with superb soup dumplings, I have quite high expectations for my xiao long bao. I've tried several places in SF's Chinatown, but nothing was up to par with Boston's standards. However, Dumpling Kitchen changed that and this is the go to for soup dumplings in SF!

FOOD: as mentioned above, the Shanghai Soup Dumplings here are incredible!! Unlike the places I've tried in Chinatown, the soup dumplings here are actually filled with soup. AND you get 10 dumplings for $10, which is such a great deal. I only ordered the soup dumplings, but really that's all you need. It was filling and perfect on a cold day. 

SERVICE: the service was good - our waiter quickly placed our order and repeatedly refilled our waters when necessary. We also ordered takeout and our waiter made it so that our order would be ready to go by the time we left. 

All in all, this place is my favorite soup dumpling location in SF. No other establishments even compare to this (of the ones I've tried), so if anyone has a better suggestion, let me know! Until then, Dumpling Kitchen will be my go-to.
author: Grace L.

description:
Vegetarians beware - Ordered vegetable potstickers and was horrified to bite into one filled with chicken! While the food here in geniuienly good, the shock and utter disappointment has been hard to get over.

If you enjoy meat, please don't hesitate to visit. For the rest of us, this is your first warning.
author: Joshua K.

description:
I came here with another person because our usual spot kingdom of dumpling up the street wasn't open yet. I had heard some people talk about this place before and I was craving dumpling so we decided to spot in. 
From an interior standpoint it's nicer than kingdom but that's about it. We ordered soup dumplings, beef noodle stew, green onion pancake, chili oil wontons and dry friend strings beans. The soup dumplings were very good and the string beans as well as the beef noodles were good. However the wontons and green onion pancake was straight bad. The wontons were too big and the sauce wasn't good. The skin was so think. Then green onion pancake was weird. Not normal. It wasn't good. 

Overall, I probably wouldn't come back here.
author: Andrea W.

description:
Lmao this place was aightttt. I've had better tbh. However, with that being said, I think there are less options for dumplings in SF so it gets a passing grade. As you can tell from the Yelp page, this place is in general really popular and busy, though the wait isn't unreasonably long - I think we waited maybe 15 minutes to be seated. I came here on Saturday evening around 7:30pm and ordered the Tofu + Spinach soup, potstickers, and pan-fried pork buns. 

First, the pan-fried pork buns are smalllllll. They look really pretty and cute and aesthetic, but the flavor is kinda whatever. The bun itself was a bit soggy/soft, and was lacking the really thick breaded texture I like in pan-fried pork buns. I think I would have definitely liked these a lot more if they had been normal size, because these are just too small to be satisfying. They're kinda like... crispy-bottom XLB which is like wtf lmao.

The potstickers were better than the pan-fried pork buns IMO but again, I was underwhelmed. Just like pan-fried pork buns, the potstickers are kinda small, and though they are REALLY CUTE AND AESTHETICALLY PLEASING, the taste definitely fell a bit short for me. 

On the plus side, the filling is put together very nicely inside and doesn't fall apart when biting into the dumpling(s). Also, the dumplings all come out piping hot, so you can tell that they're really made fresh.

Anyway, I probably wouldn't come back here. Really cute place to Instagram pictures of dumplings, not a really good place to actually eat them.
author: Brian W.

description:
I know this place is a well-loved favorite, and as much as I do LOVE the soup dumplings here (for a great price too). It's unsanitary, and this place as been ruined for me. 

First off, food is great, like everyone said. It's great authentic home-style Shanghaiese food. Don't expect anything fancy, just a nice taste of home. Protip: Get on the Yelp Waitlist so that you don't have to stand outside the door awkwardly. 

Now, storytime: Last time I was here, I saw one of the old ladies that make the dumplings go into the restroom w/ her gloves on, and use the bathroom, and then walk out and proceed to make dumplings with the same gloves. I know this is a Chinese restaurant, but after seeing that I don't think I can enjoy the dumplings in the same way anymore. 

No, I will likely not come back here, but if you can get over the unsanitary conditions, the dumplings are great.
author: Sophie W.

description:
I came here two nights ago and it was well worth the trek from the city.

I ordered the chicken fried rice, vegetarian fried spring rolls, the vegetarian dumplings, the pork soup dumplings, and the Mongolian beef.

First of all, the Mongolian beef was the most tender, melt-in-your-moth dish I've ever experienced at a Chinese restaurant. It was absolutely exquisite!

The soup dumplings were okay, they were not as juicy as I would've hoped and they were too delicate, so they would puncture when lifting them off the paper they were stuck to, causing the soup to leak out prior to making it to my pallet.

The fried vegetarian spring rolls were the best spring rolls I've ever had. They were beautifully browned, crispy on the outside yet soft and moist on the inside. A true delight.

The vegetarian potstickers were beautiful and nicely browned on one side, giving it a beautiful look. However, they lacked flavor and were on the bland side.

Beware, anything wrapped (dumplings, pot stickers, and spring rolls) are VERY HOT and stay very hot. Make sure you poke holes in them before eating because they will burn you to the point where you won't be able to taste your food for the rest of the meal.

Service here was excellent, there was a pot of complementary tea served right when we were seated, and the food came out very quickly.

Overall this was a great experience and I highly recommend this restaurant.
author: Nima A.

description:
Sometimes the best Asian restaurants are little dives in strip malls where I'm the only white person. This was no exception. 

The staff spoke enough English to take the order, but not to answer questions - so we made some guesses and for the most part we were right about what we thought we were ordering. 

The XLB, which is what brought is here, were outstanding. I recommend both the pork and the crab. Also the chili wonton was fantastic. The standard dim sum fare was nothing special - stick to the dumplings and you will be happy.
author: Al W.

description:
I revisited Dumpling Kitchen again and it's not so bad

Pan-fried pork buns were delicious

Shanghai Chow Mein is good and I'd get it again but next time without garlic. 

It seems I didn't like to XLB before but I'm open to trying it again

Skip the wontons with chili oil - personal preference but only because they're not the typical ones I'm use to

I'll be back
author: Yeanne L.

description: This is probably one of the few places in SF I would go back to for dumplings and chicken wings. We got the salt and pepper wings, pork xiao luong bao, Shanghai pan fried dumplings, and green onion pancake. The pork xiao luong bao skin was a little thick but very juicy inside with the right amount of meat filling. We enjoyed the pan friend dumplings, it is something not all places have. We loved the chicken wings, the skin was nice and crispy, not too greasy and perfect flavoring
author: Andrea C.

description:
I've been here twice and it's okay. 

Parking is easy! Tons of neighborhood parking!

We ordered the xiaolongbaos (soup dumplings), fried pork buns, and green onion pancakes. 

Dish that stood out the most was the fried pork buns - but it made me super thirsty afterwards. Everything else was ok! Not bad, but nothing special.

I think this spot is ok if you're tryna fill your cravings, I think it's a solid 3 stars.
author: Melanie T.

description:
3.5. We went at 2:15 pm on Saturday, 10 minute wait. We ordered xlb, panfried buns, stir fried rice cakes, and hmm taco shell + plum sauce + pork stir fry dish, chives and pork dumpling.

Xlb: 3 stars. it's okay. Nice soup but skin is soggy and breaks easily. Meat is also too soft, also soggy. 

Panfried buns: 4 stars. better than the xlb. I'd recommend this as something the most people are likely to appreciate.

Stir fried rice cakes: 3 stars. Not enough flavor in the rice cakes. Cakes are a bit sticky if you like it that way (I kind of like it the Korean style better: super chewy but not so sticky and doused in sweet-spicy sauce).

Taco shell+plum sauce+ pork stir fry: 4 stars. I don't know the name of this but imagine Peking duck with duck replaced by pork stir fry and using a soft taco shell instead of the soft white bun. I liked this but my parents did not. I had never had this before and enjoyed it. The stir fry is almost identical to the rice cake stir fry except with pork rather than rice cakes. I would recommend this if you haven't had it before. 

Chives and pork dumpling: 4.5 stars. The best thing we had. I recommend this. The meat was firm and the chives gave it a nice fresh taste.
author: Jill F.

description:
Really liked their food. The stir fries were not great and the vegetables were cooked but crunchy.
Lots of varied mushrooms.
The soup dumplings didn't fair well during take out, most of the soup was in the paper napkins they placed them in in the box. But, tasted nice.
The staff was excellent, very cheerful and welcoming.
Recommended for sure.
author: Hal S.

description: Very impressed by how authentic the soup dumplings taste. They taste just like the ones in Shanghai proper. 10 dumplings per servicing, which is just the right amount for two people! We also had the preserved egg with tofu and shredded pork, authentic as well. The green beans were delicious too. Sad that we missed the savory soy milk because they ran out, but would definitely come back to have some perhaps during the day before it runs out. Overall, pleasantly surprised that I found this gem!
author: Yingna L.

description:
Oh. my. word. I could rave about this place for days! It definitely has its name for a reason. Serving the best dumplings in SF, you will crave them all the time. Not only is the food delicious, but the atmosphere is so cozy and warm. Gather your family/friends together and share (or hog) all the dumplings your stomach can bear. 10/10 would recommend. 

As a vegan, I got #10 steamed vegetarian dumplings and #58 vegetarian fried rice with no egg. (Next time I want to try the chow mein- if it's vegan) Portions are huge and can be shared or taken home for later! Decent prices too! 

Be prepared for the 20-30 min wait!
author: Amanda C.

description:
We went in dumb hungover.
They dropped the complimentary hot tea on the table,That was it. That's when we knew. We were in safe arms. I felt like this was my Asian grandma I've never had. 
Next we the vegetable chow mein and pot stickers. I don't even know where to start. The noodle thic-ness really had me in awe. The crunch on the potsticker was divine.

"My mouth did a backflip"-Eric 
10/10 will be back soon.
author: Carlee L.

description:
Honestly don't know why this place has 4 stars and a ton of reviews. I wasn't too impressed with the flavors of the food and I thought everything was mediocre at best. My friend and I came here on a Saturday at around 11:30am and there was no wait time. Ordered some oval rice cake noodles (never had this dish before) with pork, pan fried dumplings, and Xiao long baos. These three dishes were shared between my friend and I and we had a bit leftover. I thought the oval rice cake noodles were way too oily and salty (was very thirsty throughout the meal), the pan fried dumplings didn't have the crisp I was looking for and the Xiao long baos' skin was too thick for my liking. Overall, I wasn't too impressed with everything and I am indifferent about coming back again. 

Note: as time went on, the line got extremely long and there were people out the door. Try to show up around the time it opens and you will be good to go!
author: Amy L.

description:
We've recently been into dumplings and have now tried a few local spots. This one is my favorite so far though. I am judging as a vegetarian so keep that in mind. 

Service: came here for lunch and we got seated immediately. The service was quick and our food came out very fast! Good thing because we were starving haha.

Food: We got two orders of the vegetarian dumplings. My boyfriend is a pescatarian and was bummed there wasn't a shrimp dumpling option, but we both agreed that there was so much flavor in the veggie dumplings. The sauces here are really good too- we mixed all 3 that are on the table. They went perfectly with the dumplings. We ate every last one and were satisfied!

Will be back for sure. So happy they offer vegetarian options! Thank you
author: Hayley D.

description: Wow! Husband and I had dumplings for dinner here and it was delicious. The juice of the dumpling burst in your mouth! Yum! We ordered the, Shanghai and crab & pork dumplings. Thank god to #yelp we made reservations and got in quick! The line was so long by the time we got there. Check this place out! My future go to for dumplings fix!
author: NkaujLig Y.

description:
Came here on Friday during lunch hours and there wasn't a wait.

There was a few of us so we got a variety of items to share:
- shanghai dumplings: The shanghai dumplings were okay. They weren't as soupy as I thought they would be, but there was still a tad bit of soup.

- pan-fried pot stickers: My favorite out of the 3 dumplings. The skin was good and it was fried perfectly. It had a nice flavor but also was not dry on the inside.

- shanghai style pan-fried pork buns: This was pretty good. Very similar to the pot stickers, except the skin seemed thicker.

- mu shu pork: It came with 6 shells for you to load up the mu shu pork with. This was extremely good and satisfying.

- pork belly with preserved vegetables: The pork belly was soft, the amount of vegetables was just right, and it was delicious. Put it on top of rice, and you have yourself a great meal. This would probably be my fave dish out of everything.

- chow mein: I can't remember which kind, but it was full of ingredients. Meat, veggie, noodles... everything was balanced.

Overall, everything was tasty. It definitely fixed my Chinese food craving. Next time, I'd say skip the shanghai dumplings though.
author: Julian Y.

description:
My favorite go to spot for affordable and tasty authentic Chinese food. Their soy milk and Chinese donut are also what I crave on a lazy Sunday afternoon (so so good).

Only downside is that the wait is super long. Would definitely recommend using the waitlist feature they just released on Yelp while you're on the way to the restaurant!
author: Lily W.

description:
We were heading to the city and my boys were hungry. We wanted to try something different so I yelped "dumplings" and found this place. Yelp gave us the option to sign up on their live waiting list and we did! It also gave us a timeframe of the wait and I immediately received a text confirmation. Great! No need to worry about waiting too long.

With traffic, we made it there in 25 mins just in time to check in with the host. Luck happened to be on our side as we drove 1 round and found a parking spot in front of the restaurant. I checked in with the host and waited about 15 more minutes before we were seated. 

We ordered 5 plates for 2 adults and 2 kids. Yes! It didn't seem like we ordered enough. Lol  We love to eat. We finished 2.5 plates and took the rest to go. The Shanghai steamed dumplings and fried pork dumplings were delish! The fried chicken was covered in a spicy sweet & tangy sauce but it wasn't spicy at all. The braised pork belly & preserved veggies were very flavorful. Lastly, the beef & brocolli over rice was yummy. This plate was for my boys and they almost finished it for a 3 & 5 yo boys. The beef was very tender that we were able to cut it in small pieces using the silverware. 

The service was quick and great given that it was run by young adults. Surpringly, they run it better than other restaurants I've been to. Everything was smooth & fast with cleaning up tables, seating customers, taking orders and food coming out. Definitely worth the extra 15 mins wait and would recommend putting yourself on the live waiting list ahead of time.

*Cash or Debit only
*kids friendly
*small restaurant but has a few round tables for large parties
author: SuYen N.

description: I meant to come here yesterday, but they were closed so I had to try it today! I was seated immediately when I walked in. I ordered the soup dumplings, dried fried chicken, and wontons in chili oil. The food didn't take very long to come out, less than 10 minutes I would say. The soup dumplings were perfect! The soup was flavorful, the wonton wrap was soft but thick, sturdy enough to not break. The meat was tender and juicy! The wontons were similar in taste, but paired very well with the chili oil. The chicken wings had a crisp on the skin and was moist. No complaints with this place! I will be coming back the next time I am in SF.
author: Tammy L.

description:
This place is definitely worth the trek out to the Sunset if you want excellent Chinese food. I went with 3 friends and we ordered family style (the best way to order here). We ordered a few extra dishes that we probably didn't need but we were hungry and everything was SO good. I recommend the salt and pepper fish (battered and fried, served with fresh jalapeños); the eggplant garlic - the eggplant is suuuper fresh and cooked just right (a lot of places do it undercook eggplant), and the seafood and tofu soup which doesn't need any additional sauces at all, though a little spicy chutney never hurts ;)
Other items we ordered that everyone loved were sweet and sour fish, Kung Lao shrimp, sweet and sour shrimp (seriously SO good), and the Chinese donuts which is basically fried dough that tastes amazing dipped in the soup.

The service is really quick, the place is clean, and the food is perfection. I will for sure be returning.
author: Farrah N.

description: Saw the review on Yelp and decided to drop in.  The dumplings were kind of a disappointment.  We ordered the Shanghai and crab dumplings.  It lacks texture and the dough was a bit thick for my taste.  Flavor was average, and nothing exceptional.  We also ordered the braised pork and sweet and sour soup.  Again, nothing amazing.  Decent price for what it is worth.
author: Lap L.

description:
Me like!  Extra points for being "authentic enough" for my date who is picky on dim sum.  Came for a later lunch on a Saturday (1pm-ish).

Venue / Service: tiny unassuming restaurant on the outside, almost like a hole in the wall.  No reservations, so you have to time it correctly so you don't have to wait long; we waited around 30 min for a table to open up.  Surprisingly fits a decent amount of people inside.  Service was pretty quick, given how busy the place was.  Probably helps that they don't do it the cart-style- instead you note on a menu what you want and how many orders and they fire that order.  

Food: between 2 people, we ordered the right amount.  Highlights were the dumplings of course and went on my date's recommendation.
-- Sizzling Rice Soup with Chicken ($10.50) - never tried this before, but was surprised how light the dish was.  Perhaps it's b/c most soups are on the oily or thick side, but this one was somewhat refreshing.  Liked how there were chunks of chicken, mushroom, and then the crispy rice that pops when it hits the soup (think snap crackle pop).  

-- Pea Shoots w/ Garlic ($12.75) - I usually order this whenever I do dim sum to have a veggie, and this one didn't disappoint.  Not too oily and a lot of garlic (beware those who don't like garlic).

-- Crab + pork steamed dumplings ($11.50 for 8 pieces) - we went with this one since my date recommended this type vs. the usual pork ones.  Definitely a different flavor profile and slightly lighter on the palette with the crab.  Wrapper wasn't too thick either (yay) so you really could taste the filling and soup inside.

-- Beijing style Sweet Buns (deep-fried)($3.75 for 4 pieces) - never tried this before but a good dessert option if you need a sweet fix.  The bun was slightly on the oily side but tasted good when you dipped it into the condensed milk sauce.  The sauce on its own was a bit sweet but together it all works.

All together came out to less than $20 per person, which I think is a good deal.  So if you are looking for a dim sum spot and specifically want good dumplings (especially the xiaolongbao), this is a spot to try!
author: Audrey H.

description:
Okay Chinese food.
Soup dumpling isn't that impressive.
West lake beef soup was good.
author: Christine Z.

description:
Salt and pepper wings were amazing, better than dry wings. Rice cakes were amazing again, better than chow mein. 

Pan fried pot stickers have thin skin and are surprisingly juicy inside. Yum!

Recommend pea sprouts with garlic vs with house broth

Salt and pepper fish fillets and beef with bok choy were delicious today. 

Pork dumpling's with chili oil were ok. Wouldn't order again.
author: Peter C.

description:
Food: 5/5   Price: 5/5     Service: 5/5    Ambience: 4/5

Dumpling Kitchen was definitely worth the hype - delicious authentic Shanghai dumplings, baos, and dishes at a great price! Dimpling Kitchen has everything from XLB, Pan fried buns, potstickers, chicken, veggies, and many other Shanghai dishes. Once you arrive, you have to sign your name on the waiting list by the door. The list may be long but the wait wasn't that bad - around 20 minutes for us (7th on the list) to get a table on Sunday 1:30pm. 

#1 XLB - Shanghai style steamed pork dumplings(10). These are the best! It came in a pretty clean bamboo steamer, served pipping hot. The skin wasn't thick like most restaurants, but obviously isn't as paper thin as Ding Tai Fung's but I'm not complaining considering this is the bay area. The pork filling was bomb - Perfect meat to fat ratio, and extremely juicy! Just the way it should be. 

#5 Shanghai style pan fried pork buns(10) - I've been trying so hard to find a place that makes decent pan fried buns, and I think I've found it! Their buns are small but a great size. CRISPY bottom, juicy pork filling, and puffy dough.

#22 Crispy egg puffs(3) - Perfect dessert! Order ahead because it takes 20m to make, so it will be served around the time you finish your meal. The egg puffs are super fresh and delicious - puffy, eggy, and sugary. 

#75 dry braised string beans - classic order, and delicious. Very generous portion. I liked how the string beans were not overly fried and oily, and had a nice taste blended with Chinese pickled radish and soy sauce. 

#119 Dry Fried chicken wings(9) - good! Every restaurant has their own style (eg. San Tung) but theirs is not bad either. I feel like Dumpling Kitchen's is less sweet and has a vinegar / tangy taste to it that I enjoyed. The wings are crispy and soaked with a thick syrup sauce.

The location is a little inconvenient and far from downtown SF, but if I'm around I'll definitely come back!

Favorites:
* #1 XLB - Shanghai style steamed pork dumplings ($8.95)
* #5 Shanghai style pan fried pork buns ($8.95)
* #22 Crispy egg puffs ($5.75)
* #75 dry braised string beans ($9.50)
* #119 Dry Fried chicken wings ($10.50)
author: Victoria L.

description:
What are people going on about? I tried Dumpling Kitchen recently on a weekday afternoon and was flummoxed by the mediocrity of the place.

True, I got takeout so maybe the wow factor was diminished by the time I got the food on my plate at home.

But the Shanghai pan fried dumplings and the Shanghai chow mein were both blah in flavor as was the Mapo tofu lunch special. Not even the addition of dipping sauce on the buns improved the flavor by much.

Maybe I need to eat there with a big group and try lots of items.

Guy on phone and at register was pleasant and food was ready when I got there so service was fine.
author: Trish W.

description:
This used to be one of my favorite restaurants, but haven't been here in a couple years after I moved. Decided to get food to go last week and was really disappointed. Did they change owners/chef?

Their onion pancake is the worst I've ever had. It's dry, thin, has no flavor, and very little onion. I used to love their potstickers (with delicate thin wrappers and juicy filling with great ginger taste), but this time they came in thick wrappers and the filling had little flavor. 

The weirdest thing was they packed my Dan Dan noodles in a paper takeout carton! The box was almost disintegrated from the hot noodles and wet sauce! 

The 2 stars are for the friendly cashier and that they stay open in the afternoon, unlike many other restaurants nearby. Also, they only accept cash or debit card.
author: Ellen H.

description:
My favorite dumpling place in SF! 
I've tried so many dumplings places in downtown SF so as in Sunset, but in my opinion, this place is the best one overall. I just wish they have more roasted food like duck.
Great dumplings (especially the pan fried dumplings and xiao long bao) and noodles soup.
author: Thùy Linh N.

description: This place is one of the few places I found that served salty soy milk. If you have never salty soy milk, definately try it. Food is good but not impressive. Their soymilk is good but way too salty. The shanghai dumplings are too doughy. The pan dried dumplings was better but skin tasted a bit dry.
author: Diane Z.

description: Food was ok. Had to ask for water and utensils a few time. Employees are not very attentive. Probably will not be returning
author: Jenna L.

description:
Check the estimated wait time online before you head over to the restaurant - if it's long, you can put your name down first! I've never had to wait more than 20 minutes, and that was because I had a pretty large party. 

This place has really yummy XLBs! The kitchen and wait staff are highly efficient and every time I've been there, the food comes out quicker than I can stuff it in my face. Because of how busy they are, sometimes it takes a while to flag down your waiter to get a refill on water or tea, but not the end of the world. I'm just happy I don't have to wait long for my food! 

Besides the xiao long baos, the sheng jian baos are also pretty good here! I've also tried some of their other basic Chinese food and everything was pretty tasty! 

Highly recommend if you want some fast, cheap, and pretty good xiao long baos & other Chinese food!
author: Sarana C.

description:
Dumplings are delicious 
Service was hit n miss
Super noisy 
Be nice if they take credit card
author: P C.

description:
Dumpling Kitchen is alright. The restaurant serves your typical Chinese dishes ranging from different meat options, noodles, and rice plates. The menu reminds me of San Tung's but nowhere near as good. I was really disappointed because nothing was impressive nor memorable; it's decent at best.

We ordered:
1. Shanghai-style Steamed Pork Dumplings (10 pcs) - $8.95
- This was mediocre. The dumpling was dry and cold.
2. Crab and pork Steamed Dumplings (8pcs) - $11.95
- I enjoyed the flavor and texture of this dish, but I don't know if it's worth it for this price.
3. Shanghai-styled Chow Mein
- Oily and super salty!
4. Dry-fried Chicken Wings
- Disappointing. Keep in mind that this isn't San Tung; the chicken wings are not fried and the sauce is somehow tasteless.
5. Chicken and Corn Soup (basically like egg drop soup)
- I surprisingly enjoyed this soup even though it lacked in ingredients.

When my party of 4 came on a weekday, the restaurant was fairly full. We were seated immediately and the wait time for the food was slightly longer than expected. No complaints here. The biggest disappointment was definitely the food; I expected better and it didn't deliver. It's not worth it for the price and I don't think I would ever come back again. 

Instead of Dumpling Kitchen, I recommend San Tung (for your chicken wing cravings) and Shanghai Dumpling King (for the Xiao Long Baos/steamed dumplings).
author: Michelle L.

description:
My friend and I were both craving something warm and soup dumplings just seemed to hit the spot.  To our pleasant surprise, they also had fresh soybean milk, and Taiwanese delicacies such as the fried donut crueller, fried dumpings scallion pancakes, and more.  However, since we were craving dumplings we ordered the soup dumplings, green beans, donut cruellers, and soymilk.  It was probably slightly overboard haha.

Fried donut Crueller (you tiao)
PROS:
- hot, fresh, not too oily surprisingly
- great quantity
CONS:
- none

Soymilk:
PROS: 
- FRESH MADE! I haven't had this taste in years, basically when my mum used to make it when we were growing up.
- not overly sweet, but can also get a salty version
- good quantity, not just some small sized cup but a nice big glass sized.  I could sip on this all winter long.
CONS:
- none

Soup Dumplings (regular pork ones - they have crab ones too)
PROS:
- came out hot (steaming)
- decent quantity for the price actually
CONS:
- not much soup inside.  Super sad at this.

Green Beans:
PROS:
- great quantity
- good flavor, not overly salty
- actually less oily than most other places' green beans but also the beans weren't ridiculously wrinkled - I think this means that it wasn't sitting in oil for that long either.
CONS:
- not really a con but it was oily hahaha.

Man I really like this place.  I'd definitely come back for the soymilk and then to also try the scallion pancakes as well as the crab soup dumplings.  The one thing that was a bit of a turnoff was the cash-or-debit only rule.  Luckily I had enough cash on me and that I had seen this on YELP prior to coming here.   We will be coming back again, and maybe just to get a gallon of soymilk!
author: Vera L.

description:
Went on Sept 2018, this place can get pack. We ordered xiao long Pao, spicy wonton, spicy pork belly n shianghai style chow mien. 
The dough on the xiao long Pao n wonton were thick, I like it thinner. The chow mien I don't like it that much . I like the spicy pork belly though.  Maybe we didn't order The best ones . The place does get pack towards noon. So maybe they have other better items.  It's a small family run restaurant . If I live close by , yes I can go back to try other items but I won't drive far just to go eat there !
author: Lisa D.

description: This was a very very small place with only about 5-6 tables, there was a wait but not as long as the other dumpling place close by so this was our second choice. We ordered different types of dumplings including shrimp & pork which were decent but have definitely had better. The xiao long Bao was very good though, it was steamed well and the soup inside the dumpling was flavorful and meat was perfectly cooked. Would've gone with 4 stars but all other dishes we okay.
author: Jean L.

description:
Long wait on a Friday night.

The soup dumpling was awesome. I tried both the regular one, and the crab meat ones, and they were both delicious.

The string beans were decent, although I wish they were stir fried a little more.

Prices are fair. Overall decent experience.
author: Christina N.

description:
The dumplings were amazing! The XLB was nice and moist inside with lots of soup. The best I think was definitely the potstickers. I'll be coming back for those, they were nice and crispy and the pork inside is so juicy.

We also got the bean noodles, they were okay. 

Came here at 7:30pm on a Friday and we waited like 10 minutes. It gets kind of noisy but it's just like a typical Chinese restaurant noise with lots of families. :-)
author: Iris H.

description:
Came here for the soup dumpling and was not disappointed!

The soup dumplings were oval shaped instead of circular which was very odd to me when I first saw them.. but the skin was thin, the filling was delicious, and there was adequate amount of soup/fat. 

We also got the pan-fried pork buns just to see what the hype was. These were crispy on the bottom and soft on the inside. Yum!

I'd recommend both the soup dumplings and the pan-fried pork buns. 

This place is popular, even at 11am (before busy lunch hour!) so expect somewhat of a wait if you come later. The restaurant itself is rather hectic as well so it's not quite the place to sit and chill for lunch.
author: Sally L.

description:
As a dumpling lover, Dumpling Kitchen is pretty good! I was able to join the waitlist via Yelp so by the time I arrived, my table was ready. I ordered the basic Shanghai style steamed pork dumplings ($8.95), and the wonton in chili oil ($8.95). Both orders had ten pieces. Since I went with only one other person, these two dishes were more than enough.
 
The Shanghai style steamed pork dumplings were delicious, not the best I've had, but they were good and I would definitely order them again. The skin was made perfectly, and the soup and the meat were very flavorful, but there wasn't as much soup as there could & should have been. I actually preferred the wonton in chili oil over the Shanghai style steamed pork dumplings. The wontons were pretty large but the wonton skin and meat proportion was perfect. I wouldn't really call the chili oil a chili oil, nor would I say it was spicy, but it seemed to have a hint of maybe a peanut flavor (?) and a slight hint of the Szechuan numbing chili. The sliced green onion on top was the perfect garnish for the wontons. Overall, I would definitely return and would recommend this location to other dumpling lovers!
author: Victoria H.

description: My favorite Chinese restaurant in SF!  I'm probably a little biased, but their dumplings are amazing, especially the soup dumplings. You really can't go wrong with any of the dumplings on the menu. Their other food is pretty good too, but the dumplings are really what you come here for. The service is usually pretty quick, although it's sometimes hard to get a good amount of water here, which is kind of necessary to balance with salty food.
author: Claire C.

description: Great soup dumplings.  Probably the best in town.  It is worth the wait.but if it is like a two hour wait go to the place in Westborough
author: FanOf 4.

description:
My boyfriend and I were really craving some dumplings so we found this place on Yelp. There wasn't a wait which was really nice because we certainly came hungry. We ordered chicken with mixed vegetables, Shanghai pork dumplings with a little side of rice of course. It was absolutely delicious. Downfall was we ordered won ton and vegetable soup. One bite into it tasted like dish water. I had my boyfriend take a sip in case I was tasting things and he said it was awful as well. We asked if we can return it because we didn't like it. The staff looked at us crazy and then was clearly
Talking about us a few steps away. Just a little awkward. We got our check and was surprise that we both had full bellies for only $26 bucks. If we are craving dumplings we will definitely come back just no won ton soup please.
author: Melissa P.

description:
The dumplings here is legit. I came here on a Weekday and the line was super long. The spicy dumpling was my favorite. But the skin was a bit thick on the regular wonton, but then had a good amount of filling. The 

Taiwanese style soup was warm and comfy. It has the fried donut inside and a milky soup. It's different but worth a try.

The shanghai dumpling was delicious. It was juicy and soupy. For those who tried shanghai dumpling, you will understand what I mean lol...
author: Bonnie C.

description:
We happened to wander by this place after picking up some frozen dumplings from Asian American Food Company.  It was only 11:40 and it was packed.  And it looked like people were eating for a while too.

We had 3 items: Pan fried pork dumplings, Soup Dumplings (XLB), and just a regular noodle dish.

The pan fried pork dumplings were decent/good.  The noodle dish was ok as well, but the XLB was NOT!  The XLM skin was quite thick almost like a dumpling skin.  Once biting into it the meat was minced.  There was no structure to the meat at all and it basically was ground pork that fell apart.  Somewhat disappointing.
author: G M.

description:
After a morning run, my friend recommended to eat at those restaurant because it was one of his favorite places to eat pan fried pork dumplings. I saw the pictures and noticed they had braised pork with preserved vegetables, so I was very excited! It was about noon and we waited about 20 minutes before we got out table. There's a separate male and female bathroom in the back of the small restaurant. They serve tea in a teapot for you, there were four tea bags steeping in the pot. 

We ordered the xiao lung baos, braised pork, and pan fried pork dumplings for the two of us and surprisingly we finished it all! It was really filling but we did run 5 miles so we definitely had an appetite. The reason why I'm giving the three stars was because the XLBs were pretty bad. The stuffing was not solid, it was this mushy undetectable filling of who knows what inside. The only saving grace was the wrap and the vinegar dip. I WOULD NOT RECOMMEND THE XLBs, save it for another restaurant! The next dish that came out was the braised pork and I've had better. The pork meat was a little chewy and not as melt-in-your-mouth pork that I'm used to. The flavors were amazing though! Lastly, the pan fried dumplings came out and that was amazing all around. The crispy texture of the dumpling with the flavorful pork filling was delicious! 

Overall, I will come back to try their other food but it was a little saddening that their XLBs were that gross and the braised pork was a bit dry for my taste.
author: Ada C.

description:
I really enjoyed eating here! They have a big menu for plates and a limited menu for the dumplings. 

I was really sad that they ran out of the Pork buns when we were there but everything else was good!

The restaurant is small so wait time is about 25 minutes to an hour. They had more tables for 2 and 2 rounds for family size with a lazy susan. 

I would definitely come back here again. :)
author: Sol P.

description:
I enjoyed this place while my son and boyfriend, no so much.  If you expect to have your typical dim sum dishes, this isn't the place to go.

We ordered:
Hot and sour soup - Very tasty and full of ingredients
Honey walnut pawns - Good, but a little on the citrusy side
House fried wings - could be crispier, but good flavor
Pan fried pork buns - I would go back for these alone!  They were delicious.  Little pouches of goodness...crispy on the bottom, but soft on top and delicious pork filling.  

This is a small place, we got there and there was no wait us, but the tables were filled.  The service isn't great either and they are SLOW.  You have to ask for everything you want... drinks, refills, extra napkins...  Next time I'm in the area, I would just order to go.  I wouldn't choose to eat in again.  After all, I'm paying for service that I didn't get.... hence the 3 stars.
author: Leizel B.

description: Ordered a bunch of stuff, they were all delicious! My favorite tho was the soup dumplings.... and the pork... and the fried donut thing.... they were all so good! I can't decide! You haveeeeee to try the fried donut thing! My husband and I literally fought over the last piece! Lol
author: Becky S.

description: We were pretty disappointed with this place. We really wanted soup dumplings and they were pretty mediocre. The shanghai noodles were good but nothing special and the sautéed string beans were a little undercooked and not flavorful.
author: Karen W.

description: Good selection and good food. Obviously the Shanghai dumplings are the star here. We also tried the pan fried version and the spicy dumplings. All were great. We had to order to go due to time constraints. I hope to dine in sometime soon.  Cash or debit card only. Lots of people order to go so they're good at packing the food.
author: Lily F.

description: Old grandma that works there gave very bad attitude when she didn't hear our order. You can see the look at her face at how annoyed she was just cause she didn't hear us the first time. Very rude unprofessional and the food is not good at all. Panda Express better
author: Jenny Z.

description: Wow, this place is delicious! It is exactly what I expect in great Chinese food, especially the pork dumplings! I have visited twice for dinner during the week. My partner and I were seated right away both times, and the service was a quick...there is no room to sit and chit chat, which does not bother us. The restaurant is not the cleanest, but it has the feel you look for in an authentic Chinese restaurant. I highly recommend trying this place out if you are looking for amazing Chinese food.
author: Leonora H.

description:
This is only based on a couple of items we tried here, as a snack. 

On a recent trip to SF, we dropped by here in mid afternoon, a few hours after brunch and a few before meeting w/ friends for dinner. 

Around 2:30, the place was still pretty full, but we were seated immediately. The interior is definitely dated and lacked any style, but that just adds to the authenticity of the food. They seem to have a long wait often, because wait times are estimated and posted so hungry folks know what to expect. 
https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=48_KF22-a2J6W1e6HzVWSA&userid=n8YKNoz1xJHJDe-_jxfbcQ&utm_campaign=www_photo_share_popup&utm_medium=copy_link&utm_source=(direct)

We just had an order of potstickers, and no sauce was needed. It was great on its own, unlike other places where I had to use soy & hot sauce. The bottom was crispy, the skin was chewy. We also had an order of fried red bean pastry. It came out hot & crispy with red bean filling. Not bad. 
https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=x2KVtIGefEwt5NvCGo3thA&userid=n8YKNoz1xJHJDe-_jxfbcQ&utm_campaign=www_photo_share_popup&utm_medium=copy_link&utm_source=(direct)

The service is what you'd expect from any Chinese restaurant, not bad but nothing worth noting. But based on the 2 items we snacked on, we'll make a point to come back & try the other items on the menu. This is more like a 3.5 based on flavor.
author: James L.

description:
Still solid, quickly executed food. Dumplings are still the star of the show but don't overlook their other dishes. Noodle dishes are delicious. Their egg puffs are still a delight as well. Prices are still reasonable.

Parking is difficult

Gets really busy starting at 7pm.

Cash or debit card only
author: David G.

description:
This was my second time at the Kitchen, and I have to say it was better than the first, not to say the first was bad. On this visit I ordered a lunch special, Mongolian Beef with rice. The beef was quite tender and tasty. However, the star was my second order and what I came for, The Shanghai Fried Pork Dumplings (上海生煎包) . These were quite a surprise. They had a nice crispy bottom that when went well with the upper portion of the dumpling.  The texture of the dumpling was not doughy at all. I added some hot oil along with soy sauce, delightful. I can highly recommend the Shanghai Fried Dumplings. 

It's probably best to come on a weekday in the afternoon, if you can. No lines.
author: Anthony W.

description: Not bad. I would come back here.  Even with the American sized (large) portions which usually negatively impacts the taste, that didn't seem to have happened too much here. Had the xiao long bow & boiled dumplings which are usually signature fair and if they are not good, nothing else usually is.  Test dishes if you will, like getting capris and linguine and clam sauce and Italian restaurant. If these things are good are those are probably going to be OK.  Not the best that I've had, but both were pretty good.   I'd come back.
author: Leung T.

description:
I came here once before with my friends and I remembered that all the dumplings we had were amazing! My boyfriend is NOT the type to drive long distance just for food, especially to San Francisco, so I had to butter him up and up-sell the food. I kept on insisting that what we had was amazing (he is also a lover of xiao long bao), so he finally gave into making the trip. Oh, and it was our 5 year anniversary, so he let me have my foodie day trip in SF. hahaha

Dumpling Kitchen is located right off of Taraval Street, so you have to find street parking. Pretty difficult..we kept driving around in circles and finally found a 1hr. parking area. We arrived to the restaurant around 2:30pm, so luckily we missed the breakfast/lunch rush for a Saturday. YES-we were starving by that point. Such a long trek from SJ to SF because we have to drive locally after exiting the freeway for quite a bit, just to get to the restaurant. 

The restaurant was nearly full but we got seated right away. I had everything I wanted to order memorized by the time we got out of our car, so I was ready to order once we sat! The waiters/waitresses were more focused on bringing the food out and cleaning the tables, so it look awhile to wave one of them down.. They seemed confused if we asked for anything extra, even for water/ice water and we had to always repeat ourselves at least 2x.

We ordered..

GREEN ONION PANCAKE $5.95 -not even crispy! :( This is usually the highlight of our dumpling meals but Dumpling Kitchen's version was just soft and flat. No green onion flavor-no crunch, it just tasted like bread dough. 

STICKY RICE ROLL $4.75 -aka "fan tuan" meh. The sticky rice surrounding the thin chinese donut was very dry/chewy?..not soft and sticky at all. Actually the whole roll was just dry..from the powdery pork sung to the chinese donut to the 'sticky rice'. It would literally fall apart once we removed the plastic wrap that held everything together. 

SAVORY SOY MILK $3.75 -didn't really taste like soy milk..pretty bland. There were a few pieces of shredded meat and pickled veggies at the bottom of the bowl, and they topped it with chinese donut. 

WONTONS IN CHILI OIL (10pieces) $8.95 -the wontons were HUGE! My boyfriend really liked this but I thought it was OK. I ate half a wonton and let him devour the rest. The wontons were made of pork and some sort of veggie. The "chili oil" they were sitting in was creamy and had a peanut sauce flavor to it. 

PAN FRIED PORK BUNS (10pieces) $8.95 -aka "sheng jian bao." The best item of our meal! Loved how the pan fried pork buns actually had CRISPY BOTTOMS and the dough wasn't too thick! It wasn't heavy and you wouldn't get full/tired from eating just one pork bun. YUM.

STEAMED PORK SOUP DUMPLINGS (10pieces) $8.95 -aka "xiao long bao/xlb's/shanghai soup dumplings" The girl who brought this out threw a giant silver spoon into the steamer basket and popped one of our xlb's!! :( Uhm, hello..you're ruining that best part of this dumpling! The soup dumplings were pretty soupy but we didn't think the meat filling itself was that great.

Everything we ordered came with a giant silver spoon..which I thought was kind of funny. Their black vinegar and chili oil available table side were great! I think there was something in the oil that made our mouths numb because we both agreed that after a few bites, we weren't really able to taste anything. Not because it was spicy, but something in the oil just numbed our tongues. ha!

Don't think we'll come back anytime soon, only because its such a far drive for us. I can see it as a local favorite and we would probably stop by more often if we lived closer..but only for the pork soup dumplings and pan fried pork buns.
author: Truc T.

description:
OPINION - There are a lot of Chinese restaurants in the area to choose from but this one wouldn't be my first choice. Not special in my opinion but it is solid. The wait can get long during prime time so get there either early/late or be prepared to wait (bring a jacket, it gets chilly in the city).

SERVICE - So so. Not the most professional in my opinion. Waiters came to our table maybe 2 minutes after we sat down asking if we knew what we wanted to order (didn't have appropriate timing). We also had to flag them over later when we wanted tea. Not the most attentive. 

FOOD - (split between 3, lots of leftovers)
This is comfort (Chinese) food for me! I grew up in this area so this is the food I'm used to. 
-Shanghai-style steamed pork dumplings: Not as flavorful as I wanted. The texture was nice as was the amount of soupy liquid inside.
-Beijing-Style boiled pork and chive dumplings: a lot better than I expected! Full of flavor. Loved the texture and dumpling skin.
-Seafood Stir-Fried Rice cakes: some rice cakes were over cooked so they kind of melted)
-dry-braised string beans: nice and crispy.
-pea sprouts with garlic: not the season for pea sprouts so they were really chewy
author: Alyssa L.

description:
I've been here several times with different groups of family and friends, and the food is consistently good. You can't come here without eating dumplings. The XLB is on point, the pork & crab is excellent, and even though the pan fried pot stickers sound basic, it's anything but. The broth in soups are tasty. The salt & pepper chicken wings are to die for. The stir-fried rice cakes (I've tried combination and pork w/ preserve veg) are the best I've had anywhere so far. 

It gets super busy here any day really, but especially the weekends. My course of action is to go right when it opens or after the lunch rush (2-3pm). If there are only two of you, they can seat you pretty quickly, but even for several people, they are able to move through a good pace for the amount of people waiting. 

The best dumplings... and priced accordingly. I've seen lots of dumpling places that are a little more because they are closer to tourist places. Not here! Come to the Sunset.
author: Lani S.

description:
Perhaps an off day
or expectations too high
it was just ok

We came with some friends
highly recommending it
they frequent this place

Place was all filled up
before 11:30
on a Saturday

Standard Asian joint
no one comes for ambiance
or for great service

Was salivating
over the thought of dumplings
bit disappointed

Dough not delicate
filling flavor average
XLB lacked soup

Scallion pancakes
was practically tasteless
on many tables

Ordered some egg puffs
never showed but on the bill
take cash or debit
author: Jae R.

description:
It really takes a lot of negativity for a restaurant to pull me out of a 2377 day yelp hiatus... But alas one has proven worthy.

We roll up around 11:10 on a Saturday morning and get seated immediately. We perused the menu and finally decided on four dishes: Xiao Long Bao, Shanghai Style Chow Mein, Pea Sprouts with Garlic, and Beef and Mushroom.

We're starving and the food comes out in a timely manner which is awesome. First the Xiao Long Bao. Tasty, but not as good as Shanghai House. Nevertheless, its tasty and we are chowing down. Next comes the Shanghai Style Chow Mein. This one is pretty tasty as well and we are digging in. Great start to the meal so far.

This is when things went south... 

Next up was the Pea Sprouts. Being part of the InstaMafia, the camera always eats first. I snap a pic and then the SO turns the plate around and shows me the tiny half inch worm in the dish. I'm not offended or miffed as these things happen and I'm pretty easy going. We tell the waiter and he takes it back without hesitation. He comes back out in a few minutes and asks if we want another pea sprout dish as a replacement. I declined because I'm weary of restaurants and sending back dishes. Who knows if they would just pick the worm out and re-serve it to to us as "new". To avoid that whole mess, we just decline. 

We go back to chowing down our first two dishes when our last dish comes out. Beef and Mushrooms with some veggies. Looks great! Before I can whip out the iPhone, the SO points at the dish and there's a 5 inch black hair right at the edge where the sauce meets the plate. You can't miss it. We wave down the waiter (Johnny) and tell him there's a hair in the food. 

Johnny: Is this your hair?
(Note: My head is shaved and the SO has super long hair)
Me: Ummm what?
Johnny: It wasn't there when I brought it out.
ME: (Caps not for dramatic purposes, I was really yelling) WHY WOULD WE PUT HAIR IN OUR FOOD?!? 

So the waiter takes the food back with a scoff and that was the moment I decided NEVER to come here again.

The check came and we were never happier to just pay and get out of this place to find some better food since we were still hungry.

Looking back, not sure why the waiter got angry. Its not like we were demanding free food or anything of the sort. We just wanted to eat food without worms or hair in it. Is that too much to ask for?
author: Leo C.

description: One thing San Francisco is known for is there little neighborhood hole-in-the-wall restaurants. And this little neighborhood eatery does not disappoint!! My dad and I ordered a double cooked pork belly and some pork dumplings. DELICIOUS!! The juices from the dumplings poured into your mouth as soon as you take your first bite. The pork belly is mixed in with onions, bell peppers, and green beans. Very tasty.
author: Mikey S.

description:
If you are into Din Tai Fun shanghai dumplings without the headache of reservations or of credit card on hold, them this is the place.  The dumplings are freshly made, tasty and first come first serve although it is a smaller restaurant the wait was not bad.  Everyone signs in with clipboard and staff calls your name.  

Quality 5
Freshness 5
Not easily accessible near bart -1 star as restaurant is near the sunset district of SF near zoo and the grove.  Traffic around that area is always a mess like the rest of SF
Cash only -1 what about venmo PayPal credit Apple Pay?!?

4Affordability 

Friendliness of staff 5

Probably best to call first to make sure the hours on yelp are correct.  There is 1 man 1 woman bathroom each so pretty amazing for a tiny place!  If you are expecting a quiet romantic date spot this isn't the place for you as the tables are pretty closely situated to others and you likely can easily hear neighbors conversations...
author: Emi J.

description:
Extremely good Xiao Long Bao (soup dumplings) and Sheng Jian Bao (pan fried dumplings) - highly recommended.

The skin for the dumplings are soft but does not tear easily - there is definitely enough soup to pack in all the flavors. The filling is soft and is very perfectly done. The filling is not just a meatball but blends well into the overall experience of the dumpling. Perfect balance of soup, skin, and filling. 

The pan fried dumpling's got all the greatness of the soup dumpling plus the fact that it's got more form. I really enjoyed it as well.

We also ordered a mushroom and bok choy dish. This dish runs a bit oily and did not wow me away. Therefore taking away a star here.

I definitely recommend both the pan fried dumplings and the soup dumplings. 

P.S. you can reserve your spot in line with yelp
author: Ruby W.

description:
This is my favorite chinese food spot in San Francisco. It has taken me years to find a spot for Chinese food that tastes this good!

Highly recommend:
Garlic string beans
Chow mein
Deep fried sweet buns with condensed milk on the side
Honey Walnut Shrimp(sooo good! not dry and flaky as other restaurants fall prey to with this item annnnd the walnuts were fantastic) 
Hot and Sour Soup

I went with a party of eight and was able to sit at one of those big circle tables with the lazy susans in the middle. Truly the best way to enjoy this restaurant is with a big group doing family style. 

Definitely coming back soon.
author: Cynthia G.

description:
Decent dumpling place! Came here on a weekend dinner time and had a short 5-10 minute wait time. 
This place (unlike many dumpling places in Daly City) has pretty substantial seating that fits small and big groups.

They have many different dumpling selections and other original Chinese dishes (seafood, chicken, beef, etc). DEFINITELY recommend getting their xiao long bao (soup dumplings) that comes with 10 pieces in a bamboo tray, fresssshly steamed! The meat inside is tender, juicy pork and they definitely master the perfect amount of soup/dumpling ratio! I love dipping it with vinegar and soy sauce! 
I also tried their beef and string beans entree and it was decent (not delicious but not bad). I think the sauce they cook it with was definitely lacking some flavor. 
Lastly, I tried the Wontons in chili oil.. bleh.. the wonton meat was good but tiny compared to the wonton amount. The "chili oil sauce" was bland, tasted like nothing whereas its supposed to be spicy and at least somewhat flavorful. I'm usually very sensitive with spicy food and i couldn't taste a thing. The bill ended up being about $30 for 2 people with a small amount of leftovers. 
Also, RICE DOESNT COME FREE; you have to pay extra for it ):

Service is decent and pretty fast but I definitely wouldn't come here for anything but the xiao long bao. Also PSA they only accept cash and Visa/MasterCard debit cards- no credit cards!!
author: Lilly N.

description:
Pretty decent dumpling place in sunset.
We visit here at lunch time around 11. 11 was fine but it went packed right after that.
We ordered
- 小籠包: must have. Soup inside was juicy and good.
-peanut noodle: I thought it's similar to 担々麺 but apparently not. Don't order this. 
-水餃子: it's really good too. Actually i like this more than 小籠包
author: Nazuki Y.

description: This place is legit! I love their xiaolongbao (soup dumplings)! One of the best for sure! This place located on Taraval street and parking is not hard to find on the street. I'll def be back!
author: Rissa K.

description:
My favorite spot to get soup dumplings! I come here almost every time I'm in the city. It can get pretty busy depending on the time you go since it's a small restaurant so I suggest going right when they open. If there is a wait, it's usually not too long. Plan for some time finding parking because its's all meter parking and not lot. 

I typically get an order of the pork xiao long bao and an order of the pork & crab xiao long bao. I highly suggest trying the pork&crab, it's delicious!! Sadly, I was super excited about the wontons in spicy chili oil but it was so bland. Overall, this place always hits the spot!
author: Tracey N.

description: Love this place! We added our name to the wait list while en route to the restaurant and got right in. The soup dumplings where flavorful, hot and came out quick. We also got the fried rice and Mongolian beef, the rice was tasty and the beef had a great texture and also full of flavor. Highly recommend.
author: Sarah F.

description:
A more affordable, more "hole in the wall" version of Din Tai Fung.
I'd recommend this place for any DTF lovers who crave XLB, fried Shanghai buns, or stir fried green beans. The wontons are good, but their chili oil flavor isn't as good as DTF. 

Seems like people love to get the crackling rice soup or something like that. I want to try that next time. My favorite dish was the green beans. Can eat that all day. 

The servers are quick and friendly. Nothing too outstanding about this place, but I'd come back for the comfort food.
author: Audrey D.

description:
We came here after Corgi-con, after finding it on Yelp. Everything in the area was totally booked up on a weekend afternoon, but we were able to get in the queue through the Yelp app. We had trouble finding parking, so we were nervous that we'd lose our spot, but when I called they were very reassuring and didn't mind that we were running a couple minutes late. We were seated immediately.

The dumplings really hit the spot! We got the green onion pancakes, soup dumplings, and fried dumplings. Everything was great! The green onion pancakes were different than most, but really flakey and interesting.
author: Holly J.

description:
Let's get this one straight, their food is delicious. We practically ordered two of everything. Almost. Wontons in chili sauce, xiaolong baos, green onion pancakes, and fried rice. After a six-hour drive from LA to SF, stomachs were making everyone pretty hangry. And as the birthday girl the first meal I craved for was dumplings! 

Now for the real reason why some stars were knocked down: time constraint. We were being told they were having a hard time figuring out where to seat us because there were too many bigger reservations coming in that night (who weren't even there yet!) BUT if we manage to finish eating by 7:30pm then they can seat us.. It was bad courtesy in my opinion. The kind that would draw away customers but luckily for them we were too eager to eat and not willing to wait for another line at another joint that we took on their challenge to eat by their allotted time. They sat us by 7:00pm! They rushed us in every possible way but we ate and took however much time we needed regardless of their disclaimer. 

ALSO, they need to be more weary of allergies.. Because their wonton spicy chili sauce has peanut in it. So do be aware because my best friend got a reaction from it but thankfully had Benadryl. They were so focused on rushing us that they didn't allow any communication in between before ordering and that definitely brought down the experience even more.

So the moral of this experience is that Dumpling Kitchen shouldn't be intimidated by larger groups or forget good customer service. You get better business from them! So don't rush your customers who are there to appreciate your food and business. 

Because of the service they offered us that night, I doubt we'll be coming back. Thankfully it's SF. There will always be the bad and the good. 

Pro-tip: All I'll give these guys is that because they aren't in Chinatown, it is a dumpling house that is slightly better priced. Just hope you go with better service. If you're more than four people, go elsewhere or reserve.
author: Julienne D.

description: Being in the their name, you might have guessed they serve pretty tasty dumplings. You've guessed correctly! The dumplings here are made in house and filled with the perfect amount of meat and wrapped in the perfect amount of dough. In addition, they also have a great selection of Chinese dishes in general. And just a little cherry on top of it all, they have delectable chicken wings too!
author: Tina Z.

description:
Awesome dumpling place! Our group of four came here on a Sunday around 5 pm. We got super lucky and parked on the street right in front of the restaurant. We also had no wait, which wasn't the case for everyone else when we left about 45 minutes later. 

We ordered several dishes, such as the pork dumplings, the crab dumplings, the chili pork dumplings, the red bean pancake, and the sweet buns. The vegetarian in our party had the veggie dumplings, spring rolls, and the sweet and sour soup without any meat. 

The food was phenomenal. Everything came out really fast, except for the red bean pancake. That came out after our check, but we think it's because they initially forgot about it. 

In any case, I would highly recommend this spot. The dumplings are amazing, prices are reasonable, and service is fast and efficient.
author: Alyssa B.

description:
Phenomenal. 
Sunday afternoon, we came in with a group of 12 and somehow got seated right away even though the place was packed! #win Its a small hole in the wall but it seemed pretty clean. 

I've had Din Tai Fung in seattle which blew my mind after having mediocre dumplings in Portland, Oregon (where we are from).  Their dumplings come out hot, fresh and you can tell its made with love.  We basically ordered about 10 dishes x3 (dont judge, we're just hungry girls)  and loved every single one! 

Service was good.  They were patient with us even-though we were being a bit loud -- not in a bad way.. we were just  having a good time. =)  

We went into beast mode when all of our food arrived and left with very full and happy tummies.  Some of us couldn't breathe properly but no regrets.  

I highly recommend trying out Dumpling Kitchen if you're in the area!
author: In B.

description: Nice place for fried pork buns and you can change the meat if you need them too. Wish Parking was better though! Staff is very nice there and it's our to-go place at least 1-2x a month!
author: Karen H.

description:
I'm from Shanghai, where I've sampled soup dumplings and pan fried pork dumplings extensively. I know, it's totally unfair to compare, so I'll try my best to forget my benchmarks. 
Let's start with the soup dumplings. I don't think they use jellified stock (pidong), so the soup comes out to become more salty without any sweetness of the pork to balance, making it less satisfying to eat. All the meat fillings disintegrated inside, and were mixed with other vegetables to make it taste more like a chinese dumpling (the kind that is normally boiled). The skin was very noticeably handmade and was resultantly quite thick.
