One commendable practice about the dumplings though is that they're made and steamed to go: you can tell as the skin swelled noticeably with the last few dumplings. 
The pan fried pork dumplings were very impressive effortfully as the wrapper is leavened but still very thin. However, they pan fried the thin bottom instead of the thicker top, so that the dumpling isn't able to last too long in the pan. Resultantly, the wrapper's texture was less crispy and slightly too soggy than I would've liked. I did quite like the meat filling; a little sweet mmm. 
The fried mantou is good; a classic that's hard to mess up. The mantou could've been smaller; the essence of the dish is not the mantou but to eat fried stuff and dip it with the overly sweet condensed milk. 
The twice cooked pork was decently cooked. One question though: why have such large slices of meat? Also the dish could've benefitted from some actual peppers instead of sourcing the (weak) spice flavor from a mild hot sauce.
Overall, the dishes are a commendable effort. I know, I'm at the more extreme end in terms of criticality. 
But is it worth trying? Well...it's definitely not bad.

Flavor: 6
Quality: 7
Value: 6
Service and setting: +0
Presentation: +0
Legitimacy, skill, and effort: +2
Memorability: +2
Score: 53
author: Alan L.

description:
Mediocre food. Dumplings weren't great. Green pancake was very disappointing and not done right. Saw them on another family table and they were not touched either. Vegetable potstickers tasted like an American made them with little flavor from the vegetables.

Passable.
author: Lily A.

description:
Was looking for a late lunch place near Taraval somewhat close to the Zoo since my goto (i.e. Old Mandarin Islamic) wasn't open for lunch today.  Was drawn here by the high Yelp reviews and promise of delicious Shanghai soup dumplings.  Did not disappoint; the dumplings were delicious and a good value.

Shanghai-style Steamed Pork Dumplings: Amazing tasty xiao long bao at a fraction of the Yank Sing price!  Filled with lots of savory soup.  Soft ground meat interior.  The pre-mixed soy vinegar sauce on the table was a nice pairing, though I kinda missed the ginger sticks usually served with this dish.

Shanghai-style Pan-fried Pork Buns: Such a nice crispy sear on the bottom of a soft doughy tender dumpling.  The pork filling was a tad firmer than the xiao long bao, but still packed with flavor.

Dry Fried Chicken: Was just ok.  With so many places specializing in super crispy wings, the skin on these felt a bit limp.  Only the outermost edges were crispy.  The sticky sauce was nice, with a strong star anise aroma.  Enjoyable for sure, but not as wow-worthy as the dumplings.
author: Adam B.

description:
I've gone to dumping kitchen a few times with my family and friends for yum cha. My friend and I went today around noon, specifically for xiao long baos (which is the pork soup Dumpling). My friend arrived first and got a table relatively quick, but I think you also have the option of sharing a table if you aren't with many people, or if you're eating by yourself. The last time I came here with a friend we were served quickly because we said yes to sharing a table, and then once a table cleared up we were moved over. 

The dishes we ordered were XLB, combo chow mein, spicy wontons in chili sauce, and walnut shrimp. My friend and I are big eaters (no shame) and the portion sizes were nice and filling. And I thought the actual dishes were alright and reminiscent of any other chinese restaurant. I thought the XLB was good just because I really like them, but I've had better at other places. Also the food is more Shanghai style, so you won't really find typical Chinese dim sum/dishes.
author: Melody Y.

description:
I've been to a lot of dim sum restaurants and quite honestly, most of them are pretty bad.

I think it's pretty surprising to find so many bad dim sum restaurants in the Bay Area. I was quite honestly hoping for more considering the rich Chinese-American history and culture that's ubiquitous with Bay Area living. But alas, I'm finding the dim sum along with many of the other Chinese restaurants lacking.

Yes, this is a hole-in-the-wall and you kind of get that authentic, crowded, lively atmosphere while dining that I've sorely missed from living in China so it's fun to go with friends just to get out of the usual SF hipster-ish, overpriced French or fusion-style restaurants. 

Food was decent. Nothing mind-blowing so I feel like most of the people who really enjoy the dim sum here are either enjoying a particular style of dim sum (I prefer Hong Kong over Shanghai / Taiwan / Guangzhou / Shenzhen) or just the overall feel of the place (cozy and you gotta get friendly with your neighbors).

The service was fine and they offer all of the usual items you'd get at dim sum oh and unlike many places, this dim sum spot actually serves dim sum for dinner as well, which is a plus for late-night dim sum lovers.

Parking sucks so I would definitely plan ahead and take into account you might have to park 10 blocks away depending on the time and day.

Parking: Limited street parking
Wait: No to little wait depending on day
Price: $$ Cash / Debit Card only
author: Pourio L.

description:
I came here on a Tuesday for a quick lunch with my dad right when it opened at 11am and there was still plenty of street parking (2 hours free). We were seated immediately, but we had to ask for a couple items throughout our time there (menu, vinegar for the XLB) since they didn't seem to be completely ready/prepared.

We ordered the Shanghai-style Steamed Pork Dumplings (10 pieces) and the Steamed Vegetarian Dumplings (10 pieces). Everything came out in about 10 minutes. Both dumplings were satisfactory and filled me up. The only thing I did not like was the vinegar for the XLB, which looked and maybe tasted like it was left sitting out for about 50 years. Overall, the food is a bit pricey ($8.95 each pre-tax & tips), but I might be back if I needed a place to quickly satisfy my XLB cravings.
author: Winnie Y.

description:
Came here for lunch on Saturday and had to wait in line for about 30-40 minutes for a table of 7. It was quite busy and lots of folks in line, also all tables were full inside when we arrived. Once seated, we ordered:

1) dry fried chicken wings: very good, great flavors & would recommend! 4 stars
2) sweet & vinegar spare ribs: ribs were very tiny bite size, on the sweeter side 3.5 stars
3) pork soup dumplings (x2), meat was too mushy inside, fell apart before it went in the mouth, 3 stars
4) pork & crab soup dumplings, same as above
5) chicken fried rice, big portion size 3 stars
6) seafood soup, shrimp & scallops included, 3.5 stars
7) pan fried dumplings, only ok 3 stars
8) crispy egg puff, interesting round puffy dessert made of egg, 3.5 stars

The total came out to be a bit over $100 (not including taxes/tip) for a lunch feast.

We have to wave at the servers every time we needed something since they are so busy. They were nice about it.
author: Yonnie C.

description:
This place gets packed really fast so we were so lucky to stop by and free street parking right in front and a table for four right before their huge dinner rush!

Today we mainly ordered soup because it was a cold rainy day. We also tried a wide array of their dumplings like the soupy one, pan fried dumpling, etc. I forget the names of our orders because it has been awhile and I didn't have time to snap pics.

Dumplings: 5/5 so fresh and yummy! Perfectly cooked. Good portion of meat and flavorful as well

Soup: It was a hit or miss for some of the soups. Some of them were really bland. My favorite one was the beef soup which had the most flavor. Meat was tender as well.

Service: Fast customer service!
author: Michele G.

description:
Super delicious crab and pork dumplings! We also got the Hot and Sour soup (comes out in a huge bowl) and the Dry Fried Chicken Wings, which were juicy and tender. The total came out to be around $32.00, definitely very cost-efficient. 

I also loved how we were able to easily put our names down on the waiting list through Yelp app. Barely had to wait at all by the time we got there because it told us exactly how long the wait time will be.
author: Mandy C.

description: Very good food! Dumplings were delicious! Like everyone else says, the XLB's were on point. Not too sticky, and did not rip apart. Only 4 stars because they did not have any  shrimp dumplings when I was craving. Very good restaurant
author: Manny R.

description:
I've developed a hankering for them XLBs.  Those soup dumplings have a little broth in them and are a wonderful #1 dish.  They come ten per order and in a steam basket.  

Next time I go (which will happen as Grandma digs this place), I'll have to order some fried pork buns.  Pass on the noodles, but egg rolls continue to taste wonderfully.  

My verdict:  pass on the (grocery store style) noodles and grab some mo' dumplings.  It's what they call themselves and it's what they do.
author: David B.

description: I love this place. Reasonable prices, HUGE portions! One order of soup dumplings comes with 10 :) The hot and sour soup is solid, and so is the mapo tofu. I love this place and feel like home eating here!
author: Alice L.

description:
Best chowmein I've ever had sober/not hungover- that's damn good! *drool*


Wait was 20 minutes, easy peasy. Service super prompt. Lots of veggie options! We got chicken chowmein, veggie dumplings and dry fried wings. Chowmein was the star of this show hands down!
author: Rachel L.

description: This is my weekly dumpling go to spot and it never disappoints. The dumplings are amazing and very solid service. The green onion pancake is a favorite and the Shanghai dumplings are some of the best I have ever had. Heads up - they only accept debit cards.
author: Jordan C.

description:
Xlb was full of fat and little to no soup.  Dumplings smaller than the ones found on Noriega or 1/2 the size.  Been here before and now there is almost no Asians in sight headed to better waters I think.

4 people have us a small table that could not fit all the food we ordered... unacceptable service!  Mediocre food.
author: David H.

description: Delicious food with a variety of choices.  Dumplings in and out of soup were terrific .  One of the Go to dumpling spot in the SF parkside sunset.
author: FG L.

description: The soup dumplings are fine, but definitely not the best. The spicy wonton / 红油抄手 though, was a huge disaster. It tasted nothing like the authentic version complete with a flavorless sauce and huge thick skinned wontons
author: Kyle D.

description: The XLB is ok. Nothing wow. I had better. I did enjoy the rest of the food and service is ok. 3.5 star. I probably come back to try their other dishes to see if this place is really a 4 star since yelp shows it is. Everyone's taste is different and I base off mine due to trying really good XLB in Vancouver and ding tai fung (many other locations). So far 3.5 for now.
author: Christy V.

description: Super fast service, the food its amazing! It was our firts time here and we loved it. If you are vegetarian, they have vegetarian dumplings filled with goodness! Highly recommend it. For faster sitting, you should check-in on Yelp.
author: Perla M.

description: We decided to go on a Sunday and appreciated the fact we were able to add ourselves to the waitlist online once we were close enough to the restaurant. This is a low-key, no fuss place where you can come with a large group and share delicious family-sized plates. Definitely try the Shanghai dumplings and pan-fried pork buns!
author: First L.

description: The crab and pork XLB tasted like Vietnamese Bun Rieu, really odd and took me by surprise. The wontons in chili oil tasted a bit off, not what I'm used to and lacked flavor in the sauce. The restaurant is pretty much a hole in the wall, not that nice and tables and menus were sticky...service was great though, so I'll give them that at least. Glad I didn't order too much.
author: Evelyn N.

description: Better than Din Tai Fung, well... As far as soup dumplings goes. The #1 is something you must get everytime you go here. The onion pancake was also very good. Just the right amount of crispy and soggyness. Service was average for a Chinese restaurant. They take credit cards, so no need to get to the atm. Overall the food makes my drive from San Jose to SF totally worth it.
author: An T.

description: THE BEST DUMPLINGS EVER. This place is so bomb! The pan fried dumplings are perfectly fried without an excess of oil. The wait is a bit long but totally worth it!
author: Alexi D.

description:
Not a fan at all. I came here on New Year's Day for dinner and had my hopes up since there was a long line outside. However I was pretty disappointed in the food...maybe the chefs were tired since it was a holiday, but it was just not worth my money at all. 
- xiao long bao: I thought that this was just basic, I didn't really like the texture of the dumpling skin, it felt like t was over cooked :(
- Shanghai style stir fried rice cakes: this one was probably my favorite out of all the dishes I ordered there so if you ever decide to go, get this dish. I still prefer this dish at other restaurants, however as it was a little bland.
- green beans: these were extremely greasy, which is actually pretty standard at Shanghai dumpling restaurants...but they were also very salty. I needed to drink so much water throughout.
- wonton in chili oil: okay this had to be the worst dish. I'm sorry, I don't mean to be rude, but I didn't taste that flavorful chili oil at all. It actually tasted like wonton in sesame/tamari sauce or something...it was just really disappointing and I wouldn't recommend it at all.
- green onion pancake: The flavor was a little bland once again, and the texture wasn't crunch on the outside and soft on the inside like usual. It was just straight up soft. I also would not recommend this.
author: Amanda C.

description:
So they don't have the typical dim sum dishes that you normally would ask for.. so don't be fooled! Other than that, the dumplings, walnut prawns, and greens were delicious. I also got the house noodles but those were a bit bland for my liking. I took it home and did some extra seasoning on it. 

Star of the show: DUMPLINGS!
author: Vina V.

description:
Lunch time!! We had to pan fried bao, stir fry rice cake, sweet soy milk, Chinese donut, and green onion pancake. Hehe we were being fatties. Everything tastes pretty good. I really liked the pan fried bao. However everything was really greasy. I didn't love the green onion pancake as it isn't what I was expecting. The prices are not bad, but they don't take credit card. Debit and cash only! Parking might be difficult in this area too! However, I would totally come back for some rice cake and bao!! 

:)
author: Judy W.

description:
This is one of my favorite places in SF!!!  However, since I moved away, it's been inconvenient to come.  They are usually always busy with minimal space in the front for waiting patrons.  

IMPORTANT NOTE:  They only accept cash and debit.  They do not take credit.

I typically order the Shanghai dumplings (Xiao Long Bao) and Shanghai New Year Cake/Rice Cake.  They are also known for their soy milk and egg puffs.  The food is good and homey.  

The space is small and cozy.  It feels pretty quintessential San Francisco  wherein they pack as many tables/people as possible into a given space.
author: Stephanie L.

description: Unassuming looking restaurant but delicious tasting food. We got the green onion pancake, more eggy than I've ever tasted but fluffy and tasty and good for mopping up the soup from the Shanghai soup dumplings! Also had the Beijing chive and pork dumplings as well, also extremely juicy. Dumpling skin is chewy but not too thick. 10 dumplings in each serving so it became two meals for me! Great meal for not too much money and very relaxed atmosphere. Good tea as well!
author: Zoë M.

description: I am a fan- it has a energetic atmosphere + although busy, you can make a reservation through yelp so the waiting is a minimum.  Shanghai chow main was my favorite.
author: Paul R.

description:
We always order the XLB, Shanghai Chow Mein and one other item that rotates between the pan fried pork buns, the green onion pancakes, and the occasional point-at-food-on-someone-else's-table dish. 

The XLB keeps me coming back every time. If I could change it to be better, I would add more soup inside and I would grind up the meat more for a better mouth feel when you bite into it. But other than that, the skin is the right thickness and texture, the flavor is delicious, and they seem to bring it out at exactly the right temperature so you can pop it in your mouth without burning it. 

Down the street, Kingdom of Dumpling has really gone down hill; I recommend Dumpling Kitchen as of late.
author: Sheewon B.

description:
The main stay here is the dumplings in case you miss it in its name. This is a Shanghai style of dumplings: silky doughy skin with a savory soup and tender meat inside. 

It's hard to get all three right: the taste, the thickness of the skin and the tenderness of the meat inside. 

We ordered the Pork dumplings and fried dumplings. Both had savory juicy soup spilling out, so use a spoon when eating. That's how Dumplings should be eaten anyways. 

Loved the string beans. Cooked to the right crispness with garlic. 

Enjoy
author: Wayne L.

description:
Came here on a Sunday around 1130am with my family. Didn't have to wait but the servers were not friendly.  They do not greet you! One of the male servers threw the check on our table and one of the older female servers spilled XLB sauce on one of our plates. WTH -1.5 stars
Just because this place has overall 4 stars, you shouldn't treat your customers like this. 
Food was mediocre! I don't even know why they have 4 stars. Only XLB and the dumplings were edible! We ordered onion pancake, sticky rice roll, the wonton in spicy oil, soy milk and minced pork noodle. The spicy oil tasted like spicy ketchup and the sauce on the noodle was watery. -1.5
Overall food was meh and don't think I'll come back at all!
author: Jaine L.

description: Not a typical dumpling place... I tried the seafood stir-fried rice cake dish, 3 types of the dumplings (pork dumplings in chili oil, crab and pork steamed dumplings, pan fried buns). The rice cakes were kinda blend, was not a fan of this dish... and the 3 types of dumplings all tasted very similar, except for the skin. Of the three, the pan fried buns were my favorite because of the crispy outer layer of the bun. The chili oil dumplings had a strong peanut taste. The oil seemed like it was mixed in with some peanut sauce, so if you are allergic, stay away! The crab and pork steamed dumpling had no taste of crab, just all pork. The place had a lot of people and my friends who went with me liked it, but wasn't a place for me :/
author: Jane L.

description:
No wait Easter Sunday at 11:30 am. Pretty darn impressive. They have rest room that was pretty clean so that's a plus. Service is quick. They don't take credit card- debit and cash only. 

Soup dumplings: 5/5 deliciousness bite size dumpling that is best with the ginger sauce and a little ot sate (crushed pepper in oil) . I'm glad they had sate as most Asian restaurants I went to didn't have it. The dumpling didn't break open upon being picked up! So good! 

 fried dumpling: 3.5/5 bigger sized than the soup dumpling and fried on the bottom only. I felt like it wasn't cooked thoroughly but ate it anyway. 

Snow pea leaves with garlic: 5/5 it's always good to have a veggie dish with oily foods and this one was rave worthy. Whole garlic cloves and fresh peas. 

Shanghai noodles: 4/5 it was a good filler as we didn't order white rice. Wasn't memorable IMO but the party liked it. 

Walnut prawns: 4.5/5 with sweet mayonnaise sauce and crunchy dried noodle?? No idea what the shire things under but it served as a crunchy bed which the prawns lied upon. I enjoyed it. 

KoreAn fried pancake: 4/5 I liked that it didn't have onions and not too oily. Wished it was crispier. 

Sweet buns: 5/5 four buns with a small side of condensed milk. A sweet dessert to end the meal. The inside didn't have custard like I expected but it was still very enjoyable.
author: Han N.

description: Overrated. The staff was friendly, good service, but the dumplings were no good. The dumplings were extremely oily too. The prices were good for the quality of the dumplings though.
author: Nicolette L.

description: Wow, we ordered 3 dishes and got way more food than we expected. The restaurant is packed at dinner. Highly recommend the soup dumplings and green beans. Really delicious! Also! If i recall correctly, the place is debit card/ cash only. So be ready!
author: Julie L.

description:
Went here around 3 PM for late lunch.  We ordered Xiao long bao, pork buns, fried dough, sweet soy milk and wonton in house broth. 

It was a lot of food between two people but we managed to finish it. 

Everything was pretty bomb and tasty. 

Except for the wonton dumplings. Although it was flavorful, the textures weren't right for me.  The wonton dumplings themselves were huge!, and with thicker skin than I prefer.  The inside of the dumpling was slightly dry for me. Really needed sauce on them to get through it. 
I was also not a fan of the House broth that it was served in.

If I were to come here again, I'd just get the fried dough and Xiao long bao. And maybe the pork buns.
author: Daisy S.

description:
True to its name, this place is great for dumplings. Lots of them, in fact, so come here with a good group and go nuts with your ordering!

Go with the Shanghai-style steamed pork dumplings (xiao long bao) to start. They're reasonably soupy and have enough filling in them. The Shanghai-style pan-fried pork buns are also a solid bet. Both dishes are reasonably inexpensive and come with good portions (10 pieces each). 

In addition to the dumplings, there's a complete array of traditional dishes here, whether appetizers, soups, noodle and rice dishes, and meaty / vegetarian entrees. Again, all decent and fairly inexpensive. 

Service is quick and efficient, and while the venue has a hole in the wall feel to it, the most important thing is that you'll leave full and happy without draining your wallet. Authentic in every way while being accessible to those who aren't Chinese and Asian.
author: Vincent L.

description: Dumpling Kitchen beats most of the places I've been to SF purely on price. The xiao long bao's were pretty cheap when sharing with a group of folks and everything came with pretty large portions and enough to share among 4 hangry eaters. I'd say this place merits a visit if you're craving soup dumplings and wouldn't like to shell out too much money on a meal.
author: David Y.

description:
SOLID XIAO LONG BAO option in South San Fransisco!  My quest for delicious XLB (steamed juicy pork dumplings) continues and of course, we had to look for an XLB joint 'round here in S.F. during our recent visit.  Actually quite a few options here, hard to decide which to choose to explore lol!  Einee, meenie... I finally decided on Dumpling Kitchen solely because it's right by my favorite gelato spot, Marco Polo Italian Ice Cream.  Oh YEAH... DONE!  Parking is rather difficult as it's all street parking from what I could see, and the streets are packed!  Took a good 10 minutes before i was able to find suitable sized parking spot.  Wasn't close either.  Another 10 minutes to walk there lol!  Not much of a wait to sit when we arrived for lunch on a Sunday, yay for us!  Friendly service makes for a nice initial impression, as usually, chinese restaurants are filled with gruff  unfriendly servers.  But enough of da chit chat, let's get our grub on!

*STEAMED PORK DUMPLINGS (1 order $8.95 for 10):  Our XLB arrived rather promptly to our surprise. Not use to that kind of response time down in SoCal!  The thin wrapper sticks to wax paper so gotta be gentle as you pull them out or you run the risk of losing the "juice" inside from wrapper tears, as it happened to us a few times.  And there is quite a bit of juice inside to lose.  A PLEASANT SURPRISE!  So... GOTS TA SLOW YUR ROLL so you dont lose the perfect mix of yumminess! ;)  Tasty stuff, probably one of the better ones I've sampled in all of California.  Worth a visit just for this.

*WALNUT PRAWNS:  I like that there's a bit of caramelization on the prawns.  It adds a nice texture to it rather than it just be a creamy mess.  Prawns are plump and juicy.  If you really enjoy these, may wanna consider getting more than one order.  This feeds one person a lil too easily.

*GARLIC BOK CHOY:  Gotta have fiber with every meal right?  This was an ample serving to share with our family of 5.  Wonderful flavor and still quite crisp with a healthy green hue to it.  This can be filling in a good way ;)

*SHRIMP FRIED RICE:  Standard stuff. Nothing wowzers to bust down the door down for, but decent enough that the plate was cleaned up by the young squires.  Not too greasy either.

*CRISPY EGG PUFFS:  Never had this before and its good!  Crispy exterior and an almost kind of custardy soft inner content.  Combined, its a pleasant dessert.  No wonder its recommended by many.  I bet it doesn't taste good if you wait too long though.  That didn't happen on our table... nyahh!

We were really happy with this find!  Its the first XLB option we've sampled in this area of the world and its an easy recommendation just for those lil morsels.  Looking forward to explore more of the menu on the flip side!  And yes, I did hit Marco Polo after ;)
author: Dave A.

description:
Sometimes when you're a little more outside of the city, the best thing to crave is dumplings! In the avenues, we are spoiled with good dumplings and dim sum. Dumpling Kitchen does not disappoint. Been here twice now and both times the dumplings were great. I'll admit, I like the atmosphere and pace here better during the week vs the weekend.

I wouldn't order the onion pancake, that was one item that came out flat compared to the first time we had it. Definitely order steamed or pan fried dumplings, depending on how healthy you're trying to be. 

The staff is pretty friendly here. They're super patient with us, even when we're being loud and obnoxious. Definitely need to wave to call to their attention, but it was packed. The night I came during the week was a lot more intimate/personalized service since less people. Prices went up since more people have been trying here instead of the other dumpling place a couple blocks down. ;)
author: Arezou A.

description: Authentic dumplings and tasty Chinese dishes in this neighborhood gem. The very reasonable prices will make your pocketbook happy.
author: Angela B.

description:
It was very crowded when we arrived at the restaurant.  The dining room was already full with diners at 11:30am.  We waited about 15 minutes to be seated.  The tables were very close to each other.  People sitting next to you can hear your conversation.  

They accept cash or debit cards only.  

Mon - Fri   11:00am to 9:00pm.  
Sat, Sun & Holidays   10:30am to 9:00pm.
Kitchen closes at 9:00pm.   
Closed on Wednesday.  
Restaurant is between 29th & 30th Ave.

SERVICE:
Great service.  The servers were nice.  We asked for red vinegar and ginger and one server didn't hesitate and brought it to us.   When we got up to leave, another server said bye to us and started cleaning the table.  

FOOD:
Shanghai-Style Stir-Fried Rice Cakes $10.95 - 5/5
The rice cakes were cooked just right and has good flavor.  Large portion. 

Steamed Pork and Napa Cabbage Dumplings $8.95 - 5/5
Get 10 pieces in a bamboo steamer.  The dumplings were very good and somewhat juicy inside.  

Walnut Prawns $13.50 - 5/5
The prawns were cooked with a sauce which has a hint of lemon flavor and mayonnaise.  The walnuts were a little sweet and crunchy.  

None of the food was salty or bland.  Would definitely return to try their other dishes.
author: J W.

description: Some of the best dumplings (and string beans) i ever had! Ordered number 5 and 9 from the dumplings menu, and an order of string beans. The string beans were really good, and they have a generous portion size as well. I think number 5 for dumplings was my all time favorite! Would definitely recommend trying!!
author: Kathleen Q.

description: Disappointing! I compared them to House of Pancakes I went to within the same week. I ordered Shanghai Style Noodles, Fried Pork Shanghai Bun, Green Onion Pancake... The only repeat order I may have in the future is the fried pork shanghai bun... Noodle cant beat the house pulled noodles server in House of Pancakes. Do not order the Green Onion Pancakes!! Compare to House of Pancakes, everything on the menu is $1-2 different... Well i would give them a second chance next time and see how they fare...
author: Dedy G.

description:
Must have gone on a bad Thursday night.  Still in search of a good Shanghai Dumpling restaurant in the city after our Shanghai Dumpling King debacle earlier in the year.  Decided to visit Dumpling Kitchen five years later.

We ordered Vegetarian Goose, Shanghai Dumplings, Mushu Pork, Dry Fried Chicken Wings, and two Soy Milks, one cold, and one hot.

Cold Soy Milk brought out first, not filled to anywhere near the top of the glass.  Figured they were warming up the Hot Soy Milk and expected it later.  Vegetarian Goose was next and had too too much sesame oil taste in the mushroom filler.  Still no Hot Soy Milk.

Next came the Mushu Pork, which was okay.  Then the waiter brought Dumplings and luckily before we touched it the Head Waitress / Cashier came over and said it was Crab and not ours and took it back to the kitchen.  She immediately came back out and presented the same dish to the next table.  We asked for the Hot Soy Milk and they said it is coming.  We see two Hot Soy Milks go out to other tables, obviously they work on one ticket at a time and ours had passed.....

In the meantime, our not too fried, too syrupy, Dry Fried Chicken Wing is served.  We ate half and boxed it.  Appears they fry their chicken without batter and put a lot of sauce on it.  Nothing close to San Tung or Korean Garlic Fried Chicken.  Pass on this order if you expect such.

So still waiting on Hot Soy Milk and Shanghai Dumpling.  Finally the Hot Soy Milk is brought out and happy that it was filled to the top.  Still no Dumplings.  

After awhile, the Crab Dumpling table is checking out and said there is a discrepancy on their bill, they had ordered two Shanghai Dumplings (one to eat in and one to go) and were charged three.  Waiter says the "to go" is coming as they had already served the two "in house" orders.  The table said they only wanted two orders not three and had them cancel the "to go" since they boxed up the second "in house" order thinking that was the "to go" order.  Confused?  

Ding Ding....Light Bulb.. Wake-Up... Obviously you guys gave away our order early in the meal and did not realize it.  We cancelled our Dumpling order since we were disgusted with the service.  Yeah, we went to the Dumpling Kitchen and did not eat Dumplings......fail.

If you go here, be aware of questionable service, good intentions, but utter failure...food is average.  Downgraded due to service.
author: Scott L.

description:
I've often been quoted saying that Annie Lennox is the only ginger i'll ever love. 

But that is neither here nor there. Dumpling Kitchen is the most satisfying dump experience I have ever had. Some of my all time favorites: 

Shanghai dumps ("soup dumplings") 
cabbage pork dumps 

Each order comes with around 8 dumps, and between wanting to order several to share and a vegetable plate, one can get very full on not that much money.  

They also have great lunch specials during the week that come with a choice of entree and rice or chow-mein for a small upcharge. Much less crowded than coming here on a weeknight or on the weekend, but still totally worth the wait.
author: Amber D.

description: THE BEST. Hand down, on the floor, in the basement. See how all the local chinese guys go there? That is a good sign.
author: Jonah K.

description: Tried a few dishes and it was very satisfying.  Soup dumplings are small though tasty.  Chicken dishes are nicely seasoned and not too salty.  yum!
author: Mark M.

description:
Cash or Debit card only... (almost had to go wash dishes) oops! 

Get here early and find street parking, place gets busy quick. Got here at open (10:30am) and literally 10 mins later 10 tables filled up!t
author: Jerome S.

description: Some of the best dumplings I have ever had. Although this restaurant is very plane, their food is amazing and surprisingly very cheap. The serves was good and everyone was very nice. My only advice is don't get the crab dumplings.
author: Matt N.

description: Hands down my favorite dumpling spot in the city (do we still call Outer Sunset the city?)! My must-haves are the XLB, steamed pork dumplings, and the scallion pancakes. Being extremely picky about the quality of my XLB (are the skins too thick and chewy? do they fall apart when you try to pick them up?), I am consistently impressed by the eats at Dumpling Kitchen. Not to mention, the extremely affordable prices in a city where the food prices seem to constantly be on the rise. Worth the extra detour to have a satisfying dinner!
author: Nerri Y.

description: Just my personal opinion but the wrap on these dumplings were really thick and doughy.  That's not how I want to be satiated.  Will try again to make sure it wasn't an off day for them.
author: Esther W.

description: The first time I had ever tried dumplings was at this place this year. I know...Where have i been right? Haha... Anyway, ever since then, I couldn't get enough. Dumplings are my absolute fave at this point.  Been to this place 3x and have had a great experience 3x. I highly recommend this place if you are in San Francisco & craving dumplings. They get pretty busy so you may have to wait outside in the cold until a table is available & they do close due to special hours so check to see if they are open first before you drive out to dine.
author: Jennefer C.

description: Ordered take out from here and everything was just okay. A bit salty and I'm not sure if everything was very fresh. But, on the whole, good for a late night craving or for extra appetizers if you're having a dinner party. I liked the noodles with the cucumber and brown sauce. Green beans were bit overcooked. Dumplings were fine. Nothing was bad, nor amazing. That said, I would order again.
author: Jeanne R.

description:
A bit of a wait but nothing terrible. Food came out really quickly, which was great cause we were super hungry. 

Yummy yummy XLB, the skin didn't feel too thick. As always, the main worry here was not burning my mouth trying to eat too fast. The fried pork dumplings were also really good, nice and crispy on the bottom.

We also ordered the chow mein, most of which will be eaten as leftovers. Good home made noodles, but other than that pretty standard. I might add a little bit of spice when I sauté this later.

The warm soy milk was nice, clean and delicious. Not too much sugar.

Definitely a family kind of joint, babies crying and all. Didn't take away from the experience for me but just keep that in mind when visiting.
author: Vanessa S.

description:
Dumpling Kitchen is a solid dumpling place. We arrived at 7:15 pm on a Thursday and waited about 15 min before we were seated. As a party of two, we were seated at a larger table with another party of two. Not bad if you're open to meeting strangers and being nosy about what other people ordered!

We ordered soup dumplings, pork dumplings, pea shoots, and Shanghai noodles. All delicious and filling! It's not gourmet by any means, but the food was warm and good.

Will return!
author: Julianna K.

description: So. Good. I've always been a shanghai dumpling king regular but this place has got me. They've got much better service and the place has decent seating and an organized waitlist method!! You can just hop on the waitlist on yelp when you get there or even before on the app. We got the pan fried pork buns (mm, 10/10), the crab xlb (10/10) which was soo juicy and when you poked it, it had actual soup coming out, which compares to shanghai dumpling king as muuuch better bc their xlb's lacked juicy flavor and much soup at all. If you go during their lunch hours they have a lunch special where you can get a combo meal of rice (we got fried rice) and an entree meat like general tso's chicken. The portion for that was a lot in my opinion!! Definitely coming back. One thing that I did not like was the wonton in chili sauce, that had a bitter taste and lacked a lot of flavor/juiciness to me compared to Shanghai.
author: Kimberly L.

description:
My mom and I love to get xiao long bao, we used to frequent kingdom of dumpling a few blocks up, but after a few visits with a long wait (regardless of the day) we decided to check out something else. We've been to Dumpling Kitchen 3x now and it's been great each time. 

Here are some of the dishes we have tried: [1] XIAO LONG BAO - delicious broth and filling, nice thin wrapper that doesn't break easily when you pick it up, [2] GREEN ONION PANCAKE - fluffy and less oily than I've had at other places, [3] SHANGHAI STYLE FRIED PORK BUNS - tastes pretty similar to XLB but fried, [4] HOT AND SOUR SOUP - ok, [5] SIZZLING RICE SOUP - ok, [6] SEAFOOD SOUP - ok... Clearly I'm not a soupy person. [7] STRING BEANS WITH BEEF - good!, and [8] BRAISED TOFU AND BOK CHOY - lots of fluffy tofu but not enough veggies. 

Overall the food is great, there's barely any wait, service is very attentive and friendly, and the parking is easy. Can't ask for more these days in SF!
author: Elaine N.

description:
The siu long bao (pork soup dumplings) are pretty good. The skin is a little bit thicker others I've had but there's a good amount of soup. The shen jian bao (pan fried pork bun) on the other hand had one of the thinner skins I've tried compared to others... It was so thin I was wondering if it was going to be made of bread because they looked so similar to the soup dumplings. The bottoms were not as crispy as others I've had but it makes up for it with the thinness of the skin and a good bread to meat ratio. I found the meat in the shen jian bao to be more flavorful somehow than the siu long bao...I wonder if the pork mixture is different or just in my head.

We also had the egg puff, which was crispy yet not greasy on the outside, and custardy on the inside. Not the best one I've had but a solid dessert to end the meal.
author: Estella H.

description:
I absolutely like this place!

I find it extremely authentic and original and the flavors of almost every single item my party and I ordered was delicious.

We especially liked the soup dumplings and everything on that front page of that menu. We also ordered the dried-fried chicken and I was hoping that it would be similar to those at San Tung, but unfortunately it didn't (it was still good though). 

This would be my go-to place when I want dumplings from now on :)
author: Crystal H.

description:
Everything I ordered here tasted great. The XLB (Shanghai dumplings) are a must if you come here, they're fantastic! I also ordered the dry chicken wings, Shanghai chow mein, and beef with bok Choi. 

The chicken wings aren't as crispy as other popular spots such as San Tung, but they have a better sauce that isn't as sticky or overwhelmingly sweet. The Shanghai chow mein was very good and I would recommend it.

Service was good considering that the place is filled during lunchtime and food came out quickly. 

Overall, this is a great place to eat that stands out in a city with so many Chinese restaurants!

Food: 5/5
Value: 4/5
Service: 4/5
Overall: 4.75/5
author: Brian G.

description: Still a fan of this place after 5 years of not coming back, but the quality of the food has certainly dropped. The atmosphere and food all remind me of home. Their pan-fried buns and potstickers taste exactly like how my mom makes them, and they're damn cheap for the quantity and quality you get. The XLB aren't like the traditional Shanghai ones, so don't expect a paper-thin wrapper with hot juices inside. This one is thicker and more lukewarm. When it comes to the string beans and pan-fried noodle dishes, their chef is using a heavy hand with soy sauce now, and most dishes come out too salty. However, the food is still a solid price for the handmade quality you're getting. You could do much worse.
author: Danny C.

description: Super good dumplings and a lot of the dishes on the first page are great, but all the other dishes are OK. Really great tasting pork buns and pork dumplings, food comes out hot and quick. A bit of a long wait to get to table so plan accordingly (like all other popular spots)
author: Bethany A.

description: Wow this place is great. I just ordered everything the family at the next table ordered and then we added a few items like fried dough, green onion cakes and green beans. OMG every dish was delicious.  The best sauté green beans ever.  The pan fried dumplings were the best ever.  Service was fast. And dishes are rushed out ASAP so they are HOT.  Love it
author: t d.

description:
I knew there was something I didn't like at this place - it was either the chili wontons or the xlbs. I was too lazy to look at my previous review and ended up ordering the chili wontons, which were so disappointing. They had too much skin and they were extremely bland. The chili sauce on the side didn't help with the flavor much either. What a waste of $10. We also ordered something new - their Beijing black bean sauce noodles and their dry fried chicken wings. We wouldn't have ordered this much food if we knew how big their portions were.. 

I guess that's a good thing about this place - big portions. Their black bean sauce noodles weren't the typical ones you'd expect. We should've known when we read the name. It tasted more like a very wet version of minced beef noodles from DTF? There was nothing black bean about the sauce. The wings kinda reminded me of BBQ pork at Chinese restaurants. 

Ehhhhh it was ok! They only accept DEBIT and CASH. No credit cards.
author: Sydney C.

description: Great hole in the wall place for xiao long bao! We got pork and crab. Both very delicious! The noodles were delicious as well. Very good, and affordable. Just wished they filled up my water cup a little more. Over good food!
author: Alissa T.

description: Love the food here!! Very inexpensive and tasty! Best soup dumplings I've had, so far my favorite is the pork soup dumplings. As well probably my favorite dish here is the spicy peanut noodles, fast service, good atmosphere really good food and a good price, it's great for larger parties as well judging from how big the round tables are.
author: Michelle M.

description: I love XLB so much, so when I saw the reviews and pictures on Yelp I just couldn't wait to try it. My friend and I ordered #1 which is their regular XLB. There's 10 pieces per order and the price is reasonable. We also got the green beans with garlic, they give you such a big portion for this and they are amazingly flavored. The last plate we ordered were the fried chicken wings. Everything was so good and we actually came at a really good time too. There wasn't much people there when we came, but quite a few tables arrived after we did.
author: Siera O.

description: Dumplings are amazing! Brought the Family here and everyone was very surprised. We are hooked and will be back. Honey walnut shrimp is the best I've had.
author: Sandra P.

description:
FOOD:
Been here about 4 times now and it's the first place I've ever had XLB! One order comes with about 8-10 which is a lot for the price of only $8! You can basically be full off of just that. Also I really recommend their noodles in peanut sauce. It's the bomb! Portions are quite large and well worth the money. 

ATMOSPHERE: 
The place is also family owned with great service! Highly recommend!
author: Sun L.

description: BEST Dim Sum I've had in the city! I I would definitely eat here again, I highly recommend trying Dumplings Kitchen!
author: Mandy B.

description:
A neighborhood small gem of a restaurant on a beautiful day in the city was a great way to end the day. We picked Dumpling Kitchen based on the reviews as we were looking for a dumpling restaurant.

SERVICE - Fast and efficient, promptly seated in a packed restaurant, food was served in a quick manner and the staff was attentive and helpful.

FOOD - Great tasting food. Ordered the Green onion pancakes (well cooked, light and crispy, best eve), Shanghai Dumpling (well cooked, juicy and large portion), eggplant with garlic sauce (the best we have tried anywhere, could be a bit more spicy), Mu Shu beef (very tasty and healthy portion, had not eaten this in a long time and it was a perfect mixture of vegetables and beef),  and Kung Pak Chicken (great that it was stir fried with enough flavors and spicy).

PRICE - nothing we ordered was more than $10, and had enough left overs for another meal as the portions are very large.

All together, it was a great experience and will be back to try more dishes.
author: Mehrnaz H.

description:
I strait up love this place, and not just for their famous dumplings.

Whenever I come here I always order the XLB, shanghai pan fried pork buns and chow mein.

The XLB is alway delicious, the soup is always so flavorful while the mean is not chunky and melts in your mouth.

Iv had a lot of chow mein but this is the best chow mein Iv ever had! The noodles are thick, the meat inside it is cooked and seasoned to perfection while the vegetables are crunchy.

The Shanghai pan fried pork buns are super filling and simply delicious. They are slightly crunchy on the outside and soft and juicy on the inside.

If you are ever near taraval or even if you are not, simply jump on the L to taraval to experience this place.
author: Jonathan B.

description:
I am a regular at this place for take out and ohh my god is it delicious. Full 5 stars for their delicious food. The dumplings are handmade so none of that frozen crap with preservatives you find at the supermarket. I have seen a van filled with fresh dumplings that are brought in everyday just to meet the demands of the hungry customers. I only and ONLY order the pork with corn dumpling because it is super super delicious. I also order jelly fish alongside some random appetizers, but the dumplings are the staple. Not to mention how good their salt and pepper chicken wings are (if your vegetarian give the pepper and salt fried tofu instead). 

I highly recommend this place to people, but like I always tell my friends and people that I recommend this place to, make sure to come early like around noon in order to avoid the long wait. This place is small and they have another location down the street, but both locations fill up quick and the wait for seating is limited.
author: John M.

description:
This past Tuesday, my friend and I had a hankering for dumplings. I've always passed by this place on the weekends and have seen the lines outside, so I was curious if weekdays were better, so I suggested we could go here. 

We got there around 5:45, so there were several empty tables and we were seated right away. We ordered the Shanghai style pan fried dumplings, the wontons in chili oil, and the sizzling rice soup.

DEM DUMPLINGS THO. The Shanghai style were amazing. Flavorful meat, and the dumpling had the right amount of crisp that you'd expect from something that was fried, but it wasn't soggy or overcooked. We loved them so much, we got another order of them immediately. The wontons in chili oil were good too, but they were a stand-in to the star of the show.

The sizzling rice soup is why this review doesn't have 5 stars. The broth had mushrooms, and carrots, but the taste was odd. It tasted like the brine that canned carrots come in, but like it was steeped for way too long. It's not what I'm used to, and my friend agreed. There were also supposed to be chicken pieces in there, but they were so tiny as to be invisible. The rice part itself was fine though.

Service was great, and pretty attentive, even after the restaurant started to get busy.

So if you come here, get the Shanghai dumplings. Get any of the dumplings. All of the dumplings. And forget the soup exists.
author: Maria M.

description: Love this place! Always has the best dumplings in town. Can get a little crowded, but that's expected for good food. The line moves fast.
author: Kayt C.

description: This place was the bomb! Quick service, hot dumplings and all the classic comfort Chinese food - you can't go wrong. Lines tend to get pretty long on weekends and this is definitely a "family dining" place - but I'd definitely recommend it!
author: Sam M.

description: Meh. Have had much better Chinese in L.A. Dumpling dough was too wet/mushy, Shanghai rice cake didn't taste Smokey pan fried enough, Mongolian beef was tender but too sweet. Lackluster mediocre Chinese cuisine. Wouldn't waste time dining here if on a short trip to SF.
author: Marmar Q.

description: YUM! Worth the hype. Get in line on Yelp if it is busy. I went with my sister on a Sunday night and there was still quite a wait. We placed our order quickly and received our food quickly also. The green beans are a must! The noodle soup was also pretty tasty. I can't even remember which of the buns I had, but you can't go wrong! Only thing I was sad I didn't see on the menu (and I totally could have overlooked this) was steamed buns filled with the bbq pork. The ones i ordered were just plain buns, not filled with anything. They were still yummy, just not what I was anticipating.
author: Alexandra C.

description:
This place is not fancy or hip or the place to be "seen" as far as SF standard go, but hot damn is it delicious.

I was bummed that I was in a group of 4 as we couldn't order as many dishes as I would have liked, but we still managed to work our way through a number of tasty dishes-

You obviously HAVE to get the XLB when you come here- they were quite tasty, but I also thoroughly enjoyed the crab and pork dumplings. 

The winner for me, though, was a toss up between the pan fried Shanghai style pork buns or the stir fried rice cakes. The pork buns are more like dumplings that have been lightly fried on the bottom and practically melt in your mouth, and the rice cakes are unlike anything I've had before.

"Rice Cakes" is fairly deceptive as it's more like a noodle and a rice grain had a baby or something (so yes, the dish is more like a pasta than a rice dish)- the flavors were on point and you'll get a mix of shrimp, chicken and pork in this dish. We CLEARED this plate in about 3 minutes flat as a group of four so do yourself a favor and order more of this.

We did have a couple of "eh" dishes- the mu shu pork and the green onion pancake. Both were good, but not great, especially when compared to the dumplings and rice cakes.

Don't believe they take reservations but the tables turn over really quickly so you won't have to wait long if you have to wait at all. Only a couple of beers for alcohol options!
author: Elliott W.

description:
Amazing! Starved after a run, my boyfriend and I were looking for a place with a plethora of yummy food. We stumbled across this place on nearby us and we couldn't have made a better decision. 

We ordered the pan fried pork buns, beef with string beans and rice, and hot and sour soup. 

The pan fried pork buns are A MUST. Plump, juicy, and a perfectly seared casing. The beef and string beans reminded me of hasty home cooking, coming from a Chinese household. And the hot and sour soup, not authentic I know, but still SO delicious. It's good to have "fake" Chinese food here and there. 

For the portions, quality, and price, you can't beat this cozy Chinese spot. Easily one of my favorite meals I've had in SF/Bay Area.
author: Anna Z.

description: I am very impressed by their authentic texture and flavor. I thought this is another Americanized Asian Fusion but most of their menu items are very authentic. The dessert buns (especially taro) are so soft that they melt in your mouth. I am most impressed by their taro buns because the filling isn't just any artificially flavored paste. I am not sure what their secret is but the filling tatses like the steamy soft taro buns from my childhood memories in Shanghai. I haven't had anything like it in two decades. The shop that sold this made fillings by squishing  real yam. I also recommnd the XLBs, pan seared bbq pork buns, and seafood potsticker. Authentic taste and seared just right. However, the seafood potstickers were a bit oily and I also ordered the shrimp toast (basically fried dough 油条 with shrimp paste ), but the fried dough is way too over fried. The authentic ones are soft with some crispyness (yup, hard to describe but the best ones are found at a chain Chinese supermarket's food court Marina Foods in Cupertino/Fremont, etc). This is why I am giving four stars and also the service could improve. The waiter appeared to be overwhelmed and was not too friendly. The staff just put food down in a hurry at any available space on the table. But I was very satisfied with the overall food quality, I could settle with a little less service. Will come back for another visit and recommend to friends
author: Sharon H.

description:
Finally.
Finally, I found a place in the bay that satisfies my XLB cravings.
The XLB here are great.
The dumplings in chili oil are even better.

I'd pass on the green onion pancake next time.
author: Trang B.

description:
long story short: 5 stars for the best XLB ever! super juicy and the meat is super soft! dumpling kitchen now has the record for best XLB in my books. $6.50 10 pieces...  i mean, i thought i knew what good XLB tasted like but i was definitely proved wrong thanks to this little establishment.

you should ONLY come here for the XLB.


2 stars for every other food items that was ordered.

also ordered:
*shanghai style chow mein noodles $7.50
*wonton w/chilli oil -10 pieces $6
*wonton in vegetable soup $7.50 6 pieces
*steamed pork and napa cabbage dumplings
*appetizer-sliced beef

the rest of the food items were just very bland. lack of flavor and lack of deliciousness! service wise it was like any other asian establishments. at the end of the day if you are a huge XLB fan then you must do yourself a favor and come here. if you are not and just want the ordinary chinese food then i say skip dumpling kitchen. save yourself from being disappointment. 


tips:
*high chair available. 
*credit card and cash accepted.
*street parking.
*closed Wednesday.
*restroom is available for customers.
*staff speaks limited english.
*indoor seating only.
author: Lisa D.

description:
Shanghai-style Pan Fried Pork Buns & Xiao Long Bao's!

Trust me, you wont be disappointed. 

Dumpling Kitchen is my favorite place to fulfill my dumpling cravings. Service here is not bad compared to most Asian restaurants. The servers speak English well so you won't have any problems communicating. The place isn't as big and the ambiance isn't as nice but the food totally makes up for it! 

Dishes I recommend: 

-Shanghai-style Pan Fried Pork Bun's: Definitely one of my go-to's here. The bottom of the buns are perfectly crispy brown. Topped with chopped scallions with a juicy pork filling. 
    
-XLB: Ahh.. I can never get over of how good these soup dumplings are. The dumplings were steamy with a tasty juicy pork broth. It was so good. You have to get this! 

-Braised Pork Belly w/ Preserved Veggies: Generous amount with the perfect amount of meat and fat ratio! This is really good with either rice or the shanghai chow mein! The preserved vegetables is a nice touch to it! This is a dish that is good enough for 2-3 people! 

-Shanghai Style Chow Mein: Home-made noodles, with a generous amount of vegetables & meat. The home-made noodles adds a difference. It's noodles are thick-cut and chewy. The chow mein is not too greasy either! 

I also tried the wontons in chili oil but it was way too oily for me. It made the wonton wrap really soggy and not very appetizing. But other than that, everything was delicious! 

That's all you need to get to always want to come back!
author: Tiffany H.

description: While not the best in town, this is a solid choice for hot dumplings and other asian delights. I like this place.
author: Zeynep D.

description: Quick turnaround. Various options of dumplings all tasty and juicy, with even couples ordering several. Other options such as noodles, rice, meat and chicken dishes as well as vegetables are available.
author: Kimberly H.

description: THEIR SHANGHAI DUMPLINGS ARE INCREDIBLE! Honestly that's all I've had but I crave them every day now. I get them to go and eat on Ocean Beach :D
author: Zach W.

description:
Happy New Year!Happened to want some dumpling and they were open. We came prime time around noon. Waited about 15 minutes for a two top which is not bad considering it was NY day. We ordered the following: 

Pork belly with preserved veggies- Seasoned sweet but just w the right amount. for some reason I thought it would be crispy from the photos. The portion was generous. 

Pork and crab XLB- very good. Best I've had in SF. Meat was soft and the amount of soup inside was adequate. Advice: Put some chili oil and soy sauce. 

Pan fried pork buns- crispy bottom, tender meat inside FTW. 

Pork fried rice- not dry (a plus), the pork used wasn't the typical red pork used in other Chinese restaurants. 
 
Steamed sweet buns w condensed milk(what it tasted like) dipping sauce- it was ok. Buns were soft and moist. The dipping sauce was tasty just wish they gave us more. 

A second visit is a must.
author: Kai A.

description: Just go and eat there. It's amazing!! We're already planning for our next lunch there!
author: Hande D.

description:
A good place to be around for lunch. They greeted us all with complimentary tea. 

Tried Vegetarian Dumplings and Chow Mein; tasted fairly good. Loved the spices that they provide on the side, ask for more if you'd like. Clean and tidy. Overall good but the taste can always get better :)
author: Bhargav S.

description: One of my favorite dumpling places in SF! I have to admit the prices are expensive for what they are but I still keep coming back.  My go-to order is the shanghai soup dumplings (of course), mini steamed pork buns, and their onion pancake.  Pretty good as take-out OR sit-in, sometimes service can be slow
author: Alison C.

description:
This place is great! In comparison to Dumpling King, this place is waaay better quality dumplings and the dining atmosphere is a notch better. 

The best things are the xlb, crab xlb, green beans and egg puffs! 

Food comes out quick, service is basic, food is well priced and delicious, I'm a fan!
author: Ashley Y.

description:
Yummy and affordable dishes. We ordered dumplings, potstickers, scallion pancake, and peanut noodle dish. It was the perfect amount of food for two and only cost about $35~

Highlights: non-greasy scallion pancake, flavorful pork dumplings, and pot of hot green tea for every table.
author: Bethany K.

description:
Not the best dumplings ever, but good, familiar Chinese comfort food that keeps me coming back on cold and rainy mornings or mornings after a night out. 3.5 stars, but I'll round up... 

- Cash or debit card only. 
- There's always a wait every time I go on the weekend. Don't be deterred by all the people standing outside though, the line moves faster than you'd think. 
- Food comes out pretty quickly, and though the service is friendly, it can sometimes be slow...
- Parking in this area is a huge pain.

DO get:
- Shanghai-style pan-fried dumplings: so delicious, consistently good every time. Juicy on the inside and crispy on the bottom.
- Spicy cow stomach. Don't knock it til you've tried it: spicy, cool, and crunchy (yes). Mmm. Great appetizer.
- Green onion pancake is also good: light and flaky, much lighter than what you'd get at other spots
- Crispy egg puffs: absolute must!! How do they make these?! Highly recommended. Flaky on the outside, light and airy, topped with sugar. Light creamy layers of egg on the inside. Mmm. 

Meh:
- I don't recommend the wonton soup in house broth. I've ordered it twice, both times both the soup and dumplings were bland
- The xiao long bao's are only average imo. Not flavorful. Unremarkable...
-Noodles in peanut sauce, aka dan dan noodles: I'm on the fence. Not super peanuty, and not spicy either. They're still good, but not exactly Dan Dan noodles...
author: Ashley S.

description:
As we stood outside Dumpling Kitchen, I saw a young boy skipping down the street with his mom, singing "XIAO LONG BAO, XIAO LONG BAO!" at the top of his lungs. 

I think that was fate's way of saying it approved of my lunch choice.

Ever since my fascination with shanghai soup dumplings surged like a geyser, my hubby has been sweetly taking me to as many restaurants as possible to help satiate my craving. Dumpling Kitchen's name practically says it all so the minute we sat down inside the cramped restaurant, I scanned the menu like a laser for xiao long bao and found it as the first item on a long, long list of dishes. After some perusing, we also ordered a bowl of wontons in chili oil and my hubby's favorite, green onion pancake. 

Unlike most Asian restaurants, the service at Dumpling Kitchen was honestly quite pleasant. I suspect it stems from the fact that the servers are all young people who speak English well, allowing for easy communication. They were incredibly responsive to our requests and we barely had to ask for anything twice. Definitely a star for that!

The table was a bit small to fit all of our dishes, but we made due with what we had. The green onion pancake arrived first and both my hubby and I were a bit perplexed by the appearance, noting it looked more like fried dough than a pancake. Gone were the crepe-layers, but was instead presented like flatbread . We instantly judged the pancake to be bad before even taking the first bite, but boy, were we wrong! HOW COULD SOMETHING SO SIMPLE BE SO ADDICTIVE? Slightly chewy on the inside and super crispy on the outside, the green onion pancake quickly dwindled away as we took slice after slice, enjoying every single morsel. 

Then came the wicker basket of xiao long bao that looked positively delicious. Certainly the largest portion we have encountered so far, all ten dumplings were steaming hot and looked perfect. I bit off a hole in the soft dough, poured the soup onto the spoon, and took a bite of the pork filling. I may have moaned just a bit when that first bite went down because wow, was it good! The soup was plentiful and the flavor was well-developed. You could really taste the pork broth and the filling was juicy. Seeing how much I loved it, my hubby selflessly let me eat most of it, but even he had to agree, it was pretty dang tasty.

But unfortunately, the train of deliciousness came to a screeching halt at the wonton stop. The filling was fine; it was the dough that was the most problematic. The weird, grainy texture and the chalky taste made the whole dish unappetizing. It may have resulted from a reaction between the oily sauce and wonton wrapper, but after eating one, I decided to forgo the wrapper and just finish the filling. No good!

Still, if we ignore the debacle that was the wontons in chili oil, everything else was marvelous. Prices were VERY cheap and portions were huge. Since Dumpling Kitchen isn't located in the crazy part of SF, I think my hubby and I will be back again. No more wontons in chili oil for us, but bring on the green onion pancake and XLBs!
author: Quyen L.

description: I really like this area: full of authentic Chinese restaurants. When I went to a restaurant Kingdom of Dumpling, I found this place and wanted to check this place out. Finally had chance to come here. It was only 5 pm but tables were all full. We ordered Shanghai style XLB and dumpling, and maps tofu. All good and service was efficient.
author: Kaori M.

description: Not so good anymore... service is rushed and hurried. You ask for two things and they give you only one, so I have to keep asking multiple severs for napkins, bowls, utensils etc.... food wise... the braised lion head meatball was my favorite, it wasn't silky smooth anymore, like they forgot to mix with it tofu to give it that smooth texture. It was just ok, the dumplings were fine, they shouldn't mess those up especially since they are know for that. Parking still sucks.... saw so many almost accidents because of double parking and people fighting over spots.
author: Alicia A.

description: I came at noon and was nervous because I saw so many people outside waiting, but my friend and I got a table probably within 5 minutes. We ordered the xiao long bao which is the soup dumpling, wonton in chili oil, combination chow mein, and walnut shrimp. I really liked the xiao long bao because the soup bursts into your mouth. We were careful not to burn our tongues, but waited a little too long that it wasn't as good so make sure to eat it hot! I also really liked the wonton in chili oil because the chili oil gives so much spice and extra flavor. Make sure to eat this while it's hot too, the dumplings do not taste good cold. The noodles and shrimp were alright, they tasted pretty typical to me.
author: Lauren L.

description:
One of the better places I've tried for Chinese dumplings, and definitely the best XLB that I've had in the bay. Really flavorful filling, and the way the skin was cooked was spot on, with the perfect thickness and texture.

We ordered one order of the regular pork XLB and one order of the crab & pork XLB, but after trying both, I'd suggest sticking with the regular. Not that the crab & pork dumplings were bad because they were great too--I just couldn't taste the difference, so I don't think it's worth the extra few dollars. 

Pork dumplings in chili oil were also a highlight. The steamed pork and cabbage dumplings were probably the most underwhelming out of everything we ordered, but it's more so because the other items were so good.

Will definitely be back to get my Chinese dumpling fix!
author: Sara L.

description: Good for brunch and breakfast! Chinese fried donut was on point, savory soy milk wasn't bad at all. The dumplings, which is what this restaurant is known for, sucked. There was barely any soup in the dumpling and the bottoms are mostly ripped, so the soup was already pouring out before we even bite into them. The skin of the dumpling was mushy, and melted together with the filling, so it was like vomit texture. The shanghai styled fried buns are probably store bought, it was not authentic, and definitely undercooked. The sticky rice had very basic fillings, and it was a half assed job. Dont get me started on the green onion pancake. It was completely yellow and very weird looking, definitely not green onion pancake. Where did they buy this? Costco?! Even costco frozen green onion pancakes looks and tasted more authentic.
author: Anna L.

description: This is a pretty solid dumpling place that doesn't get as crowded as I thought. The wait for Saturday lunch wasn't that bad. I got some xlbs with pork and crab which were hit or miss for the soup. It isn't as flavorful either. We got the pan fried buns and even though they weren't as crispy as I wanted, they were good nonetheless. I also got some soy saucy chicken wings which weren't needed but I think we should have gotten a noodle dish or something. You would think dumplings wouldn't be that expensive but it added up.
author: Amy H.

description: Hands down the best xianlongbao in the city. Period. The garlic green beans are absolutely amazing and I could easily eat 2-3 baskets of soup dumplings here because they are so freaking good! The steamed dumplings are not bad either, I like the pork and cabbage.
author: Ashley M.

description: Delicious and authentic food!!! They have different kinds of dumplings along with noodles and rice dishes. You gotta try it!
author: Melody C.

description:
A no frills place where I come to get my xiao long bao's (XLB) fix. If you come here comparing it to Din Tai Fung, please, just stop. You're comparing apples to oranges. 

The XLB's always come out fresh and piping hot, so beware when eating because that soup inside the dumpling WILL burn the insides of your mouth as you take your first bite. For each XLB  order, they come with 10 pieces for about $8.95, which is really reasonable. Aside from the XLB's, I've also had their chili dumplings and shanghai style noodle. They are decent, but not something I'd crave randomly like I do with their XLB's. 

The last time I came here, the staff seemed disinterested and kind of aloof, but then again, it is a Chinese restaurant, so you can't expect great service. Parking is strictly street/neighborhood only so good luck with that. Lastly, if you drive by and see a line out the door or people waiting for their name called, don't be deterred by that. The wait is usually pretty short. If you're coming in a group, have one person put their name on the list while the looks for parking.
author: Jackie T.

description: Delicious and happy to find a good XLB place in town. We ordered the xiao long baos, green beans, dry fried chicken wings, mabo tofu, Shanghai-style chow mien, and crispy egg puffs. Loved all the dishes and plan to come back again soon!
author: Mary L.

description:
My girlfriend and I went here with my SF native friend who doesn't know a lot, but does know his Chinese food. 

(Just kidding, buddy.)

Anyways, Dumpling Kitchen is legit. The Xiao Long Baos, or soup dumplings, are pretty amazing and on par with or even better than the very popular chain Din Tai Fung's. Soft, juicy, and tender, Dumpling Kitchen kills it. Just make sure to eat them pretty quickly or else they get lukewarm and totally meh.

We also got some that are pan-fried on the bottom, and these are totally great too. The texture contrast of the crusted bottom and softer upper is simply amazing. 

We also got some fried chicken wings with sauce which were very solid, but I'm not a huge chicken wing guy so I can't offer any crazy nuggets of wisdom here. They were sweet with a slight tinge of spice and were crispy but still saucy. Quality.

A comfortable interior that feels very homey, Dumpling Kitchen only is brought down by the excessive rattling that happens whenever one of the lightrail trains shoots by. 

I definitely will be coming back here; it turns out that my broken clock of a friend can be right more than twice a day.

(Again, I'm kidding, pal--don't hurt me.)
author: Tremaine E.

description:
The best part about this place was the green beans... we also ordered the green onion pancakes, Shanghai pork dumplings, and the pan fried pork dumplings. 

The shanghai pork dumplings were pretty good
The green onion pancakes were dry and bready
The pan fried dumplings were just okay

We were one of the first to be seated but two other parties that were seated after us got their food before us (and we ordered the same things) so we were a little miffed by that.

Other than that the place was okay but not somewhere I'm dying to come back to
author: Susie C.

description:
Another great find on Teraval!
We were craving dumplings but not being crammed into a table like another restaurant on the same street that shall go unnamed. 

A short wait was handled well by staff. Ordered our food and it seemed to arrive almost instantly. 
Steamed dumplings had a bit of juice to them that just exploded in your mouth.  The potstickers were a hit. Fried and almost crunchy on one side. No leftovers on that one. 

The star of the show was the Shanghai style chow mein. Thick noodles with chicken and a deep savory flavor.  I'm going back for that.
author: Ken R.

description:
I came here with a bunch of (mostly Chinese) friends and we really enjoyed the dumplings! We had xiao long bao (of course), potstickers, boiled dumplings (pork), and the pan fried pork buns (sheng jian bao). All the dumplings were great. The pork buns were just okay. I've had better elsewhere (the ones at Gourmet Noodle House are SO GOOD). I lost track of how many plates we ordered, but we def ordered a LOT. And it only came out to $16 per person, which I thought was a great deal for the large quantity of dumplings that were consumed (one of my friends prides himself on being able to eat 60 or more...).

Also, I'm by no means a vinegar fanatic, but a couple of my friends are suuuuuuuuuper picky about the type/brand of black vinegar they like to eat with dumplings, so they ended up pestering our waiters quite a bit trying to get the correct type lol... after a couple of tries they finally managed to get what they were looking for (even if it was a very small cup given with attitude, which tbh was probably deserved haha since they kept sending back the "wrong" vinegars LOL). So.. if you're also a vinegar connoisseur, I guess you should know that they have a couple of different types of vinegar?! Fwiw, I was happy with the one they provided at the table with ginger. You can also request fresh minced garlic (which we also did... our poor waiters must have hated us).

The place is a bit of a trek but the dumplings were worth it. And we made reservations so we didn't have to wait, but there was a bit of a wait overflowing outside.
author: Grace D.

description:
My team from work came here for lunch and they accommodated our large group by allowing us to make a reservation (I don't think they normally take those). 

We ordered a large variety of dumplings. The Xiao Long Bao (soup dumplings) were decent but not the best I've ever had. The dumpling skin could have been thinner and the soup was good but could have used more Chinese wine to balance out the meat flavor. 

The star of the meal were the Pork and Napa Cabbage dumplings. Generously filled and a classic combination. 

The meal was great value for money but note they don't take credit cards - just debit or cash. 

It's a no frills restaurant with great value for money. I'll definitely be back.
author: Jeremy G.

description:
Good price, Good food, quick service, and fresh dumplings
What more do you want :)
Found this little gem after going to Stern Grove.
author: Enrique R.

description:
This place was amazing! My 3 year old son loved the dumplings  and even boxed them up himself and wouldn't let us take them !
The sweet steam buns and condensed milk sauce were amazing
author: Christina G.

description: Had a wonderful dinner here on Saturday night. Came around 6:30pm. Got lucky with parking which is street parking and can be tricky at times. Liked their electronic wait list. Waited about 25 minutes at that time. Loved their dumplings, added some greens with pea sprouts with garlic and some spicy (asked for mild) tofu. Also had wontons on house broth. Washed it down with warm sweetened soybean milk. All excellent. Comfort food for me. Service was friendly, quick and attentive.
author: Tom V.

description: Really good spicy won ton - good mix of veggies and meat so it is tender.  There are a good selection of dumplings from steamed to pan fried.  Also have a good noodle selection - favorite is dan dan noodle with peanut sauce that is mildly spicy.
author: J Z.

description: Ran across this spot while dropping my sister off at the college. Wasn't too crowded, food came out quick and delicious, staff is courteous. I kinda wish they had some type of music to create some ambience, but we didn't stay long. I'd come back if i didn't live so far.
author: Matthew R.

description:
Service sucks, typical asian restaurant making excuses for why they seated a party of  6 people before the 4 other parties that have been waiting for 1.5hrs, what makes me even more pissed off is that they don't take reservations, and then they had the audacity to say "oh we take reservations only in the morning" which is a lie because I called that following morning to  make reservations to see if it was true. 
The place is extremely small "hole in the wall," we ended up in the back corner, literally no space we had to share a table with another couple. We ordered good amount of food and I must say it was all delicious. I would definitely come back for the food, probably do take out, since the service sucks here.
author: Cassandra G.

description:
I honestly can't say that I was impressed with Dumpling Kitchen. 

My boyfriend and I decided to take my grandma here to lunch this past Saturday. I had searched and searched for a place that serves good Xiao long bao, or at least, dumplings. We had already tried House of Dumplings so we were venturing for something new. We came across Dumpling Kitchen and with that, it had a ton of good reviews with a four star rating. Bingo! 

Parking is a pain, which can be said for everything in sunset, or better yet, San Francisco as a whole. My boyfriend dropped my grandma and me off first before he ventured out further to find parking. When we went in, there was a table immediately for a party of 3. Well, that's quick. I was expecting long lines and crazy crowds for a Saturday. 

We ended up getting an order of Xiao long bao, shanghai chow mein, Beijing style dumplings with pork and chive (boiled), and fried chicken wings. 

The Xiao long bao to me looked weird. It wasn't as "full" as I'm used to seeing them. They didn't have enough soup in them. But whatever soup they did have in them was okay. The meat was a little on the mushy side. AND their meat had hints of ginger mixed in. I prefer ginger in my vinegar, not in my dumpling. Overall, their xlb won't be remembered.

The shanghai chow mein was decent in flavor. It just had a ton of cabbage in it for whatever reason. Different regions have different styles, I suppose. 

The Beijing style dumplings had sweet meat in them. Definitely not my style. I prefer savory meat. 

The chicken wings had a glaze all over it and it was decent. Except the meat itself was a little bit on the tough side. 

The sweet soy milk was nice here though. It was probably my favorite item from Dumpling Kitchen. 

Dumpling Kitchen is a one and done for me. Their style of cooking and the flavors they use is just not what I'm looking for. I most likely won't come back considering I don't even live in the area.
author: Doriee D.

description: This place is original this is a really dumpling restaurant. If your used to fast food dumplings I don't recommend this place for you. Overall this place was really good and the food was very tasteful. We got the house soup that came with noodles chicken beef and shrimp and it had chunks of ginger carrots mushrooms and the flavor was amazing.  We also got two types of dumplings there 1 number which was just pork and the number 9 that was cabbage and pork that one was my favorite. The customer service was great they were very helpful and attentive to us. I really recommend this dumpling house if you're looking for an original place to eat.
author: Noe G.

description: This place is good, simple as that. I didn't realize how much I've missed good dim sum until my family and I chose to give this place a try since it was relatively close.
