The other options that are closer is actually a bit more expensive and in my opinion second rate compared to here. Definitely my new go to when the cravings come.
author: Geo C.

description:
Oh my... Where shall I start? At the flat, grease-filled, dunked in grease green onion pancake?

Or the non-sapid non-soupy XLB orders, that were lukewarm in the mouth?

I came to outer Sunset after less than 6 hours of sleep-- for this?!?? Cmon.

What's happening that this place would get a 4 star rating? Our window table was within dragon's breath distance to the other one.

Service was pretty abysmal. Doubt I will ever come again, when Kingdom is a stone's throw on same street.
PS we were all Asian diners..one especially from Taiwan. He too said epic fail. Pass!
author: Jana C.

description:
Hands down favorite restaurant in the sunset. Authentic and beautiful dumplings. Shanghai pork and Shanghai crab and pork dumplings are my go-tos. 

This is where I always take out of town visitors in the sunset. Do your self a favor and go!
author: ryan g.

description:
A dim sum craving morphed into a xiao long bao craving, so the roommate and I decided to try Dumpling Kitchen on Sunday, June 19th for lunch. We ordered delivery through DoorDash. Placed the order at 12:30pm and it arrived at 1:18pm. I live in Outer Richmond.

1. Shanghai-Style Steamed Pork Dumplings: 10pcs ($8.25)
3. Pan-Fried Pot Stickers: 10pcs ($8.25)
8. Pork Dumpling in Chili Oil: 10pcs, Spicy ($8.25)
56. Chicken Fried Rice ($8.75)
75. Dry-Braised String Beans ($9.25)
116. Mongolian Beef: Spicy ($9.75)
119. Dry-Fried Chicken Wings: Spicy ($9.75)

The star of this meal were the dumplings! The soup dumplings were super tasty. The skin not too thick and they all survived the transport. I also enjoyed the pork dumplings in chili oil. Although since they were delivered, we got a side of chili oil instead. I did wish the sauce were a little spicier as it didn't have much chili in it, but it was good for dunking. The roommate loved the pot stickers. He's a pot sticker fiend. Unfortunately, the rest of the food was kind of bland. I loved the texture of the fried rice, but it didn't have much flavor. Same with the green beans. They were cooked perfectly, but a little bland. The dry fried chicken wings weren't good at all. Super mushy and it didn't have that garlicky, spicy, sweet and savory flavor I love. The mongolian beef was the best taste wise of the non dumpling dishes. It had a subtle spice.

Solid dumplings, but the rest of the dishes were just average. 5 stars for the dumplings, but 3 stars for the rest. Overall, 4 stars.
author: Elena N.

description:
Been here many times. Great food! 

The only dish which one of our friend's kids ordered (against our recommendation) was sweet sour chicken - which really isn't traditional to begin with. It was hardly touched as everything else was so good.
author: Y B.

description:
I hadn't been back since my last review almost 5 years ago, but I'm glad I returned.

There was a line at lunch on this lunar new year and it was worth the wait. Tea came quickly and the service was friendly, helpful, and fairly efficient, despite the packed restaurant.

In addition to veg steamed dumplings and scallion pancakes (both still winners, though the scallion pancake isn't really good value), we tried the mu shu vegetable.

The mu shu vegetable (without egg) came on a big oval plate with little pieces of broccoli in addition to the more standard veggies. I felt so lucky! We received six pancakes and I appreciaated that they were thick and therefore didn't break, as so many do at other Chinese restaurants. The hoison sauce was thick and tasty, so the whole package was good and yummy.
author: Veg V.

description: Food was mediocre.  Really hot and muggy, like a swamp.  Yelp page says credit cards accepted but only cash.  When I pointed that out, no apology.  Blamed yelp for error.
author: Antony H.

description:
Great dim sum and dumplings we came here twice with a small group and then again with 8 people. It was super good

We had an assortment of dumplings

Their soup filled dumplings were great.

Service was fast 

Would recommend
author: Jeff C.

description:
I come here a lot since my dad really likes their shanghai-styled dishes. Here is a list of our personal favorite items:

XIAO LONG BAOS 
- Eat these right away once they set it on your table!! These little things taste best when the soup is still hot as it bursts in your mouth (but don't burn yourself please)! The meat and soup inside is packed with so much flavor. 

Shanghai styled chow mein 
- This is probably one of the underrated dishes. It is mixed with meat, cabbage, and other veggies found in regular Chinese chow mein. I love how they use thick cut noodles that are cooked to a perfect soft, chewy texture. This is the reason why I love the dish so much! It is on the greasy side but that's also probably why it tastes so good haha.

Five spice beef stew noodle soup
- I don't think I've ever had Shanghai beef noodle soup anywhere else, so this opinion is based on this dish with nothing else to compare it to. The beef is very tender and there's lots of it! The stew isn't heavy at all, it's more on the light side but still very flavorful. 

FRESHLY MADE SOY MILK 
- It comes in hot/cold and sweet/ savory. I prefer it cold and sweet during the meal because I tend to get quite steamy from eating the main dishes. This drink is very refreshes you and allows you to eat more dumplings!

I'm not really a fan of their green onion pancakes; they're too fluffy (almost like pita bread) for my liking. The onion flavor isn't really present with every bite. The pan fried buns didn't really stand out to me either. 

Service is like any other Chinese restaurant. You don't get treated like royalty, but they do complete all your requests and the food is great. The younger lady at the front is always nice and welcoming!
author: Nancy C.

description: Fantastic service by Pat! We loved the bbq pork bao and the pork soup dumplings! DEFINITELY coming back
author: Lauren C.

description: Wow!!! Amazing! This place just hits the spot. I am so impressed. First of all, this place had great service. We were seated in minutes and the food came within minutes! We ordered the XLB, pork dumpling in chili oil, and salt and pepper wings. All the items were exceptional and were cheap too! The soup dumplings had great flavor and very brothy. The salt and pepper wings had tons of flavor, nice and crispy and juicy on the inside. Had a nice kick of spice too which I loved. The dumpling in chili oil had great depth of flavor. Meat was juicy, and a good amount of spice on that. This place is as authentic as it gets. So much to choose from but their most famous dish is obviously their XLB, their soup dumplings. They only take debit or cash so make sure you have some cash on hand. Loved this place!
author: Blu M.

description:
This place is great! All their dishes are amazing! The beef noodles, mushu pork, and xiao long bao are all top notch. And their other baos are extremely juicy and flavorful as well. The potstickers are really tasty, but so is everything else so it's hard to recommend any one dish over another. I think among the many dumpling places in Sunset/Parkside the food here really stands out. 

They're really popular on the weekends so the lunch wait can be a bit long. However, once seated, the food comes out really fast! This is one of the few Chinese places I've been to that actually employs a large staff during rush hours to ensure customers are served in a timely fashion and I greatly appreciate it. The staff is really friendly as well!
author: Sherman C.

description: Where have you been all my life, Dumpling Kitchen? I wish I had two stomachs like a cow so I could eat everything I ordered. Definitely coming back for more!
author: Meems N.

description:
My friends and I found this place on Yelp. Needless to say, we were not disappointed. Embarrassingly, we did not put down our chopsticks in between bites. By the time we had finished everything, we had forgotten that we didn't take any pics of our delicious meal. 

The place was clean and had friendly staffs. 
It was a treat to see the ladies making the dumplings on site. We had some meat noodle that was very tasty as well. 

I would definitely come back to try more items on the menu.
author: Valerie H.

description:
Had the green onion pancake. Came out airy, cakey and green. My guess is that the green onions are freshly cut but marinade in the batter. 

5 spice beef stew is just a beef stew with soup. Not sure where the 5 spice was but decent chunks of beef. Soup was watered down 

Xiao Long Baos - Not bad if you come for that alone.
author: Gary L.

description:
Their XLB are better than those at Shanghai Dumpling house. Here, the XLB skin is thin and holds the soup. YUM. 

We also ordered the rice cake noodles, green onion pancake, pan fried pork dumplings, and bok choy. My friend bit into the green onion pancake and said "This tastes like a pringle." He continued to eat more. I particularly enjoyed the rice cake noodles. 

After trying sub-par XLB, I was in search of ones that satisfy the soul. Dumpling Kitchen is chicken soup for my ABC soul. Slurp.
author: Joanna L.

description: If you're in the mood for dumplings or great Chinese food look no further than Dumpling Kitchen. This little place is nestled in a small neighborhood and their food packs a punch. Their house-made dumplings are so delicious we drive an hour just to eat here and its worth it. We have also tried their other food options and every time we are not disappointed. My advise if you have not been to this place what are you waiting for?
author: EJ A.

description: Love the freshly made dumplings, you can taste it. The staff are friendly and will suggest you dishes to order. Everything they have on the menu is super tasty. It feels like coming home to a meal cooked with all the fresh ingredients.
author: Mehran A.

description: Had XLB and pan fried pork buns. Meh... wouldn't go back. Haven't been able to find good XLB in town :( Flavor was ok but XLB were very thick and pork buns didn't have enough pork.
author: J D.

description: My bill was around $25. I gave them $40(2 $20s) and expecting to get my changes. I waited 10 mins and still didn't get my changes back until I asked them for it...I have a feeling that they just wanted me to leave and quietly keep my changes as tip. smh.
author: Siyi W.

description: These were the best dumplings I have had the pleasure of eating. Hands down. The service is quick and friendly. The food is hot and fresh. No fuss dining. It's all about the food here.
author: Sara K.

description:
Ive always wanted to try this place cause I love Xiao long baos and the reviews are really good. I finally came upon this place at a random time on a Sunday with surprisingly no wait at all and a lot of empty tables as well. Probably cause of the random time that we came, I wanna say around 3pm but I don't really remember.

We ordered the shanghai chow mein noodle, wontons in chili oil and shanghai dumplings. I did not enjoy the shanghai chow mein and wontons, the flavor of the chow mein was not like the usual shanghai chow mein flavor that I usually have at other restaurants. It was very oily and bland as well. The wontons in chili oil was not very flavorful either and wasn't spicy either, does not compare to din tai Fung at all. The Xiao long baos (shanghai dumpling) was OK but not amazing. It had some soup in the dumpling but not a lot of it. Overall, I would say the shanghai dumplings were OK but the other two dishes I would not recommend. (Unless the chef was just having a bad day) then I guess you can go for it just to try it but I do not think I will come back and if I do, I definitely would not order those two dishes again.
author: Bailey L.

description: We were seated almost right away. I knew we had to get soup dumplings, because that's what they're known for. They did not disappoint. Soup dumplings aren't easy to get right, but they were pretty tasty here. We also ordered these spicy pork dumplings and the beef stew noodle soup. I love beef stew and the meat was soft and this really hit the spot. Perfect comfort food. This place is also not too expensive. I would definitely come back.
author: Allyson L.

description:
I gotta say that I love the xiao long bao and the Shanghai-style pan fried pork buns at Dumpling Kitchen!

I usually go on the weekdays during dinner time, and I've never had to wait. My friends and I usually order: 1) Shanghai-style steamed pork dumplings (xiao long bao), 2) Shanghai-style pan fried pork buns, 3) Pork dumplings in chili oil, and choose a vegetable dish on the side. The three dishes I listed were 10 pieces for $8.50.

Overall, the food is great and the service is pretty good too. If you're craving dumplings, I'd say Dumpling Kitchen is the place to go!
author: Erica L.

description: My girlfriend and I tried this place for the first time, and I was happy to see a number of vegetarian options. The vegetarian dumplings and chow mein were delicious, as was the complimentary tea. The service was prompt and friendly. We had to wait about 20 minutes for a table, but it was well worth it.
author: Andrew M.

description:
Downgrade Tuesday!  Maybe they were having an off day today, but today's meal at Dumpling Kitchen was less than stellar.  The food and service was very different than from what I normally experience.  Friend and I stopped in during the mid afternoon where all the workers were folding take out menus.  There were only two other table of patrons at this odd hour.  We ordered the XLB and Beef Brisket Noodle Soup.  The waiter was very apathetic and when our food arrived, the lady just shoved our dishes on the table and walked away.  The staff pretty much ignored us the whole time and we had to get their attention to ask for things.  

The XLB didn't taste that great as the dumpling skin was thick and doughy while the pork filling was too fatty and had little flavor.  The Beef Noodle Soup came with wonton noodles instead of thick egg noodles.  The beef brisket was mostly fatty and inedible.  The only saving grace was the beef broth.  It had decent star anise flavor but probably laden with MSG.  Portions still large and tab was $19 and some change.  I'm not sure why we felt the need to even leave a more than deserving tip of 22% especially since no one acknowledged us when we got up to leave.  Hopefully, friend and I will have some good karma for supporting small local mom and pop shop even when they are ungrateful for our business.
author: Liv A.

description:
This is definitely one of the better dumpling shops in San Francisco. It's always super busy so come ready to wait but it's totally worth it!

Shanghai Style Juicy Pork Dumplings (Xiao Long Bao): a must at any dumpling place! This is how you can tell if any restaurant's dumplings will be good or not. The skin isn't too thick on the dumplings here and the filling has just the right amount of soup and flavor. 

Shanghai Style Pan Fried Buns: these are my absolute favorite! I love the fluffy exterior of the buns and they pan fry them so they have crispy bottoms. The inside is so juicy and delicious. Sometimes other places the filling gets too dry especially with the thick exterior bun, but this place is sooo good! 

Green Onion Pancake: again one of the best I've had. You get a big portion. The pancake is thin and crispy. Not too thick or floury. Good green onion flavor. A+. 

Try this place out for sure! I've had a ton of other food and everything is amazing!
author: Kelly N.

description: Great XLB. We also loved the pan fried pork buns. Service was a bit strange but the place definitely is a fob establishment. I usually judge how authentic an Asian restaurant is based on how rude the servers are. Maybe I'm weird, but I am immediately suspicious if I go to an Asian restaurant and they're nice to me! We got the wontons in chili oil but I wasn't a huge fan. They were not actually dunked in chili oil but rather in some sort of sesame sauce (kind of like what you put on dan dan noodles). Don't get the wontons in oil if you have a nut allergy.
author: Cindy N.

description:
This is tough to write.  Dumplings, wontons, and potstickers are 4 stars but the chow mein and sweet and sour chicken we ordered for the kids were less than 1 star.  So... Depending on what you order you may be very happy or you may be very disappointed.   

Ordered
XLB
Wontons in chili
Pot stickers 
Chicken chow mein
Sweet and sour chicken
author: Madhuri K.

description:
Good lunch spot! They have fresh soy milk and good portions for their dishes! Sad to say I actually didn't get their xiao long bao since I came with my mom and she didn't feel like eating them at the time. 

We ended up ordering their famous noodles, crispy sweet egg puffs, dumplings in chili oil, potstickers and of course their clay pot. All of it was delicious and I especially liked how quick their service was! 

My only gripe is the cleanliness of the place. I sat by the window near the entrance and there were at least 2 huge flies buzzing around our meal the entire time and smaller flies landing near my tea. 

Overall, I'd definitely be back but I'm going to request to sit towards the back. They were quite busy at 1pm as our wait was about 25 min. After we finished around 2:30pm, the lunch rush must've ended because the entire restaurant was almost empty O.o
author: Shelly W.

description: My boyfriend and I love going here for dumplings. The food tastes really homey and their dumpling sauce is to die for. There's always a wait when we come here, but it's definitely worth it. We usually order their jajiang mian, XLB, and crab and pork steamed dumplings - all delicious! I do wish it was a little bigger because it's definitely a rubbed elbows type of place, but the food makes up for it. Of course I'll be back
author: Kimmie N.

description:
First time trying soup dumplings and wow!!!! It's so goooood. There's 3 locations (that I found on yelp similar to this place) and we chose to go to this one due to their reviews. I actually really enjoyed eating it all. We got the XLB's 10pc, dry-fried chicken wings, Shanghai Chow Mein, rice and pan fried pork buns to go. It was all delicious and flavorful. My tummy is satisfied! 

The restaurant is small, but given being in SF.. There isn't much room for a big restaurant haha! It's a bit hard to find parking and the line was long but it went by fast. You need to put your name on a list too! It's a pretty busy restaurant, but it's fast paced. The food comes out hot and quick. The workers here are nice too!

Overall, come and enjoy their bomb ass food! I'm super down to try other dishes next time.
author: Katie L.

description:
Their Braised Pork Belly is absolutely amazing! I know it's probably not that for my health, but I guess once in a while is OK ( what an excuse :P). I also like their Shang Hai Xiao Long Bao, very juicy! 

The one thing I don't like about this place, like any other good restaurant in the bay area, is that the line is long.
author: Hazel B.

description:
Had a craving for some XLB, and Dumpling Kitchen definitely fixed me up! Though not quite as small as Kingdom of Dumplings (my girlfriend swears there's only about 15 seats there, lol), DK is also a fairly small joint- you have to put your name down on a waiting list. For our group of 3 to get seated around 12:30pm, we waited less than half an hour so that wasn't bad at all. Service here is very quick, which also helps with the turn around time. =]

Peanuts: Aside from the usual free hot tea, each table gets a small sauce dish full of roasted peanuts. I have a hunch they have been lightly seasoned with 5 spice/star anise because these are not your usual boring salted peanuts, lol. Delicious!

Hot and sour soup: Hot in temperature, but not super spicy. Very accessible dish for everyone, particularly on chilly days! Also as a bonus, there's hella egg ribbons in it! Love that!

Wontons in chili oil: Not my fav. The wontons themselves are alright, but the chili oil here was quite bland. Not really salty, not actually spicy....just really thick. For me, that made the dish pretty heavy, even as I was trying to dilute the oil down with some of my soup lol.

Shanghai dumplings: SO GOOD!!! The dumpling skins were of medium thickness to keep the soup contained, but still quite pliable and not too floury tasting. Meat filling was well flavored. I don't know if this comes as a surprise to anyone else, but I was weirdly impressed by the gel-ifying property of the soup in the last dumpling we accidentally let cool to room temp...the kind of gel you can only get from the tons of collagen extracted from real bone broth....good stuff!

Definitely gonna swing by again the next time I'm around these parts! =]
author: Yen D.

description:
This place is way, way, way in the Outer Sunset, a real slog for me.  But Hong Kong Lounge II, which is near to me, has gotten to be a place that serves up attitude. They don't want to seat single diners, even if you get there early, are at the front of the line, and reservations are available. So, to the Sunset for me. And it was worth it.  My strategy was to get to Dumpling Kitchen early on Sunday afternoon and have the place to myself.  At 4 PM the place was largely filled but they seated me and provided great service.  

A ten dollar serving of Mu Shu Pork was immense, properly cooked, tasty, and a meal in itself.  That says everything about this place.  

I took the ten dollar serving of mixed chow mein home.  It was great: the noodles were al dente, and the chicken, beef, and shrimp in the mix were fresh and properly cooked.

And the food wasn't too salty.  

Dumpling Kitchen has everything Hong Kong Lounge II now lacks: heart.
author: David D.

description: One of my most terrifying dining experience ever. I'm a Chinese born and raised in Sichuan, the home of "红油抄手", or in English "Wonton in Chili Oil". But whatever they served me was NOT "Wonton in Chili Oil" AT ALL! WHAT KIND OF CHILI OIL IS NOT TRANSPARENT?!?! But this is not the worst, the worst thing is that I started to have tummy pain and minutes later I had probably the most serious diarrhea in my life ( I was literally pooping water). If you love genuine Chinese food and your life, stay away from this place. I have already reported it to the city department of health.o
author: Jim D.

description:
Solid Chinese food. I don't particularly crave their xiao long bao (the crab xlb at Shanghai Dumpling King is WAY better) or their dumplings, despite the name. The #1 reason why I come here is for the braised pork belly with preserved vegetables--it's the bomb dot com! Generous tender slabs of pork belly with that perfect amount of fat (I prefer fattier than average so I understand not everyone will share this view). That dish plus rice is all you'll need (and the portions are considerable too, probably sufficient for 2-3 people).

The dry fried chicken wings lack that special blend of sweetness and spice that has become San Tung's signature, but they're crispy and tasty enough. The pan fried pork buns (sheng jian bao 生煎包) are pretty good too, with a fluffy and sweet exterior. I still prefer Shanghai Dumpling King's, if only because the skin isn't as soggy, but bear in mind that both fail to provide that rich gelatinous soup which you should be slurping with each bite. Actually, I still have yet to find a place in the Bay Area that makes it as good as they do in Hong Kong. I may be searching for a unicorn...
author: Tiffany H.

description: Words cannot describe the deliciousness that are the sheng jian bao (pan fried buns) here. Perfect dough/filling ratio, pan fried with a perfect crust on bottom. The meat inside has a savoriness that can only be achieved with pork fat. Only the best. I always inhale these before they cool down and burn the top of my mouth. NO REGETS. Do yourself a favor and order these right now. The potkstickers are pretty good too, but they are like the Chewbacca to the Han Solo sheng jian bao.
author: William W.

description: This place is all about the dumplings and pot stickers. House made dumplings were full of flavor. The rest of the Chinese food was just ok. I thought the eggplant dish was very greasy and lacked flavor. The chicken & Bock Choi & shrimp fried rice were ok. If you enjoy dumplings & pot stickers and your in the neighborhood this place is worth a try.
author: Kevin B.

description:
I love this place. Kingdom of Dumpling imho still has the best XLB's, however, this place is better for groups and offers more variety if someone in your party is the type to ask for items you can find at Panda Express *face palm*. 

My favorite things here are: 

- XLB (does anything need to be said about these babies?)
- String Beans (flavorful, tender yet crisp)
- Shanghai Rice Cakes (so tasty)
- Chinese Ham Clay Pot (pour a little chili oil on top and )
- Chinese Donut (crispy outside, fluffy inside)
- Sweet Soy Milk (not too sweet, just right - always!)
author: c c.

description:
I've been here multiple times in the few months I've lived in SF. That alone says a lot. Everything I've ordered here has been good - the dry fried green beans are my go-to to add some fiber to the meal. I think for two people, ordering two or three dishes is plenty. I've over ordered twice and to be frank the dumplings don't reheat very well! Best to order what you can eat on the spot. 

It's usually pretty crowded here, but if you have just a couple of people you can usually get seated quickly. Easily accessible by Muni (take the L) and there's even a good gelato spot nearby if you want dessert! (Marco Polo, a few blocks down). I'm usually stuffed after my meals here though, so you probably won't be needing dessert at all. 

Service is quick, and friendly enough. Overall you can get a good meal for a good price here. Go for it!

Btw, it's cash and debit only! Come prepared :)
author: Lauren C.

description:
Came here and ordered the chicken fried rice, shanghai dumplings, chili oil dumplings, and the Shanghai pan fried pork buns. Great portions for an amazing price. 

The fried rice tasted pretty plain, but was just your average plate of chicken fried rice.

The chili oil dumplings were okay, wish I would have got the wontons instead. It wasn't spicy, they added black vinegar to it, so it was more spicy than anything. 

Shanghai steamed dumplings: XLB! The skins are the right thinness and do not break, I would like there to be more soup in these though and a bit more seasoning to the filling . This was my boyfriends favorite, and his first time having XLB. I wish they did give some ginger to eat it with though. 

Pan fried pork dumplings: I would highly recommend these. These were my favorite out of the entire meal. The bottoms were crispy and the skin wasn't really thick. The flavor of the filling was super delicious.

The food came out super quick and the staff were constantly checking on us. We were put in a corner in the very back, it wasn't entirely cramped, but I would have liked a little more space away from the other tables. Our dishes barely fit on the table, but at least the venue is bigger than most places in SF.
author: Manda A.

description: This is one of the best Chinese places I've been to all the food had lots of flavor, I will definitely go back.
author: Krishna H.

description:
4 stars for the XLB- the skin was thin, lots of soup, decent flavor. 

Otherwise the food was pretty below standard. 

We ordered the beef stew noodle soup- not enough broth, no flavor, beef was a horrible cut and mostly grissel and fat. 

Green onion pancake was strange- never seen a Chinese pancake like this- not a lot of flavor here either.

Don't come expecting great, clean decor or amazing service- its just not that kind of place.
author: Mandi W.

description:
When you craving some Xiao Long Baos and there's nothing around the city like Din Tai Fung in SoCal, this spot will do the job. For a pretty affordable price and something for a good snack i do recommend coming here for the Xiao Long Bao (pork for that classic taste) , Chilli Wontons and well some noodles or rice plate to make it more filling. 

The Xiao Long Baos here are very soupy and has a great flavor to it even if its on its own. The recommended way to do it is lift it up with a spoon ( so that the soup base doesnt leak out everywhere) , then bite off the top of the XLB, add some vinegar into the middle for extra flavor. I personally just rub chilli sauce/paste all over it which kind of tastes like a chili wonton but flavorful soup base when you bite it. The Chilli wontons here are no match for Din Tai Fungs' as it tends to be a larger wonton itself but the flavor isn't as balanced. 

On my most recent visit i also ordered the Mongolian beef just to add in some more to the XLB and wontons, it seemed like a large portion at first but in reality it does have a way larger veggies ratio to the meat so it really isn't too bad. Flavor was cool, nothing rather special! 

Small neat restaurant with street parking and JUICY XLBs.
author: Auden W.

description:
This place is located down the street from my home and I do frequent them a lot!  That being said, there are certain dishes I prefer and some I don't think I would ever order again.  

Their xiao long baos, chao nian gao (stir fried rice cakes), xiang jian bao (pan fried buns) and warm soy milk are delicious.

I'm not a big fan of their fried chicken wings and veggies (tend to lean on the oilier side).  I've had their tan tan mian and it was ok.  It's not as flavorful as I've had in some other places.

It's easy and convenient for me. One of the better restaurants I've tried on Taraval.
author: Colleen L.

description:
We came on a Sunday for lunch and waited only 10-15min. You can check in on Yelp and follow on many people are ahead of you in real time :-)

Pros:

- The food was great
- No wait time to get served
- Great servers
- Decent prices
- No take-away, the kitchen is 100% focused on serving the actual customers, in the restaurant

Cons:

- Cash and debit only
- You will most likely have to wait outside
author: John D.

description:
My friend stopped by here a few weeks ago and posted tons of tasty-looking IG photos that just begged me to come check this place out. The perfect opportunity presented itself last week when my family was visiting SF.

Rating Breakdown:

1/2 Stars for Taste --
We went a little carb crazy... we ordered the sheng jian bao (pan fried dumplings), green onion pancake, dan dan noodles, wontons in chili oil, chinese ham and rice clay pot, and fried buns with condensed milk. You know, nothing really blew me away. Everything I ate, I was like "Hm, I'm not mad at that" yet it wasn't the best of that thing I've ever had. The most disappointing thing was probably the wontons. The wontons themselves were aiite, but the sauce was more peanut than chili oil. The dan dan noodles were on point, chewy and perfectly Q, but the sauce tasted almost like...instant noodle flavoring? It wasn't BAD, but it wasn't what you'd expect from dan dan noodles. The rice clay pot was nothing to write home about -- salty ham, salty rice. The onion pancake was like no other onion pancake I've had before. It was very flaky but not very flavorful. I guess I just prefer my green onion pancake on the denser, chewier side. Even the fried buns were like, meh. Hot. Crispy. Smothered in condensed milk, what's not to like...yet I've had better.

1/1 Stars for Value --
Most entrees cost around $10. Ideally come in a group of 4-5 and share a few dishes. You'll probably pay about $12-15 per person with tax and tip...depending on how crazy you go. 

1/1 Stars for Customer Service --
This place is definitely a mom and pop shop. All the servers look like they could be family members of the owners. People are friendly here and service is fast.

No bonus star because there are better places for me to get my Chinese carb fix...
author: Abby W.

description:
Loved the soup dumplings! The beef and spinach soup was also quite perfect for a stormy day. It came with a lot of servings so if there are less than 4 people, you'll probably have extra. 

For something sweet, we had the egg puffs. These are like the pastry from a cream puff with granulated sugar on top. They were okay, but I probably wouldn't get them again. 

Service was prompt, but they don't speak much English and aren't that friendly. The ambiance was clean and bright. Lots of large tables. We came at an off time and there was plenty of seating but not much parking.
author: Susan G.

description:
I was so disappointed with this place. Based on the other reviews, I really expected better. We watched the sunset nearby at Fort Funston and stopped in here at 6:30 PM on a Sunday for a lighter snack dinner.

- a basket of xiaolongbao $8.95 - thick skin and no soup/broth
- a bowl of wonton in chili oil $8.95 - no flavor and excess wonton peel

Seriously. I really have no good things to say about this place but service was decent... I don't eat much XLB except for twice a year or so in Flushing, so yes, that much means I've had the best on the East Coast. And man, does SF disappoint. Surprisingly, even Dallas has better chili oil wontons (bottomless pit eater boyfriend agrees).

Sigh. So disappointed.
author: Lucy Z.

description:
Shanghai Dumplings are da bomb! They are so so good, the skin thickness is just nice, they are served warm, the soup within the dumpling is fantastic. Absolutely in love with the dumplings and should really have ordered more!

A colleague recommended this place for their XLB and we finally have the chance to visit. There are street parking available near the shop but take note of the parking restrictions before you park! 

We ordered XLB (5/5), Pork and Spinach Soup Noodles (1/5), Soy Milk (2/5) and Dough Fritters - You tiaos (3/5). The XLB were really good and the rest was not great. 

The XLB are so good that i am confident we will be back again but just for them. The rest of the food was just disappointing. 

Service is medicore as well. i notice they have a clipboard with a busy looking wait list. We were here in the late afternoon around 4pm, and there was no line and we were seated immediately. There were quite a no. of empty tables too. My guess is that it probably get really crowded during lunch/dinner time. 

All i can say is... come for XLB and XLB only
author: Cindee T.

description:
Dumpling Kitchen is legit! Finally made it out here and loved the piping hot soup dumplings that are carefully hand crafted. We were also pleasantly surprised that the prices here are rather reasonable still after all the hype, and they do take credit cards now (no Amex).

Among the five of us, we got two orders of XLB, two orders of Chicken wings, chili oil dumplings, a veggie dish =all for $70 after tax/tip.

The ambiance is pretty bland but at least can accommodate plenty. It's your typical chinese-joint with paper napkins, sans tablecloths of course.

We arrived a little before 11AM and waited about 15 minutes. Around noon, there were definitely a good number of parties waiting outside!

Top notch fresh food and can't wait to be back.
author: Veronica S.

description:
Dumpling Kitchen is a friendly neighborhood Chinese restaurant on Taraval that offers up tasty dishes--obviously from the name of the restaurant, you can tell that they have a huge selection of dumplings. I came here for lunch with a group of four on Christmas (as it was one of the few places open) and we waited for about 20 minutes before being seated at a table.

Family style is the only way to go with this type of dining--we started with the Shanghai Chow Mein, which came with strips of pork and was fairly greasy (the flavor could probably have been a little stronger). We also had the seafood fried rice, which was a nice staple dish. On the side, we had the cold cucumber salad, which was dressed with sesame oil and raw garlic--this made for a refreshing addition to an otherwise meat-heavy meal. My favorite dish was the lion's head meatball in house broth--in addition to the delicious, tender pork meatballs themselves, this dish came with mushrooms, napa cabbage, and rice noodles. The broth was so clean-tasting and warming--very delicious! Finally, we had to get a steamer full of soup dumplings (xiao long bao). Although the flavor was nice, I wouldn't say these were true soup dumplings at all, as the skin was way too thin and flimsy to hold in any of the soup!

The pluses to this restaurant are most certainly the large portions, the value, and the super quick and attentive/friendly service. The food was kind of average for a Chinese restaurant, as it was generally a little greasy and contained a fair amount of MSG. Nevertheless, this restaurant is definitely a solid bet if you're in the neighborhood and wanting some nice Chinese dishes.
author: David K.

description:
Exceptional dumplings!! We ordered pick-up so didn't have to wait for a table (the line looked pretty long at 11:30 on a Saturday). 

We ordered three different style of dumplings. Ranked from most delicious/mouth-watering to just hella good, they were: pan-fried pork buns (DO NOT miss out on these), xlb, and the pork and cabbage dumpling. We also got the green onion pancake - wasn't anything too exceptional. 

If you order pick-up make sure to ask for the chili sauce as they don't include it in your order - same goes for soy sauce if you like that on your dumplings. Can't wait to try the pork and crab dumplings....Those looked soooooo good! Will definitely be back - probably multiple times.
author: Elisa P.

description:
This may be a harsher review, but only because I've had many, many dumplings in my lifetime! It's actually 4 stars, but compared to the other places I've been to this gets a 3....eh 3.5. 

XLB: You're here for XLB. $8.75 for 10, not bad. Let's talk skin-soup ratio. The skin is thick. I personally don't like thick xlb skins. It makes it too doughy. But with such thick skin, I would want more soup inside. Right? Thicker skin for more stability so that the soup won't burst out. Not enough soup in this little dumpling. Size-wise, perfect. I like xlbs that can fit in my mouth. Just one bite. Still had good flavor though--sweet broth, not too salty. My favorite dumpling? Still the overly popular Din Tai Fung. They got the skin-soup ratio just right. But I ain't waiting in that line. 

String beans: Not bad, but a little too salty with the preserved vegetables that they use. For the best string beans though, head over to San Tung. 

Dry Chicken Wings: Fried chicken wings then tossed in a sweet and spicy sauce. It had good flavor, but the chicken wasn't crispy enough so the sauce made it soggy. San Tung, people. 

Spicy Wontons: I like the wontons here actually but it was just too overcooked. The skin was too soft and lost all of it's texture. It was mushy. The spicy sauce just wasn't that burst of flavor that went bam in my mouth. Z&Y Restaurant, people. 

Tip: If you don't want to wait in that ridiculously long Din Tai Fung line, come here for the XLB. If you don't want to wait for chicken wings at San Tung, this would be a nice alternative.
author: Jen P.

description:
This place is soo goooddd. People need to find out more about this place.

With my friends, we all ordered a Xiao Long Bao each. It's thin, juicy, and don't break easy. The place is a little bit far out, but definitely coming back coz it's also affordable. Woot.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Outstanding Fast neighborhood Chinese 
Everything is great
We tried several dishes all great
Don't expect to make it a long all night 
Dining experience 
It's fast
author: Kevin R.

description: My favorite XLB and dumpling restaurant in San Francisco! I really like their Xiao Long Baos (#1) on the menu. Their #2 with crab is really good too. Well everything here that I've gotten is good. I usually come here with a group and do family style meaning everything is shared like how you eat at home. They do have somewhat of a long line on the weekends so if you're planning on coming here over the weekend, I'd suggest coming early. They open at 10:30am and we got here at 10:40, found a parking spot right in front of the restaurant (score!), and got seated right away. There was only one table taken when we entered, but by 11:11 (make a wish), all tables were taken and lines started forming. When we left, there were maybe 10-15 people waiting outside. Parking here isn't too bad. It's mostly residential so you won't need to pay meter. We tried the crispy egg puffs with sugar at the very end for dessert and it's actually pretty good. Come here for their dumplings and end with the egg puffs! Can't go wrong.
author: Alvin Y.

description:
Went with a group of 4 on Sunday night and only waited 10 min to get seated. Parking was not that easy. What we ordered:
Soup dumplings: flavorful but not as juicy as other places
Pan fried buns: very good
Wonton in spicy sauce: very good
Eggplant: simple but one of the best I've had
Shanghai stir fried rice cakes: very good as always 
Overall this is a very reliable place for Shanghainese cuisine.
author: Lisa D.

description:
Very disappointed in
Lunch today.  Xao Lin bao thick and poorly made.  Little soup and tasteless pork meatballs.  Chicken wings ok, dry fried green beans excellent.  Wouldn't return.  Nothing photo's.
author: Carol F.

description:
We usually dine in but decided to order take out the other day.

Shanghai dumpling - super soggy and all clumped together. 
Beef Cilantro Soup - flavorful and good portion
Shanghai Chow Mein - A bit too oily and not flavored enough. 

I would definitely recommend dining in since it seems to taste better when it's freshly made.
author: Nancy T.

description: Dumplings were nice for breakfast though we felt that they could have been more fresh and tasty. They had fresh soya milk with was good!
author: Carolyn L.

description: This is my favorite place to have dumplings. The food is good and comforting . It's busy but quick. My kids love this place. Prices are reasonable.
author: Gina C.

description: Decent dumpling spot. I like the wontons in chili oil and the pork dumplings. Soup dumplings are good but don't hold a torch to Dumpling King. Satisfies my recurring dumpling cravings.
author: Ravi K.

description: The xiao long bao was pretty good and the right flavor. I had to ask for ginger to make the sauce right and then it was perfect. I would go back for just the xiao long bao.
author: Ellen L.

description:
Pretty good love them onion pancakes, superb 
Every thing is well made and makes me smile the service is ok not great but the exceptional food makes my review 4 stars
author: Jayden B.

description:
My friends and I were pretty excited to try out some xiao long bao in the city since we were all waiting for Din Tai Fung to open in Santa Clara. My xlb expectations are a little high since I have tried many xlbs and have ate at DTF in Hong Kong in the past. I can say this place is just really mediocre. 

Their XLBs are thin-skinned and freshly steamed, but the XLB lacked in soup and lacked in flavor. The skin was too soggy and the xlbs looked a little sad and droopy. No ginger is offered with your xlb vinegar sauce here either. We ordered both the regular xlb and the crab flavored xlb. The crab flavored xlb was lacking in crab flavor and all I really tasted was the little pieces of crab roe on the top and that was it. Definitely incomparable to the crab xlb from DTF as the soup there was a golden yellow. We tried their wontons in spicy sauce and it was not that good. The wontons themselves were fine, but where is the spicy mala peanut sauce that goes with them? We also ordered their braised pork belly and it was good. Very tender and fatty, a dish to go perfectly with some rice. 

Overall, I wouldn't say the xlbs were mind-blowing, but they do semi get the xlb cravings job done because there are not many other options in the bay area. DTF in Valley Fair, can you please open up faster? pretty please?
author: Hoyan L.

description:
I was ready to eat some delicious dumplings while in San Francsico on a gloomy, rainy day so I am happy to report this spot didn't disappoint.

I had seen a few things on Yelp I was sure I wanted to try and we opted for some options not pre-meditated. 

We ordered several items to share; green onion pancake, veggie pan fried dumpling, Shanghai-Style Stir-Fried Rice Cakes, Shanghai-Style Pan-Fried Pork Buns, wonton veggie soup, and egg puffs. 

Everything was delicious but I have to say the rice cake dish was outstanding!! Not at all what I expected; the rice cakes were flat thick noodles shortened to about 1.5" long. Slightly sticky, and a little gummy but in a good way and the Shanghai-style seasoning is delicious!! 

The Shanghai-style pork buns were equally delicious with a crunchy bottom and nice texture in the dumpling skin. I was happy to bring home leftovers for another round of deliciousness. 

I'll happily come back next time I am in the area and I look forward to trying more of the specials. 

It is a hopping place; they want you to eat and leave - visit and dilly-dally somewhere else because they will give you a couple minutes then start clearing it all away to give you the hint to move along. Even with that the food and price point makes it worth the trip. Clean, mostly friendly, delicious food. Can't go wrong.
author: Mandy L.

description:
Less than a month ago we were here, because my sister was on the quest for the perfect XLB, and luckily, this joint was in her neighborhood. Then again, this was the 3rd joint we'd been to that day/night!  They did have good ones.

We came back today for a late lunch/early dinner to try everything else. 

Steamed pork dumplings (10) = XLB. Piping hot, juicy and full of great flavor. $8.50 

Pan fried pork buns (10) = okay but I'm not a fan of the dough, as it should be different from the steamed ones. $8.50

Green onion pancake = slightly thin, imperfect and delicious. Hit the spot. $5.75

Steamed thread roll = man tou with condensed milk. It was good but not what I was expecting per the description. $3.75 

Pea sprouts house broth = great. Plenty of pea sprouts with mixed mushrooms and carrots. $15.75

Shredded pork with pickled mustard greens and peppers = tangy and plenty. Definitely want rice to go with this one. $10.00

Eggplant with garlic sauce = good but sweeter than expected, and not really spicy at all. $9.00

Wonton noodle soup = good wontons, spinach, decent noodles in a simple broth. (I added chili oil to my serving.) $8.50

Sticky rice roll = a very dry version of chi fan. Glutinous rice with doughnut, pork sung and preserved vegetables. But very dry. I'd skip this next time. $4.50

Steam rice = $1.75 x3

Portions = generous. 

Service = efficient. 

Prices = moderate. Meal for 4 came out to $86.45 with leftovers for another meal or two.
author: Fannie S.

description:
Fast service and a variety of dumplings. Wanted to satisfy my most recent craving so we ordered the soup dumplings, Shanghai style pan fried dumplings, and spicy wontons. 

Soup dumplings are yummy and very comforting. Ask for ginger if they forget! The pan fried dumplings are in a kinda fluffy bun and the meat is very tender. Spicy wontons aren't that spicy and the sauce is more peanuty than spicy oil but the wontons are big and they give you a lot! 

I was happily surprised by how full I was from sharing dumplings but definitely recommend going with a group to try more things.
author: Maryann S.

description:
This is my favorite Chinese/Taiwanese eatery in the Bay Area. It's starting to get more popular as the restless people waiting in line at Kingdom of Dumpling wander down the street to find Dumpling Kitchen and come back again and again as loyal patrons. 

Must order:
#1 Xiao Long Bao (XLB) - This dish really surprised me. I would compare it to the XLB you find at Ding Tai Fung, but sometimes you'll get a bad batch where the skin will break before you can slurp up all the yummy soup inside
#5 Shanghai pan fried pork buns - Soft, savory, and crispy in all the right places. I haven't found another restaurant in the Bay that makes these quite as good! 
#103 Braised pork belly with preserved veggies - The pork belly will melt in your mouth and the accompanying bok choy is so tender I promise myself I have to learn how they make this dish every time I eat here. Best served with a bowl of rice since the preserved veggies can be a bit salty on its own. 
#17 Sweet soy milk (warm) - Freshly made and comes at the perfect level of sweetness.  
#94 Shredded pork with string beans - Standard dish but great execution. Plus, you need a bit of green on the table! 

Tips: Good for large parties. Cash or Debit Card only. Avoid coming on weekends if you don't want to wait but the line tends to move pretty fast.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
***CASH OR DEBIT CARD ONLY***

We got here right when the place opened at 10:30am on a Sunday and was seated right away. However, by around 11am, the place was packed (the place itself is pretty small) and there was a line, so if you don't want to wait too long, I would suggest coming right when it opens.

We got 2 Shanghai-style steamed pork dumplings (10 pcs, #1 on the menu) for $8.95 each and black bean noodles for $8.95. I've never had Shanghainese food before so I have nothing to compare the food to, but the dumplings tasted great. I would highly recommend #1 on the menu to anyone. I've had black bean noodles before, but the ones from this restaurant tasted different (probably because Shanghainese). The taste wasn't what I was used to so I was thrown off by the taste at first, but it went well mixed with the spicy chili sauce. However, the black bean noodles by themselves without the spice tasted a bit odd for me.

Taking one star off because I didn't like the black bean noodles very much and I wouldn't necessarily come back here again unless I'm in the area. But the dumplings were great and the service was awesome!
author: Jen S.

description:
Hands down one of the best xiao long bao (shanghai soup dumplings) I have ever tried. I have tried almost all the dumplings they offer here and have not been disappointed. Also worth getting is the garlic string beans and salt/pepper fried fish loaded with garlic and chillies.

The food comes out fast, steaming hot, and delicious!

I always come back here every time I'm craving dumplings. Service is fast and efficient. I am a repeat customer for life.

Pro Tip: Avoid peak dinner hours (starts around 7pm) if you don't want to wait at least 30 min.
author: Jane C.

description: We wanted to try something different so we went here for the first time. I'm glad we did! Generous portions. There were 4 of us and we were all hungry so we ordered a lot. Tried the pork soup dumplings, the pork and crab dumplings, pork dumplings with chili oil, twice cooked pork with leeks, a tofu dish, and fried fish fillet. All were really good but the twice cooked pork with leeks was one of my favorites. I liked the pork soup dumplings too. They are a good size and have plenty of soup in them. We waited about 20 minutes for a table. Well worth it!
author: Ally W.

description:
I thought the soup dumplings were good but not great. There wasn't much soup in it and they gave me a metal spoon which quickly broke the skin.  I wish they would have told me how I was suppose to handle these delicate things.  Even the unbroken dumplings had very little soup.  The flavor was a bit on the bland side but they were big dumplings.

We had the pan fried dumplings which were good but again, nothing special.  The fried part was slightly crunchy but the meat inside was small and bland.  The dough was nothing special.  It was like a small bun. 

The egg puffs (5.50 for 3 puffs) were our favorite for lunch today.  Super custardy and eggy.  They were like amazing popovers but much more moist!  I would have loved having them with strawberry jam and clotted butter.  They were covered with loose sugar which was still amazingly delicious.  Prices are a bit steep.  Dumplings were 8.50 and lunch added up quickly to about 24 dollars but it's San Francisco so it's easily a pretty good deal considering this restaurant has a nice clean bathroom, clean dining area, and service was fast.  The outside is cute and the restaurant is actually much bigger than anticipated.  It's a very nice modern looking place though could definitely benefit from having some plants.  The food is authentic though and having authentic Asian food in a clean restaurant should really bring it up to 4 stars but I just felt underwhelmed by their dumplings which were supposed to be their best here.  Come try their egg puffs!  They are definitely the star here!
author: Lorissa W.

description:
Looking for fantastic dumplings and authentic Chinese food? You've found it! Everything here is handmade and so tasty. The Shanghai Chow Mein is one of my favorites. The noodles are homemade and wow does it make a difference! I came here searching for good dumplings and was not dissapointed! 

I recommend:
Pan fried potstickers
Pork buns
Crispy Egg Puffs
Any chow mein (the noodles are homemade!)
author: Katie C.

description:
We searched Yelp for a new dumpling place. I am a die hard Yank Sing loyalist but I wanted to try something CHEAPER but I wasn't willing to go completely rogue searching in the China town hole in the walls.  I did that in Seattle and my digestive system paid the price. 

Tried
Green Onion Cake - Great - Has a sort of cornmeal flower texture different than the lighter fluffier puff pasty green onion cake at Yank Sing

Shanghai Style  pan fried dumplings - These are listed on the menu as steamed you have to ask for them to be pan fried. Round balls of meat are traditional and tasty. The meet expectations for the price. I've had better

Garlic Green Beans- Excellent. Surpassed expectations. Fresh,  with the perfect crunch and wok style garlic carmelized and delicious. Surprising it was a last minute choice. I thought it was the best thing we ate

Wontons in Chili Oil - I've decided I'm not a big Won ton Fan.  I just don't like my Dumplings in broth. 

For the price we paid I only wish they had soup dumplings. They have been other standard menu items BESIDES dumplings that we didn't order. 

Casual, family style place located in the Parkside neighborhood. I think its accessible by Muni train.   Its away from the tourists. the entire staff was talking their late lunch break and dining on their own food in the restaurant.
author: Vanessa R.

description: Great dumplings!! Delicious! If you're looking for dumplings this is the place to go!
author: MariTess C.

description:
I was really excited to try their Shanghai Style Pan Fried Pork Buns & Xiao Long Bao, however, my friends and I were pretty disappointed afterwards.

Here are some items we ordered:
--Preserved eggs w/ tofu (3/5): they just dumped a whole box of silk tofu onto the plate and cut one small preserved eggs. The whole dish was completely different from what I expected. It was bland, dry, and full of tofu. The ratio was so off. Definitely would not recommend to order.
--Beef Noodle Soup (4/5): The beef was cooked really well--tender, flavorful and juicy. However, the noodle & the soup part were too bland. I personally like House of Pancake's beef noodle soup more. 
--Shanghai Style Pan Fried Pork Buns (3.5/5): they did not fully pan fried the pork buns at first since the bottom did not that brown layer and it was not crunchy at all. So, we had to ask them to take the buns back to the kitchen and refried again. The refried buns looked great and they were not bad. Wish the pork could be a bit juicier.
--Xiao Long Bao (4/5): they were not bad but not amazing. The dough part was a bit too thick.
--Shanghai Rice cakes (3/5): this dish was way too bland. I could barely taste any pickles in the dish and the rice cakes were cooked for too long. When we were eating them, the rice cakes just stuck on our teeth.

Probably will not visit again. There are definitely much better Chinese restaurants near inner richmond/sunset/outer richmond if you are craving for dumplings, potstickers and noodle soup.
author: Clare L.

description:
All I can say is wow, mouthwatering soup filled shanghai style dumplings.  This place is the best place I've tried as far as dumplings go,  I don't really get anything else but dumplings when I come here and it hasn't failed.  The only thing I was slightly disappointed at was at the fact that there was no ginger to go with my dumplings :/,  even without the ginger they're still a 5 in my book. 

Btw up the street there's dumpling kingdom which is also amazing, I don't know how they managed to put 2 great dumpling places right next to each other, easily the 2 best spots in sf for Shanghai style dumplings.

Dumpling kitchen however it's much bigger and its a nicer setting, while kingdom it's more of a hole in the wall.  This place is a must for your sf bucket list.

I will be back and then back again :)
author: Josh Giosue D.

description:
Solid place to get dumplings if you're in the city. I've been looking for a good places for years and no one seems to know any besides this one. 

The place could use some touching up, but it's SF, so... can't really expect too much. 

The XLBs were tender and the skin wasn't too thick. Overall really good, but still can't compare it to something like din tai fung. 

If you want other dishes, this place definitely has lots of options and all are pretty decent.
author: Scott K.

description: Good and relatively inexpensive Shanghai style food. This place amazingly good, food is packed with flavor and just the right texture. Would go there again.
author: Zoe B.

description: First time coming here after searching on Yelp, I like it except trying to find parking was not easy at all.  Just a little neglected with the customer service when waiting to be seated; otherwise, the rest was fine.  My pan fried bao was good but my Mongolian beef was a little too sweet.  Good place to dine in for lunch!
author: M P.

description:
Dear lord, this place was delicious! 

I was craving dumplings and found it on yelp. We ordered the pork dumplings and pork pot stickers. They were very flavorful and the meat was perfectly seasoned. We also got the spicy mabo tofu which was good. 

I'd recommend getting your food to go as the inside of the restaurant isn't anything special, with strong fluorescent lighting and lack of ambiance.
author: Christine M.

description: Really good Chinese food with wonderful service.  Very good spinach dish and Benghai noodles.
author: Thomas P. L.

description:
YOOOO this place surprised me with how good it is. Definitely the best Xiao Long Bao I've had in SF. Really enjoyed the texture of the skin and it was filled with flavorful soup and tasty pork. I like how it was so easy to pick up with chopsticks (y'know that feels bad moment when it just tears apart and the soup start leaking out like your tears of a good dumpling gone to waste). 

Also got the green onion pancake, pan fried pork buns, and wonton in chili oil. 

Green Onion Pancake (3/5)
-Different than any pancake I've ever had, was very light and crispy. Personal preference though I prefer my pancakes more dense but it was still good, just was not a standout.

Pan Fried Pork Buns (3/5)
-Had a higher expectation for this dish, but the filling was 70% meat & 30% awkward hollowness, making the juices of the meat inside make the bun inside moist which I was not a fan of. The only pan fry or dry doughiness I craved from this dish was the pan fried bottom of the bun.

Wonton in Chili Oil (2.5/5)
It was meh. Skin was a bit thicker than I would have liked and the filling did not interest me as much. The chili sauce has a bit of a sweet peanutty taste. Friend said Din Tai Fung's wonton is better if you would like a comparison.

Would come back for the XLB and to try other dishes they have on the menu though! Left feeling really satisfied. If you're looking for a nice Chinese comfort food joint, this is the place for you.
author: Katie G.

description: Super tasty dumplings and the chow main is pretty yummy too. My sister took me here for the first time about 3 months ago and ever since that's one of my go to spots for Chinese food. On the weekends it definitely gets busy so either get there early or plan to wait.
author: Stephanie D.

description:
Just eh. I've definitely had better dumplings.

My friend came back to the city and wanted to eat Asian food. I've always wanted to try this place, so we ended up coming here for dinner at 7:30PM.

Wait was around 5-10 minutes on a Friday, wasn't too bad. 

Ambiance was just a typical Chinese restaurant, althought it was awfully small for what it was. Kinda seemed like they converted the room from a living room lol. Three of us were cramped into a small table in the corner. 

We ordered 2 XLB, one pork and chive dumplings, green onion pancake, and bok choy. 

The green onion pancake was just "OK". It was kind of soggy and not crunchy. I was disappointed that there was no sauce that came with it. The bok choy was pretty good though! I could really taste the smoky wok flavor inside the bok choy, but it was very greasy. I was extremely disappointed in the XLBs. First of all, the top of the XLBs were very doughy, almost as though they didn't cook fully. Second of all, they were not as juicy as I hoped it would be. The dough surrounding the XLB was also pretty thick, so it ruined the experience for me. Lastly, these XLBs were very small... The only good part of it was the meat that was inside. The Pork and Chive dumplings were pretty good. The meat inside was flavorful and seasoned well. 

They specialize in dumplings, so I would just stick with those the next time I come here. All in all, I would avoid the XLBs and everything else.
author: Harmony C.

description: HILARIOUSLY terrible, both varieties of XLB had no soup in them, the regular one was hard as a rock, while the "lobster and roe" one had the shittiest of tobiko pathetically spooned on top, with the exact same meat as the regular one, except with the worst texture. The dry cured ham fried rice tasted as if someone used acid to wash the ham, then just plunked it into a vat of salt, how the hell can you call yourself a chef if you don't even know how to make the most basic of chinese salt-cured staples? The fried noodles were almost borderline edible, if that can be considered a compliment, in a sort of panda-express esque sort of way, I have no idea how people can stomach this absolute garbage.
author: Raymond W.

description: This is a solid place to eat at. Their Shanghai-Style Steamed Pork Dumplings are my second favorite in the city (first being Yank Sing). Their Wontons in Chili Oil are to die for. I'm a fan of their Spring Rolls but not of their Green Onion Pancake.
author: C L.

description:
So good! Almost all of the dishes we've ordered are loved.
You gotta try Chinese type of brunch here with soymilk and rice balls.
author: Rachel L.

description:
One of my friends recommended Dumpling Kitchen, and I'm always looking for a place to satisfy my craving for those wrapped bundles of greatness.  We ended up visiting on a Friday night, and I was dreading a long wait in the fog.

Well, it turned out not to be foggy at all, and we got seated in under 5 minutes (it probably helped that we went around 30 minutes before closing).  We ended up trying a selection of different pork dumplings (including the xiao long bao), steamed vegetarian dumplings, a green onion pancake, and the dry-braised string beans.  I thought all of the dumplings were excellent, and the string beans were flavorful without being overly salty.  The only item that was somewhat of a miss was the green onion pancake; I thought it was too dry, but it was not a complete failure.   

The service was expedient and friendly, and the size of the restaurant is accommodating for large parties.  I'm definitely going back!
author: Keith H.

description:
My favorite soup dumpling in the city. If I'm craving soup dumpling, I'm coming here. Dragging my friends with me and they love it as well. Coming with my group of friends, we order 6-8 orders. YUM! Many places in the city have gone down hill. Either they always over cook it which means no soup or the skin of the dumpling is too thick. But dumpling kitchen is on point. The soup is sweet and the skin is thin. Perfect!

I also love their string beans but their shanghai noodles is not my favorite. Better else where but you got to order it if your eating soup dumplings. Their spicy wonton isnt good. maybe because of the peanut sauce. The pan fried buns are good but I can only eat one. Even tho its small its very filling. Also really like their clay rice is good. I love it because the flavor of the meat makes the rice so flavorful. 

Also they always serve with free peanuts!
author: Sandy B.

description:
I was impressed with many things but hoping a three star review will give them incentive to make improvements. Biggest fault was the inconsistent wait time for food from table to table. It seemed as though they had forgotten about us in the corner, but we had a span for about 20min where there was nothing on our table after our first serving of dumplings. The waiter(s) were incredibly friendly and you could tell they were very busy and doing their best...but seeing other tables that ordered after you get their food first is a bit of an annoyance. 

Ambience: 3 stars A nice relax environment with a projection screen going on on the main wall with music videos. Great place to have a small group of friends and not have to worry about getting too loud. 

Wait-time: 2-stars. An awfully long wait during dinner hours, but they are consistently getting people in and out the restaurant. Also, a nice big wait area outside with seating which is nice. 

Food: 3.5 star. They have a really good range of dumping and bun choices. A solid grasp of each dumpling / buns' own identity, but some menu items seem to be a bit over-priced. Not the best dumplings I've had in the Bay Area, but still above average.
author: Christy C.

description: Loved the veggie dumplings and veggie mushu. HUGE quantities. LOVE IT!
author: Anna B.

description:
Started with a warm glass of sweetened soy milk.  This simple drink makes me feel cozy and special.

The xlb here have a sweet, savory pork flavor.  The light broth shimmers with tiny drops of rich pork fat, and the meat is light and tender.  I'm used to the pink ginger vinegar sauce for dipping.  Here they serve a soy and vinegar sauce.  Not as pretty - or tasty.

The wontons in spicy sauce have that bitter heat that catches up, in a nice way.  They're filled with a meatball of pork, chive, egg and spinach.  The sauce is more heat than peanuty, and the filling too bland for my taste.  I prefer the ones at Dumpling Kingdom.

A tip I learned from another Yelper:  to eat the xlb, use a spoon, cut a hole in the dumplings so the soup runs into the spoon.  Slurp the soup and dip the dumpling into the dipping sauce.
author: Sondra H.

description: Seriously worth the 20 min wait. The group l went with liked - vegetable potstickers, green onion pancake and dried wings. I personally loved their fried rice too! The host was very patient with our multiple requests for chicken options and random stuff. Must try place
author: Neha L.

description: Best place ever I come here weekly !! If you want amazing dumplings come here ! And order the Shanghai noodles they are the best
author: Kloe K.

description:
Recently went back after my first time a few months ago. Looking forward to my third trip.
 
- XLBs: yum (try to be patient and let it cool down before stuffing the whole thing in your mouth), could easily polish off an order (10) by myself except there are so many other dumplings to try
- Wontons in chili oil: good meat to wonton skin ratio, the chili oil is not that spicy
- Wontons in vegetable soup: tasted fresh, broth wasn't too salty, came with some spinach for those who want some veg in their life
- Chive and pork dumplings: solid, tastes fresh and clean since they're boiled, good with some vinegar or chili paste
- Noodle in peanut sauce: interesting to try and tasted fine but would not get again
- Dry-fried chicken wings: delicious the first time, sauce was watery and the flavor wasn't as great the second time (maybe our fault for showing up so close to closing time)
- Pea sprouts: nothing special, tastes like what you get at other Chinese restaurants
- Wait time: long wait during peak hours, go later if possible
- Parking: can be difficult since the area is mostly residential
author: Venna L.

description:
Some people like to wait hours for a certain super hyped up Shanghai dumpling place. Don't get me wrong, that certain place's food is quite charming, it's just that it's a tad hyped ;) But sometimes the hole in the walls are the places to hit. Dumpling Kitchen is one of those good hole in the walls.

I've been here 2 times already in the span of 2 months. And 6 times since it opened. This place is extremely solid. True, it's doesn't have the modern interior design appeal of some places, but who cares when you get good food?

On this particular occasion, I brought 2 friends to try this place for lunch. We ordered the following:

SHANGHAI-STYLE STEAMED PORK DUMPLINGS ($8.50): You get 10 pieces of scrumdiddlyumptious Shanghai Dumpling or Xiao Long Bao. Each one is a soup wrapped bundle of joy. Each dumpling has delicious pork and chives filled with soup. The skin is not too thin, and not too thick. They are pretty sizable compared to other places.  DIRECTIONS: The way to eat these involves (1) plucking one out with your chopstick (2) placing it on your soup spoon (3) placing vinegar and chopped ginger on top (you gotta ask for some) (4) taking small bites while sipping the soup. Now you can eat Shanghai Dumplings like a PRO! Don't be an amateur and plop the whole thing in your mouth; you'll only burn your tongue have have all your friends laugh at you. This is a must have if you come here!

SHANGHAI-STYLE PAN-FRIED PORK BUNS ($8.50): This is by far one of my most favorite of all Shanghai-inspired dishes and this place really delivered. They put a good amount of meat and chives into a bun that is perfectly sized for your mouth. It's a perfect combination of opposites: (1) the top of the bun is super soft and the bottom is nice and crispy, but not burnt (2) the super juicy center is complemented with the soft and absorbent texture of the bun. Best of all, it came out nice and piping hot! Writing this review right now makes my mouth water at the thought! This is another must have!

DRY-FRIED CHICKEN WINGS ($10.00): Not the best thing on the menu, but it sure looked good on our neighboring table's wait. The chicken was prepared OK, but the sauce had a bit too much star anise for my taste and the chicken wing could have been a bit crunchier. You can safely pass on this if you come, but it doesn't hurt to try.

-SCORE BREAKDOWN--

SERVICE: 4 stars--they were solid; not bad and not amazing.
AMBIANCE: 3 stars--nothing special but hey, it's cleaner than your typical Chinese restaurant.
FOOD: 4.5 stars--one of the best pan-fried pork bun places that I've been to and a very solid Shanghai Dumpling.
PRICE: 4.5 stars--it's a suitable price for an excellent meal.
TOTAL: 4 stars for an excellent meal.

Bottom Line: Want a good meal to fill your hungry belly? Better yet, want a great place to try Shanghai Dumplings and pan-fried pork buns at an extremely reasonable price? This place will not disappoint. I'm coming here for the foreseeable future!
author: Andrew C.

description:
EDIT (5/18/16): Begoni Bistro in Chinatown is xiao long bao king.

I want to fill my kitchen with these dumplings. Dozens and dozens of dumplings.

To paint the background, I've only consumed soup dumplings (xiao long bao, XLB, whatever you wanna call 'em) in limited contexts: Shanghai Dumpling King in SF, Din Tai Fung in LA and Taiwan, and random restaurants in East Bay (anyone from Fremont remember San Liu Jiu in that Warm Springs plaza near the freeway intersection? haha) and China.

Dumpling Kitchen's xiao long bao remind me of those at San Liu Jiu. My family frequented that restaurant fairly often, and little bitty me didn't know much more about xiao long bao aside from the metal steamers we would order from that restaurant. So, if my parents approved of those, they would definitely approve of these.

#1: $8.25 for a steamer full of 10 Shanghai-style steamed pork dumplings, each one consistently full of soup at the right temperature with dumpling skins not too dry and pork fillings salted just right. The wrappers are thicker than those at Din Tai Fung, the xiao long bao champion, but Dumpling Kitchen makes for a pretty good substitute. And, yes, these are WAY better than Shanghai Dumpling King. Hands down don't even question. However, I have yet to compare it to Kingdom of Dumpling.

We also ordered #5: $8.25 for 10 Shanghai-style pan-fried pork buns, also called sheng jian bao, which are heavier than xiao long bao due to being fried rather than steamed, as well as the thicker breading. The buns here outshine those at Shanghai Dumpling King by nature of less breading and a nicely fried bottom--thick breading at the bottom makes for a nice crispy layer that can soak up the juices, but too much breading all around makes the buns way too dense (so many inappropriate jokes to be made, not enough time). If only these buns had soup for those bottoms to absorb! Needs more juice, sigh.

Fam fav for sheng jian bao in Shanghai? Xiao Yang Sheng Jian, or Yang's Friend Dumplings. You're welcome.

Per Yelper recs, we also got #103: $10.25 braised pork belly with preserved vegetables. Huge portion, absolutely delicious. Get this. GET THIS. And thanks Yelp :)

$1.25 or $1.50 for a small bowl of white rice.

Closed Wednesdays.

Until Din Tai Fung opens up at Westfield Valley Fair, I will take my parents to Dumpling Kitchen.
author: Adele F.

description:
We ordered five dishes for three people. 
Overall, the food was great. My favorite would be the XLB. The dumpling wrap was thin, but thick enough to serve.  

1-twice cooked pork belly ~ 3 star.. Too greasy for me 
2- walnut shrimp ~ 4 star.. Yummy 
3- Shanghai fried noodles ~ 3 star.. It's just okay. Not outstanding 
4- XLB ~ 4.5 star.. Yummy 
5- egg puffs ~ 2.5 star.. Not my favorite
author: Rachael C.

description: The service here is terrible. The waiters are extremely rude and don't give a crap about you. The atmosphere feels old and dirty, I think they should remodel! The food on the other hand is pretty good especially the soup dumplings. The fried noodles and rice are really oily and greasy. I would not come back because of the service and atmosphere.
author: Carissa C.

description: Not the best dumpling place in SF but if you don't want to venture out to Richmond district to Shanghai Dumpling King, it's not too bad.  Don't forget to order the wontons in chili oil - they're not too shabby.
author: Lilan D.

description: FANTASTIC soup and regular dumplings (big size meat inside too). Great portions too. Really hits the spot. Skip the Kingdom of Dumplings and pay the $1 more. Worth it. Will definitely be back.
author: Jenny Y.

description:
Stopped here before leaving back out of town and put our names on the list and waited like everyone else. He came out and asked who were the names on the list, basically looking who each person was, then told us we were next. But... He calls two other people before us although they were clearly AFTER us and same party size. Even one of another party felt bad for us since it really felt he was picking based on other factors. 

We finally get called and he sat us in the most cramped tight seats in the restaurant. Basically gave us the seats slightly above sitting on the toilet and clearly the worse seats in the house. Thought the food was decent, not the best dim sum but good. We got XLBs, braised pork, dry chicken (which isn't dry), potstickers, pan fried buns and crab and pork dim sum. As if we needed more incentive not to come back we found a long black hair in the food. We tried to make the best out of the visit and struck up a conversation with the guests next to us and tried all the foods we could. 

Overall would we come back.. Not likely. We REALLY wanted to love this place but left extremely disappointed. Treat ALL CUSTOMERS the same since we dropped $90 there and still tipped although being slighted and they never wanted to check in on us although checking on everyone else. Plus hair in the food which was obvious and they get their wish. Never been more offended at ANY asian restaurant like here.
author: Mike D.

description:
We got lucky and was seated immediately on a Friday night!

I did a lot of research for Shanghai soup dumplings. But I was won over by Dumpling Kitchen's Shanghai Style Fried Pork Buns!!! The portion was large but still close to the size of a dumpling. I loved the crunchy bottom and the warm fluffy bun with a hefty amount of meat inside! It came right out of the oven and still steaming! It was super super delicious!!!

The green onion pancake could've been avoided. I enjoyed the light texture of it but it was lacking a crunch. Also, there were barely any green onions! It didn't taste like it either, boo.

And for the main course, the soup dumplings! They came out in a rack of ten and I was glad that I didn't order two rounds. The texture of the the skin was mildly soft and thick. The juicy meat oozed with the flavorful soup coming from within! We jumped right on it right as it came to our table and it actually wasn't piercing hot! It was easy to chow down in just one bite. 

I'm very satisfied with our meal! It was delicious and cheap! I would say this was one of the best I've ever had!
author: Linda K.

description:
Been here a couple times; food is delicious but service isn't so good. I'd rate this place 5/5 if their service kept up with the good food. The workers seemed like they didn't want to be there... female worker sitting on the round table with her shoes off when customers were present... male worker always on his phone and walks/does work slower than my grandmother lol. 

Despite that, I would still come back to this place for their good food. The shanghai dumplings are my number one favorite, walnut prawns, noodle soup, and chicken wings are also delicious.
author: Kelly Z.

description:
My parents have been asking to go to dim sum for a whiille but there are very few good, cheap, and vegetarian-friendly places in the South Bay. So we drove up to SF to spend a delightful Sunday and came here. 

Parking -  street parking, you'll probably have to do a couple rounds. 

Wait - on a Sunday at 7:30pm, we waited max 15min for a party of 3 

Service - typical place where there's 0 interaction from the servers. They will give you your water, do their job, but nothing else. That's fine with me.

Food - Really good!! We got the hot and sour soup ($9) - same as any other place. Big bowl enough for a group, scallion pancakes ($5) - little different than I'm normally used to, and didn't love this style. Veg potstickers ($9) - my favorite!, veg steamed dumplings ($9), and spicy pepper tofu ($9) - wasn't spicy but good. The only thing that was missing was the good dumpling sauce they only had usual chili oil and soy sauce.
