Prices - As mentioned above, everything is under $10. For us 3, the total bill post tip was about $50 which is pretty reasonable since we were stuffed and 90% of the tofu entree was taken home. Of course there are much cheaper dim sum places though.
author: Aria S.

description:
This restaurant is near residential area, so it is relatively easy to find parking. We came as a group of 6, so we got a round table by the back corner after 15 mins wait, not too bad. 

We came for lunch and ordered many dishes to share, I would recommend soup dumpling/ xiao lung bao (their signature dumplings) as well as the braised pork belly. The dumplings of course is no match for Din Tai Fung, but it is not bad for a local Chinese restaurant. The skin of the dumpling could be thinner and the meat inside is a little greasy, but there's a good amount of broth. The dumpling is definitely good quality at its price range. 

I was really surprised by the braised pork belly. It was SO delicious! It was a big portion with some veggies on the side. The layer of fat is not too thick, so I don't feel too guilty eating the skin plus that layer of fat. The entire pork belly is well seasoned, not too salty, and it was so tender! Pork gets tough and chewy easily but this pork belly is so soft, and it does not take any effort to chew it. 

Service is ok, typical family style Chinese restaurant. Price is reasonable. I would definitely come back for the soup dumpling and pork belly!
author: Karen C.

description:
This is good food and service at a very reasonable price. 

At $8.50 10 pieces of Shanghai-style Steamed Pork Dumplings come out perfectly so they don't break when picked up spilling their soup contents. 

At $11.50 8 pieces of the Crab and Pork Steamed Dumplings are also delicious.

At $8.50 8 Pan-fried Pork Buns are also good when they are not burned, don't be ashamed to send them back; they will come out just right the second time around.

At $9.50 I liked the Dry-braised String Beans with chunks of fresh garlic and at $8.50 the Pork Dumpling in Chili Oil is another favorite.

I would skip the $8.75 Noodle in Peanut Sauce. It looked and tasted like a bowl of noodles drowning in peanut flavored oil. May be its just me, I thought it was awful.
author: Caesar A.

description: I love XLB and when my friend told me to check this place out on yelp I couldn't wait to go try it after seeing all the yummy photos. We ordered the XLB and an order of the pan fried pork buns. The XLB was so flavorful, came with 10 pieces. My favorite was actually the pan fried pork buns, it was pan fried perfection on the bottom! I would return and 100% recommend this place to any dumpling lover. Can't wait to return! -- they only take cash or debit card.
author: Sherry F.

description:
It was very delicious. I ordered pork dumplings and crab and pork steamed dumplings and beer. I recommend shanghai style steamed pork dumplings. 
Beer and dumplings are very nice combination. I'll be back soon.
author: Nishigami T.

description:
Really enjoyed this quaint little place! 5 stars for their dumpling selection but there other menu items aren't as specialty and well thought out. 

Come to this place to get dumplings!
author: Ian L.

description: I love eating here with my family! We have nice family meals here and the food is wonderful. The parking is okay, it depends on what time u go. The lobster noodle is my favorite.
author: Juno C.

description: Such a delicious lunch today at very reasonable prices!  We were greeted immediately and sat down with a pot of hot tea.  Because we were at Dumpling Kitchen, we thought we had to try the variations of Dumpling!  We tried the pot stickers, pork buns and won ton soup.  All were delicious. More than enough food for three people.  Definitely will be going back when we are in the area!
author: Sarah R.

description: Love their hand made dumplings, if you ask for something mashed ginger into the vinegar for dipping. OMG !
author: Joyce Y.

description:
Came here for lunch with my parents, uncles, and aunt.  It looks like a real hole-in-the-wall dumpling place on Taraval St near a residential area, but inside is pretty brightly lit and clean.

They specialize in Shanghainese dumplings - my uncle ordered for the entire table.  Overall I think the food is 3.5 stars, so rounding up to four for attentive service.  Dishes I tried were pretty good!

Lion Head soup: This is a large bowl that has a gigantic, soft meatball submerged in broth, rice noodles, and shredded cabbage.  The meatball was cooked through, with slightly pink center.  Incredibly soft and juicy - you don't have to chew much.

Green Beans: Crunchy and good, nuff said.

Xiao Long Bao: Pretty good sized and juicy, but lacking sufficient broth inside.

Dan Dan Mian: Sauce was spicy and good, but I think there was too much of it compared to noodles.  Noodles on the soft side - I prefer some chew.

Chow Lien Go: Similar to chow fun, but with far less oil and interesting, firmer and chewier noodle pieces - shaped like little paddles.

Chinese Donut: Similar to a Beignet - I really liked the eggy interior, but the skin was softer and could have used some more crispiness. Koi Palace in Dublin has a pretty good version.

Pan Fried XLB?: Not sure what these are called, but they were decent - like a round pork potsticker.

I would consider coming back to try their other offerings, since they have a good sized menu.  Parking on the street is a bit tricky - they have meters nearby.
author: Daniel C.

description: This place is cheap which is wayyyyyy more than you can say about ANY dim sum place. It's no Din Tau Fung or Yank Sing, but Din Tau Fung's prices aren't Dumpling Kitchens. While the food is average, it's a great place to go if you need a dim sum fix without playing the exorbitant prices normally affixed to it. I had dinner with two for $18, while normally I'm used to paying $50 for a two person dim sum meal. And on a group outing we paid $40 TOTAL for 8 people! And we still had leftovers.
author: Jack M.

description:
Pretty good XLB, steamed dumplings, and the like.  Although these were not the best XLB that I've had, they were pretty good for what I can get in the States.  The skin is a bit thicker than Din Tai Fung and had more of a homemade dumpling skin kind of flavor and chewiness.  But, the flavor of the soup inside it was definitely set it apart from other XLB's that I've had in the US.  The soup inside is a little more greasy than what you might get from Din Tai Fung, but was rich with flavor.  Wish they had the thinly sliced ginger though to accompany it!

We also ordered the steamed vegetarian dumplings, which I enjoyed, and the pan-fried steamed pork buns (the dough is slightly sweet which makes it the perfect bao--these are pretty filling though!).  As some others have mentioned, the chili wontons were not the best (although they were alright and are always a favorite order of mine).  We also ordered the snow pea leaves (yum!) and shanghai-style stir-fried rice cakes.

Service was not spectacular--but what do you expect?  Their English is good though so it's easy to order even if you don't speak Chinese.  Wait was about 30 minutes on a Friday night around 6:30 PM.  There is no space to wait inside though, so make sure you dress warmly!
author: Jess Y.

description:
Classic San Francisco XLB restaurant, with the long lines to prove it. Consistently delicious food for when nothing but XLB will do.

FOOD: NOMZ. Skip the standard American-Chinese fare here and go for the gold with the authentic stuff. Obviously the xiaolong bao are a must; I prefer the pork to the crab, which have a fishy taste. The Shanghai Sheng Jian Bao (pan fried buns) are also delicious and make *delicious leftovers*. The Shanghai stir fried rice cakes are also very tasty, and the garlic eggplant is *amazing* - NOT overly oily or sweet like other places. Finally another MUST is the braised pork belly with preserved vegetables - definitely make sure you have some steamed white rice to soak up the sauce/melted fat. The green onion pancake is tasty but seems to be made of a batter rather than a dough - not my personal preference. They also have tons of noodle soups - definitely want to try these in the future.

AMBIENCE: A little cramped, loud, and bright. This is not the place for a romantic candlelit first date. But definitely a good spot to go with family and friends for a casual but delicious meal.

SERVICE: Get here early or be prepared to wait! There are a handful of large round tables, and the rest are 4-person or 2-person tables. I believe they take reservations for larger parties, so definitely try calling ahead. Otherwise, the wait can be anywhere from 15-45 minutes depending on the time/day. Servers are generally pretty quick, leading to pretty quick turnover which is great when you're 5 parties deep in the line. However, we sometimes have to flag someone down for more water, rice, etc.
author: J L.

description:
Amazing !!! I will go back again.. 
Good price!!
The chicken wings were amazing.
The place is small but cozy.
author: Maritza P.

description: Recommended this place !!! The best dumplings which I've tried. A big variety of tasted food. Sometimes it can be crowded on weekends. Nice staff. I'll be back for sure.
author: Dinny S.

description:
I came to visit after finding several grate reviews from fellow Elite yelpers and boy was it worth it! This was pretty much across town from where I was staying, but if you are wanting some great XLB, dooo it! It won't go to waste! 

It's a small little place, but if you get in at a right time, you won't find yourself waiting long. My husband and I came in around 12:30 on a Sunday with no line, but left with a few patrons waiting to get in.

Between the two of us we ordered Rice Cakes, Pork XLB and Crab/Pork XLB, also a wonton soup. For some reason my husband felt liking getting it. Folks.. its not worth getting. I felt it was a bit bland. But everything else, please do get!

I believe there were two types of rices cakes. Do get the one with shredded pork with preserved veggies, I think its most favorable over the other. At least in my eyes =) You can't go wrong with either XLB. Both were yummy. So glad we were able to get in before they went on vacation!
author: Kathy D.

description:
We visited on a Saturday afternoon around 8PM, and we got seated almost immediately. I think we arrived right after the dinner rush. The wait staff was friendly and courteous - always a plus at any Chinese restaurant. 

The XLB were well wrapped in smooth skin. The soup was fatty and steaming hot, just like what XLB should be. Definitely one of the better XLB out there. 

The Shanghai styled pan fried buns were well fried. Crispy bottom and fluffy everything else. The meat filling was well seasoned, although a little on the bland side for me. 

We also had dry fried chicken, which were basically orange/general chicken. I wasn't particularly impressed or disappointed, but I think the wings would probably have been a better choice. 

Three dishes were plenty for two, and we had to take most of the chicken to go.
author: Quyen T.

description:
I came here because I love dumplings so I'm always craving for some good xiao long baos. We ordered Shanghai-style pan-fried pork buns, Won Tons in Chili Oil, XLB.

The Shanghai-style pan-fried pork buns honestly was extremely delicious and it was the best dish that I got. It's crispy on the bottom and on the inside is soft and flavorful. I got best of both worlds and I really think that the crispiness on the bottom made it 10x better. I would recommend getting this.
I don't think you can ever go wrong with XLB. The soup and the meat on the inside were really flavorful. 
I think the Won ton's in chili oil could have been better though, it was delicious but maybe if it was a little spicier it would have gave it more of a kick.

If you're looking for somewhere to eat that's affordable and filling I would recommend coming here. I came here on a weekday around 5-6 so there was so wait! :)
author: Sherry L.

description: Very good Chinese food, but unfortunately my kids didn't like it. Picky eaters. But the staff was very helpful as I ordered a million dishes.
author: Jordan K.

description: Decent food, good prices.  They kind of want customer's out asap though.  4 stars for their dumplings -1 for customer service!
author: Linh L.

description:
Giving the benefit of doubt that the bug was a one time accident; I came back to this place, & came back many times due to its 92/100 sanitary rating.

Their Food is also good if you know what to order.  Ya can't go wrong with #1, 2, 3 on the menu.  That is my staple here.  Their xlb dumplings are perfectly juicy and the skin is thin.  The soup is intact in almost every piece.  Their meatball dish also taste excellent. 

However...I'm disappointed to say I found a piece of hair in that meatball today.  How about hairnets in the kitchen?  After that, our minds just went to all these wild thoughts of where their hands went before making these meatballs rolling it in along with their body hair. So yeah, major turn off for our appetites.  Suddenly everything felt gross.

Rolling right along, Dishes I didn't like includes any noodles here that are all oily IMHO.  Their rice is cooked too raw (usually still taste like hard grain).  Their potted rice is also a bad choice, because it is a combination of the same overcharged bland rice with meat thrown in a pot and cooked till it's slightly crusty.

All in all with the good and the bad.  I once again recover them with this 3 star.
author: Juila L.

description: I absolutely love the xiaolongbao and dumplings here Ive come here twice in the last week because I was getting cravings for them and the bill came out to be pretty cheap for me and my friend and we were extremely satisfied with our food :)!
author: Wren X.

description: Love this place.  Food is always delicious.  They make the best shrimp chow mein I have ever had!  Other favorites include dry fried fish fillets, Shanghai pan fried dumplings and dry braised green beans.
author: Kim T.

description: The wontons in chili oil is going to be my downfall! This dish has quickly become one of my top favorite things ever, not good for my diet, but so delicious!!!
author: Brando W.

description: My first time I stuck to what I read in reviews, wontons in chili oil and sweet and sour soup.  Very authentic. When I go back the only thing I would change would be to get dumplings instead of Wontons.  The wontons were a bit to dough-ee but the severing portions are big. Free jasmine tea and very attentive service. Do your research before eating here as to what is good , the menu is big and not very descriptive.
author: j. g.

description:
Very good dumpling place. 
Shanghai dumplings were prob our favorite. 
Second is the pan fried Shanghai dumplings. 
Third, stir fried green beans. 
Wanton soup was also good. 
Don't know why the green onion pancake is so popular... I thought it was kind of dry. 
Overall, very good little restaurant.
I would definitely come back!!
author: Harry P.

description:
I've been waiting to check this place out as it was a popular place among my yelp friends. We arrived after 7pm and had about a 20 minute wait. There's not much of a waiting area inside so you're better off waiting outside unless it's cold.

Once we were seated, we ordered the fresh soy milk, green onion pancakes, pork XLB, pan fried pork buns, pork belly, and the crispy egg puffs for dessert. These were all recommended by yelpers and they were pretty spot on. I especially enjoyed the pan fried pork buns. I was afraid 10 pieces were going to be too much for our part of three but they were small. The outside was much thinner than most places which I preferred. The XLB were pretty decent but I still wished there was even more soup inside. The green onion pancakes were different than others because it was fluffier but still good.

Overall, this is a place to check out if you're in the area. Good good, affordable prices.
author: Steph F.

description: Standard XLBs and dumplings. Come here for a cheap and filling meal. I tried the XLB and the crab/pork dumplings along with the Dan Dan noodles. The Dan Dan noodles(peanut butter noodles) were watery/ more runnier than I am used to but still tasted fine. Good service and spacious, however I will stick to the dumpling place closer to my house.
author: Corinna T.

description:
We ordered the XLB (#1 on the first page of the menu), #22 (the crispy egg puffs), and #48 (the rice cake with pork and vegetables). We went around 5PM on a Sunday, and there was no line. 

The XLB is really excellent. Some places make it too meaty, i.e., they stuff it with too much pork. But not this place. They make the XLB with the right mix of dumpling skin/dough and meat. This place does not provide the premixed vinegar with ginger (I think Ding Tai Fung does). Nevertheless, the XLB is one of the best the best ones I've had in SF. $8+ for an order of 10.  

The crispy egg puffs were good, but nothing to write home about. 

The rice came with pork and vegetables - that's very mediocre. I would say there are probably way better dishes on the menu. This dish comes with very little pork. The rice cakes don't taste as bland because they use garlic, so that gives it a nice flavor. But still, I wouldn't get this dish again, it's mostly dough with very few strips of meat.

The service was good and quick.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
The xiao long bao dumplings here are simply perfect. The skin is perfect, the flavor of the filling is perfect, the amount of broth that pours forth after that first bite is perfect. They're just all around the best I've ever had. I've never tried Din Tai Fung but I'm not a fan of commercialized food anyway. Their onion pancake is also very good and lives up to its popularity. 

Will definitely come back!
author: Lina L.

description: The food was very tasty! I've been to china and I can very well tell the difference between authentic and "Americanized" Chinese food, and this was some very delicious authentic Chinese food! I recommend the Shanghai style pork dumplings :)
author: Jacob B.

description:
What this place lacks in ambiance they completely redeem in taste. Dumpling Kitchen is ridiculously delicious and one of the top spots in the Outer Sunset.

For a place that gets so packed on the daily basis, the service remains top notch here. I mean seriously, these guys literally are walking out of the kitchen every few seconds with food. It makes sense, as they need to work quick when there's a full house, but I commend them for putting on a show when I was there. It was like free entertainment while I ate!

On to the food: 1 word. Fantastic.

I waited about 10-15 minutes to get seated when I first arrived (which actually is very reasonable for a Dim Sum spot at lunch time), and about 5 minutes after my order was placed, my food started coming out (see my earlier statement on how fast these guys are). I ordered a bunch of stuff: XLB, veggie pot-stickers, spring rolls, chow mien with beef, chicken with rice, etc. I can't compliment the cooks enough. Every single dish that came out was perfectly made. It was perfection and it's finest.

Now, a question that may come up for people that live further away from here: Is it worth my time to drive all the way here for an experience I can get elsewhere? YES! First of all, this spot makes some of the best XLB you'll ever have. You can say they have nailed the recipe. Secondly, it's affordable, especially for the food you're getting. Thirdly, the service is quick and reliable. Plus, wouldn't you want to stop by the beach afterwards and take a relaxing stroll alongside the water so you can work off all that food? Point made.

Final verdict: Dumpling Kitchen offers the full Dim Sum experience. Incredible food, shorter wait times compared to similar spots, fast service, and reasonable pricing. Years later, this spot is still gaining momentum, and there's a reason for that. Also, what better way to work off that food than a walk on the beach?
author: Alex B.

description: This place has delicious dumplings, the service is great and above all the food is clean and fresh. My -1 star is because our dumplings weren't really soupy. I do recommend this place however, they have this wonderful combination dumpling that is both a soup dumpling which is steamed, that they also quickly fried up like a potsticker. I think that was wonderful.
author: Kambiz K.

description:
Friend was craving Chinese food, so we came across dumpling kitchen! 

steamed vegetarian dumplings (10 pcs) - it was a salad in a dumpling! there was also an alcoholic/chemical taste to some of the dumplings?? can someone explain to me what's happenin in the kitchen 

green onion pancake - it was more of Chinese breadsticks. was doughy but not greasy

Beijing-style sweet buns (deep fried, 4 pcs) - crispy buns with a condensed milk dip! yum
author: V L.

description:
This restaurant's service is great.  I think they have enough employees working at each shift that no tables get ignored, which shadows some good management and attention to customers.
The food is good, probably why there's usually a crowd during peak hours.  The XLB is made very well and the skin used to wrap the baos are at a good consistency to not break easily.
I brought my dad here, who is Shanghainese and he said this restaurant is pretty good compared to other Shanghai restaurants in the SF area.
As a family we ordered their sizzling rice soup, XLB, green beans, green onion pancake, dry-fried chicken wings, shanghai chow mein, and that Chinese dough bread-looking dessert w hella sugar on top (LOL).  Everything was quick, well made and tasty.  Their chicken wings were a little more on the saucier/wet side so I didn't really like them that much.  But other than that, would come back and bring the fam again to this place!
author: Tiffany Z.

description: Dumplings were great, definitely would recommend. They were fresh and well made. As for the other dishes, I would be careful. In addition to several dumpling orders we decided to try some other dishes on the menu. The drunken chicken was one item that traditional Chinese restaurants should have down to a science. However, the one we got tasted like it was drowned in alcohol and not cooked with it. Literally tasted like vodka. Service was also slow and not great. The waiters took their sweet time and took literally 20 minutes to get us our check. We had asked one guy, he forgot, so after 5 minutes we asked a female waitress, then she forgot, so finally I walked up to the cashier and paid there. Not a great experience, but not a horrible one either.
author: Jackie C.

description: Not bad for dumplings and other signature dishes. Price is reasonable and the place is your typical hole in the wall, but pretty clean. Close to transportation but if your driving, parking is a PAIN in the toosh!
author: Nance L.

description:
4.5 stars bumped up for some astonishingly derricious Shanghainese cuisine...from a guy who generally doesn't gravitate towards Chinese food ever after eating so much of it growing up.

While the resto is on the cozier side, my family and I were able to land a table upon arrival after church nearby.  The line picked up considerably by 12:30 - 1 pm though, so aiming for noon or earlier on a weekend would probably be ideal.

"A little bit of everything" summed up our meal as we tried to get a taste of all the standards to get a gauge of the chef's skills.  Both the classic and crab xiao long bao were very well done - thin dumpling skins just resilient enough to be picked up that opened up to flavorful pork swimming in a mini-sea of juice.  Likewise, my brother and I were blown away by how thin and perfectly crisped the pan-fried pork buns and pot stickers were.

Shanghai-style chow mein was on point as well and reminded me of one of my favorite iterations when I was growing up.  For heartier dishes, I'd highly recommend both the lion's head in either preparation for its crazy tender meat and delicate flavors as well as the pork belly with preserved vegetables.  The latter may be too lean for some, but I really enjoyed the balance between the fatty layers and leaner, yet plenty tender meat.

And for rice lovers, I was pleasantly surprised by the texture of the clay pot rice served with greens mixed in and topped with smoked ham.  Really tasty and it paired well with all the meat dishes.  Lastly, the mildly sweet soy milk was great and a similarly great pairing.

What ultimately rounded out our awesome meal though was the quality of the staff.  They remained attentive and available despite having a full house and I truly appreciated how helpful they were with packing up our dishes to go.  The fact that they were more than willing to do it mid-meal to help open up table space for more food was especially notable.
author: Eric F.

description:
I was craving the comforts of home, so Dumpling Kitchen definitely hit the spot. There was also a bit of a wait, which meant that this place was doing something right.

The wait was reasonable and the service was quick. We had someone with us who knew what to order, so he ordered the things they were known for, namely their xiao long bao.

Back home Din Tai Fung is the go to spot for dumplings, but I was never a fan of it. The wait at DTF is atrocious and the food was just mediocre. The dumplings here were kinda the same size, but the broth was flavorful, and it was cheaper.

They had some sort of noodle with a gravy-ish sauce. I'm not sure if that was what we meant to order, but it was still good anyway. I ordered a beef and onion dish which was wasn't too bad, but you can't really mess up beef and onions. I personally didn't care for the wonton soup though.

The other notable things we ordered were their pan fried dumplings. There was one that came with vinegar that's worth ordering.

If you couldn't tell, we ordered A LOT of food. In fact, our server said we ordered too much and that what we had was enough already. Sometimes your hunger just impairs your judgment, you know?
author: Kurtis C.

description: Over priced, but good! I could get the same thing for less expensive elsewhere, but if I'm in the area, I'll definitely be back.
author: Michael P.

description:
Fast service and delicious food. Came in around 4PM with a friend and got seated right away. We ordered the Cucumber Salad, Shanghai Dumplings, and Pork and Chive dumplings.

The food came out pretty quickly. The cucumber salad was good and refreshing, and their shanghai dumplings were pretty darn good. This place is a must try if you are in the area!
author: Linda C.

description:
Came here for the first time with my sister & boyfriend to have lunch. The restaurant was small & there wasn't really much decorations inside. When we first came, there was already a long line. We had to wait about 20 mins.
What we ordered:

Braised pork belly with preserved vegetables - It was very tender & had a good amount of fat in it. The flavor was good. 

Spinach with garlic - It was good. No different from any other spinach with garlic at other Chinese restaurants. 

Crab & pork steamed dumplings - This was definitely something different. Crab flavor was there. Never had a combination of crab & pork together. It's worth trying.

Shanghai-style steamed pork dumplings - It was good but could use a little more soup inside. 

Shanghai-style pan-fried pork buns - This was good & really filling. It was soft on the outside & fried at the bottom. 

Dry-fried chicken wings - It had a lot of sauce on it but the flavor wasn't that great, felt like something was missing. I was expecting for the chicken to be more crispy but it came out a bit soggy. Some of the wings were not cooked thoroughly so that was a big red flag. 

Overall, the food was mediocre. I've had better Chinese food elsewhere. The dumplings here would be better if it came out hot. When we got our dumplings, the soup inside were already warm. The service was okay. Our waiter was a bit rude. Would I come back? Probably not.
author: Thanh T.

description: Best pork dumplings with chili oil I have ever had.
author: Ankit A.

description:
Tried their pot stickers and hot and sour soup so far.  Though it doesn't beat Pot Sticker King in Cupertino, it's pretty darn good.  Added plus is that it's a much shorter drive for pot stickers than Pot Sticker King for me.

I hope to come back for their XLB next time!!!  :P~~
author: Joanna R.

description:
It is so hard to find a legit hole in the wall with seriously delicious food and a line out the door, that still seems doable.  A wait that you could tolerate because the food will be good and the value will be remarkable.

Dumpling Kitchen is such a place.  A tiny drafty place on Taraval with a family of all ages racing around in a postage stamped sized back kitchen, the flash of flame coming from behind a curtain, the sizzle and smells of some very good food on its way to your table.

At Dumpling Kitchen, you can get three orders of Shanghai soup dumplings (XLB) rice cakes with pork, chive pancakes, spicy green beans, a pot of jasmine tea, and all this for less than $40.

It just reminds me why San Francisco is a tough food city to top.  This meal at Din Tai Fung in Seattle would be around $80 and while the atmosphere and service would be far more sophisticated certainly, its hard to argue that the XLBs would be any better.  This is a terrific hole in the wall, in the very best sense.  You can even BYOB here  --lots of dumpling fans came in lugging their own Belgian beers to pair with their XLB. Genius.
author: Rachel H.

description: I was surprised that the food was as lackluster as it was based on the reviews.  We went on a Saturday at lunch and ordered a few different types of XLB, seafood stir fried rice cakes, and some chicken wings.  Stay away from the chicken wings.  The meat consistency wasn't right for both the crab/pork and pork XLB, the flavor was ok.  The seafood stir fried rice cakes were delicious and good quality.  I don't think I would opt to go back here.
author: Jolie N.

description: The Xiao Long Bao dumplings are me and my friends favorites and that's usually all we order! I also really enjoy their green beans. I've tried a few other plates and dumplings but they are not nearly as good as their soup dumplings.
author: Erica C.

description: I went there with my parents couple times. My father used to live in Shanghai for 5 years. He does not think their food is authentic. The Shanghai soup dumpling is just average.
author: North C.

description: Ordered two vegetarian items and was told it would take 10 minutes. Waited 30 minutes, finally got the food, only to find meat dumplings instead of veg. Went back and the employees could not care less. They said it would take 20 minutes to replace the order. I asked for a refund and no one ever apologized or cared. I will never be back.
author: Molly P.

description:
This is a great dim sum place! It doesn't have the traditional carts that are wheeled around probably because the location is relatively small, but the dumplings are awesome nonetheless. I have been here twice now at noon on a Saturday and both times the service was fast and I was able to order plenty to eat. Both times we were seated immediately. The price is very reasonable. The main drawback of this place is parking in the neighborhood is very limited.

Recommendations:

The soup dumplings (Shanghai dumplings) are excellent. They give you a pop of delicious broth when you bite into them.

The pork dumplings

The pork and chives dumplings

The green onion pancake

I would arrive earlier if possible because this place does get very busy on the weekends in the afternoon.
author: Molly M.

description:
I find dumplings kind of adorable. They're dimpled one-bite wonders that are soft and squishy and filled with all sorts of tasty treasures. What's not to like? And Xiao Long Baos...does anyone else wanna poke 'em until they explode? I resist though and delicately cradle them with my chopsticks and pop 'em into my mouth. Then comes that wonderful 10 seconds of delicious dumpling bliss as the flavors envelop your mouth and fill you with that warm fuzzy foodie feeling.

The two must-get dumplings to get here are of course, the traditional Xiao Long Bao soup dumplings, and their plump little homies - the pan fried pork dumplings. They're puffier versions of the XLB with a thicker skin and less liquid. Each order comes with 10 dumplings for ~$7.50, which is usually enough for 1-1.5 people depending on your fatty status.

Other popular picks are the braised pork belly, dry fried chicken wings, green beans, and green onion pancake, which is light and crisp. The rest of the menu doesn't really impress me. I've had the Chinese ham and bok choy clay pot it's basically just slabs of ham, chopped bok choy, and white rice that gets dully crisp on the edges. There's no gravy to bring the dish together. The fried rice, chow mein, and Shanghai style rice cakes are all just okay too. I wouldn't recommend any of them to order specifically, but they're good filler type of side entrees. 

Dumpling Kitchen is your typical hole-in-the wall with plain decor and mediocre service, but the awesome dumplings make up for it all. I like coming here for brunch on the weekends. There's hardly ever a line and if there is, it's usually 10-15 minutes. One of my go-to dumpling spots!
author: Deanna Y.

description: Good menu of Shanghai specialties especially the dumplings and noodles.  Onion pancake wasn't as layered and flaky as other places but not greasy. The soy milk soup was like warm but had great flavor with the pickled veggies and preserved pork. The fried dough was added on top. Clean and fast service. Chicken wings had good texture but overly heavy on the five spice flavor.  Would stick to the Shanghai menu especially since it's hard to find...
author: jennifer m.

description:
BEST XLBs aka xiao long baoos!! Shanghainese food is just bomb in general. We ordered the rice cake, green beans, XLBs, and combo noodles. The sauce of the rice cake and combo noodle dishes were the same, so next time we'll just stick with the rice cakes probably. No complaints re green beans. And most importantly, the XLBs were super soupy, warm, and omg delicious. I thought Shanghai Dumpling King was good (yes, they all have similar names), but this place just upped the standard by a notch. I have only come here only once so I can't comment about the consistency of the soupiness, but seeing how this place is highly rated on yelp, there must be a reason. 

As for parking, there was plenty of street parking. The wait-to-be-seated is a bit unpredictable though. The waiting area is pretty small so expect to stand outside. There are not that many interesting shops nearby, so either choose to come during odd hours of the day, or prepare to wait. Lots of city people come here for the XLBs probably. If I ever get another craving (which I will), I'm going to come back here for suree.
author: Connie L.

description: The staff was so welcoming and friendly. Dim sum was exceptional. We had the house dumplings and vegetarian dumplings. Excellent. Casual and easygoing atmosphere.
author: Kimberly C.

description: My go-to place for XLB in SF. We order 3 at the minimum to make the most of our visit at this place. Be sure to order the egg puff ahead of time as that takes awhile to make.
author: Dru K.

description:
2:30pm is the time to come to avoid the lunch crowd.

Ordered the XLB, pan fried buns, hot and sour soup, and red bean cake. The XLB was just okay in my opinion. They were kind of on the small side and didn't have a lot of juice. We also had to request for vinegar and ginger...only got the vinegar though. But it's okay...cause the pan fried buns were the ultimate redeemer. They were delicious! Fried just right and it wasn't too doughy or oily like other places. LOVED THEM. 

The hot and sour soup was pretty decent as well. Not too overwhelming on the tastebuds and it was definitely a good starter to get the appetite going. There was enough to provide our party of 3 with 2 bowls a piece.

The red bean cake for dessert was super yummy too. It was deep fried but with a mochi-like interior and stuffed with azuki paste. It was a nice switch from my family's typical preference for the fried sugar puffs.
author: Elaine Y.

description: Nice home-style Chinese food in the sunset. Ordered XLB, pan fried pork buns, Shanghai chow mein, preserved vegetable rice cakes, and pea sprouts. Food is not too oily. XLB is soupy with great flavor, but the meat collapses kind of easily. Pan fried pork buns are really good, the dough portion is a little soft though. Really good chow mein with the thick noodles. Would not recommend preserved vegetable rice cakes (meat is fatty and very little preserved vegetable; I think preserved vegetable's flavor is too strong - not like the real thing)
author: SY T.

description: Yes, you have to wait a bit but it makes your mouth salivate for the food more. Delicious items. Dumpling are delicious (steamed or fried). The prices are reasonable and not overpriced like the places in the city.
author: Marcus C.

description: LOVE COMING HERE FOR SHANGHAI DUMPLINGS! Pretty crowded during lunch but worth going! Definitely have to get the xiao long bao and their Dam Dam Mein (peanut sauce and noodles) and pot sticker, but there are other foods you have to try, these are just a few i love getting! DEFINITELY WORTH GOING!!!
author: Tiffany C.

description:
This place is over rated - we thought we would try it because there is always a crowd outside whenever we pass by.
One of the staff was so rude - she just slammed the water on our table.  The foodcomes out literally 5 minutes after you order, so I'm not sure if it's made to order.
The vegetarian steam dumplings were so bland!  The Shanghai chow mein and the rice cakes tasted the same.
Overall, very bland.  We were really disappointed.
author: Nicole S.

description:
I am a huge fan of cheap (but good) Asian food in the Sunset, and this place is great for a no frills bang-for-your-buck kinda restaurant. 

My aunt always get takeouts of their XLB here, so I treated out my two aunts and grandma here for a late lunch/early dinner on a Thursday. We came around 3PM and there was NO ONE! We ordered everything fairly quick and easy and all the food came out at once. We got an order of XLB (which I have to say are my favorites by far; 10 dumplings per order), shanghai noodles, their 5 spice beef noodle soup (totally recommend if you want to try their soup noodles!), their pork lettuce wraps, and veggie tofu dish. My aunt really likes their heated soymilk drink which is pretty good. 

Their portion sizes are huge for the price! For about $60, we were all stuffed and still had plenty of leftovers. Located right by the L Taraval line and close to my grandma's, I think I'll be frequenting this place more often.
author: Kathleen S.

description:
I've been here several times, and the food here is legit.  The XLB and the potstickers are my favorites.  You have to use the hot sauce at the table to go with this dish.. The hot sauce is out of this world.  Gives you the perfect kick.  It's hard to find the sticky rice roll and I finally found a place near me that has it. The sticky rice roll has the chinese donut in since with flossy pork as well.  The perfect combo to go with the sweet soy milk, which they serve hot.  The rice cakes here with pork is also really good.  You can tell they use really good ingredients because the pork didn't have any fat in it.  They use lean pork to make their dishes, which makes me feel healthier.  The Egg puff is reminds me so much of the ones in Hong Kong, except its missing the red bean paste that the ones in Hong Kong has.   I always have to get this for dessert no matter how full i am!.   
Just a world of advice.  they will charge you for to go containers, but the food is so good.. it's totally worth it!
author: Belinda C.

description:
Of course- and luckily given its popularity- my lil boy and I went for an early dinner last Friday night.

As such, Dumpling Kitchen was a little off its mark with the dearth of diners, forgetting when I asked for extra napkins and that Tsing Tao beer, please?

The dumplings were delicious, particularly the Shanghai Soup dumplings (aka "XLB" or Xian Long Bao) but where was the ginger/vinegar sauce? I now know from other Yelp reviews they serve it but not for us! 

(1/2 star demerit). 

The one entree my little boy *insisted* on ordering - beef with broccoli- he ate the generous slices of tender beef but left all but one daintily nibbled broccoli floret for me to eat.

And I swear there was an entire head of broccoli in the entree- florets only- along with a side of dry braised green beans. Combined, there had to be a pound and a 1/2 of vegetables between the two dishes leftover. 

(How do these folks make money? Really, they could throttle way back and it'd still be a solid deal). 

And for the record, I made the leftover broccoli and braised green beans a dinner unto themselves the following evening.

To finish, we waited 15 minutes for the kitchen to make their fabled Egg Puffs for dessert. As tired as my 7 year-old was after a full week of school, he wanted to wait for this highly-touted item; he wanted dessert. 

And were the Egg Puffs worth it- OMG!

Yorkshire pudding eggy-ness but hot hot hot, a lil greasy (in the most delicious way) and dusted with confectioners' sugar.

If you had to wait in line IN THE RAIN, order some Egg Puffs and consume them immediately while they're hot. 

Yes, they're that delicious. Worth trekking across town for this item delicious. 

The dumplings were very good; the Egg Puffs will make Dumpling Kitchen famous.  

I'll return for sure.
author: Jennifer O.

description:
True story: we almost accidentally walked into Kingdom of Dumpling instead while walking down Taraval--I can never seem to keep track of all these endearingly simple dumpling/noodle restaurant names.... Dumpling Kitchen, Kingdom of Dumpling, King of Noodles, House of Pancakes

[THE DUMPLINGS]

I must say though, among the various Kitchens and Kingdoms and Houses, Dumpling Kitchen's XLB are the best I've had in SF/SSF.  I admit to being an absolute snob about XLB with ridiculously high standards based on XLB excursions in Asia, but Dumpling Kitchen has it just right: 

1. The skin must push the boundaries of being delicately thin (I know, a true delicacy =P) without falling apart and spewing out the insides when you pick it up
2. The broth must be flavorful, arguably ramen-grade
3. The pork should be succulent and savory, but not rely completely on fat because then it gets heavy and makes you just feel uncomfortably fatty and full after a few dumplings

We also got the cabbage and pork dumplings which were amazing as well, satisfying the same criteria as XLB minus the soup and plus the cabbage.

[THE NON-DUMPLINGS]

Because it seemed strange to only eat dumplings for dinner (though after my first visit I would have been totally happy with that), we got the pork and leek stir-fry dish, which was more delicious than it sounds, as is the case for most Chinese dishes.  The portion was generous and I liked how there was a lot of leek.  The cooking style was homemade, though I personally would have preferred that they don't use sugar (yes I'm such a health freak... being a fan of leeks and complaining about sugar).

[THE SERVICE/AMBIANCE/MISC]

It has the typical Parkside nice Chinese restaurant vibe--no flashy alters with phoenixes and dragons, but not a dingy hole-in-the-wall looking like it serves street food.  Service was courteous as well (FYI they speak Canto and Mandarin), and I liked how the waitress was honest when we asked whether we could request lean meat for twice cooked pork and she said it was only pork belly which had strips of fat.  Prices are great too, with almost everything under $10 (makes Park Tavern across the street seem really pricey for dinner)

I'll be back!  In my opinion, Dumpling Kitchen is too modest of a name for such amazing dumplings--they should reign the SF dumpling turf as the King of Dumplings or Dumpling Palace.
author: Edna C.

description:
Came here for dinner with my friend and her family. We got here around 7 for dinner and it was already filled but we were seated quickly. The venue is light and bright and a good amount of space for seating.

For dinner we ordered Dry Fried Chicken wings, Shanghai- style steam pork dumplings (XLB), Shanghainese pan-fried dumplings, Steamed Vegetarian dumplings, Beef noodle soup, Sautéed string beans, Shanghai chow mein, and sugar donut puffs. 

The service was very quick, everything came out within 5-10 mins from the time we ordered. The first thing that came out was the beef noodle soup. It was very light and the meat was cooked tender and seasoned well. Next came the sautéed string beans and they were light with a crunch although there could've been seasoned a little more. The steamed vegetable dumpling was really juicy and tasty. The dried fried chicken wings were crunchy and tender but I think their sauce could be sticker or thicker possibly. The Shanghai chow mein had beef, chicken, shrimp, and mixed vegetables! I was surprised how there were so many things mixed into this dish! 

My favorites were the dumplings of course! We had the Shanghai-style steam pork dumplings (XLB) which are my absolute favorite. I enjoyed the soup flavor and the seasoned meat inside the dumpling. The shanghainese pan-fried dumplings were delicious, they weren't soft and moist with a light crunch on the outside and the inside had great seasoned meat. 

For dessert we had sugar donut puffs and boy these were great! They were light, flaky, and delicious. 

Although this place could expand a little bigger, the food is delicious!
author: Michele W.

description:
I like the xiaolunbao and pork bun 
The thick noodle taste great
Also like the rice cake stir fry
author: Xing M.

description:
So it occurred to my partner and I that it had been a long minute since the last time we had dumplings. I'm finally getting to the point after a 6 month adventure in South East Asia, that I want to eat and enjoy deep Asian flavors again. We came across Dumpling Kitchen on Yelp and since had never ventured out to the Sunset before, the decision was easy to make! 

It was one of those nights I ate to the point of being sick, but it was so easy to do. We ordered way too much food. The wait wasn't long on a Friday night although the restaurant was pretty packed. I'd say expect about at least a 15 minute wait. This restaurant is friendly for large parties, too. There was a birthday in the house. The servers were fast to set up our tables, serve up hot green tea, and take our orders. 

DUMPLINGS
- We ordered one of the steamed Shanghai pork dumplings. These were amazing. I had a spot back home where I'd go for pork soup dumplings and these were definitely reminiscent of my old go-to. It took me to my happy place. The wraps are on the thinner side and the dumplings are kind of small. But the portion was plenty to share between the beau and I. 
- Pork dumplings in chili oil. After having the Shanghai pork ones, these didn't quite provoke the same excitement and burst of flavor. It was toned down and very little chili oil. I guess maybe I was imagining them to be more like wontons in chili oil that I've had before - just doused with that shiny red oil. The meat flavor was kind of muted, too. Not bad, just doesn't stand well against the Shanghai ones. 

SZECHUAN BEEF
- Great flavor with tender beef bites and I really loved the sauteed cucumber. I'm not sure what that's about because I've never seen a stir fry done this way before, but it actually worked pretty well. Our only complaint about this was that they really didn't do justice with szechuan spice level. They just sparingly threw one or two fried red chilies on there. Boyfriend had to add a lot more hot sauce to get it up to his level. A side of rice was a must with this plate for us. 

NOODLES IN PEANUT SAUCE
- So they forgot about my order for these noodles, which honestly I wish I had just left it at that. The noodles were more Ramen style which I didn't expect. The serving size it ginormous, but my disappointment with this dish was that it barely had any flavor. It was really gummy and I had expected a sweet peanut sauce. This was a weird half savory half- inexplicable. I have no knowledge on this dish, so I can't speak to it much. But I had expected something completely different Kind of like a dan dan noodle in sweet peanut sauce. This was not that at all. 

SWEET BUNS
Amazing. She asked whether we wanted it steamed for fried, and since there was so much damage already done. What the hell. Fried, please. It comes in 4 small buns that were SUPER fresh. We had to let it cool, so as not to burn our fingers. The sugar sweet on the side and the fried bread was just a great finish to our awesome meal. 

The Shanghai dumplings alone are a reason to come back. The service was also wonderful for it being so busy and with several large groups.
author: Priti K.

description:
Thank you to the reviewer who told us to get #103!!!! 
That had to be the best pork belly I've ever had in my life!!!  It was so tender and melted in my mouth!!! 

The soup dumplings was the reason why we came here.  They only ended up being ok. The dough was thick and nothing like Din tai fung. 

4 stars because of the pork belly. You will not regret it!!!
author: Cindy S.

description: Vegetable dumplings were fantastic!  Pan braised tofu and vegetables and chicken mushu were decent as well but can't exactly rave about them.  While the food was pretty decent, the service wasn't great, pretty poor actually.
author: Bill H.

description: There's not much to the ambiance here as it is pretty small and simple. As for their service, they are quick and polite but not going out of their way to be really warm and friendly. However, the food is absolutely delicious... loved their sauces to dip in! Didn't seem terribly busy here for lunch, so no wait time necessary.
author: Candy L.

description:
This place is AH-maxing truly worth trying and worth the wait if you're looking for an authentic Shanghainese style Chinese food. The soup dumplings were almost exactly like the ones I had at Din Tai Fung in Shanghai. 

We ordered based off of YELP photos the: walnut shrimp (so good, not too mayonnaisey, I'm craving it right now), pork dumplings, Sechwan  noodles, pea sprouts, wontons in chili oil and the green onion pancake. I would recommend it all!

It was very filling and we even ordered some soup dumplings to go!
author: Anastacia W.

description: Celebrated my brother's 18th Birthday here because he wanted dimsum & XLB's! Haha. Very easy to find, as it was just on Taraval Street (between 29th & 30th Avenues), not too far from SFSU & Stonestown Galleria. Parking is tough, although we got lucky as we parked just the next block away. The restaurant is lacking in decor, plain white walls & your typical, average-looking, Chinese restaurant. Very simple, yet cozy & has that "hole in a wall" place. Found this via Yelp, and we got promptly seated right away & no language barrier! Servers were very attentive & took our orders right away. Waters are served upon request, don't forget about the drought, folks! Our bill came to about $70 something, however, we were all stuffed & had leftovers to take home, as well! We got a bowl of their Hot & Sour Soup, General Tso's Chicken (it's not greasy!), ShanghaiStyle Noodles (hand pulled & homemade), Combination Fried Rice, Honey Walnut Prawns, Salt & Pepper Rock Cod w/ Fresh Jalapeños, AND of course, authentic Shanghai Xiao Long Baos (aka Steamed Pork Dumplings) that come in those steamer baskets! Hella fresh. Hands down, one of the best, if not, THE BEST XLB's that aren't mainstream & typical! I'm not a fan of XLB's, but this establishment gave me the reason of wanting more! Highly recommend this place if you're on this side of the City by the Bay! I'd definitely go back and try their Vegetarian XLB's lol.
author: Alvin M.

description:
UPDATED REVIEW:

Dumplings here are still good as ever, and dare I say it.. maybe even better than Kingdom of Dumpling. Despite their namesake, all of their other items are really good. I've had the pea shoots, chicken wings, normal dumplings, XLB, wontons.. seems that you really can't go wrong, and you can't beat it for the price!

Unfortunately for me, this place has gotten more popular since my last review about 3 years ago and there is now a wait T_____T .. but I'll still wait for you.
author: Emily C.

description:
Place usually has a line. What's good, the XLB. It has exactly what you would expect it to have. It's pretty juicy on the inside, and the flavor is good. The shanghai fried buns, don't get that, it'll be a let down. The buns are moist and there is no crispiness to the bun. If that's what you are into, then sure.... The shui zhu yue was very poorly done. Just don't order that period. The other dumplings in chili oil was pretty solid, but I wish there were veggies inside it, was purely just meat and I think there needs to be some veggies to add to the taste and texture.

Stick to dumplings, and you will be fine
author: Victor D.

description: Food is pretty good. Ordered the pork belly and the soup dumplings. Seafood fried rice is not bad either
author: Eyy M.

description: Got the Crab & Pork and the Pork XLB with the green onion pancakes. The XLBs were either overcooked or the wrapper was too thin but I could not pick up a single one without it breaking on me. The wrapper kept getting stuck to the paper on the steamer. The wrapper itself was pretty mushy and the flavor was nothing special to me. There was not much soup inside the XLB either. The Crab and Pork XLB filling was pretty mushy, they need to add more pork to make it a tiny bit more dense. The green onion pancake came out oily and soft. I am not comparing this place to Din Tai Fung, but when you have a restaurant called Dumpling Kitchen, I definitely expect a lot more.
author: Brandon L.

description: The dim sum police have arrived and this xiao long bao is under arrest! The pea shoots were quite tasty, good ambiance, chill, but the signature dumplings are overly fatty and the texture is off, not chewy enough, not enough lean meat. We're locking this place away and throwing away the key.
author: jacob m.

description:
By name alone, it's hard to decipher Dumpling Kitchen from other dumpling restaurants on Taraval.  Luckily, that's where the confusion ends.  In December, it'll be my one year anniversary since discovering this yummy dumpling eatery.  The noodle skin on their steamed dumplings aren't too thin or thick and has good tenacity.  The force meat is tasty. Although, on more than one occasion I've bitten into a chunk of ginger that was spared by the food processor.  

Everything you want in a dumpling is here - they're delicate when they need to be, they're perfectly seared with a crunchy skin, and not soggy or limp.

The only complaint I have - and it's not the service - is that their XLB are good, but not as great as their other offerings.  i.e. the pan friend dumpling or the pan seared steam buns.  I recommend Shanghai Dumpling King in this instance for their XLB.  However, overall DK offers a better product.
author: Josh S.

description: This was my first dim sum experience and it was fantastic. Shanghai steamed dumplings and pan fried dumplings were all delicious. Hit and sour soup also on point. Definitely panning to come back again soon.
author: Kelden C.

description: Ordered the 2.) pork and crab xiao long baos and the 7.) Beijing style pork and chive dumplings. They were pretty good. Good enough to make me want to come back. I really enjoyed the texture of the xlb skin. The meats were also very flavorful. Prices are bit high though.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
We came here with high expectations as the photos looks pretty nice, but overall were disappointed.
We ordered a bunch of popular items, Xiao Long Bao, Sheng Jian Bao, Chao Shou... They all taste authentic but low quantity. Similar to those you can get from very low end food stalls in China.
author: Chen P.

description: Can't put my finger on it - but I just love these dumplings
author: Russ L.

description: Researched a ton of dumpling houses in the SF area... most have 3.5 stars or less, so when I came across this restaurant with the 4 star rating, decided to give it a try. We went on a Thursday around 2pm so there were only a few tables occupied and we were seated right away. Ordered the shanghai dumplings, pork dumplings in chili oil and lunch specials, sesame chicken and mapo tofu. Both were ok... nothing special, and the dumplings were just decent. Overall did not exceed my expectations.
author: Cat K.

description: I had to update because I'm extremely in love with the food at this place. The shanghai soup dumplings and the fried pork buns are TOO GOOD! You must try the two if you come here for the first time. Service is quick and fast. All the people who work here are very attentive. Favorite dumpling place everrrr!
author: Tina R.

description:
I was a little disappointed, only because expected a lot for the hype. Food was good, but not 5 stars. (Little bits of bone/cartilage in the dumplings almost make it 3 stars).

25min wait on weekend afternoon. Could use more parking, but can't be helped in SF.

I would come back but not worth a special trip.
author: D K.

description:
Favorite place in SF to get my XLB and beef noodle stew fix! I also love their lightly sweet pan-fried pork dumplings. Everything is so cheap and delicious.

I honesty haven't tried anything else except for random veggie dishes like garlic bok choy and mushroom tofu to balance our meal. Oh and the Shanghai style rice cakes, which are pretty good. I haven't tried Kingdom of Dumpling so I can't compare, but this place is legit and there's hardly ever a wait (huge plus)!
author: Stephanie G.

description: Pretty good xao long bao. Everything else was meh... ok. Fast service with easy servers. Reasonably priced. Next time we'll go for the seafood, that looked pretty good.
author: Angela N.

description: Good but unexceptional. Restaurant environment is industrial. Best dumpling:Shanghai style steamed pork. Good fried potstickers but no yummy sauce
author: Angela B.

description: Our friends took us here for their soup dumplings and now every Chinese restaurant we go to will not be the same. We ordered pan fried pork buns, pork belly, soup dumplings (pork and shrimp) and Shanghai style pan fried rice cakes. The pork belly was so good. It was tender and melted in your mouth. The Shanghai pan rice cakes reminded me of Korean duk bok Yi (spicy rice cakes) with Chinese flavoring. And the soup dumplings were amazing. Each bite of the dumpling had the perfect amount of soup inside and overall just delicious!
author: Jennie Y.

description:
Thanks to my fellow yelpers and their thorough recommendations, I just enjoyed my first scrumptious dinner here. Uber yummy! Can't wait to come back and try the chicken wings. They looked super bomb! 

Tonight we devoured the shanghai style chow mein. Thick noodles with perfectly sautéed cabbage and other yum yums. Not oily or overly seasoned. Just right. 

Everyone in the place had an order of the dry braised string beans on their table. Noticed this dish was a highlight to many yelpers. Was not disappointed. Cooked well but still very crispy. Not oily or saucey. Just tasty, garlicky, healthy string beans. Very good! 

The #1: Shanghai style steamed pork dumplings are one of their signature dishes. (Also known as the XLB dumplings.) A must have dish. These dumplings are better than most but not the absolute best I've ever had. But second to the best I've ever had. That said, they're the best dumplings in the neighborhood. 

The #5: Shanghai style pan fried pork buns seemed the most risky to me but were outstanding! Similar to the #1 with the sensual, steaming hot broth inside. But with a sweet tasting pan seared bottom and thicker dumpling wrapper than the #1. Slightly different but oh so delectable! 

Upon sitting they brought hot tea and roasted peanuts. It's a nice welcome gesture. One thing I found to be true from other yelp reviews is the necessity to flag down the servers. Under normal circumstances I would never do that. But seeing as this is the MO here, it was an imperative procedure to ordering and getting the check. 

Overall, a pleasant and mouth watering dining experience without being too expensive. Thumbs up!
author: Rosalyn W.

description: Not impressed...soup dumplings were ok without being memorable (had better dumplings at Canton, not soup though) and the pancake was disappointing, no comparison to House of Pancakes goods....
author: VIORICA C.

description:
Been having a crazy shanghai dumpling cravings for a couple weeks now. The crab and pork dumplings hit the spot perfectly! Green beans were well cooked too but a little oily and the portion was huge!

Also ordered the shanghai style fried pork buns and they were okay. There was too much bun and not enough meat.

Standard Chinese place so service was okay and restaurant was filled with Chinese parties of 7+ so its loud!
author: Mimi T.

description: Their XLB is really juicy and delicious. I tried their crab with pork dumpling and they were delicious also. Their pea sprout was OK. Sold 4 stars. They never let us down. We will be back.
author: T.J. Y.

description: This review isn't based off the food because I didn't stay long enough to try it. As I waited for the bathroom I heard the toilet flush and a woman with a hairnet rush out without washing her hands back to the kitchen. Needless to say I lost my appetite.
author: Jessica N.

description:
Came to Dumpling Kitchen with my girlfriend who was craving some soy milk and dumplings which brought her here. I usually just tag along for the ride because I don't know much in terms of good Dumpling places. She's the expert. But she wasn't wrong about here. The wait was long which is usually an indicator of a good spot. Waited maybe 30 mins for a table for two. 

We got seated and began browsing the menu. Obviously get dumplings at the dumpling kitchen. We did with some chili sauce which gave them a little extra kick and then we also got some steamed dumplings. In addition we got a rice roll and some xo rice noodles as well. 

Food came out quick and it was very tasty. The dumplings were some of the best I've had in quite a while. The rice roll was a little dry and the xo rice noodles were pretty standard. Overall I liked the dumplings here and in the different methods they serve it so I would definitely come back.
author: Jeromy G.

description:
Pictures look way better than they taste.  Call me critical but having grown up eating XLB and shen jian bao (Shanghai-style pan-fried pork buns), I found the ones here dry, doughy, soupless and not lovable.  
Also tried several of the noodle soups - nothing noteworthy.  
Warm soymilk was the only right order, great for a cold and windy day.
author: Angel W.

description: Loved the soup dumplings I had. The scallion pancake was also phenomenal. However the dessert Bao Bun that I had was just a bun with some sweetened condensed milk on the side. The service was a little slow but I really loved the food for the most part!
author: Natalie M.

description:
Hands down the best Xiao Long Bao (Shanghai soup dumplings) in the city. I can't help but compare this place to Kingdom of Dumpling, which is just a few blocks away. Kingdom of Dumpling used to be my favorite until the food quality got worse.

The soup dumplings itself get four stars. These dumplings are the best because they are packed with flavor. The skin that hold the deliciousness together is thin compared to Kingdom's which is so thick, I end up not eating their skin. It would be cool if they could somehow put more soup into the dumplings here though.

Other popular items here won't disappoint either. Their chicken wings are decent but not comparable to San Tung's. I like their green onion pancake because it's not oily, but Kingdom's is still better. The stir fried rice cakes are great too but it would be better if they fried it a little more to make it crispier. For vegetables, I like getting the pea sprouts and string beans.

The service is pretty good. Though the workers don't seem the friendliest, they're pretty attentive and cater to your needs.
author: Derek T.

description:
I've always thought dumpling was dim sum, but I guess it's not. Well my friend was trying to explain to me that it's different. As you know, most Asian restaurant is small. Rents too expensive or something. But this dumpling kitchen is very small. I won't review on service cause, it's a Chinese restaurant, what do you expect? A 5 star service, in an ok neighborhood? No way. 

Anyway, we got a seat quick despite the line, and we had a party of 11. The people cared more about cleaning tables than ordering which is ok because we were still deciding. So they didn't bother you much. On the table were peanuts. And a tea pot. 

We ordered a lot. Veggie dumpling, pork and cabbage dumpling, crab and pork dumpling, Shanghai dumpling, dry wings, Shanghai noodles, string beans, and honey walnut shrimp. 

The dumplings were really good. I thought the Shanghai was very good. It's a soup dumpling so you have to be careful not to break it. Tasty. The string beans were good. Ahaha it's weird but the taste was citrusy. Oh the walnut shrimp had a citrus taste to it. In a good way though. The dry wings were very sweet. It was ok to me.But I would suggest getting the dumplings. It was good. 

I probably would try other dumpling places but if you're in the neighborhood and you're in the mood for dumpling try this place out.
author: Ameenah M.

description:
Best soup dumplings in San Francisco - and FINALLY, something on par with NYC soup dumplings (albeit smaller and more expensive).

I've had soup dumplings at Yank Sing, Chino (now closed), and Shanghai Dumpling King, and none of them were good enough (Shanghai Dumpling King was BAD).  These are great.  Thin skinned, served piping hot, ample soup filling, nicely salty.  We tried both the Shanghai Style Pork Dumplings and the Crab and Pork Steamed Dumplings, and while the latter were tasty and lightly sweet, I always prefer pork soup dumplings (so, no surprise here).  We ended up getting two orders of the pork and one order of the crab/pork for two people.

We also had an order of the cucumber salad (could have been a little saltier, but overall very flavorful and enjoyable), the dry fried chicken wings (I didn't like how sticky/sweet they are, but my boyfriend loved them), and the pea shoots in house broth (loved this, super yummy).

The free tea was good and the restaurant vibe is lively and bright.  Oh, and they take credit cards - yay (just not Amex)!

I will DEFINITELY be coming back here!
author: Tay H.

description: Great food but somewhat poor service. A friend and I came here on a Friday evening at around 7:30 and it was pretty packed, but we were seated at the last two top table. Within 3 minutes of being given our menus, we were asked if we were ready to order (!!!) - of course we replied we needed some time. We eventually settled on pork dumplings, vegetable won ton soup, sweet buns and red bean pancake, pictures attached. We received the first three items but has to ask twice for the red bean pancake, which they forgot to give us. Not long after the red bean pancake was given to us (no apologies or comment), we were asked if we wanted to go boxes - which felt like they were trying to get us out of there - we were still working on our first three items and hasn't even gotten into the pancake. Then all of a sudden the bill was on the table??!! I just felt like we were rushed out of there and any attempt at a leisurely dinner was impossible. The food was excellent; however I'm not sure I will go back due to environment.
author: Jen D.

description:
Awesome food & friendly staff! 

I work right next door to these guys and because I don't have a break, I usually call in my order and run next door to pick it up. The panfried pork buns are seriously to die for. The flavor, the meat and the crispy bottoms!  The price is reasonable and when they say that it will be ready in 15 minutes, believe them, it will be ready in 15. The host/hostess are always super nice and friendly and that's always a plus and a reason to go back.

I have never dined inside of the restaurant but I believe that if they treat pick up orders this seriously, the service for dining in will be even better.
author: Alyssa H.

description:
Our group ordered all kinds of XLB and had over 8 orders combined. As soon as one order came on, we devoured it. The XLBs never broke when we ate them, which either indicates that these are some high quality XLBs or we are too pro at eating them. I'm thinking the former is the case.

We also ordered a few entrees and dumplings to mix it up, but the XLB are definitely the highlight. Service was quick and the food came out fast.
author: Edward W.

description:
My family and I came here on a Sunday right around noon so the wait was about 45 mins or longer. The restaurant is small so we had to wait outside. The host was apologetic about the wait and tried as best as she could to have us seated right away. There were a total of 9 of us -  5 adults and 4 kids, so the wait was understandable.

They put in an order ahead for us before we got seated to speedy up the wait/service once we were seated which was nice. We had 3 orders of the dry fried chicken wings (about 10 pieces per order), 1 order of the crab and pork dumplings, XLB, braised pork belly, bok choy, shanghai style chow mein, eggplant with veggies, and an egg soup for the kids. It was a lot of food for sure, but we like to have variety when we eat out.

My favorite dish had to be the pork belly, which was super tender and flavorful. This dish came with some bok choy to balance out the flavor, it is a slight bit greasy, but pork belly is gluttonously delicious. I had high expectations of the XLBs, but they just good nothing amazing. I feel like there could be a little more soup inside. The crab and pork one was a little dry.

The service was fair, all our orders came out promptly once we put in our big order. Overall, my family was pleased with our meal here, but the wait kind of made us have high expectations of the food. Hopefully the wait won't be as long next time.
author: Georgina G.

description: Dining at Dumpling Kitchen is necessary. My bae and I have been coming back the past three consecutive weeks and it almost impossibly gets better each time. You NEED to get the mushu pork, braised string beans, and Beijing style boiled dumplings. These three are seriously insanely tasty and delicious. This place is amazing. Eat here today and everyday.
author: Cameron M.

description:
Walking in around 11:30 am and it was pretty mellow, just a few other tables being served. Once I sat down and picked up my tea cup, instantly see thick yellow residue that sat on the edge of the cup... Gross. 

Don't have too much experience with soup dumplings, in fact these were my very first ones! And I brought a friend from Oakland to enjoy some with me on a rainy San Francisco day, and let me tell you it was a real disappointment...
The dumplings themselves were small and droopy, pleats looked like someone pushed it together in one go, one of the dumplings were torn, amount of meat was pretty small,and it lacked any soup at all. 

What we did have that were pretty good was their garlic bokchoy and wontons in chili sauce, which in comparison to the soup dumplings were like at least double the size of them.
author: Shaina J.

description:
I came here with my family on Chinese New Year because all the Chinese restaurants had a wait time of forever. I was starving so I suggested this place because I have been wanting to try their Xiao Long Bao. We got there on a Monday around 1 and we got seated right away. There were a lot of tables filled but not a full house. 

Our order: 
Sweet soymilk
Pork Dumplings
Crab and pork dumplings
Pan fried pork buns
Shanghai style noodles
Shanghai style rice cakes


The dumplings were not to die for. I wish it was because I've been wanting really good dumplings. Everything was only okay and I feel like it was pricey for what we ate. I won't be back to try other dishes.
author: Joey C.

description: The Braised Pork Belly dish was the best thing about my visit to SF. I truly started missing the dish the moment i finished eating it:) this dish is like heaven at least. Please, can someone name a place that serves the same or similar dish in Los Angeles? Shanghai dumplings were good too but there were four of us sharing it so I barely remember it. I think one basket should be shared only between the two.
author: Linda L.

description: No frills, but amazing food and the prices are great. Sometimes there can be a wait, but it's pretty quick. The soup dumplings are a must! Green beans, Pork Buns, Chow Mein, and Sweet and Sour Chicken are delicious as well!
author: Stephanie S.

description: Food is amazing! Its hard to find good food and good service now adays. Just gotta wait a little bit to be called in to be seated.
author: Yesenia H.

description: I love this place! Super good! Definitely try it. Love the dumplings and chow mein, super fast. Great for rainy days.
author: Gracie B.

description: I have decided that this is my absolute favorite restaurant in the city for XLB (soup dumplings). I've had both their regular soup dumplings and pan fried ones, which are excellent (although I prefer the standard). The skins strike that great balance of being not too thick yet rarely breaking. Dumplings are flavorful and juicy.
author: Jane C.

description:
Our group of 4 (2 kids, 2 adults) came out here to Parkside today because of the great Yelp reviews -- great lead, thanks all! 

We got lucky with parking right on the street about 50 feet away on the other side of the street, with no meter. 

At 12 noon on Sunday afternoon, they were doing a brisk business with mostly Asian customers but we only had a 10-minute wait. Service was great, very quick and polite. They even boxed up all our leftovers for us at the table :) 

Prices are very reasonable and portions are generous: we had a huge amount of food with plenty of leftovers for dinner for under $100 including tip. 

Decor is pretty plain and functional, with an altar set high up in a wall alcove, white walls with wainscoting, dark blue carpeting, tables covered in cream table clothes with glass tops, heavy duty white plates and tea cups, ivory plastic chopsticks or metal silverware, and paper napkins. Hey, it's not glamourous but it's neat and clean (check out that 92 out of 100 Health Inspection score, yo -- EDIT on Dec. 18, 2017: Food Safety Score now 71, uh oh!) and the food is well-worth your attention! 

Note they only take cash or debit cards with the Visa or Mastercard imprint, no straight credit cards. 

Our Sunday feast included: 
* Green onion pancake (light, crispy, so good!)
* Shanghai-style steamed pork dumplings (Shanghai-style = with plentiful broth inside, "soup dumpling" aka Xiaolongbao or XLB)
* Pork pan-fried dumplings (nice crispy bottoms!)
* Chicken and corn soup (extra good imho with a little pepper added) 
Shanghai-style steamed crab and pork dumplings
Sticky rice rolls (with fried pork inside, served wrapped in plastic wrap to stay moist)
Mu shu shrimp (served with thin pancakes and hoisin sauce)
Shrimp with rice cakes (the "cakes" are short, oblong flat rice noodles) 
* Crispy egg puffs (light and puffy, sprinkled with sugar, YUM) 

* EXTRA DELICIOUS

All was tasty but especially great was the starred stuff. All comes with plenty of hot pale yellow mild jasmine tea. 

Enjoy! We will definitely be back!
author: Sarah J.

description:
I love me some XLB [aka xiao long bao (aka soup dumplings)] and heard they were good here, so of course I had to check it out.  Good news...it lives up to the hype!   I might have gotten carried away with ordering, but we had just enough for 3 people to feel very full.

XLB: pork x1, crab x1; good thick skin and full of just the right amount of meat and broth.  both were yummers but I liked the pork ones better
Black bean noodles: the sauce was soupy-er (not a real word?) than I expected, but still good
Green onion pancake: very tortilla-like; don't get this

We were seated immediately and the food came out quickly.  Cheap, yummy eats!  My only complaint is finding parking in this neighborhood, but that's no big surprise.
author: Lyn C.

description:
The XLB (shanghai-style steamed pork) dumplings from Dumpling Kitchen are not bad at all. The skin is a little thick, but not overly thick, the flavor of the soup in the dumplings is light and subtle, and the pork is tasty. Overall, pretty good dumplings!

I wasn't too crazy about the other dishes I ordered though. The dry fried chicken wings have a good, sweet and spicy flavor, but does not have that immense delicious flavor that Santung's chicken wings has. Also, the skin was not fried crispy enough. The green onion pancakes were thin, yellow, doughy, and not very flavorful. I prefer the thicker, oilier, crispier kind with more green onion flavor. The last dish we ordered was the dan dan mien...aka...sichuan-style noodle in peanut sauce (what it's called on the menu). Although there is a chili pepper sign next to this dish on the menu, I was looking for a non-spicy version. The waiter let me know it's not really spicy, but it turned out to be pretty spicy! Spice levels do vary per person, but there is no way this couldn't be called spicy! Later, the manager informed us there was no way they could make this dish non-spicy. In addition to the spiciness, the noodles were a little on the hard side. 

The service was polite, but not super efficient. Items that I had asked for (extra spoon, water, etc.) were brought very late. I came to Dumpling Kitchen on a Sunday evening, the restaurant was busy, and there was a short wait. Overall, food was okay, but for each item, I've had better tasting versions at other Chinese restaurants.
author: Jean S.

description:
My sister, my cousin and I came here today for lunch after my sister's final. We were starving so we order lots of food, but it was also to take home later for another cousin. We got the Mongolian beef with rice lunch dish, Shanghai pork dumplings (which was the main reason I wanted to come), wontons in chili oil sauce, green onion pancake, salt and pepper fried chicken, pan fried potstickers, as well as an order of the crispy egg puff all for three people dining in. 

The Mongolian beef lunch dish was big enough for I think two people to finish as a meal in itself. The beef was tender and we'll seasoned. The onions and peppers took up a large portion of the dish but they were also well seasoned and the onions were sweet which I liked.

The shanghai pork dumplings were juicy and very flavorful. An order comes with 10 dumplings. Really enjoyed them :)

The wontons in chili oil sauce were pretty good. I'm not quite sure what it was but there was some sort of nut butter smell. Either way it was good.
