The green onion pancake was different from other ones I have tried. They were thin and very crispy. They also had sesame seeds in it. I would order that again if I ever make my way back. :)

The pan fried potstickers were perfectly fried on the bottom. Very tasty.

For the salt and pepper chicken, we actually meant to order the chicken wings but we accidentally ordered the chicken pieces. These were okay but the breading was too thick for my liking but the flavor was good on the pieces with the crumble of garlic and salt and pepper. The other pieces were not salty enough. I probably would not order these again.

Lastly, I loved the crispy egg puff! They were a real puff. So airy and crispy and kind of light. Would definitely get again :)

Service was fast and since we came in early, there was no wait.
author: Linda T.

description: We were given raw dumplings and told that pork is supposed to look pink.
author: Margaret R.

description:
A little something for everyone. I like this place. There's almost always a wait though. 
XLBs, sticky rice roll, hot soymilk, and chilled tofu with preserved egg. This is what I almost always order depending on who I am with. 

XLBs are decent. Pretty darn juicy but the skin is a little on the thick side. I love the sticky rice roll and the chilled tofu with preserved egg has so much garlic in it you could kill Edward Cullen (Sorry not sorry, I fcking hate Twilight). 

Very affordable. Come early because there's almost always a line , parking sucks.
author: Susy C.

description:
Not the best dumplings I've had in SF, but it did hit the spot :)

Every true dumpling test definitely falls to the XLBs; naturally we ordered that along with the wontons in chile sauce and the Singapore chow mein. 

Sadly, the XLBs did not hold up to our expectations. They were lacking in filling and the dumpling skin dried out very quickly. Surprisingly, the wontons were much better though a bit bland. Nothing that a little extra soy + chili oil didn't solve :)

The noodles were just okay. Naturally a bit greasy and also a little bland in flavoring (a little dash of soy helped these as well)

Overall, the experience as average and nothing stood out. King of Dumpling being just a block away does give some solid competition to this place
author: Jay P.

description: I have never left a review on yelp, but i felt the need to say that this was the best chinese food ive ever had. If you are thinking about going then you should definitely go.
author: Jordan M.

description:
I came here on a Friday evening shortly after 8pm (Kitchen closes at 9pm). The place was busy but there were plenty of open tables. We were seated promptly with no wait.

Service is incredibly fast. Almost immediately, we were served with tea. About 3 minutes in, we placed our order of : Xi Long Bao, Pan Fried Pork Dumplings, Pork Belly with Preserved Vegetables, 1 bowl of rice (rice costs extra). 

The pork belly was excellent and I would highly recommend getting this dish. There was about 10 pieces of pork belly surrounded by bok choy and piled with preserved vegetables. The dish was steaming hot and came about 5 minutes after our order. The XLB came second and it was  equally as satisfying. I loved the thin wrapper and the flavorful soup. It has a strong ginger taste and the pork inside it was delightful. Recommend eating this with the vinegar sauce on the table. The last dish was the pan-fried pork dumplings. They were pretty good but I probably wouldn't order it again. The pork tasted similar to the XLB - replace the XLB with a bun outside and you'd have your dish. Those to dishes are too close in similarity for me.

Overall: Fast service, no wait, accepts credit cards. Order XLB and pork belly with preserved vegetables.
author: Nicole J.

description: I would say this is one of the best dumpling places in town. I have tried a few and as far as pricing and quality and quantity, this place has it all. Make sure you get the dumplings though. That is what they are known for. The chili wontons are good as well if you like spicy. I never really have to use the soy sauce or anything with their dumplings here which says a lot! Of course it doesn't compare to Din Tai Fung, but for something in San Francisco, its pretty good and convenient for me.
author: Tony C.

description:
My new favorite XLB place. Its pretty close to kingdom of dumpling (love that place as well) but the wait here isn't as bad as kingdom of dumpling.  Their menu isn't as big when it comes to dumplings but there are plenty of other items to order.

XLB: 4.5/5: They are extremely tasty! It has a good skin, so it holds the soup in quite well. The soup is tasty, theres also plenty of tasty pork filling. I actually didn't like their crab and pork XLB as much just because it tasted a little fishy.

Soymilk: 5/5: Tasted so fresh and it was delicious, it wasn't sweet but really smooth. Definitely getting this again next time!

Shanghai chow mein: 4/5: had thick noodles, they were slightly greasy but had a good amount of veggies and chicken and they were not bland at all. I definitely like this noodle dish here. 

I will be back here in the future, prices are reasonable and the food is good! 

Total for 2: $40
author: Stella J.

description:
Haven't gotten around to trying this place but my mom loves this place...so we came here for dinner tonight. The wait was about 20-25 mins for a table but that's not bad considering how there were 5 parties ahead of us when we first signed in. The wait staff also moves pretty quick, which is good. My mom is one of those customers who like to sit at big tables and the hostess was willing to give us the big table but I glanced at the wait list and felt bad to be "one of those customers", so I got my mom to settle for a smaller table since it was just us 3 anyway. 
We ordered the chow mein, clay pot rice, salt and pepper chicken wings, green onion pancake, pan fried pot stickers and a glass of sweetened soy milk. The service was great! Everything came out pretty quickly. The chow mein was really good and not overly greasy. The green onion pancake was crisp and definitely not dry. The salt and pepper chicken wings were fried nicely and the meat was juicy on the inside as well. The potstickers were amazing!! There was so much flavor and juice from the filling, it was great! I didn't get to try the clay pot rice since I was so full but my mom loves it. As for the sweetened soy milk, it was pretty good too. 
Ugh I left feeling so satisfied and full. I will definitely be back!
author: Coco L.

description: Pretty good. XLB skins a bit thick but reasonable XLB  flavor.
author: Dave C.

description:
Yelp rave about this place. Nothing special about the place. I have better dumplings and food. 
place is so so, bathroom simple and atmosphere is ok. 
Server are friendly and prompt..wait takes awhile to get things corrected. parking is also hard.
author: Marlui A.

description: We had Dumpling Kitchen as dinner on our first night in San Francisco. The food was amazing! Some of the best I've ever had. Everything was fresh and very quick to come out. This was a great option for our first dinner in the city. The only downside was that the service could have been a little better.  But the food is worth it!
author: Jessica R.

description: The food here is really good and the place is clean. I will definitely go back. The only issue I have is that they don't have a changing station for my 3 month old daughter. Its a little tight in the restaurant but it is definitely worth it. I recommend the pan fried pot stickers!!!
author: Ashley S.

description: I'm always in search of the best dumplings in the city and this is my favorite place yet! The XLB are flavorful, tender, and do not fall apart when you pick them up. Other favorites here: pan fried pork buns, wontons in chili oil, string beans, and shanghai style chow mein. The wait can be long on weekends so plan ahead. I will come back here again and again and again!
author: Melissa B.

description:
Been here twice, I considered this to be a better than average XLB place but it's expensive and it's not fall to the floor delicious, hence 3 stars. We got the XLB (crab) and it was $10.50, the skin was thick and the XLB itself wasn't too juicy - disappointed. 

Also got the pan fried bun and that skin was also too thick and the meat was not super flavorful. The potstickers saved the day with its thinner skin and more flavorful meat. Other friends got the chicken chow mein and it was huge portions and the other friend got their beef stew noodles and completely demolished it signifying it was probably pretty decent.

The service is slow and they tried to tell us not to sit down since their kitchen was closing in 30 mins (which I think is a reasonably long time from then because we got there at 8:30 and they close at 9:30). Oh also, I got food poisoning from the pork belly dish and was vomiting all night but I had since forgotten that incidence. 

Their soy milk drink here on the weekend is pretty good though, I'd have to say it's my favorite part of the meal.
author: Vanessa K.

description: Best XLBs in the city!  Even their potstickers are delicious and juicy.  We've tried many other restaurants for XLBs but we always compare them to Dumpling Kitchen.  Still can't find another restaurant that can beat them!  The skin isn't overly thick where you only taste the wrapper and their meat is plump and juicy and not at all dry.  Parking can be difficult, but worth it if you're craving dumplings!  Most of the time, there's a wait and you'll have to write your name on the list.  But on those late afternoon off hours, the restaurant can be somewhat empty.  That's the best time to go!
author: A. C.

description: You can get A U T H E N T I C  Cantonese Dim Sum dishes for a reasonable price in San Francisco.  We ordered pork dumplings, fried rice and few other dishes between 5 people and only had to pay $ 10-13 each.
author: Hirofumi M.

description:
I FRIGGEN LOVE DUMPLING KITCHEN!!! This place is now my new go-to for satisfying any and all of my dumpling-related needs.

The xio long bao, artfully made Shanghainese soup-dumplings, are made with a great wrapper:meat ratio and are literally bursting with delicious soup! 

The food is as cheap as it is delicious: ridiculously so!! Each dish is about $8 and the portions are generous. 

Aside from the waitress smelling like very strong Bengay one time, (which I can't hold against her- the stuff works) my experiences here have been nothing but perfect!
author: Stephen D.

description:
I don't think you can make reservations here, but we put our name down and got seated in 30 minutes on a Friday night.  The place had no music, had stark lighting, and low/minimal service... but the place was swarming!  We ordered a variety of things and had some favorites.  We look forward to coming back here sometime to try some other options:

Salt and Pepper Dry Chicken - tasty and flavorful.
Chili Wontons- It sounded very tasty on the menu, but it was a bit soggy and tasted like peanut butter.  Perhaps they used peanut oil?
Shanghai noodles/rice cakes - Our friend who is a veteran at Dumpling Kitchen recommended this dish and it was a winner!  The rice cakes are very thin and mixed in with delicious vegetables and pork. 
XLB - I came here for the soupy dumplings and they did not disappoint.  I had to remind myself to share with the group.  :)
Twice cooked pork belly - Again, it sounded tasty on the menu, but it was okay.  They were very generous on the pork belly, but it may have needed to be mixed with a different vegetable or sauce.

Glad to have found another dumpling place to satisfy my cravings!
author: Helen T.

description:
I love xiao long bao. If you haven't had them before, they're basically dumplings that contain soup inside. I don't know why, but I love that. There's something fun about trying to eat dumplings without spilling the soup inside the dumplings all over my plate. It's like a little challenge I don't get tired of. So when I read reviews about how great the xiao long bao were here, I had to go try them.

My family and I spent forever deciding on what we wanted to get. And I think the other customers thought we were weird because we kept looking around to see what everyone was eating. I'd tell my sister, "That looks good. What do you think that is?" And every time a server brought out another dish, we'd go, "Ooh, that looks good."

We finally decided to order one order of xiao long bao which are Shanghai style steamed pork dumplings, a plate of the dry braised string beans with rice (lunch special), Beijing style boiled pork and chive dumplings, seafood chow mein, and a glass of sweet soy milk. 

The xiao long bao were as good as the reviews say. The dumplings were served in a wooden bamboo tray in a set of 10. They were warm and filled with delicious soup and pork with a hint of ginger. I hope to return soon and order them again. 

The Beijing style boiled pork and chive dumplings were okay, but they didn't amaze me like the xiao long bao. Maybe it's because the dumplings weren't as flavorful. These dumplings were filled with pork and chive and also a hint of ginger. 

The dry braised string beans with rice was also very delicious. It was part of their lunch special and I felt that it was a generous portion. The dry braised string beans were stir fried with finely chopped onions and preserved vegetables, which enhances its flavors. This dish was very flavorful and more on the salty side, but perfect if you're eating with rice. I did feel that they were a little bit on the oily side. However, if you're okay with that, this is definitely a plate you should consider ordering. 

The seafood chow mein was delicious, but also a little more on the oily side. It was filled with fried fish filets and shrimp along with chopped yellow and green onions and julienned carrots. The noodles aren't the thin egg noodles but the thicker lo mein type of noodles. It was tasty and flavorful and I would consider ordering it again.

The sweet soy milk was nothing special. It was slightly sweetened and warm and perfect with the meal. I would have enjoyed it more if I weren't so full from the rest of my meal.

A few tips regarding this place. It is extremely crowded. There is a constant line out the door. Make sure to write your name on the waitlist the moment you get there. Also you want to open to the idea of sharing a large table with other guests. If you're not, it might take a lot longer for your group to be seated since it's always filled. Although they didn't charge me, the bottom of the menu does recommend that we bring our own containers. If we don't, we get charged 25 cents per container. I have never seen that before so my family and I had a good laugh when we saw that little fine print at the bottom.

I recommend coming here if you're a fan of dumplings. They have a good selection of them. But they also have a large selection of other foods too. You have a lot of choices to pick from. A little pricy for the dumplings but it's so worth it because that's what they're known for. So definitely give this place a try. But be prepared for the wait.
author: Andrea G.

description: Great shrimp Kum pow but the tofu and vegetables should be called tofu and mushrooms. Loved the pot stickers will return for those! Smells heavenly inside and real fast service, a dish came before my sapporo lol
author: Ricki M.

description:
The most whatever experience of my life.

I wish I liked it more but I just wish I would have eaten anywhere else.

All of the food was so bland and nothing stood out.

I hope we just ordered all the wrong stuff and would be so open to suggestion. 

Eggplant was good, rice cake ok, dumpling was sad.

Service wasn't service but that's ok if that's not a part of what they do, I just felt like I was bothering them when I ordered/ was there at all.

Wouldn't go back unless guided by someone who vouched for them.
author: TC B.

description: This is, indeed, as good as it gets. Arrive right when they open and you will be treated to the freshest dumplings you've ever tasted. This "mom and pop" shop is the real deal. Order the house specials. Don't try to order anything off the menu (including hot mustard).
author: Ericka L.

description: Best soup dumplings I've ever had! I'm living in SF for the summer and have been here twice and plan on going here one more time before I leave!
author: Lauren V.

description:
I feel like Dumpling Kitchen is just a very standard dumpling place.

Their XLB was good but not mindblowing - I've had better. The skin on the XLB was thicker than I had anticipated. Their pan fried potstickers were also pretty good, I think I enjoyed those most.

Stay away from the green onion pancake - has no flavor and is greasy.

Service is your normal Asian restaurant service, they want you in and out and fast as possible. 

 3 stars for decent food and decent prices. Maybe would come back if we were in the area and craving dumplings.
author: Kimberly H.

description: This is not the place for Dumpling. The steam pork dumpling's skin is thick. The pork inside is dry. The frozen one selling at Asian supermarket even better. The noodle soup is salty. Fried noodles are too greasy. We will not go back again.
author: Susan L.

description: Most amazing Authentic Chinese style (shanghainese) breakfast ever. Really brings out the home flavors and takes me back to the Chinese breakfast food stands I used to go to as a child. This is a must try for those of you who miss those home flavors. Definitely get the full experience by getting the soup dumplings, the pan fried pork buns, and Shanghai style stir fried rice cakes. Last but not least you have to wash all the grease down with delicious hot soy milk! :D so yummmm. I'm definitely coming back again!
author: Sherica L.

description: This place has the best dumplings I have ever have. It was super busy and we had to wait, but omg when the food arrived. Sooo good!!!! Get the #1. It will be the best decision of your life.
author: Mary K. H.

description:
Oh baby yes! My new go to dumpling place! This place is sooooo good. Anyways, I'm a pork eater so everything I ordered consisted of pork. 

We decided on the pork dumplings in chili oil. They said it was going to be spicy, but it wasn't at all. So no fret on the heat. We also got the pan fried pork dumplings. I've never had them before, but this place turned me into a huge fan. It's a must get. I also ordered the shanghai dumplings because who wouldn't? Soup dumplings are the ish. Last thing we got was the twice cooked pork belly with leeks - DONT DO IT! It was so salty and basically inedible. 

Come for the dumplings and eat your heart out cause I'll be back.
author: Kenitha Y.

description: This place is large and clean. The drunk chicken which was served in a good portion has a hint of Chinese wine. It also came with a delicious oily ginger sauce on the side. The green onion pancakes were very impressive. They were flaky and crispy and most importantly double layered. Most places mess it up by making it soft and single layered. The soup dumplings as expected were served piping hot and contained a reasonable amount of broth. I was disappointed that I could not taste the the crab in the crab soup dumplings, which made it not much different than the pork soup dumplings.
author: James S.

description:
The two stars are for their friendly service.

Cons:
You'll find animal feces outside their restaurant while you wait to be seated.

My husband and I went their for some take out and when we got home we found a pincher bug in our Dry Chicken.

Inspect your food before consumption.
author: Maryann B.

description: Great! In a cute neighborhood with muni running right past the front door. Quick service and amazing fresh food. We will definitely be back!
author: Deanna R.

description:
I've not made enough rounds to say if this has the "best" xiao long bao (XLB), but I will say they have a damn good one. I recently went in with my boyfriend for a late dinner. Even though it was a weeknight, it was still pretty busy. Thankfully, we got the second to last table before it was at full capacity. 

We ordered the XLB, shredded pork with string beans, and Shanghai-style pan-fried rice cakes. First, the XLB was on point. It came out hot, but didn't scald our tongues upon first bite. It was juicy, meaty, and the dumpling wrapper wasn't too thin or too thick. The soup came out runny, savory, and slightly sweet. Now, as a couple other Yelpers noted, I was shocked to find there wasn't the signature slivered ginger and soy sauce-vinegar mixture to dip in. That was a total bummer. I was looking forward to having that sit on my spoon with the XLB. Oh well. Nevertheless, the XLB themselves were delicious. Second, the shredded pork with string beans were tasty. I was surprised they weren't cooked down a little more. Typically, these long beans are stir fried until the skins are a little more wrinkled. (Maybe they're not the same type of string beans?) At any rate, the dish was very good and, of course, was even better with a steaming cup of jasmine rice. Third, the pan-fried rice cakes were pretty good: fair balance of meat and vegetables. It needed a tad more salt to round it out though. 

Service was efficient. Dinner came with your standard hot tea. Overall, Dumpling Kitchen is 4-star material: solid value, good portions, all-around tasty.
author: James Z.

description: Delicious xiao long bao! Found this spot to eat lunch after Bay to Breakers with a party of 6. We had about a 20 min wait. We ordered right away- food was amazing, and satisfied my craving for dumplings! The winner though, was the salt and pepper fish- probably my favorite dish at Dumpling Kitchen and the best I've ever had! It was perfectly fried, hot, and seasoned. Definitely recommend checking out this place if you are in SF.
author: Jessica Y.

description: Best place in town for authentic shanghai cuisine. Dumplings are a must but so is their home made soy drink. Their rice cake dish is my favorite -- it's like a noodle dish cooked with onions and goes well with other dishes. Their pan-fried dumplings and chicken wings are delicious and cooked well! They accept reservations too.
author: Kerry K.

description:
This place is SO GOOD that I don't even know where to begin describing just why this is the BEST dumpling place in the city. Let me give this a try anyways.. 

This restaurant serves dumplings and its kingdom is the great city of San Francisco. I'd visit Dumpling Kitchen over Shanghai Dumpling King and Kingdom of Dumplings any day of the week (give me a note if there's another dumpling place I should try). 

+ Food: The XLB, pan fried buns and green onion pancake are all VERY good. The real must try here is the Egg Puff Doughnuts. HOLY CRAP! These things must be the pride of the Kitchen. I actually ask the waitress to bring those out before any of the other food. I don't mess around with my desserts and I can't have all this delicious chinese food fill up my Egg Puff Doughnut stomach. Order it. You won't regret it.
  
+ Service: The staff is very nice and the kitchen is very fast. This place can get crazy busy but the servers all keep their cool like real professionals and get people in and out. Props to the team for bringing their A game each and everyday.

+ Experience: The whole experience is just phenomenal. The restaurant is larger than both Shanghai Dumpling King and Kingdom of Dumplings. They can accommodate large groups and I believe they also accept reservations. Parking isn't too bad in the area and also right off the L line. 

Absolutely a 5 star establishment. I come here just for those tasty Egg Puffs. Everything else is just a really, really sweet bonus. Their whole menu is really solid. Dumpling Kitchen reigns supreme. I highly recommend a visit to try these mythical Egg Puffs.
author: Chris W.

description: Really soupy dumplings! Definitely a go to place for our Shanghai dumpling cravings. Their rice cakes are amazingly tasty, but their fried you tiao is too hard, and their green onion pancakes are not the best. Strangely, the green onion pancakes were too fluffy and pastry like. Their red bean cake is absolutely delicious though. Will definitely make the trek out here again!
author: Ke C.

description:
My friend was able to come first and put our name down. We only waited for about 10 minutes for a party of 4 on a Sunday, but it was getting pretty crowded when we got seated. We had the shanghai style stir-fry chow mein noodles, green onion pancake, savory soy milk with chinese fried donut, dry fried chicken wings, green onion pancake, and two orders of xiao long bao. 

The shanghai noodles were thicker than most places and had a nice chewy texture to it. There was chicken, green and white onion, and carrots. The dish had an overall tasty flavor. 

The green onion pancake was definitely different than the regular crispy green onion pancake. This green onion pancake was huge, light, and fluffy! It reminded me of the Indian naan bread. I think I prefer the regular crispy green onion pancake that I am used to having. I like the texture and overall taste better. I felt like this green onion pancake was lacking in flavor. It was bland and did not have a lot of green onion in it. 

The soy milk (savory) was also bland. I have tried this before at a different restaurant and it tasted better there. However, I do prefer the plain sweet soy milk over the savory. We wanted to try something different so we tried the savory. The savory soy milk has Chinese fried donut in it already, along with drops of chili oil. 

The dry-fried chicken wings were tasty. I definitely tasted the soy sauce, honey, and garlic flavor. 

The xiao long bao was pretty good. The skin was definitely not too thick or too doughy. I prefer thin skin and the broth was tasty.
author: Kimberly H.

description: Perfect cold weather brunch!! The service was quick - had dumplings, beef and green beans, and eggplant - portions were large.
author: Janet C.

description: My friend was visiting from Colorado and wanted soup dumplings.  We had both the steamed and fried ones, as well as a few other options.  Everything was good and there was no wait around 1pm on a Saturday, so I'm sure I'll be back.
author: Seong P.

description:
I would first like to say that the service was definitely a-ok. Average, but not superb. The lady that took our order asked if we wanted a veggie dish because we didn't have one. Like a mother. Sweet. Not much more contact afterwards but I liked it that way. The wait to be seated was 20-30 minutes on a Friday night - understandable. The food arrived very quickly, within 10 minutes. Eating took about the same time as the seating wait.

The food was mehh to average. I've definitely had better XLBs elsewhere - barely any soup and the skin was too thick, I think. The Drunken Chicken was the smallest dish I've ever seen. The Wontons in Chili Oil was good but not as spicy as I would've imagined. The Lion Head Meatballs in the House Soup was my favorite! It says there are 4 meatballs, but don't be fooled - they're HUGE!!!

Not the best but I'll definitely give this place another chance though - maybe not on a Friday night though.
author: Athena C.

description: I was so excited to discover this place because it offered all the delicious styles of dumplings without the ridiculous wait that is the norm these days at other popular spots. Freshly made, flavorful, and great quality.
author: Briget P.

description: Great service, delicious food. I do t usually like Chinese but this is fresh, authentic and left us feeling great!
author: Patsy D.

description:
Search for THE BEST XLB continues...

We ordered one XLB dumplings (10 pieces), one Shanghai friend dumplings (10 pieces), green onion pancake, and sweet fresh soy milk. 

I think the best thing I've had here was the fresh soy milk, which is not what you're looking for in a dumpling restaurant. 

The XLB came out SOOOO tiny! No room for soup! Why make them so tiny?! Yes they tasted great, but I want soup in my soup dumplings. Also, when you get them, they should be piping hot, burn your mouth because you're so excited to eat hot. Here, not so hot. 

The Shanghai pan fried dumplings were though! They were piping hot and had a nice crunch to go along with the doughyness of the dumpling. If I could be super picky, the dough was so sweet it overwhelmed the meat. 

Last and least the green onion pancake is a pass. Not worth ordering. 

OVERALL: not coming back. 
(My goodness they don't even give you ginger and the vinegar sauce unless you ask )
author: Davina B.

description:
This one is a winner in my book!

Tofu seafood soup was good.

XLB /pork dumpling is the bomb- affordable too!
The vegetable dumpling was also yummy. Serving of the dumplings are good for 2 people (10 pieces per order).

My little girl was ecstatic and loved the egg puff pastry.

We will be back!
author: kyra d.

description:
Came here from the East Bay last Friday to check out the xian long baos. I invited my elderly parents to come along to experience shanghai food with me and my kid. I was actually nervous to bring them to something new because they're super critical and unfiltered about their food. Thank goodness Dumpling Kitchen turned out live up to its ratings and reviews on yelp. We ordered a lot of dishes, since driving over the bridge is like crossing an ocean for us,  we (I) wanted to get the most out of the experience.

Xian Long Baos - hell yeah! 5 stars
Green onion pancakes - 5 stars
Shanghai style pan-fried pork buns - 5 stars
Steamed vegetable dumpligns - 5 stars
Shanghai style rice cakes - 5 stars
Zah Jian Mian - hella good!! 5 stars
Spicy fried chicken wings - meh 2 stars
Crispy egg puffs - Surprise of the whole meal...you know when you're hella full and can't really eat one more bite? Then you're like I need to try just a bite to taste it. And then it's like OMG! This is hella good!! 5 stars plus a bonus because it was THAT good.

I'm craving his now as I write this review.
author: kewlby x.

description:
Dumplings are the bomb. I can't speak on behalf of anything else on the menu, but here are my observations:

1) Only 4% of people inside were white so you know it's real
2) Although I was hungover from my birthday the night before, the 9 dumplin' meal I had (shared my 10th with my friend who NEVER tried a dumpling - WHAT?) really helped me cope with my post-bday gloom
3) Everyone I interacted with was super friendly, like the rest of San Francisco :)
author: Alexia S.

description:
XLB = 1 star
If you're looking solely to get your XLB fix then this doesn't cut it. The pictures from Yelp doesn't do justice either since the appealing ones are from 3-5 years ago. In present day, they are a lot smaller, dry, and the soup is bland(that's if you actually get some soup in the dumplings). 

On the other hand, I also ordered the braised pork with veggies and that was 5 stars. The meet was tender and had a lot of flavor. The veggies were delicious as well. The service was excellent as well. We were seated right away and our server always made sure we got what we needed.

Overall, if you're here for XLB and have a very high expectations, i suggest that you keep it low to not be disappointed. Also try their other dishes. They hit the spot for sure.
author: Ron T.

description:
Good dumpling place with a short wait. The portions are huge! Meant for family style sharing.

I had the braised pork belly- tender and soft! It was a big portion so now I can enjoy it for a few more days.

The garlic eggplant was too sweet and didn't taste the garlic at all. I wouldn't order this again.

The pan fried vegetarian dumplings were pretty good- a lil on the salty side.
author: Vanae W.

description: Oh the search for good xiao long bao continues!  These were not bad, but not great either.  The casing was sticky.  The soup inside tasty, but very little.  The meat almost had a ground consistency.  Again, not bad, but not great.  Service left much to be desired.  We were there for Friday lunch, and we often had to flag down our waiter for basic water and the bill.  Street parking available if you're willing to look.
author: T D.

description:
This is my favorite dumpling restaurant by far! The XLBs are always good and decently priced compared to the many other dumpling restaurants. Another one of my favorite dishes is the peanut sauce noodles, which is absolutely delicious! 

The only bad thing is that there is often a wait during lunch hours on the weekends, but the line usually moves pretty fast since most of the food comes out fast.
author: Andy Z.

description: Great #2 XLB to DTF. Dumplings have a lot of soup and great flavor.
author: Alic H.

description:
I'm going to dock 2 stars for cleanliness. The menu, table, and tablecloth were not clean. Some leftover food particles on the dishes. 
Still though, solid 3 stars for food and I've been here 3 times. Nice employees. Sometimes there is a wait, but go slightly outside of lunch and dinner hours and you can get sat right away. 
Delicious soup dumplings. Yummy mushu. Crisp beans in their chicken and green beans. Flavorful tea. All in all, happy to eat here and I'll keep coming back.
author: Heather F.

description:
Due to long lines on other restaurant nearby, me and a friend came here to eat because we couldn't wait on the line any longer. 

We got broccoli and beef, XLB, pork dumplings and sesame chicken. I really liked the pork dumplings and it could compare to the dumplings from kingdom of dumplings. 

Service was friendlier than I thought and the environment was a little on the loud side due to lots of people chatting and it was very crowded too during lunch time. 

Prices were very reasonable, if not they were on the cheaper side. Worth recommending people to try them with families.
author: Jenny L.

description:
The restaurant itself is pretty HUGE and relatively clean compared to Shanghai Dumpling King and Kingdom of Dumpling. There are a lot of tables so the wait is never too long and I'm sure they offer community seating if you're up for it! Service is also pretty fast considering they have to steam all and (possibly) pan fry all their dumplings. I ordered to-go so the young lady helping me was really nice and gave me some good recommendations.

I ended up ordering their pork XLB (aka the Shanghai style steamed pork dumplings), pan fried pork and chive pot stickers, green onion pancake, steamed pork and napa cabbage dumplings, and pork dumplings in chili oil.

XLB: Not the best I've ever had, unfortunately. It was EXTREMELY SALTY!! The skin was nice and thin and the soup burst in your mouth upon eating it, but, I didn't care for the actual soup nor did I like the sauce they provided me with. It was a sweetened soy sauce and vinegar mixture versus the usual red vinegar with thinly sliced ginger. I guess I should have asked for it since I ordered to-go. (FYI I tried their XLB right when I stepped in my car so it was still fresh!)

Pan fired pork and chive pot stickers (aka pan fried pot stickers) and Pork dumplings in Chili Oil: BOTH ARE A MUST TRY! Crispy on the bottom, skin was just right (not too thick and not too thin), filling was nice and juicy--I LOVED everything about these!! (Luckily, I had two orders!!) Again, the sauce they give for the spicy version (since both pot stickers are the same one just comes with spicy chili oil) wasn't all that great and more on the sweet side versus spicy. I preferred eating them plain or dipping them in siracha sauce.

Steamed pork and napa cabbage dumplings: similar to the pan fried pork and chive dumplings except they use napa cabbage instead and it's steamed. Pretty good but I miss that crunchy texture the pan fried pot stickers have. Unless you really like napa cabbage---you can pass on these!

Green onion pancake: SUPER OILY!!!!! I definitely DO NOT RECOMMEND THESE!!! (Refer to my picture of the bag they were given to me in--it's almost see-through due to the amount of oil they use to cook it!!) Wasn't all that great either... similar to naan but I'd rather have garlic naan ANY DAY over this!!

Overall, a decent place to go for dumplings but they really need to improve on their sauces! Using a sweet soy sauce with vinegar mixture for everything  is a no-go! I'd rate their food a 3.5-4/5.
author: Steph M.

description:
At 4pm on a Sunday, this place was already almost filled up! I took this as a good sign! My family and I were pretty hungry and was ready to order as soon as we sat down. It didn't take too long for the food to come out, which was great!

We ordered two orders of xiao long bao. The soy sauce they have is really salty, but the dumpling itself was good! The shanghai stir fried rice cake was devoured instantly. Some of the rice cakes were overcooked as they stuck to your mouth, but the taste made up for it. The wonton soup was very cleansing as well. The dry fried chicken wings kind of tasted like it was coated in orange chicken glaze, which was a decently good marinade!

Wouldn't mind coming back if I was ever in the area!
author: Steven C.

description:
Came on a Sunday right when they opened. The place is small so filled up fast. Ordered two number 1 dumplings and dry fried chicken wings; hot/sweet soy milk and a donut. 

Dumplings were plump and juicy. The liquid was held perfectly inside the little pouches of deliciousness. The ginger vinegar dipping sauce was perfect compliment to the dumplings - careful not to put too much. 

The dry fried wings were not bad. Sticky, sweet and has a nice kick. 

If you come, get here before 11 on weekends to avoid long wait times. Service was fast and friendly.
author: Margaret W.

description: Read Yelp reviews and ordered steamed dumplings, pan fried dumplings, green onion pancake, and fried chicken wings. All delicious and would order again.
author: Blair R.

description:
A very homey style restaurant that serves food your grandma would make. The XLB are always a good choice - juicy, with tender meat, and wrapping. I'm also a big fan of the rice cakes with pork and preserved veggies - that's a must pretty much every time we come.

It can get pretty packed during peak times, so to walk on come in before 6pm to beat the typical dinner crowd.
author: Vi N.

description: Great, fast service with reliably yummy food. Watch out the veggie dumplings are more bitter tasting than I had expected, but the pan fried pork dumplings are amazing!
author: Zoe B.

description:
The shanghai dumplings are what most people come here for and I think they are just ok. In the bay area there really isn't that many restaurants with memorable XLBs. I came here on a Sunday night and there was a short wait (20-30 mins) which really isn't that bad considering that SF is a city where waiting in line is part of the norm. We ordered the garlic with shoots, wontons in chili oil, and XLB. The wontons tasted exactly like the XLD in a different skin and soupless. But then again the XLB we got were dried on top (tip was doughy and hard) and the soup was barely there. Normally the XLB is served with ginger and vinegar but this place only had vinegar. As for the garlic with shoots, they were made to perfection. This was probably the only dish I truly enjoyed.

Over all thoughts...it was just mehhh.
author: Tiffany C.

description: I always order the soup dumplings and the braised pork belly. Since the first time I've tried this place, I have always come back. Sometimes there's a wait, sometimes there's no one- but more than not you'll probably be waiting in line. Despite that everything else is pretty good.
author: Jessica L.

description:
I had a really excellent meal at Dumpling Kitchen. Attentive service, fresh food, and a price that can't be beat. 

We got veggie dumplings and pot stickers (they are the same thing, just PS = VD's fried on one side). Great veggie option, with a good filling of mixed veggies, a little tofu and mushrooms. The egg crispy puffs were great as well.

It was a great meal, and we ended up getting out of there for $11/person including tip. 

However, I left feeling a little over salted, and that it wasn't exactly a balanced meal, but that might just be b/c I didn't know how to order.

Definitely would come back.
author: Ari F.

description: The peanuts are awesome!  As soon as you sit down, they serve a small bowl of five spiced peanuts. Yum!! The teapot is teabag vs leaf, but they use 2 bags for some added flavor.  Ordered crab pork dumplings and chicken wings (to compare with San Tung).  The chicken wings were horrible, and I'm tempted to knock a star off just for that.  They were not crispy, and seemed as if they were just boiled and then sauce poured on top.  The sauce was tasty, but the chicken was not prepared properly.  Please go to San Tung to see the difference.  The dumplings:  EXCELLENT, and perhpaps the best I've had in SF or the Bay Area (mind you, I haven't been to the new Din Tai Fung yet).  The wrapper was super thin, good amount of soup and tender, melt in your mouth tasty filling at the right temperature.  I would definitely return for the dumplings, but no way for the wings.
author: Brian K.

description: Ok, my friend and I got here, stood for five mins and they ppl that were working seem like they didn't even know we were here. Finally when I asked them "do we just sit ourselves??" he then asked how many do u have. WTH, so inattentive. After we sat down and the waitress gave us a pot of tea then left, BUT WHERES THE MENU?! Ugh...food was alright, I've had better. Order crab meat XLB, pork XLB, and the braised pork belly with preserve veggie. Maybe i'll go back in the future, just maybe. I actually like kingdom of dumpling more even though that place is soooooooo small
author: Jenny M.

description:
This place is as good as it gets. I rarely head to the Sunset area. However, I was out at Sutro Baths shooting some photos with a friend, and we decided that we should probably eat out in the Richmond/Sunset area considering that we were rarely in the area. We rode out to Dumpling Kitchen -- apparently this place is his go-to area.

We ordered the following between three people:
1) REGULAR XIAO LONG BAO: YOU MUST GET THIS. It's the greatest bang for your buck - 10 XLBs for $7.50? You can do no wrong? Also, it was AMAZING.
2) SHANGHAI-STYLE PAN FRIED PORK BUNS: I think that's what it's called. In Cantonese, it's called "san jeen bao." -- Anyhow, you must get this as well! It was a great yummy in my tummy.
3) BEAN SPROUTS: I don't know what they put in here, but it was definitely crack. Something about it made it sooooo good and so crispy.
4) SPICY BRISKET NOODLES: It was good -- but I've had better. You can probably skip this.
5) DRY FRIED CHICKEN: A lot of people love this -- and it's REALLY good, but I felt like it was pretty heavy for me at the end.

Honestly guys, I think I could've just ordered two baskets of XLBs and I would've been happy. This place is AMAZING for Chinese food.
author: Joanne W.

description:
Xiao long bao is a must whenever I visit a friend of mine in San Francisco! We recently just dined here, making it our second time together with our other good friends. It was on around 7:30PM on a Saturday night both times. The wait wasn't long even though the place was filled with customers. The place gets warmer and warmer as you dine. Bewarn: you'll need to shed layers or just eat fast.

Food:
Shanghai Dumplings (Xiao Long Bao) 10 pcs- A staple whenever you visit a Shanghainese restaurant! It's better at Shanghai Dumpling King over in the Richmond district. There weren't that much soup within the dumpling and sort of plain.

Shanghai Chow Mein- Udon-like thickness noodles that taste like regular Chinese chow-mein. Not my favorite. It's harder than I like, not that flavorful and oily.

Chicken Wings- Regular friend chicken wings. I love chicken wings, so it was yummy.

Spinach with garlic- It's okay.

Egg puffs- Love love love egg puffs!! No complaints :) Sugar coated donut!

Pricing seems to be $10-15 per person including tax and tip.
author: Winnie T.

description:
I love Dumpling Kitchen!

Located right on Taraval, parking is a bit hard to find during lunch and dinner hours and there is metered parking as well as residential spots around. The restaurant itself isn't wide, but it's sort of long when you get inside and bathrooms are located all the way on the inside. 

Service here is really hit and miss. If you come during dinner, it's super insane and the workers will be rushing around and may forget to give you attention until you flag them down. It's really hard to say how service will be because sometimes it'll be good and sometimes you'll get this bored server who would rather spend time playing on his phone than focusing on his customers. Yeah, talking to you... one dude who's name I don't even want to know because you gave poor service.

Food here is good, though, provided you stay away from the noodle dishes. Their xiao long bao as well as dumplings are pretty darn good. And so is their green beans. The prices are also decent for the amount you get. 

Overall, yeah, I would come here again. I love the food they serve and since I care more about food than service... Yeah.
author: Venus L.

description:
Ventured here this past Sunday and I have to say that their food is delicious. They're XLB was pretty amazing. It was the right amount of of juiciness and the texture was great. Really well made! I came here at 8:25 and was half expecting to be rejected for a table. Luckily, we were seated and the whole experience eating here was quite enjoyable. For a party of two, we ended up 10 pork XLBs and the Shanghai style noodles. Oh my god, those noodles were so chewy in texture AND savory in flavor, it was definitely a match made in heaven with my tastebuds' preferences. Anyway, the food came out fairly quickly and I thoroughly enjoyed my meal. Will most definitely come back again. Heck--I probably can finish the entire order of XLB myself, if I let myself be gluttonous. Oink Oink!

P.S. the bill came out to be around ~$23 in total, with decently sized portions= amazing deal!
author: Denise L.

description:
Dumpling Kitchen is a nice place to get your xiao long bao (XLB) fix! Many Asian foodies will wax poetic about how wonderful and amazing XLB is. Unfortunately, I haven't had that many and I haven't found one that lives up to the hype.

That being said, I do think Dumpling Kitchen is an A-OK place to get your fix. They are flavorful and do have a nice delicate skin with the soup inside. However, I would like to have more soup inside. In addition, if you wait too long to eat them (or if you take too long to reach the end of the platter), the soup seems to magically disappear. I assume it soaks into the meat or skin, which is disappointing.

You can also get other Chinese foods here, but I do think it's a bit bland. But most people won't want an entire meal of dumplings, so the other options are here.

Service is pretty barebones, but fairly polite for a Chinese restaurant. They'll bring your tea, take your order, bring your food out, and that's about it. Time between ordering an getting your food is highly dependent on how busy the restaurant is. Expect to wait if you come for lunch on the weekend, especially with a big party.

Sadly I'm still on the prowl for a magical XLB that will knock my socks off. Until then, I have good ole' Dumpling Kitchen to tide me over.
author: Denise C.

description: Their Xiao Long Bao is delicious! It is flavorful and juicy! The XLB skin is slightly thicker than Din Tai Phung, but it still had good texture. Hidden gem!
author: Tamy N.

description:
On my most recent visit here, we ordered:
steamed XLB- ugh it's so delicious you have to get this. The skin/wrapping isn't too thick, but it's not so thin where it'll pop when you pick it up. Juicy, flavorful heaven.
pan fried XLB- Not bad, but I feel like the bottoms weren't fried enough. Shanghai House makes them piping hot, and the bottoms are crispy.
wontons in chili oil- what bothered me was these weren't really wontons.. they were like shrimp dumplings wrapped in wonton skin. Maybe I'm being too meticulous. Oh, and it wasn't spicy. The sauce it was in was like a peanut sauce. Would pass on this.

TL;DR: get the steamed XLB.
author: Leslie C.

description:
I felt so sorry for all those customers being fooled by the inauthentic Shanghaiese food!

There should be no ginger in those pork stuffing inside the XiaoLongBao, and the vinegar should not be that sweet! There should be no Chinese pickles inside the pork stuffing in pan fried  dumplings. 

WARNING!!!!Never ever order the DanDan noodle,although it doesn't come from  Shanghai, it tastes awful and all about  white pepper in the sauce!
author: Jason X.

description: Everything is delicious here!!!! Noodles in black bean sauce, pan fried dumplings, and soup with crackling rice. Also got the sweet soy milk and it was excellent.
author: Steph N.

description:
Solid spot. 
I came into Dumpling Kitchen expecting a good meal but left feeling as if I had just cheated on my taxes and gotten away with it! That would never happen...but you get the idea. The bill for this fantastic meal for two with drinks was under $30! 

Dumpling Kitchen satiated my cravings for XLB. The skin of the XLB was thin but thick enough to hold all the delicious contents in when you pick them up. I would prefer for them to be thinner but I'd still come back because these little dumplings are just sooo good! The flavors are comforting and savory and keeps you waiting more.

The sweet soy milk is a must with your meal. 

If you're a penny pincher, you'll leave this spot happy and satisfied. Their portions are generous and most of their items are under $10. 

Cheap. Fast. Delicious.
author: Victoria Q.

description:
There are many locations that serve Shanghai style dumplings, some that are even nearby such as Kingdom of Dumpling, but I find this particular restaurant decent. In comparison to Kingdom of Dumping, this place is much larger and can hold large parties. 

Overall, this place is decent and serves ordinary Chinese food. We ordered the crab and pork dumplings, dry fried chicken wings, and steamed sweet buns for two people. I really enjoyed the dumplings and would come back here again to try out the rest. Another bonus point for the restaurant since the dumplings were not too greasy. The chicken wings were tasty as well and had a lot of flavor. 

The food came out fast and the service itself was decent. There is nothing too exciting or 'over the top wow!' about this place, but I would probably come here instead over to Shanghai Dumpling King or Kingdom of Dumpling if you are not up for a long wait or hate finding parking around the area.
author: Victoria K.

description:
*Posted on behalf of my father who does not have an account*

"I can see the flaw in Yelp the more I read the reviews. 
I admit that we all have different tastes, but the numerous 4-5 stars reviews to this restaurant is astonishing.

My wife and I ordered the following dishes:
- Salted soy milk
- Shanghai fried noodle
- Xian Long Baos
- Green Onion Pan Cake

They weren't especially bad, but not good either.The meat in the xiao long bao had a weird texture, which was loose and cakey, and the vinegar had no sliced ginger.  The Shanghai fried noodles was average, not enough dark soy sauce, and a bit soggy due to too much cabbage in the noodles. 2 stars from me. Check it out yourself with no high expectations. You've been forewarned, but feel free to be your own judge."
author: Bethany C.

description:
Although I've been here at least six times, I've only had a few things from the menu. The Shanghai dumplings are what I come here for but other things I've eaten are also very very good: cucumber salad, hot and sour soup, the scallion pancake, the string beans and the greens. 

If you can go in between lunch and dinner hours the wait isn't usually more than a few minutes. And parking isn't as difficult here as some other neighborhoods.
author: Carolyn S.

description: Best Dumpling spot in the city for the price. Food is delicious, drinks are cheap and big tables for large groups. Sometimes a bit of a wait but they're really accommodating. Fun place to grow your waistline.
author: Daniel P.

description:
We had a pretty large group here last night for a couple of friends' birthdays. For the value, Dumpling Kitchen was pretty good. It's no Michelin star restaurant but a satisfying combination of price, portion, and flavor.

XLB - The skins were way better than I expected at this price point. Their texture was smooth with the right amount of firm chewiness. Just from looking at them, the fine folds at the top was a good sign that the skins would be thin and delicate. They also didn't break open when picked up with chopstick. Not much to complain about there. The stuffing was not the best but still decent for a low end restaurant. The texture of the pork was on the grittier side, and I thought it could've had more ginger and green onions mixed in for more brightness. The broth was similar to the pork stuffing in that it could be brighter and bolder, but it still had good body and was seasoned with enough salt . The broth was also on the fattier side, which doesn't bother me, but I know some people out there prefer cleaner XLB broths. 

Braised Pork Belly with Pickled Vegetables - You can tell this restaurant probably isn't run by Shanghainese people because of kitchen staff yelling at each other in Cantonese, and this is reflected in some of the menu items. This braised pork belly dish is a traditional Hakka classic from southern China, far from Shanghai. Dumpling Kitchen's rendition is actually pretty good. The pork belly was tender, and the sauce was a good balance of sweetness and pickled earthiness. My favorite place to order this is at Hakka Restaurant in the Outer Richmond. If I had to compare the two, Hakka's sauce is thicker and richer with a more complex spice mixture. There's a slight orange peel flavor in Hakka's that separates it from the rest. Despite not being as good as Hakka's, I would have no qualms with getting the pork belly here. 

Green Onion Pancakes - Not really my cup of tea. They have the lighter and fluffier version of green onion pancakes, and I didn't think it had much green onion flavor. It kinda just tasted doughy. The crispy and layered green onion pancakes are way better.

Vegetarian Potstickers - There was a vegetarian in our group so we had an order of vegetarian potstickers. I was kinda surprised because they turned out to be pretty tasty. I probably liked them more than the pork and chive dumplings. There's a good amount of shiitake mushrooms to give it a lot of umami and earthy flavors. They also put in dried tofu (doufu gon), and it's firmer texture and five spice flavor paired well with the other ingredients in the stuffing.

Noodles with Black Bean Sauce - Not good. Sauce was not very savory and didn't taste black bean-y. Noodles were mushy and gross. Skip this.

Egg Puffs (Sah Yong) - Freshly fried and really delicious. They were light, airy, and full of eggy goodness. If I had to complain about something, it's that instead of surrounding the donuts in sugar, it's just poured all on top of the donuts. I just rolled the donut around to get the sugar everywhere.
author: Nei N.

description:
He didn't know what Nutella was.

He didn't know what Pocky was.

A Banh Mi? Umm, forget it, he didn't know what that was either.

SO naturally when I texted him that I was craving XLB (Shanghai Soup Dumplings), he thought it was a typo and that I was craving an X-large 8======D. *Sigh*

I didn't want to wait for a table at Kingdom of Dumpling or Shanghai Dumpling King so I thought Dumpling Kitchen would be a good alternative. It was pretty solid the first time so it was worth another visit.

As compared to Kingdom of Dumpling and Shanghai Dumpling King, Dumpling Kitchen has a small dumpling selection with just 4 choices aside from wontons but I really like their XLBs (10 pieces - $6): http://bit.ly/UGCdW8. Arriving in a bamboo steamer lined with wax paper, the juicy bundles arrive pumping hot and were free of any breakage. The skin is nicely thin yet thick enough to hold everything in. One small bite to let some steam escape, the savory dumplings are then perfect for slurping up all the soup and enjoying the succulent pork filling with an aromatic ginger nuance. 

Not nearly as mouth-watering as the XLB, the Crab and Pork Dumplings (8 pieces - $9.50) were juicy but with a slight fishy taste from the crab: http://bit.ly/REdEa9. I would skip this.

The Dry Fried Chicken Wings ($8) were crisp and moistly tender but the savory sweet sauce was runny and not oooey gooey, finger-licking like San Tung's: http://bit.ly/13gjwJ7. It will satisfy your chicken wing craving though.

A Hakka favorite, the Braised Pork Belly w/ Preserved Veggies ($8.50) is my ultimate Chinese comfort food especially with steamed rice: http://bit.ly/VCt0Ku. The savory pork belly was super tender with a good meat to fat ratio. The preserved veggies helps balance the richness from the pork belly making it a more "guilt-free" dish.

The dinner foul of the night?

He tried to jab and pick up the XLBs with a metal spoon!!!

*Tsk Tsk*

If only I had my feather duster with me...

OTHER NOTES:
*Cheap eats and generous portions. Most dishes are $6-$7 and nothing is over $11.
*Very little MSG used. Besides being a tad thirsty after dinner, I didn't have an MSG allergic reaction (dry mouth, headache, and heart palpitations) as I normally do with Chinese food.
*Service is typical of any Asian restaurant; fast and indifferent. Staff is fluent in English though.
*Dining area is clean, not cramped and well-lit.
*CC's accepted.
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Really liked their xiao long bao and sweetened soy milk!

Came with a friend to catch up and ordered xlb, shanghai stir-fried thick noodles, and pan-fried buns. Decent service for lunch.

Unfortunately, my friend had food poisoning the same night, but I was lucky not to? For that reason, I would recommend for the stronger stomach'd peoples.
author: Sara T.

description:
I came to Dumpling Kitchen for dinner on a Saturday night and it was packed with Asian families. Thankfully, there was one free table left and we shared: 

**XLB: soupy and distinctively gingery. 
**Crab & Pork Dumplings: soupy but I couldn't detect any crab flavor. 
**Peanut Sauce Noodles: fresh, al dente noodles with flavorful peanut sauce that wasn't heavy in peanut flavor. 
**Dry Fried Chicken Wings: not the best wings I've had but they were tasty and had a special charred flavor that I haven't tasted in any kind of wing before. it was a nice surprise. 
**Crispy Egg Puffs: puffy indeed. served with white sugar and was easy to pull apart and eat. a very yummy sweet treat. 

Service wasn't the warmest but it was good enough. Found parking in the residential blocks.
author: Maya S.

description:
I really enjoyed the food at Dumpling Kitchen.  

We had:
Shanghai Dumplings - delicious, there's soup inside. 
Shanghai noodles - thick udon type noodles - delicious!
Green Onion pancake - heavenly delicious! 
Eggplant in Garlic Sauce - not so great. I'll pass next time.

I probably ate about 2,000 calories in less than half hour but it was well worth it! 

I saw some people eating some sort of soup which looked delicious!

The restaurant itself was a lot smaller than I expected so expect a wait. I went at a weird time (3pm) so I was able to walk right in.
author: Mel D.

description:
XIAO LONG BAOSSSS!!!

Dumpling Kitchen has been my go-to place for my family whenever we crave Shanghainesse food. This place is extremely reliable for your craving of xiao long baos or shanghainesse soup dumplings. The soup in the dumplings are perfectly seasoned and are extremely affordable. 

Besides the soup dumplings, the pan-fried rice cakes, veggies, and potstickers are extremely delicious as well! If you are a health freak, you can ask for less oil and less fat when you order.

If you're up for dessert.. Order the Chinese style donuts & homemade soy milk.

I give this place a 4/5 simply because of how crowded it's gotten since its opening. There is always a wait around dinner time for this place.
author: Kary Y.

description: Waited for 45 minutes and the food don't really meet my expectations for authentic dumplings. The fillings are a bit running and the wrap could be better.
author: chloe l.

description: Fantastic no frills place with fabulous noodles and other things. Great for family style and also smaller groups. Cash only or debit card.
author: Jennicer T.

description: Good place to eat xiao long bao and shin jin baos in Sunset. (apologies for the short review. This review is late and that's all I can remember)
author: Justin S.

description:
If you're looking for great xiao long bao at a reasonable price, you've come to the right spot. Located in the Parkside neighborhood, there's not too much going on here and very residential area.

The inside of the restaurant are fairly small so when me and my friend came for dinner, we had to split a table with another party of 3 at one of their larger ten person tables. It was a little awkward, but I guess it wasn't too bad if you don't mind sharing a table with strangers.

We ordered the pork dumplings, pan fried dumplings, and seafood chow mein. Everything was great and satisfying. It was nothing extraordinary, but what they do, they do well.

The only reason for 1 star off is because of the peanuts they served as an appetizer on the table. It was literally like eating cardboard and I wanted to throwup. They were stale and tasteless and should not be served like that.
author: Marvin E.

description: Very delicious and authentic dumpling experience. Steamed comes out in baskets and was delicious. Add a side of rice and we couldn't finish our meal. Definitely a nice change from the very touristy restaurants.
author: Derek H.

description: Best Shanghai dumplings in the sunset. Soup dumplings are THE BEST. I always go for #1 and the Pan-Fried pork dumplings are super delicious too. Honestly, there isn't a single thing I've tried that I didn't love. Great food and fast even when the place is packed.
author: Kayleen R.

description: Good food at a great price. Fast and attentive service. We ordered a variety of dumplings and noodles and they were all very tasty and well made. This place does not take reservations so be prepared to wait for a bit. They also do not take credit cards but they do accept debit. I would definitely revisit this restaurant.
author: Jeff Y.

description:
I visited Dumpling Kitchen for dinner since my girlfriend and I were craving some warm food. The restaurant itself is very simple and there's nothing to flashy about it, just expect good food.

For a group of four we ordered 6 dishes, and of them the standouts include the Shanghai-Style Chow Mein, Shanghai-Style Steamed Pork Dumplings, and the Green Onion Pancake. The chow mein wasn't too oily and I loved the thickness of the noodles. The dumplings were pretty good except I do wish there was more soup on the inside, but on the flip side that leaves less of a chance of it exploding on me so that's okay too. The green onion pancake was nice and flaky so it was nice to have a different texture with all the other food we were eating.

Taste-wise everything was great and the food itself was very filling.
author: Micki H.

description:
I came for the soup dumplings, but found that Dumpling Kitchen has much more to offer than just soup dumplings.

In fact, the soup dumplings were just average. The scallion pancakes were decent. The stir fried rice cakes were delicious, and the giant meat ball casserole was amazing. The sweat soy milk drinks are fresh and memorable.
author: Tunaidi A.

description: Was really excited to try this place out because of the positive review. However, I was kinda disappointed. The dumplings aren't that good and the noodles are oily and doesn't taste that good either.
author: Jessica D.

description: Excellent dumpling joint in sf. When a restaurant is nearly 60-70% full at 330pm on a Saturday you know the food is pretty good.  Prices are pretty reasonable as well.
author: Andrew L.

description:
Yum! I really enjoyed their Shanghai High Dumplings. There are 10 in each order. I had a helping before I went down to LA and once I came back, I came back. I noticed it has a slight sweetness in it. I wonder if it is from the broth or the wrapping. Regardless it is yummy! And so far, none of the ones I had here are popped. 

I also enjoyed their Shanghai High rice cakes which are litterally noodles shaped in ovals! Don't think it is some type of rectangle bar like thing. I like this dish because the "rice cake" has this nice chew. The veggies are also delicious. 

We also had an order of pork dumplings which I don't think was all that great. The two of us could have made do without them and still be full.
author: Jess W.

description:
We came here based on the reviews and I can't say the 4-stars justify the quality that you get that this restaurant.  It didn't start off well when they told us that they didn't have any cold soy milk in stock so we had to settle for the hot soy milk, which I thought tasted nothing special.  It tasted like something that you could buy from 99 Ranch.  We also ordered pork & crab dumpling and this was a HUGE disappointment.  We expected something close to Din Tai Fung but it had this really funky pork smell that gave these dumplings a funny aftertaste.  We also ordered green onion pancakes and I REALLY don't understand why this is one of the most talked about here because it's way way too fried.  I was hoping for more filling instead of just a fried crispy mess.

I doubt I'd ever return to this place.
author: Mango T.

description:
The name of this place is very very deceiving! I was looking forward to choosing from a variety of dumplings, but nope - they only have maybe 5 varieties at most. Why do you call yourself Dumpling Kitchen when you offer so little dumpling options?! I felt tricked into coming here because of the restaurant's name!

I ordered the shanghai dumplings and the pork dumplings. They were both good. But I will not be stopping by here the next time I want dumplings because I can get just as good dumplings elsewhere and have more to choose from. 

Service - there's this one old Chinese lady that was very unpleasant! She came asking if we were ready to order, we told her we were still deciding and wanted an extra menu because one of our friend doesn't have one to look at. Not only did she not respond to us, she looked at my friend with the missing menu with an annoyed face and walked away. To make matter worst, we never got the extra menu!
author: Michelle T.

description:
Back again.  :)

This time: 
- Shanghainese stir fried noodles: Standard, good
- Pan fried pork buns: very tasty
- Pork and chive dumplings: good

The wait was too long so we got takeout.  The food was still pretty tasty (dumplings were a little sticky) so that's a plus.
author: Melinda C.

description:
I came here during lunch on Saturday for the first time with my girlfriend. I grew up in China, and this place definitely had an authentic vibe to it, which was nice. The food itself was pretty good, and I would like to come back again to try different dishes. We had ordered the XBL, pork potstickers, pea sprouts with garlic, and sweet soy bean.

XBL - the flavor was definitely there, but the skin felt a bit soggy, and it wasn't as juicy as I would like my XBLs to be. My girlfriend said this wasn't the best she's had at this restaurant, so I'll give it another shot.

Pork Potstickers - this was very flavorful as well, and my personal favorite out of the 3 dishes we ordered. Could be crispier though. 

Pea sprouts with garlic - the top portion of the vegetable was good, but it felt like they hid all the tough pieces pea sprouts underneath.

Sweet soy bean - I really liked this drink and will definitely get it again. Subtle sweetness, which is what I like.
author: Albert H.

description:
The XLB were very good, but the skin was a bit tougher than I would have liked. The meat and juice was very deliciously flavored.
Their Shanghai style thick noodles were bland and not very well cooked. 
The dry fried chicken wings were so-so. The sauce was good, but the wings were not fried enough/crunchy and the skin remained chewy.
author: Tri L.

description: Visited this place a few times. Food was good. Dumplings were satisfying; however, the service was a little slow. All 3x I've came here, there was always something that our waiter forgot to bring us, whether it was a plate of ginger for the dumplings, water, or a straw. But all in all, the food was good.
author: Lisa L.

description: I like coming here because they are consistent with their xiao long bao and their other dishes. Sugar puff donuts are great when they come out fresh and pipping hot.  Not too long of a wait and their service isn't bad either. I like that they have seatings for big groups as well as for a couple. Just good Chinese comfort food without the overly crowded-ness.
author: Mandy D.

description:
Oh yum! Their soup dumpling was so tasty along with the pan fried buns!!!! Writing this review is now making me crave and hungry. This is the worst part about living so far from the bay because of all the great dining places. 
Anyway, we've never had soup dumplings before after seeing many peeps rave about DinTai in Valley fair. My now 2 yr old doesn't have a lot of patience so we wanted an easy place to try it out and they did disappoint. Food came out nice and hot, quick and very delicious. We were lucky because soon after a swarm of people arrived. We will definitely hit up this place again in the near future.
author: Rona B.

description:
Pushy, service!
Still not finish the dinner, but already started to clean our table, took all our chopsticks and bowls....
author: SteveMorris M.

description:
Just had a marvelous lunch! The Yelp reviews steered me in the right direction! Their onion pancakes are soooo good! The wonton noodle soup...yummy, yummy and more yummy! 
I love a tiny place in my hood that serves deliciousness with great service! Kudos!!! I'll be back for sure.
author: Lisa F.

description:
Overall good, not the best I've had. Expensive for its portion size: 10 small xlb. Also, the heat  and amount of the xlb was less than satisfactory. 

On the other hand the pan fried pork dumplings were really good! Loved the heat, the dumpling dough was perfect. I was diggin' that flat chat on the bottom of the dumpling! 

Last thing: loved how quick I was seated; however, I did not like that I had to ask for the ginger to eat with the vinegar.
author: Kevin L.

description:
2.5 stars for the food but I upgraded to 3 because the wait staff did the right thing. They post a score of 94 for hygiene inspection by the register.
Jr Yelper wanted to eat shao lung bao and tried the food before. We ordered 5 dishes and I only like 1-2.  The shao lung bao steamed was the best. 10 pieces of broth infused dumplings came piping hot in the bamboo steamer.  The pan fried version with a thicker, chewier dough I didn't like as much.  
We had a green onion pancake which was crispy on the outside but lacked flavor. The frozen ones you buy at the Asian markets are better.  We had a plate of garlic stir-fried spinach which was ok but at the bottom of the dish was a short piece of black hair.  The waiter apologized and took it off our tab. I was shocked he dared to ask if we still wanted to take the leftovers of that dish home after I pointed out the hair.  Their kitchen staff should wear nets, hats or something while cooking. I saw one of the kitchen ladies come out with her long hair in a ponytail but no hairnet.  We cook a lot at home and no one's hair is in our food.
Do not order the dried fried chicken wings. It wasn't crispy fried enough even tho it was moist. The sauce was a sweet plum sauce which will not as good as San Tung's wings. 
The place is popular in the area but the only item I would order again is the shao lung bao.
author: Ry T.

description:
i maintain that this place has the best soup dumplings in sf. the skin is thin and translucent, and the meat and juice actually have flavor! usually we get one order per person, because theyre so delicious and easy to eat, and disappear wayyy too fast!

most recently we got the XLBs, the dan dan noodles and garlic stir fried pea shoots. all soo good - and only $45 bucks total including tax and tip! DEAL!
author: Christina L.

description: Pretty good dim sum in the the Parkside area (I prefer Dumpling Kitchen over Kingdom of Dumpling). We always order the shanghai-style steamed pork dumplings and pan-fried pot stickers.
author: Kelsey F.

description: The food and staff were awesome. We had a group of 15 people and they were very accommodating. The XLB and dumplings were juicy and flavorful. We are definitely be coming back. Side note, if you have a group of 5 or more they will take your reservation.
author: Lawrence C.

description: XLB's are sooo tasty on a winter time! Sure win with that! Egg custard puff are to die for! Parking is hell, but food is good! So its worth the park maze!
author: Maria P.

description:
Nah, I think there's much better in SF area. Yes, XLBs are pretty good here but not great, and especially not for that price!! Geez. 

We came with some friends and ordered a few things. 

XLBs - pork was good, crab was ok. But neither was worth the $
Green onion pancake - I'm pretty biased with these but if I can make some badass ones at home easily, I'd expect a restaurant to do better
Spinach - nothing special, it was good. 
Soup - forgot which we ordered. But it came with the crackly rice and chicken as well as seafood, maybe beef or pork too. It was ok. 
Egg puffs - best thing we had but still pricey

I know SF area isn't cheap, but I honestly couldn't understand the price tag for some of those items.
author: Lonny Y.

description:
I do not understand the dumpling hype at all. Yes, XLB is the shit, but it's pretty hard to do it right, so there can't be so many places that have high ratings.

Anyhow, I digress. I wanted to try out one of the dumpling trifecta on Taraval, but not for the dumplings, hur hur. I can make my own just fine, thank you very much. Granted, I cannot make XLB, but technically it is a bun and not a dumpling. So I came to Dumpling Kitchen looking for some good Shanghainese food that is not XLB. Just to see if it's just hype or actually good food.

Aaaaand I was right -- it's all hype. Dumpling Kitchen cannot make good Shanghainese food at all. I got sheng jian bao (basically XLB with thicker skin and made potsticker style), twice cooked pork with leeks, and Shanghai stir fried noodle. All very classic dishes and really hard to mess up if you know how to cook it properly. So the fact that they all sucked = Dumpling Kitchen is not authentic.

Sheng jian bao -- the skin wasn't as crispy as it should be, probably because it was too doughy, and there was no juice inside. The filling was okay, lots of ginger, slightly sweet, and not too heavy.

Twice cooked pork with leeks -- I think it should actually be called lots of leeks and a couple of pieces of pork, because that's what I got. The pork was thinly sliced (which isn't a crime on its own), but came in long strips instead of bite sized pieces (yellow flag here), was few and far in between (approaching a red flag), and seasoned the wrong way. And did I mention the leek to pork ratio was too out of whack? Yeah, well it was.

Shanghai stir fried noodle -- really, this was just egregious. The noodles were not springy; too doughy IMO. Not enough veggies, not enough meat. Really shouldn't be charging $8 or whatever for this.

tl;dr: come here if you really like XLB but otherwise do not expect this to be authentic Shanghainese food at all.
author: Sherry L.

description:
I came specifically for the pan fried buns, or Sheng Jian Bao. The buns were not pan fried enough and the inside was not juicy. I would go to Shanghai House for the same dish in the future.

However, the rest were good and reasonably prices: 
Wonton in chili oil 
Puffed Egg Dessert
sweet soy milk
author: Shelley C.

description:
Everything is good here - the xiao long bao, the stir fried rice cakes, the sweet soy milk, the egg puffs, the chicken wings. I'm not a big fan of their green onion bread - it's not the conventional green onion pancake, but a fluffier flat bread type of thing. It's not gross, but not what I'm wanting here. 

The only thing I don't like is that they didn't even tell us the kitchen was closing the last time we dined here, so we weren't able to order the egg puffs
author: Aletheia W.

description:
Sometimes there is a bit of a wait, but it is always well worth it! Great prices and even better soup dumplings with accompanying dishes.

Regularly trek a little farther than usual to eat these scrumptious and savory treats!
author: Taylor O.

description:
Instead of hitting up my usual for XLB (the nearby Kingdom of Dumpling), I opted to try something new this past Saturday, dropping in to the much more spacious, and much less crowded Dumpling Kitchen. Sticking to the basics, I ended up getting an order of:

* Xiao Long Bao [ http://bit.ly/UMHu8W ] - Quality-wise, these are far better than Kingdom of Dumpling: stronger, springier, and thinner skin, with plenty of juice/soup inside, compared to the thicker skins found at Kingdom. Pretty good flavor-wise as well, but far sweeter than I'd like: I attribute it to heavy-handed usage of MSG, rather than sugar, given the typical side effects of MSG that I felt afterwards.

* Sheng Jian Bao (Shanghainese Pan-Fried Steamed Dumplings) [ http://bit.ly/WFHDh4 ] - I have a bit of a love/hate relationship with sheng jian bao, due to the nature of what they are: steamed buns, that are then pan-fried. That, of course, then means you're biting into a dumpling bun that's soaked up all the oil used to fry it, which leads to the characteristic soft/mushy texture of this dish. That said, they do this very well, with equally great flavor, but suffering from the same MSG sweetness as the XLB.

At $15 after tax and tip for the two orders of 10 each, you're getting pretty good value for your money. And while I'll probably come again, I suspect that future visits will always be a struggle between here and Kingdom, depending on my mood.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - Much more spacious than Kingdom, you should have little trouble with accessibility here, be it getting inside, or being seated. Note that the restaurant is located on a slope though, which may be the one difficulty in getting inside.

Bathroom - I didn't check them out, so I can't comment.
author: Johnny W.

description:
We go here mostly for XLB but the other dumplings are also great.  If you're in the area and feeling like having some dumplings you can't go wrong.  

Cash only. BYOB/W
author: Naty D.

description:
Really awesome dumpling spot!

Came here for the first time and while I'm not the biggest fan of Shanghai style dumplings (most of the places I've tried were really bland/tasteless) this place was great! We tried two orders of dumplings (crab/pork and one regular pork) and though the flavors were subtle they were delicious.
