We also tried the chicken wings (absolute must for the chicken wing slut of a bf I have) and they were meaty, juicy and seasoned well.

There was also the beef with sweet vinegar sauce which the bf was a huge fan of but my favorite was the rice cake dish with pork and cabbage. 

Definitely coming back to try other dishes
author: Pauline T.

description:
Came here on a whim because of a soup dumpling craving. My favorite is Din Tai Fung but of course there isn't a location near here sooooo we came here. We ordered the braised string beans which were pretty good but not the best I've had (clearly I'm biased). We ordered shrimp fried rice & instead got shrimp chow mein but didn't want to be rude & send it back so we just bit the bullet and ate it. The noodles were undercooked but the shrimp was good. Overall, this dish was just edible, not anything great. Finally, we ordered the Shanghai steamed pork dumplings (xlb) and I reallllllly loved these. I thought they were just one step under DTF's. Especially with the vinegar & soy sauce....mmMmMMMMMMM! 
All in all, would definitely come here again when I'm in SF and craving xlb BUT would probably only order the soup dumplings- nothing else. I should've read more into the Yelp reviews! 4 stars because the xlb is bomb and that's the only thing I care about!
author: Danielle T.

description:
I would give zero star to this place if I could.

For starters, they serve us with expired peanuts that tasted weird. I chose this place because it says on Yelp that it has a health inspection score of 92. The truth is, the spoon is not cleans, the table is greasy, the bathroom is a complete mess.

The food. Oh the food. For XLB you should use regular dough and the skin should be thin and neat. Our crab XLB is a complete mess, with undercooked skin and fillings, without a hint of crab meat.

For the pan fried bun, you were supposed to use fermented dough and pan fried to crispy on the bottom! None of that happened. The skin was almost the same as the one of XLB. No crispy bottom, no juicy filling. I want to throw them out.

The chicken wings are OK, compared to its dumplings. But it is way too salty and salt is the only seasoning I can taste out of.

The crispy egg puff is better, this place should only sell this.

Totally ruined my day.
author: Chen Y.

description: We love this place and were introduced to the soup dumplings. Green beans are a must and the Shanghai noodles are fantastic.  we were on our way to the SFO airport and we will return.
author: Wendy C.

description:
I found the best place to go for Shanghai pan-fried pork. Pork mixture is so juicy and flavorful, just sooooo good!!! I also got the crab xiao long bao and braised pork belly and braised vegetable. They're equally delish, but I'd take out one point from crab xiao long bao because it was a little too dry like it was made for a while. 
I heard they're busy at lunch time so I chose to go around 3p.m., which there're only two tables in the house, and we received quick services.
author: Yanakon D.

description: I was craving for some dumplings for lunch and saw the great reviews so went out on a whim to check this place out. I ordered General's Chicken rice plate and the highly recommended Shanghai Fried Pork dumplings. I don't know why I ordered a lunch special when the dumplings alone were filling. The reason for 3 stars is because my chicken was undercooked. It was slightly pink and the texture wasn't like chicken at all, but soft like tofu. I picked through the rest to see if any of them were cooked, but found only a few. Ended up just packing it up to try to salvage it at home and cook it all the way. I hope I don't end up with food poisoning :/ if I do, I will update. The dumplings were very good though and I wish I would have stuck to my first instincts and ordered what I originally came for.
author: Dahlia C.

description:
Came in on a late Sunday afternoon as a party of two.  We were seated right away, and ordered the Xiao Long Bao and Shanghai Chowmein.  The chowmein noodles were thick (pleasantly just the opposite of "spaghetti noodle" style chowmein) and the dish was packed with cabbage and just enough chicken.  It comes together well with chili sauce provided on the table, otherwise I just remember it being bland, especially for the price.  It was on the greasier side too, but not overwhelmingly so. The XLB were good.    

Again, this place is definitely on the pricey-er side for what you get. The servers didn't look very happy to be there, which isn't really a deterrent for me or what this rating is based on, but just a heads up if that kind of thing bugs you.  The phone was also ringing continuously at a reeeaallly high volume for the majority of our meal which didn't make the environment all that appealing - I guess nobody felt like making to-go orders that day...  However, our waters, to-go box and check were delivered promptly when asked for.

Overall, I think we'll be trying the other dumpling places around Sunset next time around.
author: Emily M.

description:
The XLBs were the best dish of the night.  Dumplings come in second and the rest of the dishes were pretty standard of a chinese dumpling restaurant.  

The green onion pie seems like a different variety.  Still yummy, just thinner and eggier than the flakey doughy kind I'm used to.

Located a little further down on Taraval, so it's not located in the middle of all the action, but there was still a wait and a decent sized line.

Next time we come, definitely trying the Sheg jian baos and the fried mantous!
author: Janel C.

description:
Is it me or are their xlb getting smaller, lol 

I took a friend over for lunch and had a wonderful time, we ordered our usual 2 xlb and another order of dumplings with chives, also spicy tendons.....

Delicious as usual but sure seems like the dumplings are getting smaller...
author: Leslie Y.

description:
Haven't tried too many places that specialize in xlb in the bay, but this place is one of the better ones.  It's not sweet like some places and not as bland either which was a plus.  The skin could have been less doughy and thinner but other than that , I think the taste was decent. I like how they garnished the pork and crab xlb with fish eggs.

The dumplings in chili oil was good.  Usually, i find chinese dumplings to be on the bland side, but these weren't.

The pea sprouts with garlic wasn't bad.  I didn't like how it was a tad too tough though.  

The fried rice was nice and flavorful, but the rice seemed overcooked.
author: Heejin L.

description:
Came to this place for the first time, expecting a good meal, but dang, that place was better than I expected! 
We got a few different dishes and each one was pretty freakin good. 
Service was fast and fresh and the bill was fairly cheap! 
I'll be coming back in the future!
author: Stephanie D.

description:
I freaking love this place!!

My friends and I came here on a Friday night because a couple of other places were full with a 1-2 hour wait. (Ironically, to drive here and find parking was another 45 minutes...) 

We ordered:
*2 orders xiao long bao
*dry fried chicken wings
*shanghai stir-fried noodles
*pan fried pork buns

We got some salted peanuts as appetizers (free!) as we waited the 5 minutes before our food came. Yes, it was that fast. The noodles came first and man, it was so delicious. I literally had this same dish the day before in San Jose with my parents, and this one was bigger, less oily and tastier! The noodles are clearly made in-house. The XLBs came next and a friend had said this was equivalent to Din Tai Fung's, which are pretty strong and daring words. But he was right--these are probably 90% to DTF's!! I was in love. It was slightly less flavorful soup and they didn't give us any ginger but $7.50 for 10 dumplings with no crazy long wait MORE than makes up for it.

Another friend claimed the chicken wings were close to San Tung. Again, tall words. The sauce is darker and it tasted more like the sauce for king do spare ribs than San Tung. I still say San Tung wins here, but again, am I waiting 2 hours for chicken wings? Hell no. (Yes, that was one of the places we tried to go to before deciding to come here instead.)

The pan fried pork buns were also delicious. I've gotten really sick of them as of late, but I still enjoyed these. 

Total bill? $42 before tip. Hell yes!

This place is a total hidden gem--little to no wait (Fri 8:45pm), quick service, delicious and at a great price point. I'm totally coming next time to eat just the XLB.
author: Kat Y.

description:
Saturday night Foraging for Shanghainese @ Dumpling Kitchen.

Food and service were great, had a culinary survey including:

XLB - Crab and Pork versions - both as laudable as many loudly declare
Pork Dumplings in chili oil - great, kinda like pot-stickers in a puddle of sauce & chili oil 

Onion Pancakes - good but 2 filing to sacrifice valuable eating capacity considering XLB

Chicken wings - deep fried w/ secret sauce - Great, the tastiness is in the secret sauce

Braised green beans - While coated in oil, they were perfectly crispy and tender

Soy bean milk (hot) - the real deal of this bev, not too sweet

Service: Quite a few server/busboy's moving quickly to meet the demands of the dumpling fans. They are matter-of-fact and efficient. 

Environ: Its a fact that many high $ restaurants have a sound engineering aspect to their design to tailor the noise level to suit their intended dining experience, a joint like Slanted Door (LOUD) comes to mind. Dumpling Kitchen, when busy is a "lively" (loud) place when a good percentage of tables are occupied. While certainly unintended, it does reflect the bustle of the modern/young Shaghainese restaurant feel. It is a 'no frills' joint that delivers the goods.

Love to read other reviews (ain't that why I'm signed into Yelp?), and especially the the one that stated they were disappointed, actually cheated because based on their definition they only identified 5 versions of dumplings. LOL. They do serve more than 5, and their menu is sufficiently diverse to satisfy most of the people most of the time, which is why their usually is a line to be seated! One of the very few dissatisfied diners displaying their disappointment by taking a dump on their dumplings in a review. They must have truly regretted their large investment of eating at Dumpling Kitchen.
author: Matsuo U.

description: I have a cold so my loving husband picked up some xiao long bao and wonton soup for me. The xiao long bao was still pretty warm but had no soup inside! Out of 10 pieces, I'd say 2 had very little soup. Speaking of soup, the wonton soup was so bland...even adding a couple of tablespoons of soy sauce in just one bowl did not help. = (
author: Rose A.

description:
My boyfriend and I were looking for a light meal to eat in SF before heading back to the South Bay. Being Asians that we are, he suggested dumplings, so we found this place on Yelp. 
We ordered the XLBs, of course. One with pork and one with pork and crab. Both were equally juicy and delicious. I took off 1 star because the XLBs didn't come with gingers. XLBs are always fun to eat. The trick is to pick it up with your chopsticks, place it gently in a spoon and then poke a hole in the dumpling to get all the juices  out. The juice can burn your tongue if you don't know the technique. I had to learn it the hard way. 
I will definitely be back to try more dishes.
author: Tuyen T.

description: Decided to try this place out because it was close to home and an alternative place to go than shanghai dumpling. We went fairly early so there was no wait and not many others in the restaurant. We ordered XLB, pork and chive dumplings, chow mein and chicken wings. The XLB is good and comparable to the ones at shanghai dumpling. Pork and chive dumplings were good too! The chow mein was good, can't really mess that one up.. and the chicken wings were not good, I would not recommend them. I wouldn't mind coming here again when I want dumplings.
author: Tiff C.

description:
Dumpling Kitchen does pretty good Xiao Long Baos (XLB) for a great price. I really appreciate the ability of the wrappers and cooks to use such a thin skin for the XLB, but still manage to keep all of the yummy juices in when the XLBs are ready to be served. Personally, I felt that the XLBs were fattier than other places I have visited in San Francisco, but I think I enjoy the richer taste.

I also ordered the Pea Sprouts cooked with garlic here, and it was flavorful. The portions that the restaurant serves was huge for the pea sprouts, so be prepared to potentially take some of it home! 

Parking in the area can be difficult since its off Taraval, but you can usually find free parking after a few rounds in the neighborhoods; just be prepared to give yourself extra time for the parking.
author: Jeff M.

description: I love this place. My go to for soup dumplings! Me and my bf prefer the crab ones. And the Shanghai pan fried ones yummy!!! I got the pork belly so freaking delicious everyone get it please you will not regret melts in your mouth!!! Ever since we tried it out me and my bf have been craving it! Okay service!
author: Jennifer V.

description:
Been eyeing this place for a long time on Yelp and finally was able to get here today. I'm certain I'll be back. I'm not an expert on soup dumplings, but these are some of the best I've had. The right thickness of skin, flavorful soup, and the pork filling was minced finely. I didn't find any knuckly gristly parts, which is sometimes a disappointing dumpling detail when they're made in massive batches -- which these must surely be judging by the line at the door. 

Hot and sour soup could've been a bit more flavorful, but it was bold in the spicy department. Shanghai noodles were really fabulous. (If you're hoping to get San Tung-level chicken wings, go get in line at San Tung.) Shrimp and napa cabbage looked excellent on someone else's table. Overall, this place is quality food in a casual atmosphere. Not a total dive as some people seem to think, but not a fine dining establishment either. Comfortable. Homy. Worth the wait!
author: Casey C.

description:
Went to Dumpling Kitchen during lunchtime on a Sunday and my first thought when my friend and I got there was, "Oh, no." There were people waiting outside and the restaurant was busy and full! Instead of waiting for a table, we decided to make a to-go order. We ordered the green onion pancake, shrimp fried rice, green beans, and shanghai pork dumplings. To our surprise, it was ready within 10-15 minutes and it seemed like the wait for a table was going rather quickly despite the business! The waitress was very busy, but was always kind when I stopped her and asked her questions. 

Everything was very good, but the green onion pancake was just okay in my opinion. Maybe it was because we had taken the food to go. I thought the dumplings were very good, but not as good as the dumplings at Shanghai Dumpling King on Balboa. However, as I have said before, it also could have been due to the fact that we took it to-go so it wasn't as hot and fresh as it could have been. Overall, it was very yummy! I would recommend this place and come back again!
author: Christina C.

description:
The XLB were great, as expected. Will definitely return for those. Dumplings were good too. Guess they're their strong point. They skimped on the meat in our chicken dish, and the green onion pancake was super dry.... we only ate a piece each to try and left the rest. What the heck?!?

Got seated quickly on a weekend for lunch, which is a far cry from the wait at the tiny Kingdom of Dumpling.
author: Vivian H.

description:
I've been going here for years and just now realized I hadn't reviewed it yet! 

The XLBs (as all the cool kids call them) come out toasty and quickly, born in flavor and steam. I almost always get #1, and for good reason. It's always full of broth, always little bites of perfection. Best XLBs ever? Probably not... But good for location and proximity to my home. I've tried the other, more famous, XLB restaurant and I prefer these to theirs. 

That said, other delicious menu items include dry fried wings,  green onion pancake,  DAN DAN MEIN (yaaaaaas!!!), and lastly,  to cap off your meal, the fried sugar ball. Fried, warm, crispy, fluffy dough rolled in sugar  -  uhhggnnnnn heaven on earth. Order soy milk to dip dat shet in and you gots a winner. 

Service? Quick. It's an Asian restaurant in the outer sunset... Don't expect much. 

Patrons? Mixed. It's great -  most Chinese restaurants in the outer sunset you expect all Chinese people eating... But you get a good mixed crowd. 

I knocked a star off because the last time I ate, it wasn't as good as my previous experiences.
author: Christina B.

description: The soggiest dumplings I've ever eaten in SF. Please save yourself the time and money and do NOT come here! Kingdom of noodle or shanghai house is soo much better. They also got 2 of my orders wrong and their green onion pancake is made of the wrong batter and tastes very strange. Their chowmein looks and tastes like Panda Express noodles. And their pan fried shanghai dumplings look sad and barely seared on the bottom with no soup. The only thing I liked was their walnut prawns because they were suuuper lemony. But I don't think it's supposed to taste like that lol. I would not recommend this place to anyone. Take your money elsewhere.
author: Christine Q.

description:
I brought my lovely date here for lunch~
We had so much to talk about ad so many dreams to share, however, neither of us had a word to share once the food arrived. 
Dreams can wait. 
Amazing dumplings are here! 
Order the #1: some of the best xiao long bao I've ever had ever. 
The pan fried order is also unique to this restaurant. 
Make sure to bring your appetite!
author: Josh H.

description: Tasty spot in Parkside just south of the Sunset district.  Quite authentic and lots of locals seemed to be there tonight.  Good sign. Try the dry spiced chicken wings. We also had the stir-fried pork buns and the hot and sour soup.  Very basic interior, no frills kind of place. No need to get fancy with food this good.  A hidden gem.
author: Matt B.

description: I DON'T recommend this place at all... the food is just ok, but the service is horrible!!! Tonight is my first time trying this restaurant, but the service was so disappointed. My friend and I were seated in a small table. We ordered 4 dishes. 2 dishes came with huge plates. The table was just not enough for 4 dishes. Then I asked one of the servers (the girl at the front desk) to see if we can have the bigger table next to us. There were a few empty tables at the time when we were asking, then the girl just said "hold on" then she went to the kitchen and seemed to ask other servers. (not sure why she can't decide immediately because not only one table available at that time). Anyways, while we were waiting, another sever took the 2 customers to the table next to us, which is totally fine because that server didn't know we requested to change to that table. Then we expected the front desk girl would come back and give us another bigger table or at least an appology. We kept waiting, but she never came back to us and no response at all. She just ignored us for the whole time even we had eye contact. In the end, she finally came to our table, but she just put down a check on our table without saying a word. Excuse me, we were still eating and haven't requested the check yet.... That was so impolite and mean. Although we have some left over, she didn't even ask if we need a to go box. NEVER go to this restaurant again!!! THE WORST RESTAURANT I HAVE EVER BEEN!
author: Chloe Y.

description: I used to crave Din Tai Fung xlb and could never find something to fulfill that void in Northern California until I came across Dumpling Kitchen. My tastebuds were overjoyed and I am addicted to this place! My favorite is the XLB, Shanghai style fried rice cakes and the pea sprouts with garlic dish. There's so much more to try but I find myself ordering the same thing whenever I go there.
author: Corie Z.

description:
I like this place. The food is good, the restaurant is fairly large so it's great for parties of people. The prices, however, are a little especially for the fact you can find so many other places similar to this that have better prices. 

The soup dumpling portion is slightly less and more expensive than most places I go to. The soup portion is decent. Soup and order of soup dumplings will more than satisfy one person. 

Service is okay, employees speak little English.
author: Alisa A.

description: We were looking for a lunch place during Christmas day and we only found this Chinese place open in outer Sunset district. The food was decent. The dumpling were good. We ordered many types of dumpling to go.
author: Raman S.

description: Top notch shanghai dumplings - the pork & shrimp ones are completely worth it. The skin is the perfect thickness. We came mid-afternoon (~3pm) so it wasn't crowded at all and we got the dumplings pretty quickly. I am willing to drive here all the way from our area (lower Mission) just to have these again!
author: Elisa L.

description: This place is cash or debit card only, no credit cards!  XLB are good; however, the onion pancake was dry and the chicken wings were ok, not as good as San Tung (guess that was expected).  The food is ordinary, I wouldn't go out of my way or wait for a table.
author: E F.

description: Everything at this place was pretty bomb! My friends and I ordered the original shanghai dumplings (xiao long bao), potstickers, pan friend pork and chives dumplings, hot fresh soy milk, and chicken mu shu. The best one in my opinion has to be the original shanghai dumplings. They were fresh, the soup inside the dumplings were full of flavor and they were super heartwarming when you eat them. The potstickers and the other things we ordered were good as well. If I were to come back again, I'd order only shanghai dumplings and pan fried versions of it. JUST SUPER SMACK!!!
author: Jimmy T.

description: I was in town for work and in search of an amazing soup dumpling. I read a bunch about Dumpling Kitchen and the "religious experience"/best soup dumpling in SF. So I ubered out, added my name to the seating list, sat down excitedly, ordered right away, and.. well, was underwhelmed. It was good, don't get me wrong. But there was barely any soup in the dumpling. Flavor was fine, nothing to write home about, and the bok choy was fine (couple pieces hadn't been washed throughly.) Would I go again and try more on the menu with a larger group? Probably. Would I be sad if I never went back? No.
author: Krystin H.

description:
Price: Great for what you get
Soup dumplings: good
Garlic beans: best I've ever had. Since going there I've been trying to recreate them myself. 
Everything else: pretty decent

Tip: Go at off-peak hours to avoid the line.
author: Jon K.

description:
- Beef noodle soup. Alright. It's the Cantonese style thin curly noodles, not hand pulled noodles.

- Fried dumplings. Good! Would order again.
author: An Y.

description:
Is meh.

Came with family to eat some dumplings after visiting the Moraga steps. It was probably about 6:30 when we came, and they seated us pretty promptly. Waitress removed a "reserved" sign on a large table for us. Huh. We didn't make a reservation...

The food was okay, but not stellar. 

Shanghainese noodles: GREASY. Super greasy. I needed rice to sop up some oil. Seriously. 

Tofu with meats: Such a deceiving menu item. It says tofu, so you think firm or even soft. No, this was the extra firm style. Like, with liquid pressed out so it's almost substitute meat. Was..not what any of us was expecting.

Xiao Long Bao: filling is ok, but the wrap was a bit too thick. Good XLB are ones where the skin is a bit thinner. It's like a challenge to pick up the dumpling, NOT BREAK IT, and actually consume the soup/filling in one delicious fell swoop. This one...I tasted much more of the wrap. Fail.

Pan Fried Dumpling: Please note...it's actually a bao. Not a dumpling. There's very different wraps on these suckers. And...this one was kinda meh. It didn't really stand out as a bao, and again. Grease. 

We ordered something else, but all I remember about it was onions. Lots of onions. It might have been the mongolian beef. I just know it claimed to be a meat dish, but was really an onions dish. Fail, you!!

Service was ok. What you typically expect at a Chinese-style restaurant. The decor inside...was kind of gross. There's a ledge along one of the walls that needs a serious scrub-down. I have a phobia about that kind of thing. If they don't care to clean their dining space...what...does their kitchen look like???
author: Lily W.

description:
I wanted to like this place more than I did. 

The flavor of the xiao long bao is pretty good.  The meat is tender, and the flavor of the soup is pretty good.  However, the skin is entirely too thick, and there needs to be more soup. 

The Shanghai rice cakes were pretty good though.  If I had a craving, I would make the drive out for these.

The salt and pepper fish was waaaay too battered.  It was like having fish from fish and chips, but with the salt and pepper seasonings.  I didn't like this.

The snow pea leaves sauteed with garlic were good, although I've never had bad ones.  Maybe I'm lucky that way.

Overall I would visit this place again, but I'm still on the hunt for really good xiao long bao in San Francisco.
author: Jaching H.

description:
Great restaurant for friends or family.  The XLB / Shanghai soup dumplings are out of this world, as are the pan fried pork buns.  I saw a lot of mentions of the "Shanghai style pan fried rice cakes" on Yelp, which were delicious.  I've never actually had those before, so I don't have much to compare it too, but totally tasty all the same.  

One note - it was cold in there, so bring a hoodie!
author: Marc B.

description:
The food was excellent. We ordered the Salt and Pepper Chicken, Mongolian Beef, and the Chicken and Peppers, along with Hot and Sour Soup and the Crab and Pork Dumplings. It was a large meal and very tasty. Plenty of leftovers that will not go to waste. 
The parking is an issue but this is San Fran so that is nothing new. I really liked that they didn't place any silverware on the table just chopsticks. 
The restaurant was very busy when we went and the serving staff was extremely busy. 

All in all it was a great meal but the Salt and Pepper was my favorite.
author: Terrence C.

description:
I think going to Dumpling Kitchen three times in one week means I have to give this place 5 stars. I went with friends on a Saturday, my parents wanted to come here on a Thursday (their second time that week), and I took the girl friend here the following Saturday.

So how does this place keep me coming back for more? Delicious juicy dumplings, fast service, and consistent quality. Their xiao long bao (or Shanghai Style Soup Dumplings) are a must, and their pot stickers and pan fried pork buns are both tied for my favorite dish. If you need something more fresh you can get garlic pea sprouts (worth the $12) or egg plant in garlic sauce (they give you plenty).

If you need a few extra dishes, you can't go wrong with Shanghai Style Chow Mein and green onion pancakes. Finally, even if you don't have room for dessert, get the crispy egg puffs. You won't regret it.
author: David C.

description:
The next XLB in the city. We've been to all of the other places (I can't remember their names but I think they have Shanghai in their names).  Dumpling Kitchen xlb's have the thinnest skin and are nice and soupy. Too bad this place is in the outer Richmond, or we'd be here every week!

This place has huge portions too.
author: howie f.

description:
The XLB are delicious but for a place that calls themselves dumpling kitchen, how come there are limited options for dumplings? 

The place is bigger than the other dumpling places, so the wait isn't as long. 

I had the pork dumplings in hot oil, XLB and wonton in broth. I enjoyed both the XLB and wontons. As for the pork dumplings in hot oil, it was little too vinegar-y for my liking. I enjoy Shanghai Dumpling King wontons in hot oil better. I rather go there, that hits the spot.

I also ordered the shanghai chow mein, which I thought was just mediocre. Service is so-so, it can get busy so flag down your waiter if you need anything.

They do take credit cards.

Parking is street parking, and it always easier to find parking on Taraval than other places in the city in my opinion.
author: Margaret L.

description: Great dim sum and shorter wait than many of the other dim sum places in the city.
author: Sara S.

description:
Just came here and ordered pan fried pot stickers, Shanghai dumplings, and soy milk. 

Super yummy!!! Total came out to $20. 

Even my super picky dad liked it and suggested we come back here in they future.
author: Elaine S.

description:
Food 4 stars
Cleanliness 3.5 at first, but after "the incident" 0 stars
Service 1 star

Take this review how you want.  I'm not angry at the restaurant, this is not a revenge review.  I'll admit, I have a couple on here that are.  My girlfriend and I wanted to take my grandma, my uncle and aunt out to dinner.  I was able to get a reservation the day of, very convenient.  However, fortunate or not, we were seated with a direct line view into the kitchen.  

The food we ordered were decent, but about 80% through our dinner, I witnessed "the incident."  A kitchen worker went to grab a tray of frozen dumplings from the freezer, but in trying to be quick, she dropped the entire tray of dumplings onto the floor.  There were about 30 dumplings in total.  A small number compared to how many they serve each day.  She quickly scooped up all the dumplings on the floor, placed them back on the tray and back into the freezer.  I wish I didn't see it, but I saw the entire "incident."  

Long story short,  I spoke with a young lady/manager, in her early 20s, that their worker put all the dirty dumplings back in the fridge.  She spoke with the chef and told us that they wash their dumplings prior to cooking them.  As an Chinese person myself,  we DON'T "wash" dumplings prior to cooking them.  You make them, and you simply steam/boil/pan fry them before you serve, NO WASHING.  I then asked her, "They just put everything back in the freezer, how would they know which one to wash?" She replied, "Oh, they did?"  She then ran off to the kitchen again and after a minute or so, I saw the initial "dumpling dropper" go to the freezer and take out the tray of dirty dumplings.  Therefore, situation solved and I wasn't going to tell on them or make a big deal out of it.  She also never followed up with me.

However, from that point on, I got the stink eye from 3-4 kitchen chefs, and a bus lady started clearing our plates before we finished everything and dropped the check on our table.  She literally tried to wrestle my uncle's plate from him while he was still trying to finish his food.  

I didn't want to alert the whole restaurant.  I didn't need them to comp anything.  I didn't need an apology.  I just wanted them not to serve dirty dumplings to other customers, that would have been the end of it.  It is not professional of them to put back dirty dumplings and it is even less professional to basically kick us out of the restaurant before we finished our meal.

I'm not that angry, I wanted to give them a chance since they have 4 stars here on yelp, but I'm really disappointed with what they did and how they reacted to the information I gave them.

I'm sure they'll still serve good food.  My family and I won't be returning.  If you still decide to go, I hope you aren't eating dumplings they picked up off the floor.  Good luck!
author: Joel C.

description: I've been coming here for 3 years as a Sunset resident so this review is long overdue. This is my go-to place for Xiao Long Baos and anything dumpling related whenever my cravings come. My faves are the original XLBs, crab XLBs, chive dumplings, Shanghai rice cake (I usually ask for less oil/salt and it's still amazingly bursting with that WOK flavor), Mushu chicken/beef/pork, Mongolian beef, and the pea sprouts with garlic. Super fast service, consistently delicious foods with a 92 health inspection food score - what more can you ask for?! Sure it may get a bit loud while dining but that's just how Chinese people enjoy their ambiance - fun and lively! That young woman up front is always so sweet, friendly, and super efficient in seating people no matter how busy it gets. She wins an extra star in my book for being respectful of customer's time and rumbling stomachs!
author: A W.

description: Love doing takeout here!!! Whenever my parents don't want to cook dinner, we should call dumpling kitchen right away to place our orders! It's fast and efficient and affordable! I love the dumplings and also their noodle plates! Nothing taste bad, it is all just pure goodness! If you want some delicious Chinese food, try this place! I recommend it to anyone who loves Chinese food!!!
author: Joanne C.

description:
I'm not a religious man by any means... But praise the lord for this glorious establishment. Hallelujah !!!! Hallelujah my brothers and sisters!!!! Hallelujah !!!!

I'm not sure what heaven is like, or if there even is a heaven, but I'm pretty sure it's a bunch of fat people laying around eating these dumplings.....and hell is bring surrounded by their egg puffs but not being able to eat them. This is how religions are born people.
author: Eucalyptus J.

description:
I COME HERE WAY TOO OFTEN TO NOT GIVE IT A REVIEW. Gotta love these XLBs...... ON a cold day in SF, I just crave soup dumplings and this place is great. Its cheap, portions are big and its tasty. 

FOOD: 
XLB: Get it. Its not even a question if you should. The only question you should be asking is if you should get more. 

Wontons in Chili Sauce: Its like mini wet, moist won-tons drenched in chili spicy sauce. Its great. Great complement to the XLB. 10/10

Cucumber Salad: I know what you are thinking....WAT? Ok In honesty, I can make this stuff too. But its cheap and makes me feel like I am not a fatty. Its very refreshing and garlicky and my bf and I have terrible garlic breath after, but its great. Tastes really good.

VERDICT: Come here. its ok, they take cash. :)
author: Eileen W.

description:
I think this place has the best xiao long bao's in the entire city.  Perfect texture, delicious soup inside, and served piping hot. There are quite a few dumpling specialty restaurants around SF these days, but I think this place beats out all of them.

The other dishes are great, as well. Their green onion pancake is different from what you normally expect -- the pancake is like a thick fried piece of dough, instead of the usual flaky layered pancake. I personally like this style, but some may not.

The black bean sauce noodles were great as well. The sauce was a slightly lighter color, but the flavor was just right.

Random question: Why are so many Chinese restaurants in SF closed on Wednesdays???
author: Kazu O.

description: Wow! What an amazing place to eat. I got to try the XLB and the Chicken and spinach noodle soup and both were amazing. Everything is cooked perfectly and the portions are very large, perfect for 2-3 people to share. It's great to know there's such a good place to eat just a few minutes away from home. Definitely coming back and bringing everyone here!
author: Maria V.

description: You know it's going to be good when the line is out the door! Seriously, the most amazing Chinese food that I've ever eaten. Service was polite and prompt. The food is just out of this world.
author: Starr N.

description:
I had Dumpling Kitchen bookmarked for a long time, and since my friend was visiting her family not far from here and wanted to meet for dinner, this was the perfect spot.  I made a reservation for us as I knew this place gets busy.  After looking at Yelp reviews, I knew to order: soup dumplings, green onion pancake and pan-fried pork dumplings.  

I couldn't stop myself from eating so many of the soup dumplings as it was a burst of yummy soup in my mouth with every dumpling - loved it!  The green onion pancake was filling and good too, and I thought the pan-fried pork dumpling was a-ok -- maybe it was because I was getting quite full at this point.  For two adults and a child, I think two entrees are perfect as I was quite full by that point.  

It is easy to get here on the Muni L Taraval exit at Taraval and 30th.  

Service was ok - they forgot to bring my friend's little boy a glass of ice, and by the time we remembered, it was towards the end of our meal...

Other than that, I can't wait to come back here again to try other dishes and have more soup dumplings!
author: Maile N.

description:
I came here on a late night mission to find the city's best xlb. Per a friend's recommendation, we came to Dumpling Kitchen, only to discover that it was recently ranked the #1 place to get xlb in San Francisco!

SERVICE
We got there at 9:01pm and were nervous that they wouldn't serve us since they close at 9:30pm, but thankfully the xlb gods were on our side because the hostess kept the kitchen open just long enough for us to rapid fire our order. 

The fact that she was willing to let us mere mortals sit down and eat to our hearts' content made me want to come back again and again. It's not everyday that Chinese restaurants go above and beyond, especially 30 minutes before closing. 

The food arrived super fast. It was probably because the workers wanted us to eat quickly and leave but we didn't mind. Bring on the dumplings! 

ATMOSPHERE
A slightly larger hole in the wall with your standard bare bones chinese restaurant decor: plain white tablecloths with plain white dishes. It's ok though. We didn't come here for the decor ;)

FOOD
Since we had about 2 minutes to read through the entire menu and place our order, we didn't have much time to think. We ended up ordering:
-Pork xlb
-Crab and pork steamed dumplings
-Dry fried green beans
-Pork potstickers

Everything was delicious but I would skip the potstickers and order another dumpling dish... Or more xlb. 

Coming from an Asian suburb in SoCal and after having tried Ding Tai Feng in multiple countries, I have high standards for xlb. 

I will say that these xlb came pretty damn close to that of DTF. The meat was perfectly cooked and it wasn't as fatty as some other xlb. The dumpling skin was perfect-- not too thick but just the right amount to hold the soup. The soup flavor was spot on but I wish there was a bit more soup. 

The CRAB AND PORK DUMPLINGS were surprisingly good as well. You could actually taste the difference btwn these and the normal xlb. Light, juicy, and savory down to the last bite. 

The DRY FRIED GREEN BEANS were among the best I've had. They didn't taste like the traditional dish but I actually preferred these because they were significantly less greasy. The savory onions has added just the right amount of flavor to the beans. 

Our order came out to about $40 after tax and tip. Not bad considering we left with happy bellies full of dumpling goodness!

 It's really far from the rest of the city but I'd come back if I had a killer xlb craving. Also heard they do a pretty mean pan fried pork bun, green onion pancake, and chicken wings. Just another 3 reasons to come back and support this hole in the wall!
author: Krystie M.

description:
We were excited to try this place. We ordered a sticky rice roll, pork XLB, "dry fried chicken" and "dan dan noodle".

The sticky rice roll was fine. there were not enough filling and a lot of rice. 

Next came the "dan dan noodle" - i'm not even shanghainese and i know this is not dan dan noodle. What they served us what essentially instant noodle with sauce and a lot of crushed peanuts on top - http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=ct_tP5CoiQ9s8kqR87jNLQ&userid=FHe8iR0zF5zt3NSiFyAk7w but the noodle had no peanut taste! 

We're onto our next disappointment, the "dry fried chicken" - http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=LQ9rjS2_L_iFii_aajPs8A&userid=FHe8iR0zF5zt3NSiFyAk7w Again, this is not "dry fried chicken". They served us fried chicken finger with sweet and sour sauce. The batter to the chicken was thick and it wasn't great. 

Finally, the XLB came and it redeemed the night a little. The XLB is good. but it really isn't anything special.
author: Terry C.

description:
I've eaten at Dumpling Kitchen several times, and I highly prefer this over Kingdom of Dumpling two blocks up. Here, the lines are much shorter, there's plenty of seating, and the menu is more extensive. Service is relatively fast and food is delicious.

Xiao long baos -- Good chunk of juicy, tender pork and flavorful soup inside. The skin has the perfect thickness (thinner than those at Kingdom of Dumpling) and still holds in the soup. They look deflated sometimes, but still, I've never torn my XLBs here. You get 10 dumplings for $6.50, which I think is a great deal. A must order every time!

Pan-fried pork buns -- Perfectly crisped on the bottom, but overall very very very oily, so you'd probably get tired of these quickly and can't eat as many as you could for the steamed version. There's more meat in these than in the steamed version, too. Once again, same price, you get 10 for $6.50.

Green onion pancake -- I'm not a big fan of theirs. It's very fluffy, airy, not dense at all. (I prefer mine to be thin and crispy). However, I like how it doesn't feel as oily as it does at other places.

Vegetarian goose -- I love it, but the bean curd texture is inconsistent at times. Sometimes it's soft (which I prefer) and other times it's hard/chewy. Overall, it's very fresh but needs to be garnished with more green onion. And they don't skimp with the mushroom filling either.

Shanghai-style stir-fried rice cakes -- Very greasy, but pretty good. I'm not a big fan of rice cake texture; it's thick, starchy, and very chewy that I probably burn more calories chewing than consuming.

In terms of cleanliness, meh... This is a Chinese restaurant. That's an excuse within itself. But it's much cleaner than some restaurants in SF Chinatown. On the weekends until ~1PM, expect a wait, but probably not as long as the wait at Dumpling Kitchen. I will be back! After 1PM on the weekends...
author: Priscilla W.

description: I'd say this is one of the best if not the best dumpling place in the entire Bay Area! I was bought by one of my good friends here during late night, ordered 小籠包 生煎包 炒三絲, and this is so amazing! Can't get enough! Fresh and yummy! Their cleaning table speed is very fast, though you might need to wait in line almost all the time.
author: Mathew Z.

description:
We were one of the early birds that arrived just after opening. The XLB are juicy but not piping hot which was odd since they don't open until 10:30 AM. The ginger should be julienne as thinly as possible. And they didn't seem to like it when you ask for more. 

We also had the savory fan tuan and the yàuhjagwái (Chinese cruller) was very crispy and so it deserves a star.
author: Clarice T.

description: plain and simple one of the best dim sum and also fantastic chinese food places in SF. no wine but they are cool if you bring your own just bring a corkscrew with you. the soup dumplings are the i have had in SF. the wrapper is just perfect and delicate. too many places make their wrapper too thick. the maipo tofu is also great. the green onion pancake gets raves but it was too doughy for me but overall i love this place and have eaten here a dozen times.
author: John T.

description: Love this place! Consistently great food. (Okay, so I've been here twice, and it might be a bit too soon to say "consistently.") Their xiaolongbao are soupy with great thin (yet not flimsy) skins, and their shengjianbao (pan-fried+steamed dumplings) are so delicious. The right balance of meat/dough as well as soft/crispy. Super addicting! I was really disappointed with Shanghai Dumpling King on Balboa, which seems to have gone incredibly far downhill in terms of food quality, but I'm so glad I learned about this place on Taraval. Quick service, delicious and classic Shanghai dishes (love that they have ci fan and savory soymilk! have to give those a try someday when I'm not too busy stuffing myself with dumplings), and will definitely be back many more times.
author: Delia Z.

description: Awesome Chinese food!  I've been searching for a spot in San Francisco that does great Chinese food that's not too salty or oily.  We had pea shoots, spicy wonton, green beans, cucumber, and veggie dumplings.  It was too hot outside for eating shanghai soup dumplings.  We look forward to trying them next time we are in the area.
author: Tori C.

description: One of the better XLBs you'll find in San Francisco based on flavor, style, and value
author: Stanton W.

description:
Xiao Long Baos, all the way.

Solid Chinese food... and of course, I came here after reading about the top xiao long bao's in the bay area from Thrillest.

Portions are ginormous, so bring some friends and eat tons of yummy, Chinese food!
author: Janet H.

description: I have been coming here for years. XLB is one of my favorites here - should get two. Love the soy bean milk and dry fry chicken wings is fantastic. Don't let the name fool you, there is sauce on the chicken wings. Green onion pancake is good.  The wonton with spicy sauce is yummy. Don't forget the crispy egg puff! I would of given this place a five star, but they just changed their policy to cash and debt card only.  Most items are price within 7 to 10 dollars range so it adds up quick, so if you bring your family to dinner, bring cash or debt card.
author: Hubert C.

description: Went on a long hike and wanted to eat something warm and delicious.  We all decided XLBs would satisfy this craving.  Looked up where was the best place to get XLB in the city and this place was one of the top choices.  Was able to find easy street parking on a Monday night.  Not a big place but there were some empty tables when we got there so we were seated quickly.  Went straight for their top items of XLB, pork buns, and green onion cake.  The XLBs are pretty tasty with thin skins and lots of soup.  Pork buns don't have too much dough either.  The green onion cake was our least favorite.  It's a bit different from other places and we decided we didn't like this version as much.  Overall a satisfying meal!
author: Esther S.

description:
Dumpling Kitchen provides an excellent and authentic taste of 小龍包s (siu lung baau / xiao long bao). One of the most difficult things about eating them though is: 1, picking them up without breaking the skin, so the juice stays within each dumpling, and 2, eating them at the right time so that the temperature doesn't burn your mouth and the skin hasn't cooled down enough to become tougher.

There are several types of SLB/XLBs that Dumpling Kitchen makes, but the original (the first item on the menu I believe) is a classic and a great way to introduce someone that's never eaten them before. Each order has ten pieces in each basket, unless otherwise noted on the menu.

There are other foods that I've tried here, including broccoli beef and the potstickers. They were both very tasty and one could taste the 鑊氣/wok hei (flavor brought by a chef's skill in controlling fire throughout cooking). Their west lake beef soup is also very flavorful.

Dumpling Kitchen makes as use of all their room, so it may be a bit tight to move around at times, which is understandable, as more and more people find out about this place. They do have a couple large tables that can seat parties of 8+, but is mostly accommodated to parties of two to four.

Parking is definitely not easy to find due to apartments that have double wide garages, soaking up valuable curbside space. There is a Muni rail line right out front as well, so double parking on the tracks can cause great entertainment for others watching cars possibly getting smashed.

Also, though the restaurant closes at 10 P.M., the kitchen closes at 9 P.M. Make sure you get in before then, otherwise you will be turned away.

Other than that, Dumpling Kitchen is an excellent place to go stuff your face with yummy goodness.
author: Henry N.

description:
Holy crap they have the BEST soup dumplings (XLB, xiao long bao) and shen jian bao in SF, and I've had 'em at lots of places -- Kingdom of Dumpling, Shanghai Dumpling King, Yank Sing, Koi Palace, Dim Sum King.

They're so good I haven't even bothered venturing out of dumpling territory... but yeah my roommate swears by the pork belly.

Value: 5/5
Quality: 4.5/5
Service: 4/5, but this is one of 'em efficient Chinese places, don't expect people to wait on you and make small talk.
author: J C.

description: If it says dumpling order the dumplings!  Ordered the Xiao Long Bao along with the Pork and chives dumpling and let me say for the price they made it well!  None of the skins were popped and everything was nice and fatty just like homemade xiao long baos.  I would recommend to order more than you initially think because you will eat more than you expect!
author: Haley Z.

description: I had high hopes for the xiao long baos at this restaurant but it was just mediocre. I came here with a friend after a hike so we were famished, ready to devour any food in front of us. I have had xiao long baos several times before so I was excited for this place because it has 5 stars on  yelp. I ordered 2 orders of crab and pork xiao long baos/soup dumplings,1 order of the Shanghai chow mein, and sweet soy milk. My favorite dish was ... unfortunately the soy milk drink which wasn't even a dish, it was a drink. The soy milk wasn't too sweet, but you can still taste a hint of it. Unfortunately, I cannot give this place more than a 3 because... the soup dumplings were not soupy. The meat was soft and tender but there wasn't a lot of juice in the dumplings. When I eat soup dumplings, I expect the soup to be spilling out of the dumplings when I take a bite of it. No, I don't think it's high expectations because other restaurants were able to make that happen.Shanghai chow mein was also a downer. The noodles were too thick. Fine, I get it because it's supposed to be that way but the dish was lacking a lot of flavors, it was very blend. I had to add more soy sauce and chili to give it more flavors. It wasn't just me, my friend had to the same thing to enrich the noodles.
author: Ngoc P.

description: Came in for the first time on a Friday night and it was packed! A little bit tight inside, but the table next to us was very friendly so it wasn't a problem. Great service, good food! Will be back for more dumplings!
author: Cheyenne N.

description:
Second visit to Dumpling Kitchen.  First was in Sept. 2013.  Had number one Shanghai style steamed pork dumplings and number three pan fried pot stickers. Portions were good, nice big dumplings perfectly fried with good filling. We liked number one better than number three but both rate four stars. Good taste and equal to the wonderful dumplings on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. 

Price: Unlike the dumplings in Manhattan, these were not inexpensive. $7.50 per order. Most of the dumplings on the Lower East Side are five for $1.25. But there are dozens of places selling them in a small area, so it is economics. ie. large supply. 

A bowl of white steamed rice with our dumplings was $2.00.

Bathrooms were clean and there were two bathrooms. We were there early so we had prompt service.
author: Steven G.

description:
I didn't expect much but oh man I was impressed and have to agree with the person who wrote that these dumplings are as good as the ones in China.

I have eaten at many places like Din Tai Fung in Hong Kong and the coveted Joe Shanghai's in NYC; however, these are some of the best dumplings I have ever eaten asides from an unknown restaurant in Hong Kong...placing this store at number 2 on my list for Xiao Long Bao and Din Tai Fung in HK at number 3! I have never been a fan of Joe Shanghai's but just thought I throw it in there for reference.

I will definately be going back and bring many people the next time I'm in town so that I can try even more of their food!
author: Anthony C.

description:
First meal after an extended Vegas trip. Our bodies needed authentic Asian food. No more Asian fusion please. 

Of course we ordered the Pork XLB (xiao long bao, aka soup dumplings), along with Shanghai-style Chow Mein and Rice Cakes. The XLB takes a little longer because it has to be steamed, but it was worth the wait. The dumplings were meaty and the skin didn't fall apart, but I wish there was more soup in them. They also didn't give us any dipping sauce, but there is a bottle of vinegar on each table. The Chow Mein and Rice Cakes were just okay - probably would've been more flavorful/crispy if left on the wok a little longer.

Service was a bit standoffish, which is expected from Asian restaurants. The place was quiet at around 2pm, but that meant I could hear the family owners' conversation from the back table. 

We left with our bellies full, so we doggy-bagged our leftovers and donated it to a gentleman on Mission. He seemed to enjoy the food, too.
author: Ashley L.

description:
Stopped by this hole in the wall while visiting in SF and it's not bad.

Came in at about 12pm on a Saturday. I had to wait maybe 15 minutes before we got seated (party of 6) so that wasn't bad at all. Waiters and waitresses were nice and came to take our orders pretty quick so kudos to that. We tried a good amount of food so let's get to it!

Xiao Long Bao (#1 and #2)- I think I got spoiled by Ding Tai Fung because I thought that these were just okay. The meat is tasty but I thought the skin was too thick. I was disappointed that there wasn't really any soup in the dumplings, either! When it came out, it was luke warm, too. I'm used to seeing the steam come out from them when I bite into it. You also need to ask for ginger and vinegar. 

Shanghai Pan fried Bao - THIS was delicious! The thickness of the skin worked for these dumplings because they were fried, which made it nice and chewy. I prefer this over the XLB.

Shanghai stir fried rice cake - I loved the taste of the dish, but the rice cakes were either cooked just right or overcooked, which made them super sticky. 

Chicken wings - The wings were probably my favorite thing out of what we ate. The inside was super moist and tender. The outside was still a little bit crispy even though there was a glaze on it. I thought there was just a little too much glaze overpowering the taste of the chicken.
author: Michelle P.
Jie M.

description: Dumpling is OK but not the best for me. I ordered Braised Prok Belly with Preserved Veggies and Shanhai style stir-fried rice cake too. There both is good. I like pork belly. Overall food come very fast and the service is good too.
author: Orange S.

description: I was pretty underwhelmed by this place given the high ratings and number of reviews.  We ordered 6 dishes and nothing stood out to me.  Maybe we ordered the wrong things.  Their Xiao Long Bao was ok, but there's definitely much better ones out there.  The Shanghai-style rice cakes and noodle soup (forgot which one exactly) were really bland.  I've eaten at several other Chinese restaurants in SF that were way better.  Wish I had better things to say about this place, but unfortunately I won't be coming back.
author: Monica P.

description:
What happened?!?!?  We came here for dinner after a brief hiatus, and everything was not as good as we remembered.  The hot and sour soup, which I had so adored, was not spicy or sour, and was more soy saucy than anything.  The noodle dish we got was bland and forgettable.  The green onion pancakes were dry and didn't have enough green onions.  Sigh, nothing but disappointment.  Sadness, now must find a new Shanghai place to get my grub on.

I will note that the XLB dumplings were still the bomb-diggidity and perfection.  IF I come again, as yet to be determined, it will be the ONLY thing I order.
author: Christina L.

description: The dumplings are amazing here! The meat was tender and there is soup inside the regular dumplings! I didn't get to try the XLB this time but I will definitely be back. The Dan Dan Noodles was yummy but it was a little bit too saucy for me. Had to knock them one star for the ventilation. My clothes smell like oil and grease when I left their restaurant. Overall pretty solid dining experience!
author: Layona O.

description:
We were on our way to another dumpling place in the Outer Richmond, but bailed on that plan due to Outside Lands music festival traffic. Good thing, too, otherwise we wouldn't have found Dumpling Kitchen. We came with a craving and we left stuffed and so happy.

Here's what we got:

#1, steamed pork dumplings (XLB) - super delicious. It's what I was craving, and I was NOT disappointed. Filling was perfectly seasoned, and they had the perfect level of soupy-ness. Can't comment on the thickness of the wrapper as a few other Yelpers have, as this was only my second xiao long bao experience, but for what it's worth, I didn't find them overly thick. Loved 'em.

#11, wontons in house broth - broth was light but flavorful, and the wontons were really tasty. Pork filling with green onion had great flavor and texture. 

#14, green onion pancake - Excellent. Crispy, well-seasoned, not oily at all. 

Overall, we loved our meal and were extremely happy we ate here. Definitely going to recommend it to our SF friends who took us to Shanghai Dumpling King.
author: Sam S.

description:
They are on vacation until 6/10 heads up =)

Love this place! Whenever I'm craving a tradish Shanghainese breakfast, this place comes to mind. 

Must haves:
Soup dumplings (duh)
pan fried pork buns
Soymilk: fresh ground in house, not bought from vendor.
author: Virginia Q.

description:
Hands down one of the best places to eat authentic dumplings that reminds me of those that I eat in Shanghai! Most of the dumplings are very good, mainly the Xiao Long Bao. 

I also tried some of their dishes and one thing I would not recommend is their soy milk or their salty soy milk which I didn't like. It has a weird nutty flavor that I've never encountered and it isn't pleasant.
author: Rainar W.

description: Came here for lunch with the boyfriend. First, the wait wasn't too bad. The soy milk was good. The service wasn't too bad either. The pot stickers weren't anything special. The rice with onion and meat was actually good. Reasonable prices and a pretty good experience
author: Maggie W.

description: Finally, some good Chinese food in the city! I rarely come to this area, but have always been told to get Chinese food when I am. We got the pork and seafood soup dumplings, which were delicious! The way they're supposed to be (none of that gross, thick-skinned, stale stuff in Chinatown). The green onion pancakes were also really good, but not like the ones I'm used to (they were yellow and less flaky). We ordered the shanghainese rice cakes on recommendation from our waitress - could probably have skipped these. They weren't bad, just kind of bland. I wish we'd ordered the pork belly instead! That looked yummy. Would definitely come back here if I'm ever in the area again :)
author: Amanda L.

description:
What made this dining experience lackluster is not only because the food was mediocre, and seemed to be prepared with more haste than love, but the fact that the entire time I was chewing on oily flavorless scallion pancakes I was envisioning my family sucking on delicious real food in Shanghai.  At the exact same moment.  Them, thinly stripped bamboo shoot drizzled in sesame oil, fresh shrimps dipped in vinegar, dainty fish cakes floating in lotus soup.  Me, a giant pool of watery beef soup noodle with boring meat and Top Ramen lookalike noodles.  

Xiao Long Bao were pretty good.  But that's about it.  I am just going to give up now.  It's either a plane ticket or no Chinese food at all.
author: Candice B.

description:
What to get: 

Shanghai Pan Fried Bao:  similar to potstickers but in Bao form

Steamed dumplings: tasty centers 

What NOT to get: any of their noodle dishes. 

Beef stew noodles: beef was tough, noodles were bland

Shanghai rice cakes: bland, no flavor whatsoever

Shanghai thick noodles: bland, but had more flavor than the other two.


On the Fence:

Spicy wontons: good flavor, but the skins were soggy. 

MuShu Pork: lots of sauce, a bit on the saltier side.
author: Adrienne F.

description:
1. Shanghai Style Dimsum was perfect. 
2. Mapo Tofu could be a little more salty or seasoned but still really good. 
3. Sichuan Beef could be a little spicier?
author: Younji W.

description: The Shanghai original soup dumpling was great, the one with crab meat is so so. Love the ShengJian Bao (the dumpling with golden crust). It's a typical small Chinese restaurant, food come fast, service is fast.
author: Mary L.

description: Holy smokes!! Have you ever wanted to try some amazing dumplings? Well, then after reading this post I sure hope you drive/walk/bike here because the food is amazing! Not only do they have delicious dumplings, but they also serve other dishes such as green onion pancakes, braised pork belly, noodles, noodle soup, and so much more. Oops! Can't forget about the bowl/cup of soy milk to wash all the yummy down! I really cannot explain just how good the Shanghai style dumplings truly are. Just splash on a tad bit of vinegar plus soy sauce and indulge yourself in nirvana! (Not literally, but you get what I'm saying!) I'll admit that being in SF, we are blessed with so many other dumpling restaurants that it is nearly impossible to taste it all (maybe not, but my wallet can't handle it...). Nonetheless, I really suggest coming here at least once whenever you have the chance. You won't regret it!
author: Benson M.

description: Awesome food, fast service!!!  Inexpensive prices.  Parking can be an issue, but well worth the visit!
author: Mimi P.

description:
Summary: In the Xiao Long Bao showdown on Taraval St, the nearby Kingdom of Dumpling is still my favorite. I do recommend going to Dumpling Kitchen if the wait for Kingdom is too long and you're willing to sacrifice a margin of deliciousness in exchange for being seated in a reasonable amount of time.

Deliciousness: Kingdom wins here with superior Xiao Long Bao flavor and their soy/vinegar dipping sauce. However, Kitchen's XLB had better structural integrity. Even the dumplings that were stuck together could be pulled apart without losing the all-important soup filing.

Cleanliness: Dumpling Kitchen by a small margin. Both health reports are pretty scary, but who cares? These are dumplings, filled with soup!

Wait time: Dumpling Kitchen wins by seating in 10 min vs wait times of 30 min or more at Kingdom. Kitchen's dining capacity is maybe twice that of Kingdom.

Service: Kitchen edges out Kingdom here ever so slightly. Hot tea was delivered immediately, and I got a water refill without asking. Kitchen also doesn't hustle you about only being able to place one order like Kingdom does.

Value: Like Kingdom, Kitchen's prices are incredibly reasonable. Kitchen's XLB cost less than Kingdom, but other dumpling orders cost more.
author: Kris H.

description: Love the soup dumplings and egg puffs! Would definitely come back again.
author: Yuan J.

description:
Very nice restaurant in the Sunset district.  We went during the week to avoid the crowd.

We had xiao lung bao, sin jin bao, cao nian gao, tian do jiang, xian do jiang with yiou tiao.  It was prepared to order, tasted authentic and delicious.

The xlb was hot with a modest amount of soup in the bao; the tdj was served in a glass and sweet but not super sweet and combined well with the yt which had the right balance of crispness and dough texture; xdj came in a bowl with ro song (pork fu), salted veggie, and yt and tasted good though I prefer the tdj.  Finally, the cng dish - noodles were of good texture and consistency; spongy but not chewy and firm but not tough.  It was cooked with a modest amount of pork and cabbage - a pretty good balance.

The biggest downside for me is that I live in the East Bay which means I'll probably try to come when we have visitors to the Bay Area.  Doing it on a regular basis in SF traffic in general is discouraging to say the least.  Maybe they will consider opening an East Bay locale!

One last note - though they say they accept credit card, it actually is debit or cash.  That is posted under the glass of the table.
author: Cheyenne W.

description: Solid dim sum! The xiao long bao are extra sticky and cling to your chop sticks, but they are delicious! And the Shanghai style chow main blew me away with their homemade noodles! I've never had chow main like this before.
author: Adamme K.

description:
Service is terrible. First you must sign in on a clip board and indicate how many people in your party. Although I signed in, a party of five were seated before my party of six. I was the second person to be called on the list. Then after we sat down at our table, our waitress was too busy to provide us tea or take our order. 

We order dumplings, soup, and a crispy chive pancake. The dumplings and chive pancake were delicious.  The soup was good too. I really enjoyed the hot sauce provided on the table. 

Overall I would have rated this place a 4 star but the service was terrible. Yes I will go back and hope the service improves.
author: Frank A.

description: Had the crab xlb, garlic spinach, dry fried chicken wings, hot and sour soup, along with fried bun with condensed milk, and a hot soy milk. This place did not disappoint at all! Got our food all fairly quick. The chicken wings were good! You guys must try :)
author: Vivian L.

description: Pan friend dumplings (Sheng jian bao) and XLB . That is all you need to leave this place satisfied. DELICIOUS. A definite hidden treasure in the Outer Sunset...
author: Caye Q.

description:
I am their old customer.

Foods: came out faster than before.
Green Onion Pancake : too much baking soda. it is bitter. 
Service: very good.
Quality of ingredient: lower than before. (rice is hard to eat, and some meats are harder than before )

Price : higher than before but SF minimum wage rises.

I just request if they use high quality rice would be great.
author: Ryan S.

description: Stars are based off the soup dumplings alone. SO GOOD. A lot of places have barely any soup in the dumpling, or the soup is bland. Here, it's literally perfect. 10 pieces for $8.50 isn't bad considering how good it is.
author: irene f.

description:
Legend tells of a legendary warrior whose Kung Fu skills were the stuff of legend.  Through focus and concentration, he had abilities few can imitate.  Here's a clip:  http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pxcI5g2iUCg&feature=youtube_gdata_player

Legend also speaks of an Elite Master Yelper whose yelping/eating skills were stuff of legend...

This Master Yelper trekked across rugged landscape in search of worthy Dumplings.  He said nothing for his mouth was full, until he swallowed his food.  As he walked through into Dumpling Kitchen, he was so hungry and fierce his enemies would go blind from overexposure to his pure awesomeness.

So he ordered his food:

Pan-Fried Pot Stickers:  Extremely delicious tiny pockets of joy.  The only reason the Master Yelper didn't beat Po's record of 40 dumplings is because they come in only 10 per order.  But if the master had 41 dumplings, they were so tasty he would have finished them.  These dumblings are of legend as well.

Dry Fried Chicken Wings:  Good sized, sweet, spicy wings.  But no match for the Master's appetite.  

Combination Chow Mein:  generous amount of house-made noodles mixed with beef, seafood, pork, and chicken.  Very good quality noodles.

Despite Dumpling Kitchen having dumplings of legend and good food, it could not slow down this great Master Yelper.  Never before has a Yelper been so feared and loved.

Even the most excellent Yelpers in all of the Bay Area would bow in respect to this Master Dumpling eater.  Skadooosh!
author: Michael L.

description: Decent comfort food. The skin on the xiao long bao (2.5 stars) was too thick and there wasn't much soup. There was vinegar as a dipping sauce but no shredded ginger. The vegetarian pot stickers (3 stars) were better - kinda greasy and the skin was thick but it was a little more pleasant probably because it was fried. The zha jiang mian (3 stars) was alright too but my brother says he's had way better ones in the San Gabriel Valley.
author: Nicola L.

description:
Used to like this place, but unfortunately cannot eat my favorite Xiao Long Bao here anymore as I've recently found out I am gluten intolerant, and the XLB here is not gluten free. They mix wheat flour with rice flour to make the dumpling skin. 

Contrary to this, authentic xiao long bao is made only with rice flour, which is not the case here.
author: Yelper 2.

description: The XLB is awesome! But other dishes were very average. We will just order XLBs next time.
author: J G.

description:
I looove Dumpling Kitchen! First of all, out of the couple of times I've been here, I've never really had to wait. Although it's a decently sized restaurant with minimal decor, it does get a little crowded, especially in the back, BUT I'm not complaining. Oh, and just an FYI, they only take reservations for parties of 5 and up. 

The FOOD though... Their XLB are sooo yummy. Sometimes I wish I could just eat them all day. I've tried their XLB and the chili oil dumplings. Both are GREAT and I really recommend you try those. I've also had the green onion pancakes, Shanghai noodles/rice cakes (?), and the dry fried chicken wings, none of which were anything remarkable...
author: Kathryn Y.

description:
10 Nov 2013, 10:30a

Second visit here and still as good as the first.  Blows the Kingdom of Dumpling up two blocks on Taraval out of the water.  Service is better, food is better.  We ordered:

1. Shanghai-Style Steamed Pork Dumplings (2 orders)
12. Wontons in Chili Oil (2 orders)
13. Shanghai-Style Green Onion Pancake
Pea Sprouts w/garlic

Wow, that was a lot of food.  Our friend's favorite (who lives around the corner) is the #12.  They are very tasty, as are the #1.  I thought the #1 here were a LOT better than those at Kingdom of Dumpling because the soup is so much more flavorful.  Of course, it could also be that a lot of the soup at KoD leaked out because the skins were so thin, but had a thick knot of dough at the top.  The #1 here are just right because the skins don't break when you try to pick them up and there's not a huge knot of dough at the top.

I've heard the #13 here is a different preparation than at other places, but I can't attest to that because I've only had it here.  Maybe it's the Shanghai-Style which is different.  Whatever it is, I like how they do it here!

The Pea Sprouts were very good, also.  They are similar to Chinese broccoli, but not.  A slightly bitter taste, cooked and served with whole garlic cloves.  Hubby's new favorite veggie, replacing his previous favorite, Gai Lon.

Again, would definitely come here repeatedly, especially when staying with our friend.  It's very convenient for a filling breakfast/brunch and easy to go from there with the Muni stop right one block down.
author: SoCal C.

description:
Omg this place is soooo yummy!!
#1, 8, 13 are the BEST!!!!!!! Definitely not what you'd expect from the outside but holy moly is this a hidden gem!!!! Highly recommend!!!!(well for takeout at least)

4stars because the service was terrible :( Our waiter forgot to include some items we ordered and was not attentive- he sat and ate lunch at a table next to us rather than remembering to put in our order.

Other than the service, the food is amazing!
author: Michelle O.

description: Food was terrific and service (once seated) was fast.  Only giving a 4 star rating because it was very busy and the wait for a table for significant but otherwise really good food.
author: Mother K.

description:
San Francisco, California
Great Food.  This is why I love yelp....this place would easily be over looked.  It's not much to look at from the street or from the inside for that matter.  But the food is really 5-Stars.

We had the Moo Shu Pork, green beans, XLB, pot stickers, steamed pork dumplings, wings et cetera.  All were great.  

Do you homework on what to order because the staff, although friendly and efficient, were not very helpful with suggestions.  

The pricing was very reasonable.
author: Kevin C.

description:
The crab/pork XLB are the best I've had yet. Be careful because it piping hot! I was too excited and burned the roof of my mouth once. Definitely learned my lesson, lol. 

Also, must get the pan fried shanghai buns. Very generous portion so be ready to share!
author: Suzie J.

description: This place is great! My friend and I bussed all the way here from Berkeley TWICE just for this place. I love their xiao long baos and hot and sour soup, but I would say that their beef noodles stew has changed since the first time I came here. The wait is always long, even when its 45 minutes before closing! After our most recent visit, my friend came out of the meal asking, "is it just me or did this place get less authentic?" And I couldn't disagree. We probably won't be coming here for a while after this.
author: Christine C.

description: Yummy!!!  Best Siu Lone Bao in SF!!!  (AKA Shanghai Dumplings or translated:  Little Dragon Wraps/Dumplings).  You can eat a whole order by yourself!  Come on an empty stomach!
author: Connie W.

description:
Service: 4.5 Stars
Food: 5 Stars
Ambiance:  4 Stars
Cleanliness:  5 Stars

Came here on a weekday afternoon and the place was empty...just between the two rushes.

I suspect that we were attended to more than others who come here during the lunch and dinner rush since we were the first patrons in for the afternoon.

Ordered:

Shanghai Steamed Dumpling (Xiao Loung Bao)
Pan-Fried Shanghai Dumpling 
Green Onion Pancake
Won Ton in Chilli Oil
Tan Tan Noodles

Everything was on hit! I cannot say enough about the food here. This place is legit. My only wish...that it was closer to home so I could come more often.

The noodles are all fresh hand-pulled noodles...soooo good.

The kids ate well here and I got my grub on like a king.
author: Tavis S.

description:
Desperate for a way to satisfy our soup dumpling craving now that Shanghai Dumpling King has gone south, we trusted Yelp on this one and we're glad we did. 

Showed up at 5:45 on a Friday evening to an almost empty restaurant; by the time we left at 6:30 almost all the tables were full. 

Down to business:
Service - did have to flag down a waitress a few times,  but it's team service so you can grab whomever is passing. That's easy and convenient. 
Soup dumplings - perfect skin + perfect flavor + soupy inside = excellent! 
Pan fried pot stickers - tender, flavorful 
Sweet buns - sinful
Garlic bok choy - meh - no good flavors. i miss the pea shoots at SDK
Shanghai chow mein - ordered some to go, it was that good. Seriously delicious. Fat noodles, vegetables, and pork. GET IT.
author: Caitlin S.

description: Is it the overcrowdedness? Is it the grimey tables and the wall decor? What is it? The food here is awesome and after about four visits to this place I always am willing to come back for Xiaolongbau's and other dishes, but I can't give five stars on this place. A real gem though; a friendly staff and a real homey feel to this place that is worth every visit. The only place that rivals the superiority of the shanghai dumplings in SF probably has to be Yank Sing.
author: Al L.

description: Solid place to go for xiao long baos in this area. Dry fried chicken wings were good but you know where to get the best dry fried.
author: Jenny W.

description: I'm often in the neighborhood and I love this food.  Best dumplings since Hong Kong!
author: Donna M.

description: the food is very good, but service is very bad.  Xio Long Bao: A+. Service: D+.  I said bye to head waiter and he ignored me for no reason. Also the glass looked dirty when he gave me a glass of water.
author: James C.

description: My boyfriend and I were in Frisco for the day and decided to get some dim sum. Of course I found this place on Yelp. rating were good and it wasn't that far from where we were. Simple and cozy. There were a lot of kids which made the noise level higher than usual I'm sure. we had the pork dumplings which were good and the salt and pepper chicken wings. Over all good, the tea was a little on the bitter side. Service was ok and we spent about 20 bucks. Not bad for the meal and we were good until dinner hit. I plan to go back and try some other stuff ont the menu.
author: Bianca N.

description: Seriously reconsider your review! This place is overrated. If you compare this place with Din Tin Fung then you know what real dumpling taste like, unless you want Cantonese Shanghai fusion dumplings!
author: Adam G.

description: Came here on a recommendation from a friend.  We really loved the XLB.  The dumplings were delicious and we loved how it held the juices inside so well.  I also ordered some mongolian beef because I have this weird thing were I like to order this at every chinese restaurant I go to when they offer it.  That was also very delicious too in my opinion.  Would definitely come here again when I am in the area.  Price is fairly cheap and food is very good.
author: Charles L.

description:
Excellent bargain with plenty of left overs. I brought a friend from out of town here and it was a great dumpling experience. We ordered the XLB, pot stickers, the chicken w/broccoli, the mapo tofu and the green onion pancake. 

Plenty for a heavy lunch for two with leftovers for a full dinner afterwards.

The XLB and dumplings were totally on point. Not soggy or greasy. My chicken w/broccoli came with a delicious and light fried rice. Green onion pancake was delicious and it was a great experience dining at this place.

I'd suggest arriving early if you don't want to wait. We came at 11:30 and got the last 2 person table and if we would have arrived 15 minutes later, we would have had a long wait (we went on a Friday during a holiday weekend).
author: Robin P.

description:
My boyfriend and I recently moved from Hong Kong and feel like we've been on an eternal hunt for good, authentic Chinese food since returning stateside. Last night, our hunt ended with basket upon basket of shanghai-style, fresh, plump, juicy dumplings and the lightest and perfectly cooked pea shoots.

The xiao long bao is the best I've ever tasted outside Asia. Unlike the frozen dumplings you find in most places, these had the perfect ratio of meat to juice to dough, which by the way was nice and thin, an instant clue that this place was legit.

The pan fried pork baos - shen jian bao - were good but not my fave. They were extremely tasty but by now I had been spoiled by the XLB - I found them a little too sweet and too oily, and they could have been fried a little longer for that nice golden crisp on the base. But honestly, I'm just being picky.
