We also ordered the chilli oil dumplings (hong you chau shou) which were tasty but weird - the filling was AMAZING - rivaling even some of the best I've had in Hong Kong - but the sauce was thick and peanutty, like what you'd get over a bowl of Dan Dan mian. It was good, but weird. Make sense?

My only, only complaint about Dumpling Kitchen is that the portion sizes were TOO HUGE. My boyfriend and I love to order lots of dishes but felt constraint here given that each order of dumplings came at a 10 piece standard serving! So, I'm demoting one star only because I wanted to have been able to eat MORE.

As far as atmosphere, it was classic, no-frills Chinese. 

Overall we left fat and happy. Worth the haul to Sunset? YES!
author: Stephanie C.

description: Amazing little hole in the wall. Defiantly worth a try if you're in the area. A future go to after the zoo or ocean beach.
author: Mike I.

description: We all got food poisoning!  We went on Sunday February 19th. My son did not eat anything but my daughter, husband and I are dumplings, pan fried dumplings, won ton soup and all are super sick. Very disappointed.  The food tasted good going down but this is not ok.
author: Julie D.

description:
*Food: I love their Shanghai Dumplings 小籠包. The sauce is great and the skin wasn't too thick. Their pot stickers were good too. We also order this onion pancake, it was a bit too oily and not enough flavoring. The Shanghai sticky rice is delicious. (上海年糕) Do order the 生煎包, my friend definitely have that thumbs up.

* Service: it was not bad for a Chinese restaurant. There were a few younger workers who were nicer and more willing to help so overall the service boosted up. 

.
author: Katie P.

description: Food is good. We ordered the crab XLB, pork potstickers and also the Shanghai style noodle. Potstickers are the best with really thin skin and they pan fried those properly. Crispy on the outside and juicy in the inside. XLB for me is a bit too much ginger, but still good. All in all, not bad. But why only 3 stars? Service! The waiters are talking all around the dining room in Cantonese just like at their home. They are chatting all the way to heaven without minding their customers. Needed to wave to order our food, wave for my bill and dirty plates were all over the table even after we paid our bill. Might be back but definitely to go only!
author: Mandy W.

description:
Way better than Kingdom of Dumpling just a few blocks down, but still not at the level of my favorite Shanghainese place in the Bay Area, Shanghai Dumpling Shop. So, Dumpling Kitchen is less of a hole in the wall that Kingdom of Dumpling and actually has tables that seat more than 4 people. This is a place that multi-generational Chinese families like to frequent, so they have a plethora of large, round tables. In fact, my party of only 3 was seated at a table that could have comfortably accommodated 6. We had to wait a bit around 7pm on the Sunday evening when we arrived, but tables soon cleared up. 

We ordered XLB (about $7 for 10), Shanghai egg rolls (sadly vegetarian), clay pot rice with smoked ham, Shanghai stir fried noodles, and pea shoots. The XLB were pretty amazing! Each of them had a wrapper that was thin, but not TOO thin that they would break upon touch. And they each carried a lot of tasty soup! My only quibble with the XLB is that the quality of the pork used seemed not very good because there were a lot of chewy bits that didn't taste so good in the filling. 

The Shanghai stir fried noodles and egg rolls were not very authentic seeming as they used shredded cabbage and carrot and green onions in addition to the shredded pork and lacked the pea shoots and napa cabbage. Traditional stir fried noodles have pea shoots, napa cabbage, and shredded pork. At least they used the right chewy noodles and sweet soy sauce to flavor it. This seemed more like just regular chow mien. And the egg rolls had similar fillings of cabbage and carrot rather than a nice mixture of seasoned and stir fried napa cabbage, shitake mushroom, and seasoned pork. They were still tasty, but not what I wanted. And they were EXTREMELY greasy too. Shanghainese style egg rolls aren't supposed to be vegetarian!

The clay pot rice was really tasty and it features large slices of smoked pork on top of the whole thing. My sister let the rice sit at the edge of the clay pot for a good long while so it got really crispy. It seemed really light, but the leftovers were perfect as the saltiness of the pork really blended into the rice. The pea shoots were perfect too, and I especially liked how they didn't put in minced garlic and went with sauteed whole cloves of garlic instead. This made it really easy to pick them out!

I would definitely consider returning to Dumpling Kitchen for the XLB, clay pot rice, and pea shoots. I would avoid the Shanghai stir fried noodles and Shanghai egg rolls.
author: Leslie H.

description:
Three stars for overall food, minus one for having a piece of little bone in a dumpling and letting a vegetable delivery worker with a few boxes passing through the middle of the narrow dining area with full of customers still during lunch time hour (1:30pm or so).
Among most kinds of dumplings, fried rice cake, and sizzling rice soup that we ordered, everything felt that there was some missing ingredient to make its taste better.  Their stir fried bean leaves was great, though!  I would order only this dish to go if I lived in SF.
It was super crowded when we went, which made them look like a popular place, but the long wait was probably only because some good restaurants were closed on Labor Day.
author: Hsu E.

description: My favorite spot for XLB in the city! I had their noodles and wings once--getting the wings just made me want to go to San Tungs instead! Their XLBs are reasonably priced I could eat a whole thing of it to myself haha.
author: Alice Z.

description:
Since Kingdom of Dumpling doesn't open until 11 or 11:30 on Sundays, we walked down the street until we stumbled upon Dumpling Kitchen.

Shanghai soup dumplings were done surprisingly well here and from what I recall, the price point is a tad lower too, so you get ten squishy balls of joy for $8. The wrapper was just right since you could see the pork through it, but no soup leakage at all!

I loved their version of Shanghai style fried noodles, partially because of the excellent portion size. Getting the dumplings and the noodle dish was more than enough for two hungry dudes.

Would love to try their egg puffs next time.

Wish they had vinegar handy on the tables!
author: Kevin L.

description:
Their dumpling skins too thick and anf doughy. It also didn't keep the soup inside the dumplings very well. May be my fault to hold every other xiao long bao to Din Tai Fung's. 
I also had the dry-fried chicken wings, which were over-sauced with this overly sweet gunk. The chicken wasn't well-fried and was missing that dry crispiness. May be my fault to have San Tung as my baseline for this dish. 
I'm wondering if I had mis-ordered and missed out on the things that got this place their excellent ratings. Based on my experience, this is definitely not a four star establishment.
author: Jen H.

description:
This restaurant is in the depressing Parkside district which makes it a good destination for locals, but not really for tourists.  The interior is about what you'd expect for this neighborhood- pretty utilitarian. 

Ah, but the food is good. The XLBs had thin skins, great flavor, and no leakage. They were amazingly really inexpensive ( something like 10 for $7.)   The dry fried green beans were perfectly cooked, and had a fair amount of pickle on top, which I like.

Service was pleasant, and the food came quickly. 

I would have given 5 stars, but there was a TON of chemical contaminant ( msg ) on everything, which might be why it all tasted so good....
author: El B.

description:
I LOVE the xiao long bao at Kingdom of Dumpling so when I heard about the opening of Dumpling Kitchen I knew I had to check it out when the xiao long bao craving hit!  

We ordered:
*Xiao Long Bao ($6)- Great price for 10.  The buns were big and filled with juice.  Not super hot as it usually is, which is kind of a plus.  We loved them of course!
*Shanghai-Style Green Onion Pancake ($3.60)--Thicker, but less doughy then others we had, if that makes sense.  The pancake was huge, and we liked it!  Not very oily either, which is always a plus.
*Dry Fried Chicken Wings ($7.5)--We were curious & wanted a little extra dish to nibble on.  They gave a lot of wings & were meaty, but we could have done without them.  Sauce was slightly sweet but made it very slippery to eat and was nothing special.  Definitely doesn't have anything on SO or San Tung's wings.
*Crispy Egg Puffs ($3)---Been wanting to try these at Kingdom of Dumpling, but they never had them whenever I went.  These are like three light fluffy sugar dusted donuts without all the filling!  Soo good!  

Dumpling Kitchen is a lot bigger, cleaner, and better staffed (they're very attentive too) than Kingdom of Dumpling.  DK also offers more menu items.  Bf would like to come back here again instead of KoD because of those reasons for more juicy xiao long baos & crispy egg puffs!  MMM xiao long bao, I just had you yesterday & I'm so craving you again!
author: Cat C.

description:
We have been coming here for several years now. The food has been consistently good. The Xiao Long Bao, which we order on every visit, is probably the best around. I've always left feeling satisfied. So why only three stars?

On our last visit, we were told that they no longer accept credit cards. Of course, with no advanced warning, we were caught off guard, and had to scramble around to pay the bill. They refused to make a one-time exception, even for a regular loyal customer.

Disappointed.
author: David W.

description: Big portions of tasty food. Be warned that they only take debit cards and cash, no credit cards.
author: Carol N.

description:
My favorite place in the city to get XLB (I wish we had a DinTaiFung though). The filling is juicy and tasty.
I also recommend the Shanghai Buns which is like a bao version of the XLB and just as good. Add on a noodle or rice cake dish and the pea shoots or green beans and that's enough for me and the Mr. 

I will say, I am not a fan of this style of green onion pancake, too doughy/greasy for my tastes but I might just be used to the flakier sort.
author: Steph D.

description:
Came here around 1pm on a Saturday and I waited around 20 minutes for a table for 2. 

Here's what I ordered:
Soup dumplings - they were okay. Good enough to satisfy my cravings but I've definitely had better. The vinegar they have is on the sweet side which I wasn't used to
Shanghai style rice cakes - they was also on the sweet side. It was good enough for my bf and I to finish but I would have liked it if it was a little saltier.

There 2 dishes were really filling (we also weren't that hungry in the first place). Will keep this place in the back of my mind if I ever crave soup dumplings again.
author: Renee W.

description:
"Pan fried pork buns, pan fried pork buns, and please more pan fried pork buns. " 

The food was unbelievably good but service etiquette department  kinda lacks.  However, the food totally outweighs the service here so i have no complaints. If you are planning to go here, please get the #1, #5, #7, and #9, oh boy i wish i took a picture of the menu. 

Five out of five!!!
author: Erwin B.

description: THE BEST SOUP DUMPLING IN SF. It's a small little place on Taraval Street. The highlights are definitely the Xiao long bao and all of the dumplings (major fan of the pork + chive and shrimp + chive). The noodle and pancake dishes are just okay, though I enjoy the green beans. The wonton soup was also good but seriously - just get the dumplings. There is oftentimes a wait, but it's worth it in this very homey, warm restaurant. You can even see them cooking massive vats of XLB if you're closer to the kitchen. You might feel a little rushed, but it's an overall must.
author: Ali F.

description: My dumplings were burnt and the space was way too cramped. I would never go back there again. I honestly have no idea how it got such great reviews. My twin and I both hated it.
author: Julie G.

description:
Great dumplings!
I got the XLB and my girlfriend got the pork and chive for a quick brunch before the 49er game.  Amazing flavors and I can't wait to go back and try even more!
author: Brandon M.

description:
So.... Being Asian (Chinese) you'd like I'd get my behind to a dumpling restaurant a lot sooner in my life.... 


Well....


False lol! 


Today was the first time being in a restaurant that has pride in their dumplings.  I didn't have high hopes but because of all the hype maybe I was hoping for it to blow my mind. 

We ordered Shanghai pork dumplings , Dan Dan noodles, and sesame chicken over rice (little guy likes panda'a Orange chicken) 

The pork dumplings were good at first, texture was great, simple, it had broth coming out, woo!!! Well..... As you continue to eat, it doesn't get tastier it's just ehh.... Maybe they're all like this? 

The Dan Dan noodles were good! I'd like a little more punch in the sauce but hey not too bad for what it was! 

The sesame chicken was a disappointment. It tasted more like lemon chicken.... And the didn't do a great job frying the chicken. It was soggy and soft.... Gross I didn't like it luckily the kid doesn't know better.  

Overall the place is alright... It isn't fancy so don't expect the best. 

 out!
author: Jorlyn W.

description:
Superb dumplings! They are very juicy and filling. I also tried the wonton vegetable soup, which turned out to be a very satisfying and healthy choice! It comes in a light soup base with house-made wontons and fresh vegetables (mushroom, carrots, bok-choy, and broccoli). 

As with many authentic and popular chinese restaurants in SF, parking is not easy and space is pretty limited. One thing I discovered while waiting in line is that it's easier to get a table if you are a party of 3+. I came with a friend and we got held behind since they had more 4-seater tables than 2-seater ones and they wanted to maximize the # of people at each table.
author: Sophia H.

description:
hella good.

though i came here for the XLB, the stars of the show were the super crispy bottom potstickers, both veggie and pork. the crab xlb and the pork were a-ok. not the best, but not the worst. it will definitely satisfy a craving.

also order shanghai style rice cakes and onion pancake. skip the meatball soup- kingdom of dumplings version is much better.
author: Vanessa D.

description:
Not bad. However not the best dumplings, noodles and vegetables I've had in Sunset. Service is acceptable but the food was served lukewarm. Dumplings are better hot! 

Despite the more favorable reviews, I'll be going to other nearby establishments for my next dumpling fix.
author: Peter M.

description: Long wait.. but the XLB's are worth it. We only had a party of 2, so we couldnt try the noodles and fried chicken,  but will definitely go back if Im in the area.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
a huge fan of the xlb here (that's "soup dumplings" for the uninitiated). the skin is thin but very durable -- exactly the way REAL xiao long bao should be. anyone that tells you otherwise doesn't know how traditional xlb is supposed to be.

we also got vegetarian dumplings that were surprisingly good. i was impressed that in addition to the smattering of green veggies usually present in veggie dumplings, there were also pieces of mushroom and tofu. LOVEEEE. large portions of sizable dumplings make for two very happy stomachs.

the green onion pancake that everyone talks about is indeed different from the norm. these are baked(?) as opposed to fried, creating a soft fluffy pancake texture rather than the thin, crispy, and oily green onion pancakes we're all so used to. i'll agree it's not for everyone -- but i quite enjoyed them and they at least felt healthier to eat.

feeling like we were missing a basic veggie dish, we also ordered eggplant in garlic sauce. that was probably our only mistake of the night. i normally find garlic sauce to be pretty heavy/oily/salty and this dish was no different. the eggplant texture was great, but the dish would've benefited from scaling back on the sauce a bit.

but hey, no wait at 8pm on a tuesday night. winnning!
author: Yiwen S.

description:
I was excited and then disappointed. The food is good but not that great that the rating has suggested. 

The green onion pancake is not the usual one. Its like bread. Not like the flaky roti. 

The shanghai fried sticky rice cake is good. But nothing special. Crab and pork dumpling didn't really have crab. Just a good, juicy shanghai xiao long Bao dumpling. Nothing too special. 

What can I say. I have high standards for Chinese food.
author: Helen L.

description:
Anytime I'm in the mood for dumplings (which is all the time), this is the first place I go to. Yes Kingdom of Dumpling down the street might get more hype and might have more publicity, but this place is where it's at. It's bigger than the cramped up Kingdom of Dumpling, and honestly, I find it much better. Whether you're eating with a large group or you're just eating with your significant other, this place has it all. 

The Xiao Long Bao and the pan fried pork buns are an absolute must. Both are so good and definitely leave you craving for more. You can't come here without trying either of these things. Other favorites of mine include the Shanghai style noodles (super delicious and filling), green onion pancakes (my only complaint is that they don't put nearly enough green onion), green beans, and the soy milk (get it!! It's warm and fresh and pure yumminess). 

This place gives the right amount of food for the amount you pay. You end up leaving satisfied, happy, and ready to tackle the rest of the your day. Just beware of the line that may form - especially during prime time such as lunch on weekends.
author: Aaron W.

description: I think this is my new favorite dumpling place! Most of the other places I like have one particular dish they do really well, but everything we got here was really tasty. Particularly the pan fried pork buns - the best I've found in SF so far.
author: Jo B.

description:
Hair in our food.

Can you please have your staff wear hats or hair nets? I dunno if it came from the servers or from the cooks. Front floor staff or kitchen staff, just make everyone wear a hat.
author: Wendy L.

description:
Dumpling Kitchen just might give my other fave dumpling joint a run for their money.


By now, I'd consider myself a XLB connoisseur, if you will. And since I've become such a regular at Shanghai Dumpling King, I was out to find another dumpling place that would be comparable and ding ding ding, we have a winner. Dumpling Kitchen isn't the usual whole in the wall joints for dumpling eatery, it's definitely big enough to bring the whole fam and even a few friends.  The first time I came, it was around dinner time and the place was full. Wait wasn't too bad and once we got seated, we went right for the Shanghai Dumplings and even opted for the Pan Fried Pork Buns since we saw them floating around other people's tables - they was looking all types of cute.


The pan fried pork buns actually took the show, they were SO yummy. Came out like..well, little buns. Nice soft outsides with just the right amount of crisp to the bottom and let's not forget to mention the warm pork on it's insides.  The XLBs were also delish; juicy and the skin wasn't too thick which is the way I like um.


Came back for a second round with the cousin's and tried the Shanghai pan fried noodles, the fatty ones - you'll see when you get there or when you browse through the pics, twas alright.  We got both kinds and eh, it's a good filler to have on the side but nothing to brag about.  We also got the sticky rice rolls which had a fried roll on the inside and was stuffed with shredded pork. It was pretty interesting, worth giving a go. Spicy wontons also made their way onto on table and they was spicy. I likes.


Service here has always been good. The ladies all speak English, so no worries my foreign friends and they're pretty attentive so always a plus. Cousins and I are gonna try to convince the whole fam to come for dinner, for ya know, those kinda occasions.
author: Annie C.

description: This place is a must to eat dim sum. Even though the restaurant is very tiny and small but they cook their own food at their kitchen, some sort of like a family kitchen kind of feeling. The line is very long due to their prestige. The owner (or maybe manager) is very friendly. He thanks and says sorry all the time to those who queue.
author: Tran M.

description: Love going here for my dumpling fix! I really like their chili wonton, pot stickers, and egg puffs!!
author: Stephanie Z.

description:
I was craving dim sum this particular day and we happened to be in the area. Or wait. Were we in the area and then I craved dim sum? Oh well, it doesn't matter, Dumpling Kitchen came up well reviewed with enough stars for me to be like, "Let's do this!" We had our two kids with us, so seeing the crowd outside kinda turned me off, but we were already there, so we waited. Trust, it was less than 7 minutes when they seated us and it was a full house. 

We ordered the family dinner which included shrimp and pork dumplings, fried chicken and chowmein. I think we were in such a rush to eat because the kids were getting restless and the hubbs was getting grouchy, we chose it without thinking. 

Everything came except our fried egg puffs at the end. We didn't even bother mentioning it because we were just having an "alright" experience, that we just wanted to pay and leave. The hot and sour soup had some sort of flavor that was pretty strong and I didn't like it. The noodles were fatter than what I prefer. They served the fried chicken but it was doused in this sweet and sour sauce that I didn't care for. The corn and chicken soup was the only thing that my kids loved eating, so that saved us our sanity throughout our dining experience.  The dumplings were good but there weren't enough. 

Yes, next time I come here, I'm definitely going to stick to the plan and actually just order dim sum.
author: Sharon B.

description: The one star is credited to the yummy food.  I was VERY DISAPPOINTED at such bad service there.  Were only 4 tables there with customers.  2 waiters there were having a good time talking so loud about the engine and power of the their cars.  Didn't bother to take our orders till we waived at them few times.  When our food came, he was so rude and just placed hot bowl of beef noodle soup in front of my daughter, where it could have easily burned her if she reached out.  I asked for extra napkins, the tall chubby waiter rolled his eyes at me and slapped extra napkins on my plate.  Service was simply rude. Will not go there again.
author: JLcam T.

description:
"Have you tried the dumpling place on Taravel"?!  "Have you tried the dumpling place on Taravel"?!  "Have you tried the dumpling place on Taravel"?!

If you're giving me recommendations to a restaurant, I would appreciate it if you knew the exact name of the place!  I was excited to try the dumplings and especially the green onion pancake.  After being deceived by the other "dumpling place" on Taravel, I finally found the right one!

All the XLB's were flavorful and juicy!  

The Shanghai style pan fried pork buns were crisy on the bottome, soft on top, meaty inside, and they were huge!

The potstickers didn't look appetizing, plus I like mine fried so I passed on those.

The Shanghai style stir fried rice cakes were bland.

The green onion pancake (which I have been a fan of since the beginning) exceeded my expectations.  It didn't look fried so it wasn't as crispy and greasy as other pancakes but oh boy these were soo good!  

The crispy egg puffs with sugar were okay.  Nothing special.  

The garlic sautéed pea sprouts were cooked nicely.  

The complimentary peanuts were nice and salty!

Come here for the XLB's and green onion pancake. that's it. do it. now.
author: Linda N.

description:
Came here for dinner with a group of 5 and was seated promptly. We got shanghai soup dumplings, pan fried buns, wonton in chilly oil, string beans, and dry fried chicken wings. For a four star 800 rating place, I was expecting something more.

Soup dumplings were fine, nothing special but perfectly okay. Pan fried buns were a bit disappointing, the flavor just wasn't really there. Wonton in chilly oil was seriously lacking on the chilly oil. Even after some mixing we still weren't able to get the chilly oil well distributed on the wontons. Be less stingy on the sauce! And the dry fried chicken wings? I was expecting something legit based on photos on Yelp but what showed up was seriously underwhelming. There was no crunch to the texture, it was like eating rubber wrapped chicken meat.

The string beans were okay though.
author: Benjamin T.

description:
Pretty decent dumpling place.  I definitely love the Soup dumplings here.  Not quite as good as the authentic one's that burn your lips if you aren't careful but for California, the quality of them here is very good.

I enjoyed certain things more than others.  The onion pancake was too dry.  The Shanghai style chow mein seemed too dry too.

But on the other hand, the wontons were really good and the same could be said for salted soy milk that comes with green onions and a fried chinese donut.

I'd definitely come here again.  Just wish that the service didn't rush me out.

The ambiance here is cozy with great air circulation.  Very good place to socialize as it is neither too loud nor too quiet.

Food once ordered arrives very quickly.
author: Tony U.

description: Went during late afternoon and ordered for a few recommended dishes after the server suggested. Had the xiao long bao (Shanghai dumpling), I had high expectations for it after reading so many reviews. Tried it and I was disappointed, it was not juicy, skin was not good. Customer service was below average, I really hate how they were all sitting a group chatting and cussing in Chinese in the back table. I find it disturbing and rude.
author: Angela L.

description: XLB's are indeed good. I was surprised how small they were when they came out. All the XLB's I've had so far are slightly bigger with more soup inside. I admit, I like these perfect bite size dumplings (: I preferred the crab and pork dumplings over the regular Shanghai styled dumplings, but that's possibly because I'm a seafood lover.
author: Trish T.

description:
Here is what I ordered:

Shanghai Dumplings, Crab and Pork Dumplings, Pan Friend Pork Dumplings, Wontons in Chili Oil, and their Beijing Style Dumplings with chives and they were all either mediocre or not great at all. The pan friend dumpling was really oily. The wontons in chili oil sauce had no flavor. The only thing that really tasted okay was the dumplings with chives. (DUMPLINGS 1.5 - 2 stars... for a dumpling house, I was hoping for better)

Stir fry eggplant dish was yummy. Great flavors. Would give this dish a 4.

Braised Pork Belly in Vegetables was not the best pork belly I've had. It was okay... but nothing I would rave about or order again. 2-3 stars

Walnut Shrimp did not look appetizing and was not delicious either. The white sauce was too heavy and didn't coat the shrimp nicely. It was pretty clumpy. 

So why a 1 star rating?! I've eating at hole in the walls... I am okay eating at restaurants that looks a little dingy... I've continued eating dishes that I found a hair in... I would love a clean restaurant, but I understand that sometimes things happen. BUT after swatting away 5 flies, trapping two and then to have flies still continue to fall on me while I eat... CLOSE the door! Then, I notice my friends looking at the ceiling above me... and as I look up... Flies. Flies all over... that is why they were falling on me -__- I picked the wrong seat. That was just a little too much for me to handle.
author: Nora K.

description:
IMO, the *best* place for some authentic Shanghainese food!  Obviously the soup dumplings are a must, but my other favorites include nian gao (炒年糕), the green onion pancake, hot and sour soup, and pea shoots. 

Nian gao is a type of stir fry with pork, veggies, and these flat rice-cakes.  The rice-cakes look kind of like watercress, but it actually has a noodle-like texture that's chewy and soft.  It's an essential Shanghainese dish and something I HAVE to order when I visit Dumpling Kitchen.
author: Candace C.

description: Pleasantly surprised by the food and service.  Gotta have the Shanghai dumplings, chicken wings and noodles (any).  Get here early or make reservations for a larger party, otherwise you'll be waiting a long time.
author: n y.

description: Great Chinese food! Favorites are pan fried buns, soy milk- I could eat these everyday.
author: Ingrid C.

description: I don't think this place is that tasty. We ordered their crab and pork steamed dumpling and some other dishes, none of them were impressive. This place is surely over rated.
author: Sharon P.

description:
A very good place for XLB without the wait.  The green onion pancakes were golden brown without being greasy. not to mention an ample portion. the dry fried chicken was done well.  the right amount of glaze over crispy skin, on top of succulent meat.  Unfortunately, it wasn't pepper hot as described.  

What more can you ask for?  Friendly and efficient service. Not to mention, English is spoken here! 

$30 including tax and tip. Doggie bagged what we could not finish. I'll be back!
author: Debbie T.

description:
As a vegetarian who has a consistently difficult time finding dumplings that are not just bland vegetables pushed between wrap paper, I was thrilled to find such delicious vegetarian dumplings and potstickers at this spot. The food through the meal was consistently delicious. Our group also ordered a potato/green onion pancake, which was large and shareable, tasty and filling. The meat-eaters in our group ordered pork dumplings and liked them more than the vegetarian dumplings (and this from people who don't eat much pork). The difference between the dumplings and the potstickers seemed to be that one was steamed (the dumplings?), the other fried. There were three beer options and unlimited green tea as well as water when we asked.  

As with many places in China Town, the signage outside was not entirely clear, but it has a yellow overhang that says Dumpling Kitchen on at least one side. Inside, it was a wide open space and easily accommodated our group of 6 as well as plenty of other groups, some larger, most about the same size. The noise level was very manageable and the service was quick and helpful. 

Entirely inside, so humans only barring service animals.
author: Christina R.

description:
Walked into this place around 3pm and we were seated right away.  Restaurant was about half full.  Metered parking on the street was fairly easy.

There were 4 of us and we decided to go for a mid-day sampling of their goodies.

Hits were their Shanghai-style steamed Pork Dumplings and their Pork Dumplings in chili oil.  We also enjoyed their Pork with Sichuan picked mustard noodle soup.

The misses for us included their Crab & Pork Dumplings and their Shanghai-style green onion pancakes.

This is not a destination for us but if in the neighborhood, I would go for round 2.

Servers were friendly enough (some language barriers) and relatively clean for a hole in the wall.
author: David P.

description:
We went here early on a Saturday evening to avoid the crowds and were immediately seated at a small table in the back.
A young man brought us hot tea and a little dish of peanuts.  Our server came minutes later and took our order.
We started with the chicken and corn soup and were surprised at how good it was.  Between two of us, we finished every drop!
For entrees, I ordered the Shanghai pork dumplings while my partner ordered the crab and pork dumplings and walnut prawns.
Everything was delicious!  We ate so much soup that we took about half of the dumplings and nearly all of the walnut prawns home.
The food and service was excellent and the restaurant was not noisy.  Next time, I'd like to try the pot stickers, the spinach with garlic and of course another bowl of that fabulous soup.
author: Philip C.

description:
Have you ever been to a place where the following occurred?

1) After ordering 6 dishes, the rude older waitress (who appears to be the owner) snarkily asks your party of 8 in Chinese, that "your table out of all the large tables in the restaurant is the one that has ordered the least amount of dishes for a party that size," even though the table behind us with five people ordered only 3 dishes? 

2) The same wrong dish is sent to you twice?

3) Towards the end of the meal, while you are still grabbing food from a dish on the lazy suzy, the same rude waitress deliberately starts clearing out the table and takes a plate from under just that dish, even though there are other obvious dishes to clear out?

4) Pay $1.75 for hard, dry, day (or more than a day) old rice?

5) When there are still leftovers, and after receiving a take out box from another waiter, the same rude waitress comes to our table and asks why we are bothering getting a take out box?

6) Passes by our table and just gives stoic facial expressions throughout our meal?

7) Puts the bill to our table with no word, when we leave, no word, but when the other non-Chinese customers leave, have their orders taken, she is giving the fake smile, greetings, and 110% customer service to these folks?

The previous three times I have come here, I have never received this below par level of service, sub par food, or apparent differential treatment by a restaurant, which is why I suggested this place to our party for a relative's birthday dinner. The younger waiters were a bit more attentive and cordial, which is why they received a tip and at least a star. But never again will I ever come here and I plan to tell all my friends living in this city never to patron this place due to the disrespectful manner by that one woman throughout our entire meal.
author: T L.

description: Love this place, the service pretty good and place clean . Love their Xiao Long Bao https://instagram.com/p/-Xrid1CIBZ/  . Price is not bad too.
author: L D.

description:
For a place that's called "Dumpling Kitchen," we were expecting more than 4 varieties of dumplings. Me and the hubs were more satisfied with the Xiao Long Baos than the dumplings. Here is what we ordered:

1. XLBs (http://s3-media1.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/MwwCeoby8xfACNV2TpwETg/l.jpg)
2. Pork and Napa dumplings (http://s3-media3.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/WDAKzC9RQy0gbPPnEB6rbA/l.jpg)
3. Vegetarian Mu Shu (http://s3-media1.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/S9qx20ArRWnWy3cDs3R2hg/l.jpg)
4. Garlic Sauteed pea sprouts (http://s3-media1.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/bxmzgRhJcdWLB895iRyvOQ/l.jpg)

The XLBs were flavorful with just enough tangy soup inside the buns. But the pork napa dumplings were steamed just like the XLBs instead of boiled, which we thought was unconventional - which may also be the reason why we felt like the dumplings tasted the same as the XLBs. 

The vegetarian mu shu and pea sprouts were a-ok, typically dishes you'd see at Chinese restaurants. 

Overall, we probably wouldn't come here again, unless I really, really. REALLY. crave their XLBs.
author: Ximeng W.

description: I'm a bit of a foodie and all around lover of dumplings. I've been to Shanghai and tried all the famous spots. This place is a solid contender for the best. In particular I love their #2 pork and crab xlb and am crazy for #5 the pork sheng jian bao or pan fried dumpling. I also get the #75 string beans because you gotta work in some veggies somewhere. I've eaten in and take out. XLB is tough to hold up to take out but I've been pretty pleased with the success of not breaking. This is the place I ALWAYS say when the bf asks what I want. And gladly they have a big menu because my bf doesn't eat pork or seafood. Thank you bf for putting up with my soup dumpling obsession and thank you DK for curing my craving! (Even though I'm walking distance from Shanghai Dumpling King in outer Richmond, this is worth the drive)
author: Jessica B.

description:
Recommended by a jet setting foodie.
Husband and I bought my folks along to attest to the authenticity.
And the folks were pleased.
The green onion pancake was untraditional but flavorful.
The sticky rice roll was prepared with a perfect crispy Chinese donut inside.
The savory soy milk was not best but close enough.
Shanghai style steamed pork dumpling was juicy and burst with flavor, though the skin was slightly thicker than the other dumplings I've enjoyed.
We also tried the wonton in chili oil which was delightful and the mixed of veggi and meat was a delicious balance.
With the husband not eating pork, we had to tried the steam veggi dumpling.
Also another delightful fulfilling tasting dumplings with wood ear adding to the texture.
The finale was the crispy egg puff, a delightful souffle like puff sprinkled with sugar.  It was like a feather light egg tasting beignet.

I'll be back for the dumpling and the egg puff for sure~~!!!
author: YC L.

description: Wonderful place for dumplings, house made chow mein, delicious food and good service. The green tea and peanuts served before your meal really adds a nice element to the dining experience. Highly recommend
author: Douglas W.

description: I was very very impressed with this place. I ordered their Shanghai style pan fried pork buns and I had them to go and I must say they were very delicious. They are the best tasting pan fried pork buns since I had in Guilin, China. Although not the best dumplings ever...that goes to a little stand in Liuzhou, Guangxi. In terms of San Francisco dumpling restaurants it is the best I have tried so far. The buns were crispy and moist and the filling was not greasy. They had ginger inside of them like every other dumpling in San Francisco but they were not heavy or anything. I want to go here again.
author: Julian F.

description: Best shanghai dumpling place in SF for sure. Dumpling skin is a bit thicker, but good soup, meat, skin ratio. The pork buns are also on point, oily, crunchy, with lots of pork - the way I like it! The shanghai rice cakes are the weak link for me. But when I eat Shanghai, I'm really here for the pork buns and soup dumplings!
author: Anna W.

description: Second time here.  The soup dumplings are amazing as is the rest of the food.  I brought some out of town friends all the way out here because it is that good!
author: Krispin M.

description:
While visiting San Fran, a friend recommended this place to my group of 12. This place is another over-rated Chinese restaurant. They're not known for dim sum apparently, so only get dumplings, but then again, their dumplings were no where juicy like the ones at Din Tai Fung. 

Everything (from the Shanghai noodles all the way to the XLB dumplings) was so darn greasy and gross...real Chinese food isn't greasy all the time but apparently this restaurant just likes to dump lard and oil (add oil pun insert here). I don't know why the other reviews say the XLB were good but they didn't have any juice come out so we knew they were not fresh. We had a Taiwanese friend in our group too and she's the expertee, of course.

I will not recommend this place if you are use to Din Tai Fung, this place is no where in comparison to DTF.
author: Neon H.

description: The food was just ok. Not as flavorful as other places. I was told the xiao long bao is smaller than other places but it still tastes good to me. I really liked their sugar puff dessert! Not super sweet but kind of sweet and chewy on the inside, delish! We ordered a few soups, a variety of baos. I would definitely go back just to try again but since the fam just thought the place was so so, that means won't be back, at least not anytime soon. Either way for a white/Chinese guy that doesn't eat "white" people Chinese food I thought it was good, not great, but good. Would def come back for the puffs!!! Yummmmmy! Haha
author: Austin C.

description:
Super crowded, small space crammed with tables & people & elbows & a long wait on the night we visited - always a good sign!  We rolled in on our way to the airport, thankfully with enough time to survive the wait for a table.  I wouldn't have been able to forgive myself for being in San Francisco and passing up the opportunity to have some xiao long bao, so it's not like any wait would have deterred me!

Service is abrupt and not always efficient, but effortful upon request (if you can catch them long enough to make the request!).  

We had traditional xiao long bao and also had dumplings in chili sauce, both good, but i'm more of a traditionalist when it comes to my dumplings, so I preferred those.  Hub had some dish that included chicken and lots of red and green peppers, he loved it, i didn't taste it (but he's a Chinese food afficionado and a great Chinese food cook, and he said it was some of the best he's ever had!)

Would definitely revisit and would recommend for a reliable xiao long bao fix despite the crowded space & long wait for a table!
author: Kathy H.

description:
Amazing dumplings at a bargain price! 

We had the Shanghai Steam Dumplings, Shanghai Pork Buns  with a side of mushroom & veggies.
author: Monique C.

description: We stopped by on a rainy cold day and really enjoyed the dumplings and potstickers. Huge portions- their lunch special is great!
author: Anastasia J.

description: I came here once before a while ago and wanted to know if the food was really as good as it seemed that first time. Thus, I returned. I think that the XLB were just as good as last time although perhaps a little fresher. Good meat with tasty juice squirting out. The fried pork dumplings were more of a disappointment, probably due to the dinner rush. The sweet soy milk is definitely tasty and the sticky rice roll was better than I expected, so overall, I'd probably come back if I was in the neighborhood.
author: Ruobin W.

description:
I was only planning on being in SF for less than 24 hours so my buddy volunteered to drive up to the city from Mountain View for dinner.  Opting for a place in the sunset, we parked at my sister's place and hoofed it to whatever was nearby and well rated.

Dumpling Inn caught our eye as we walked by and we dropped in for a long awaited Chinese meal.  We ordered the Mongolian beef and the walnut prawns with some rice.  Both dishes were very tasty and the spicy beef paired well with the creamy, crispy prawns.  This place charges for each bowl of rice instead of a flat fee which was kind of disappointing but the meal was otherwise very satisfying.

Ironically, we had forgotten to order any dumplings despite the place having the word "dumpling" right in the name. It's a little more expensive than Ming's down the street, but definitely competes in the deliciousness category.  The service was so-so but that won't stop me from coming back!

Food: 8/10

Service: 5/10

Price: $$

Atmosphere: 7/10
author: Joe M.

description: Sooooo good! Shanghai dumplings and Lionhead soup are the best!
author: Casey Y.

description:
Oh wow.

Best shanghai soup dumplings in NorCal thus far. 
Sometimes there's a short wait, sometimes no wait at all. They have this awesome garlic eggplant dish.

Service is pretty decent. Not super fast but not slow. Parking might be a bit troublesome to find around the area though.

Have brought the bf here who is a huge DTF fan. Says next to DTF, this place is the best.
author: Hanna Y.

description: I travel frequently and appreciate authentic Chinese food. In SF it's easier than most places to find. The soup dumpling are just like in Shanghai.....Excellent! Only downside is cash and debit card only...not convenient for business travelers.
author: Frank M.

description:
Ate here after running the Nike Women's Half Marathon so my appetite wasn't really there but I got to try XLB for the first time.  Interesting.  It's basically a dumpling (like the ones you eat at dim sum restaurants) with soup inside.  I wasn't expecting the meat.  haha
Also tried the onion pancakes and crispy cream puffs.  Both good but I wouldn't come back.
author: Minh T.

description:
Service is great for how busy they were on a Friday. Food came quick, big portions, reservation ready on time. 

It's loud here, so be warned. Bathroom wasn't the cleanest I've seen... not the worst, but not clean. 

And warning to vegetarians: NOT ALL VEGETABLE ITEMS ARE VEGETARIAN. The "house broth" is made from a meat based broth. WHAT! yes, true. 

SO glad I asked! 

And the cucumber salad should say "GARLIC cucumber GARLIC salad". Boy will I be paying for that for daysssssssss. But ... it was tastey!
author: Kim D.

description: Mom and pop place. A bit more pricey compared to other dim sum places. I ordered the Shanghai style dumplings and potstickers. The dumplings were delicious, but not any different from other places I tried, and I wouldn't mind getting it again, but the potstickers was a bit over cooked and bitter.
author: Nai S.

description:
Finding a flavorful and soupy XLB in the Bay Area is tough. It's always a hit or miss but with the recommendation from my friends, I paid Dumpling Kitchen a visit. 

We ordered a few dishes to share, but my go-to is always the green onion pancake. Instead of it being completely flat, their onion pancake is fluffy! It was a little different than what I'm used to, but delicious nonetheless. Now let's get to the good stuff: their XLB. What makes this place so unique is that the skin they use is extremely thin but, like magic, holds soup in very well. I'm not XLB expert and this probably isn't the BEST by any means (nothing compares to din tai fung in taiwan!) but this will suffice for now. 

Cheap, clean, and hearty food! Will definitely be back!
author: Vivian D.

description:
When I first tried this restaurant back in March this year, it surprised me with their tasty steam dumplings, freshness of soybean milk and deep-fried dough sticks. I was really happy that I no longer needed to drive all the way to South bay for a good Northern Chinese style breakfast. Time pass by, while they become more popular, like almost every other first-good-later-bad restaurant, they failed to maintain the quality of the food. Steam dumpling becomes greasy (invisible), once freshly tasted deep-fried dough sticks now taste like re-heated or overnight left overs, the soybean milk is no longer taste like freshly ground but off the shelf. I gave it couple of try to make sure the poor quality is not an one-off case. Sadly, these attempts only suggesting nothing but the deteriorating of the food quality through the time. 

Sigh, I lost a good breakfast place
author: Lydia L.

description: Grosses place I have ever ate in my life. I was craving for dumplings one day with my mom and since we were in the area we decided to eat here. We ordered the combination chowmein and an order of the dumplings, all I can say is cook your food thoroughly before you serve it to customers. Their dumplings were super soggy and the taste was disgusting, basically it tasted very old my mom and I had to spit it out. The chowmein noodles were still hard like it came out the package. Never again.
author: Evelyn H.

description:
Dumpling kitchen is my favorite dumpling spot on Taraval. Love the spicy wontons. XLB could use more ginger flavor but they held their broth perfectly and I liked the thin wrap on them. Pan fried pork buns are one of my favorites, like a cross between a bun and a potsticker, yum. I like that they offer various types of soy milk both sweet and savory and hot and cold.

Their noodles are also good if you choose to veer away from their dumpling menu. Price is right! A decent spot to have a Chinese brunch/lunch that reminds me of home cooking.
author: Melody S.

description: There is no need for therapists any more since all your emotional problems can be solved one dumpling at a time.
author: George K.

description:
-Xiao Long Bao
-sticky rice roll
-pan fried dumping
-vegetarian goose = bean curd layered with mushrooms. cold dish. Yum
-Sweet and sour?  fish dish. = I don't remember the name but it was a big plate of fried fish filets and covered in yummy sauce.

This is one of my favorite places for xiao long bao. I always want to try like everything on the menu but i keep picking the same ones. I need to bring more people.
author: Erica L.

description:
Horrified by my experiences at the over-hyped Kingdom of Dumpling from food poisoning (twice) (http://www.yelp.com/biz/kingdom-of-dumpling-san-francisco-2?hrid=mcEWO4xSC-i7Q-81iY763w), I swore off of restaurant dumplings for a while. A really long time. 

Anywho, I got the craving for some yummy soup dumplings and came to this place. The waitresses are quick and efficient. Each time they come to you, they have gifts in their hands. They guide you to a table and give you a menu, next time they give you water and peanuts to snack on while you decide on your options. Then they come back with hot tea and take your order. The next few times are with food! Can't get any better than that. 

They have a vinegary soy sauce they give you for the pork soup dumplings and it is DEEEEELISH! Their string beans are great too. One dish is enough to feed four people! Gave their chicken wings a try but they didn't impress me too much. However, I don't care too much about wings anyway. Tried baby bok choy with beef my second time coming here and it was soooo good. 

Best part about coming here is that I didn't have to sprint to the bathroom after my dinner! I can't wait to come back and try more dishes!
author: Arleen F.

description: Don't want to wait forever at kingdom of dumplings? GO HERE INSTEAD.  This place is just as good as kingdom of dumplings.  Order the braised pork belly and you won't regret.  They also have plenty of pan fried dumplings and they don't like 21398021391 hours to make like kingdom of dumplings.
author: Vince L.

description: Bad food. Soft broken dumpling skin. Not spicy enough. Not crispy skin. Don't try it at all!!!!!!
author: Zhi Z.

description: All the food I ordered were great.  The little steam bun were tasty and fresh.  The stir fried thick noodle were also great.  We were there before 11:00am and the place was almost full.  So I knew the food can't be bad.  The only down side is I had problem finding parking space closed by.
author: S L.

description:
This is probably one of my favorite dumpling places~

Three of us ordered xlb (pork soup dumplings), fan tuan (sticky rice roll), wonton in red chili oil, potstickers, chicken wings, spicy beef tripe and ong choy. Sure this was a lot of food but everything was pretty good!

Xlb was nice, not the best that I have had but it's acceptable. The skin was pretty thin but not enough soup in the dumpling. What I like better was the potstickers and wonton in red chili oil. The skin of the potsticker was perfectly thin and the meat inside was so juicy and flavorful. As for the wonton, it was rightly flavored too! This version of wonton in red chili oil is more sesame sauce base so it's not spicy at all. I wish they can make it a bit more spicy.

Spicy beef tripe was good, but lacking of the 'numbing' flavor. Chicken wings were  on the sour side rather than the sweet side (it wasn't extremely sour but the balance of sweet and sour was a bit off for me). Ong choy was huge but good~ Fan tuan was alright.

We were very satisfied with our dinner~ Don't forget to order the soy milk (chinese style of course~) because it's so fresh and good!
author: Louisa L.

description:
I'd heard wonders about the Shanghai dumplings here, so we had to come try it after attending the Stern Grove fest. We didn't try any other dumplings, since that was supposed to be the highlight. 

The verdict: While the texture and soupiness of the dumplings were great, the flavor wasn't up to my expectations. Perhaps I'm more used to the Cantonese flavor of Shanghai dumplings, but these had a stronger ginger flavor and something else that I wasn't sure of. It's probably just a different recipe for the pork filling versus Din Tai Fung etc. The dumplings also looked a bit wilted, but rest-assured they were all filled with plenty of soup. The skin was also quite thin, and none of them broke on the bottom. It wasn't piping hot, so I didn't burn my tongue on any of the soup. Success! If the dumplings had less ginger in them, this would be four stars for sure. 

Other dishes we ordered were the bok choy in house broth, which was actually my favorite dish. The broth was a bit salty on its own, but it gave great flavor to the vegetables and any rice should you choose to order some. It also came with some mushrooms and carrots sprinkled on top, which was a nice addition. Finally, we ordered the bean curd salad, which was actually served in chili oil. I actually prefer the Taiwanese style where it's just salted and maybe served in a bit of clear broth. However, it was still quite good. 

I also noticed that the service was especially fast!! We had just barely ordered and come back from the restroom and the vegetables and bean curd salad already arrived. The dumplings understandably took a bit longer, since they had to steam. It was also convenient that they accept credit cards. 

Next time, I'd like to try the Shanghai pan-fried pork buns, which I hear are delish!
author: Audrey L.

description:
XLB and Pork dumplings in chilli oil were both very good.
3-stars because of nasty restrooms. I just hope that the kitchen isn't that nasty.
author: Jake S.

description:
Shady. Check your bills, they charge unauthorized tips on your credit cards.

I ate here with 4 people. When the bill arrived we split it so that two of us would leave a one dollar tip on our credit card receipt while the other two would leave a cash tip totaling 20%.

A few days later i noticed a discrepancy on my bill and found out they charged me more than I authorized. I chalked it up as a simple mistake and called my friend to make sure. They overcharged him by the same amount. I guess they thought we stiffed them on tip and decided to take matters into their own hands. 

Fuck you guys. I'm never eating here again.
author: Jimmy W.

description:
I came here at 11 am for a quick bite during my lunch break.  The service was fast and I was very pleased that the food all got to me within 15 minutes.  I got the mapo tofu lunch special. and the pork dumplings in chili oil.  The mapo tofu was piping hot, served as a quite generous portion with white rice.  Really hit the spot.  Pork dumplings were good.

3 stars because the food was tasty and the service fast but I wasn't feeling great a few hours later.
author: Audrey D.

description:
Low quality and expensive compared to other chinese places.

Their shanghai dumplings have no taste.

Their noodle soup neither.
author: K L.

description: Driving down Taraval with my mother, I was looking for a Shanghai dumpling house. I think the one I had in mind was Kingdom of Dumpling, but I didn't see it and saw this place, so we decided to stop by and try it. We got XLB's, some other meat dumplings, and pan-fried rice noodle with meat. I liked this place and would go back again. There were people there and young people especially.
author: Denise C.

description:
Yum! XLB!!!
The fried chicken and the Shanghai noodles are good too! The wait is not so bad. Not the cleanest restaurant, but its good
author: Y W.

description: Xiao long bao was decent, but the skin could be thinner, not that much crab for the crab pork soup dumpling. Avoid the broccoli with beef dish (the beef quality isn't great.) Corn and chicken soup is OK-as expected of an Americanized Chinese dish
author: Rebecca C.

description: My hunt for the Xiao Long Bao continues, but lets remark on what I found out thus far haha. The #2 crab and pork ones are the hit here. The regular shanghai dumplings are...sad to say alright. If you have to choose, pick the crab and pork even though its pricer. The sweet soy milk is yummy but I prefer the Ranch 99 one but thats just me. The Shanghai chow mein noodle was yummy and thick like udon; def try it out :) All in all, with the nice tea service and sit down feel, I will def come back.
author: Robert H.

description: Score! Huz is not Fan of traditional turkey Thanksgiving, so after an arduous Yelp search I found this place for him. Soup dumplings (pork and ginger), dry fried wings, and twice cooked pork belly later, he's having his post-feast nap and dreaming happy dreams. Great food, nice people, and excellent health score means we will be regulars now.
author: Cydney B.

description: This place was awesome! About a min wait and we were seated. Family style dumplings and fried rice everything was delicious!!!
author: Ribec F.

description:
A Haiku for Dumpling Kitchen

X-L-B, be mine
Delicious, and whoo! no line!
One more to go, please.
author: Jacklyn N.

description: These dumplings never let me down. The pan-fried pork buns are my favorite, followed closely by the XLB and the potstickers. Consistently delicious.
author: Peter J.

description:
4.5 stars

Pretty dang good overall. Wife and I splint 1 order of XLB, 1 green onion pancake and 1 order of pan fried pork buns. It all came out fast and staggered which I appreciate. Everything was piping hot and the beer was nice and cold. The green onion pancake was definitely much different than other places in the city. Much lighter more crisp, less oily, almost like an indian fry bread of sorts. We actually didnt finish this order between 2 people, we could of but didnt and I feel that was a smart move. So in total this is enough for 3 ppl that arent starving and the bill with tip was $32 including the beer as well, not a bad shake.

I'll be back and to try more
author: Michael B.

description: This place is a little hole in the wall but the service was good and the dumpling soup was excellent! We tried a few of their other dishes too and they were all pretty tasty. We will definitely be back!
author: Si P.

description: Finally made the trek out here to pickup some dumplings to go.  The XLB and crab/pork dumplings were good.  The Shanghai fried pork buns were also good.  Had the wonton in chili oil which was just kind of meh.  I've definitely had better at other places.  That said, I would come here again but it's pretty far unless you are near Ocean Beach.  I'm still on a quest to find a good dumpling place near downtown SF...
author: Debbie L.

description:
XLB's were good, but nothing of the sort to write home about.  They were good enough not to break when picking them up, plus they also contained a good amount of juice inside.  If you really like XLB, it's worth a visit.  Their string beans and spicy chicken wings were an unexpected treat as well.

Wait staff was courteous, but it got busy and it took them a bit too long to get our bill after we were all done and wanted to get going.

Something was majorly off with their shen jian bao, so I can't recommend them...
author: Al C.

description:
As always, San Francisco was rocking its cold , foggy weather. And so I wanted some warm dumplings and found this gem! :D


I love their Shanghai soup dumplings! Sooooo good. YUM! There is burst of warm flavor that just bursts inside your mind. Mind you that it is really hot. 
I also their House soup with dumplings. I love the clean taste of this soup. Usually, I would expect it to be greasy and oily, but it wasn't! Lovely surprise

I highly recommend ordering both!
author: Jane H.

description: Craving some XLB, we headed over to this little Taraval gem to get our dumplings on. I would order the traditional XLB over the crab ones, they taste really similar but the traditional is a better value. Not to miss is their pan fried buns, eggplant, sizzling rice soup, and pea sprouts. On weekends it gets busy so they do take reservations for parties of 5 or more. We had a party of 4 and waited about 20 minutes around 7pm on a Saturday. Funny thing is by the time we left around 8:30pm the place was pretty quiet and had no wait!
author: Betty C.

description:
Food was alright.. I've been eyeing this place since it had high reviews and a long line out the door. I wanted to know what the hype was all about. The thing that made me REALLY wanna go was those pictures of the xiao long baos. They looked really good in the picture. Like the skin wasn't too thick and it wasn't oily. Couldn't tell from the pictures on the inside though... Like the meat quality or soup quality. Anyway... We ordered one round of xiao long baos, one spinach with garlic, one dry fried chicken wings, and one clay pot rice. 

Unfortunately the xiao long baos did not look like what was shown on the yelp pictures (grrrr..) a and they did not taste as good as I had hyped it up to be. They were oily and skin was okay thickness. Not as thin as I hoped it would be. Remember you gotta eat it warm! There was one left at the end of our meal and it was cold. I think the soup congealed cuz it was solid and oily. Pretty gross. Warm = okay. Cold = disgusting!

As for the other entrees. Spinach with garlic is good but hard to mess up. I eat it all the time in my own home. I surprisingly liked the dry fried chicken wings! They were really juicy..not crunchy if you're into that sort of thing. I like it when there's a lot of meat but not too much breadding or fried stuff..hehehe so this was my favorite part of the meal.

The clay pot rice was okay though I would prefer eating plain white rice with my food instead. I did like the ham pieces in the rice... But maybe as a side thing not part of the clay pot.

I would come back here occasionally but it sucks that there's a huge line nearly every time I've passed by. So..it's definitely not worth the wait.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
After we sat down and ordered I noticed the Health Department scorecard. Could that really be a 75? No it must be a 95...go take a look up close would ya? Yup it's a 75, um do you want to leave? Eh... it's ok we already ordered. (Never been to a place that scored under a 92)

The first dish out was the pea sprouts in garlic sauce. Can't say how it tasted because there was a grub worm in the dish! First dish sent back and cancelled!

Enough said...

Check out their inspection report yourself here.

http://dph-extranet2.sfdph.org:7777/pls/eeop_htmldb/f?p=132:2:1294915871374923::NO::P2_LOCATIONID:64370
author: Steven B.

description: I love this place, I love this place!!  The shanghai chow mein and pan fried pork bun is something I crave everyday!!!  thank you for existing!!
author: Rebecca A.

description:
I love coming to Dumpling Kitchen when I'm craving some Xiao Long Bao. I know there's many similar restauarants on the same street as well, but let me just talk about this one. Plenty of seating, but it does get crowded during lunch and dinner hours, so I suggest you plan accordingly!

The Xiao Long bao (Chinese dumplings) are really really good. 10 comes in an order but to be honest, I can probably eat all 10, or even 20 of these bite sized dumplings. Their lunch specials are pretty cheap on the weekdays but they do get pricier on the weekends, but the portions are HUGE. I saw multiple men sitting next to me, and they couldn't even finish the lunch special. Talk about quantity! Anyways, their Chinese Ham with bok Choy in Clay pot is very popular. Salty slices of meat served with chopped up bok choy, served in a clay pot where the rice gets slightly toasted. Their onion pancakes are also on point.
author: Carmen C.

description:
Ordered #1 on the menu, the dumplings arrived very dry as if they'd been sitting around for far too, too long.  Got the beef and cilantro soup, it had the equivalent of ONE stalk of cilantro in the medium sized bowl that was cut up into 1/2" pieces and it was so overly salted I was surprised.  

The strangest part was that all the art on the walls were missing, the very nice waitresses were nowhere to be seen, the fish tanks were covered up and the atmosphere felt less nice.  Maybe it's just me, the food here has be excellent before and maybe I hit it on a bad day.  But now I don't want to go back anymore.  This is sad.
author: Rona M.

description: Soup dumplings are amazing, the pan fried soup dumplings are even better. Come here with a group of people and just order everything. You won't be disappointed.
author: Patrick C.

description: Dumplings were good - juicy and savory. Food is pretty cheap as well.
author: Chris C.

description:
HeckYeahYummy.
Got take out from here, since it was a touch closer to us [than KoD, which we dig], and all the things were very tasty.

1. Shanghai-Style Steamed Pork Dumplings 

2. Crab and pork steamed dumplings

5. Shanghai-style spring rolls

7.  Pork Dumplings In Chili Oil

13. Shanghai-style green onion pancake

27. Sizzling rice soup (shrimp, beef, chicken)

As others have mentioned, not tons of broth in the soup dumpling, but still very tasty. 
Crab & Pork = pretty special.
The spring rolls are fried and they are in the egg-roll category. Good.
That chili oil is something else! Great taste [chives & ?] in those dumplings.
The green onion pancake reminded me a bit of focaccia in taste. :P
The soup is very pleasant. We didn't eat it right away, because the weather was too hot and we ordered a lot of items, so got full quickly. Having it later was a nice way to soothe the heartburn that I gave myself by eating the chili oil. ;)
The broth is very mild, which allowed the shrimp and rice to shine. Lots of mushrooms, a fair amount of carrots and peas.

Haven't had takeout from KoD, but regardless, will probably get some of this stuff again.
author: Ali W.

description: SOOO GOOD. Probably the best Chinese restaurant I've been to in the Bay area, and definitely comparable to the best in LA. Family and I ordered a table full of food (salty soy milk, Chinese donuts, green onion pancake, soup dumplings, red oil wontons, spicy appetizers, veggies, and fried steam buns). Everything was delicious, with the soy milk being my least favorite (just needed to be hotter) and the green onion pancake and red oil wontons being my absolute favorite. The pancake was quite possibly the best I've ever had in my life. It looked like it'd be too thick and dense but it was completely the opposite. Crisp on the outside and so soft and warm on the inside. And the wontons were just as good, if not better, when reheated later at home! Just one more reason to drive up to the city more often.
author: Kathy L.

description:
Went here with a group of 5 around noon on a Saturday. The wait wasn't too bad - maybe around 15-20min for our large group. We got the XLB, Shanghai pan fried pork buns, pork dumplings in chili oil, dry fried chicken wings, and a few other things that were less noteworthy.

Some notes:
- the XLB photos on yelp look quite tasty. The XLB we received did not look like them - they were less skillfully wrapped, if looks are to be believed. 1-2 of them popped before we even touched them, which was sad. They were also fairly low on soup content.
- the Shanghai pan fried pork buns were not like the other Shanghai pan fried pork buns I've had - say, in Shanghai (or even at other Chinese places in the bay area). There was no soup in them. If you're okay with that, the rest of it is fine, but I guess I had my hopes up.
- pork dumplings in chili oil - nothing to write home about. Decent, but no wows here.
- Dry fried chicken wings - we thought they were too wet. Go to San Tung instead for a more dry experience.
author: Chris M.

description: I don't understand why so high ratings?  I prefer the one near my house, Rice Valley. Even the simple Shanghai stir fry flat noodles wasn't as good. Prices are higher too. First time, I don't even bother to post any photos.
author: The Black Cat C.

description:
The dumplings are ok.  But the waiter was rude and scary.     After we order  dumpling and a dish, he said you wanna order one more dish?  We said we are not that hungry,  maybe we will order more a bit later.  He said "usually people order more than this , if you wanna order later you have to wait for a long time.  You must order more now."  Geez,  waiter is commanding us to order now.  What kind of service is this?  Am I in a military base?  He's also wearing martial art outfit.   Maybe he will beat us up if we don't.   
This place is also very small, could have done some remodeling.
author: Lucy J.

description: Pretty average for SF dumplings. They also didn't have much of a selection of dumplings. The walnut shrimp was very tasty. The chow mien was very plane and greasy. Overall meal was ok but not amazing.
author: Ivania M.

description: In our first 24 hours in San Francisco, we decided to try Dumpling Kitchen based on the Yelp reviews. In short, best soup dumplings and possibly best pot stickers we've ever had. Unbelievably delicious and satisfying. We normally make a point of it to not overeat, but we couldn't help ordering a second set of soup dumplings. Flat out fantastic.
author: Mr. F.

description:
Came for their item 1. Shanghai-Style Steamed Pork Dumplings (10) USD 7.5, 5. Shanghai-Style Pan Fried Pork Buns (10) USD 7.5, 14. Green Onion Pancake USD 4.75, 103. Braised Pork Belly with Preserved Vegetables, Bok Choy USD 9.5.  The dumplings was excellent with a little burst of hot, flavored soup as I bite into each dumpling.  The pan fried version also but less so.  The braised pork belly was certainly a welcome filled us up pretty good.  The onion pancake was more doughy, not too greasy, too much food ordered for two.

http://www.foodspotting.com/reviews/4829132
http://www.foodspotting.com/reviews/4829158
http://www.foodspotting.com/reviews/4829140
http://www.foodspotting.com/reviews/4829176
author: George L.

description: The dumpling were watery not great flavor! The beef oyster was ok but not great quality of meat.
author: Janet G.

description: Don't know how this place can garner 2 stars. Skip and try another place. food has been sitting on the steamer for way to long. Service is lackluster.
author: Kathy L.

description:
This place has PIDAN DOUFU!!! I saw it and ordered it immediately. It brought my back to the time I studied abroad in china. That being said, it was alright, but not as super delicious as some of the places that sold it when I was in Shanghai.

Also got some shengjianbao which weren't quite as juicy as delicious as in Shanghai, but still decent. I've noticed that all the ones I've gotten in the US were dry and not super soupy (like xiaolongbao) like the ones I've had in Shanghai. No complaints here as they were still as tasty, but didn't give you the hot explosion in your mouth, which, while delectable, usually scalded at least one spot in your mouth.

They actually serve a variety of dishes here, not just dumplings and those chinese pancakes like some restaurants with "dumpling" in their name. The food was decent overall. The service a little slow (you have to manually tell them to give you more water... though they did ask if we were ready to order like 3 times in quick succession[Actually, not sure if this is nice or rude haha]), but like I've said before, I don't really expect super service when going to a chinese place. All in all, 3 stars from me. I like the nostalgia factor of familiar dishes, but they just weren't above average enough for me to give it 4 stars.
author: Courtney Q.

description:
Probably my favorite xiao long bao place in the Bay Area. Not too sweet, saltiness is perfect, they aren't broken, they're juicy, one of the less expensive places, and can't think of more reasons why they're perfect but they pretty much are. Not sure where the ginger for the vinegar is but I'm not complaining since I don't use ginger with it anyways. 

Only Din Tai Fung can rival these and since DTF is all the way in SoCal, I can't really say which I prefer because that would just depend on where in California I am! 

Parking is okay... It's not terrible. There were times we circled around for 10+ minutes and park 2-3 blocks away, other times I find parking within 2 blocks. I almost always have to wait for a table and have shared a bigger table with other people as well. But you also have to wait at Kingdom of Dumpling (up the block) and Shanghai Dumpling King too (not that I would go to these two over Dumpling Kitchen). 

All the dishes were pretty big, we had 4 people and ordered 2 orders of XLB, 2 noodle dishes, and pan fried pork buns with barely anything leftover... If it's just me and husband, we usually order 2 orders of XLB and call that dinner. 

Shanghai style chow mein - very yummy, that has good amount of veggies but not too much where you're left wondering whether you ordered noodles with veggies or veggies with noodle. 

Preserved veggies rice cakes - thought it looked bland bc it's white but it is not! The preserved veggies are pretty salty so you eat it with the rice cakes. I can't decide which noodle dish I like better because they both taste very different. 

Xiao long bao - this should be the reason why you're here. ORDER IT!!!! 

Pan fried pork buns - it's like a XLB (the inside tastes the same minus the juicy soup) but with a thicker, bread-ier skin... My parents like it more than XLB, but husband doesn't like it. I like this crispy bottom of these but it's kinda-not-really the same as XLB. Whether you like or order it is up to you.
author: Anita T.

description:
Good, but no Kingdom of Dumpling. Definitely better than the Shanghai Dumpling King on Monterey Blvd. 

The XLB weren't soupy and the vinegar was sweet and watered down.
author: Yoeun P.

description:
Famished from a four hour day at the zoo, we found this location very quickly and for $16 before tip for all of the food in front of us, I was glad Dumpling Kitchen was one of the first handful of restaurants listed on my app. 

We ordered their green onion pancake, shanghai style pork dumplings, and steamed sweet buns. 

I know my SO likes the red vinegar dip for the dumplings, but I thought it didn't need it. That pocket of juice that builds up in the wee crevices of the dough ... and when it pops its well worth without. 

Their sweet buns is a first for me because they gave this almost tapioca/honey flavored dip that really made this dish more of a dessert one but well worth digging into, nevertheless. 

Another first is eating their half a pizza pie-like portion of green onion pancake. I never had it before and somewhat pictured a chive pie, but this fried goodness. Wow it was well-worth being completely stuffed at the end of our meal. And to think we wanted more!
author: Jamie L.

description: I really don't recommend you come this place. We are 5 people and ordered 7 dishes, the buns turn to be okay ( if you have to order, order the steam buns which are number 1$2。also this place ridiculously says the bun is 南翔小笼包 nan xiang steamed bun on their menu, the nan Xiang bun is the most known steam bun you can only have at nan Xiang steam bun restaurant in a very known temple with lots of local snacks in shanghai, I don't mind they call it steam bun, but don't call it nan xiang, totally bluffing ) , well the shanghainese pan-fried bun上海生煎包 is not authentic  ( it should have soup inside, which is very important, also the size is so small. Half of it should be). We also ordered Sichuan style spicy noodles, also known as dan dan noodles.  That comes as a totally shit. It is not like it should be at all, cheap instant-noodles-like noodles In a poop color sauce, horrible dish , worst ever noodles you ever had. There is also veggie dish with pak choi and mushroom, has no taste, except salty.  I understand shanghainese style veggie is very plain , my mom is shanghainese but at least add some oyster sauce or something else. Never had this before. Then critique comes to kung pao chicken.  It should be chicken cubes, not slices. Also the taste is much light. The dish should be red color due to the sweet and spicy sauce, with chicken and cucumber and carrot ( not sure) cubes and lots of peanuts ( important ). Well the only thing cooked right is the beef with leek and onion. So I think giving a one star is very generous. Again, if you go there , order steam bun.  That's all. Ps all my other non-Chinese friends thinks the place is okay and overrated.  不建议来这家餐厅，特别不好吃。 如果非要点，请点第一个和第二个小笼包，还可以。
author: Aaliyah L.

description:
Dumplings on dumplings.  I can't get enough of this place.  Dumpling Kitchen is a few blocks down Taraval street from the famed hole in the wall, Kingdom of Dumpling.  If you're looking for your dumpling fix and have a larger party, Dumpling Kitchen will seat you quicker since their restaurant is much larger.  A good heads up if you're hungover and hungry - or just hungry. :)

They make a solid xiao long bao: good chew on the skin, excellent filling and temperature, and tasty soup inside!  It was not a slurp-worthy xlb (like the golden standard at Din Tai Fung), but those 10 pieces definitely hit the spot. Pan fried dumplings were also fantastic and not too greasy. I am also a huge fan of the vegetarian dumplings - so much flavor packed in! Green onion pancakes are also a personal favorite.  Dumpling Kitchen's pancakes are not as dense and flaky as the ones that I'm used to.  They actually taste healthier.

Between the four of us that was enough food to satisfy!  

The wait staff is undoubtedly busy with a restaurant overflowing with its Sunday brunch customers, but they never miss an empty teapot and that's all you can ask for in a Chinese restaurant.
author: Kathleen W.

description:
Love XLBs so came here after hearing about this spot having one of the better XLBs in the Bay Area. Unfortunately, they're not. Got seated immediately and we ordered: sticky rice roll, an order of XLB, noodles in peanut sauce, and (lo and behold) dried fried chicken. When I read that, I wanted to try it to see if it matched up to San Tung's dried fried chicken.

We got the sticky roll first. Eh, nothing great. Then our noodles. Wait, were those ramen noodles? I'm sure it wasn't (I hope) but it looked and tasted like the packaged ramen noodles. As for the sauce, a bit flavorless. It didn't even taste like peanut sauce. All they did was add crushed peanuts on top of the noodles. Disappointing! Could the XLBs save the day? The chicken came next and when the plate arrived, my disappointment increased. Do not order. Their dry fried chicken was nothing like San Tungs. I should've known. Dry fried chicken = General Tsao's chicken....and it wasn't even good. Too much batter. The XLBs arrived. Were they the best in the Bay? Nah. Go a block away to Kingdom of Dumpling to have better dumplings.

Overall, super disappointed. The orders were quite large so I've got plenty of leftovers...just don't know if I'll enjoy eating them.
author: Rick T.

description:
This was an amazing meal! All of the food was so fresh and perfectly seasoned. We loved the dry braised string beans, shanghai style pork dumplings, Mongolian beef and Shanghai noodles. 

We ordered way too much food, but it was so delicious that we were happy to have the leftovers. 

I will definitely be back and take others as well!

Yum!!!
author: Amanda M.
