description: Pretty good dumplings, not quite as good as KoD down the street.  They have a much wider menu selection, though, and you don't have to sit on someone's lap to eat, like at kingdom.
author: S W.

description:
Large portions and lots of dumplings.

To order:

Soy Bean Milk
Xiao Long Bao
Green Onion Pancake
Pan Fried Pork Buns

Come here for your dumpling fish.  They offer a wide variety of noodles and rice dishes too but if you come here with more than 2 people you can try out a lot of stuff for around $10.00 a person!
author: Carli F.

description:
Food is 2 stars based on what we ordered, but price was good. We ordered:
Shanghai Dumpling- mediocre, not satisfyingly good
Fried chicken- looked good in yelp pictures, blend in taste, got nothing special going for it
Beef chow mein- super greasy which I don't mind if it's good, but I think Panda Express is better, sadness

I don't see myself coming back.
author: Happi Y.

description:
Came here after looking up the best dumplings in SF, and I was not disappointed! There was a line out the door in the middle of the afternoon on a Sunday, which speaks to this place's popularity. Waiting time was decent - about 20 minutes when we were the fourth(?) party on the list.

We went all out and ordered xiaolongbao, fried baozi, boiled dumplings, and potstickers. This was a loooot of food for just two people, but we finished it all and were immensely satisfied. I'd definitely recommend the xiaolongbao over everything else; they're tender, juicy, and really delicious. Fried baozi were pretty good, potstickers were decent, boiled dumplings were just okay.

This place is a little pricy, but I'd still come back again.
author: Jenny Z.

description: Must. Get. Dumplings.  Cucumber salad was delicious too!  Get there early unless you want to face a line of people into the street.  Good service.
author: Virginia F.

description: Unbelievably delicious and fresh. I was in Heaven. Small, but we didn't have to wait long for a table. Decor is deceiving, place looks like a dump, but food and service was too notch. Perfect. Green onion pancakes were the BEST I've ever had!
author: Sheryl S.

description: Once again, I'll keep this review short since we're on vacation.  Dumpling Kitchen offers mediocre food for a mediocre price.  Xiao Long Bao seems to be a popular item to order here.  If you've tried any Din Tai Fung restaurants, you would think the XLB here is definitely unacceptable.  But then again, that's not a fair comparison since there's no place that even comes close to DTF.  In my book, the XLB here is okay, but the bar should be set a lot higher in San Fran since there's such a huge chinese population here.  Most of the other items that we ordered were also mediocre.  This includes the mu shu chicken, the honey walnut shrimp, and their pig's stomach mustard cabbage soup.  We also ordered a seafood fried mochi, and it turned out to be quite a disappointment.  It was slightly undercooked and very bland.  One thing we did enjoy was their home made soymilk.  Delicious and refreshing!!  All in all, Dumpling Kitchen does not stand up to its name, but is acceptable to dine at.  Just don't go out of your way to come all the way here in hopes of tasting some substantially good Xiao Long Bao.
author: Steven L.

description: Dinner right after work. Lucky I came in time before the peak, which starts quite early. Their food was ok to good. I always order the usual shanghainese dishes whichever shanghainese restaurant I go to. Xiao long bou, spicy beef stomach, shanghainese rice cake. The Xiao long bou is good here. the rice cake was between good and ok. but the spicy beef stomach, I like how "Five Happiness" prepared it. Will I be coming back? Maybe, but not anytime soon, as there are many more to try and test.
author: Albert W.

description: The portions here are enormous and the food is quite tasty. I was majorly impressed by how quickly the meals came too--highly recommend the cold dishes. The hot and sour soup was good and the XLB ok but not amazing. For the price this place is a value restaurant and I will go back again!
author: Amy Y.

description: The crowd comes here to check out the xiaolongbao soup dumplings. But wait, there's more. Something even better and more satisfying. Instead of some puny soup dumplings, I recommend the pan fried pork buns, the Sichuan style noodles in peanut sauce, the Beijing deep fried sweet buns, spicy cow stomach, braised pork belly, and many other items on their menu the doesn't contain the word dumpling. There are other undiscovered items on their menu that are not dumplings that they should be called Bun Kitchen instead cause those jawns are on point.
author: Thomas L.

description:
Great dim sum. We waited for about 30 minutes for a table of 7 around lunchtime, but I think it was worth the wait.

We had a mix of soup, dumplings, and steamed buns. Everything we had was fresh, tasted great not greasy. Good value, would return, because a good dim sum place outside of Chinatown isn't easy to find.
author: Kishore H.

description:
My new favorite restaurant in San Francisco.  Coming from socal and frequenting SGV and 626, these are the best xiao long bao I have had in the city.  Hands down.  Not only are they delicious, juicy with just the right thickness of dough, but you get 10 for $7.

On top of that the fried buns which are just as good if not better are also 10 for $7!

Dumpling and post stickers also run the same price 10 for $7.

The lion head was also good in soup with clear noodles.

Everything was delicious, the restaurant is clean and spacious compared to the typical hole in the wall dumpling houses, and they take reservations!

I've been wanting to go back ever since!
author: Scottie P.

description: My new go-to place for dumplings b/c they taste like the ones my mom use to make me. That must mean that they're legit.
author: Benjamin L.

description: Dumplings and potstickers are fantastic, small miscommunication about the number of items ordered. Service was attentive and the food came promptly.
author: Karla D.

description: I was craving for soup and dumplings so I thought I'd give this place a try since it's in my neighborhood. For a place that gets a 4 star rating...I expected better. We were here at around 4PM. There were only about 3 other small groups there at the time. Why do Chinese people always seem to have a problem with making eye contact? My boyfriend and I walked in and no one in there pays attention to the door for customers. Got seated and was ready to order. We literally had to stare someone down to get their attention to take our order. We had to ask 3 times to get our water. First time I actually said it with our order. The guy acknowledged that he heard each order. As our food came out, still no water. My boyfriend asked again as the guy was cleaning some tables. He said water? Ok. So this time he really said water so we thought ok, maybe he didn't hear the first time. But as he finished cleaning his tables he walked around like we didn't just ask for some water. I was getting annoyed at this point so I asked again and GET THIS. He acted like it was the FIRST time he heard it!! When we started eating everything was fine and THEN we found HAIR in our food. Then we had to try and flag someone down again as they do their work with their heads down. The pan fried buns were awesome (noodles were..ehh..nothing special. Fried rice, no comment there. Couldn't even stomach that after the surprise) and they canceled the order with the hair but man...it was like trying to get the attention of a girl who's not into you. They just don't care. Probably wouldn't come here again. Nothing special.
author: Jennie L.

description: This place was great!  Customer service was nice and my most importantly my hungry kids loved it after walking everywhere in the city that day.  Dumplings were steamed in bamboo steamers and not the metal ones.  Just like what we do at home ;-)
author: Anthony E.

description: I had xiao long bao. My lunch partner had pork dumplings. We split the green onion pancakes. It was plenty of food for lunch and delicious. We went around 1pm and it was pleasantly crowded. We got a seat right away.
author: Little M.

description:
Quick service, good food. 

Xlbs: flavorful, juicy, mmm
Green onion pancake: dinner plate sized, light, not greasy, mmm
Hot & Sour soup: I don't usually care for this dish and it was pretty good. 

Four stars is the combo of food and price. Total w 20% tip was under $30! Had it been expensive, it would get 3 stars.
author: Cristina F.

description: The Shanghai style steamed pork dumplings, the crispy egg puffs,and the green onion pancakes are to die for.
author: Savannah T.

description:
We have lunch and dinner here often. And yes they are always busy. Dumplings are always juicy and delicious. Excellent service as always. You won't be disappointed. 
Keep up the good work.
author: Wolfie M.

description:
Surprised that we hadn't been here before, but found this to be quite the little dumpling find; also really nice full chinese menu to ensure you get a good meal that isn't only centered on the Dumplings...a bit of a hole in the wall, not exactly "clean", but good enough and food definitely worth it.

Ordered:
- Crab & Pork Dumplings
- Spicy Pork Dumplings
- Salt & Pepper Chicken Wings
- Sweet Vinegar Pork Ribs
- Rice cake w/ pork & cabbage

First off - dumplings were GREAT - can tell that they are homemade, nice and light but the wrappers not too thick to throw off the wonderful inside goodness you get - am always a bit mixed on crab in dumplings as it really is hard to differentiate the flavor from the boiling/cooking as well as the strong (as it should  be) pork inside - so while the dumplings were really good, can't say crab made much of a difference.  The Spicy Pork Dumplings were outstanding - came out with a very generously garnished plate of dumplings with rough cut Garlic - nearly cubes of garlic - think Stinking Rose version of Dumplings - and if you like garlic, these were awesome - really, really tasty and just enough spice to make it onto the back of the tastebuds while not making chug glasses of water.

Big surprise were the great Salt & Pepper Chicken wings - great coating- have been doing a more "purist" route to my chicken wings and salt and pepper, when done right, is as orthodoxy as you get...just the choice of a plump chicken wing, lightly coated, fried (and baked sometimes) to perfection...

Sweet Vinegar Pork Ribs were just a plate of diced pork ribs in a pretty think, hoisin/vinegar sauce - good, not great - I'd say that this might be better served with rice or something to cut the sauce with - ribs were good and don't get me wrong - me love ribs!!! - but it was just a bit thick on the sauce to keep eating - a few bites were all you needed, maybe not a whole plateful.

I am not usually a big "noodle" fan, but these "rice cakes" were pretty damn good - think chown fun but with a much thicker "noodle" (the rice cake) - I'd prefer a mix of mustard in the sauce, but that is just personal preference (and they don't have mustard, which threw me off a bit).

Long lines, worth the drive and wait - also they do take out!
author: Richard D.

description: I guess they're closed in Wednesday's? Went at noon and it was locked. Might try again if I'm in the area. Random day to be closed
author: J J.

description:
Four stars for the food, but don't be surprised to experience two-star service.  But for a place as popular and as good as this place, I guess they don't have to be cloyingly sweet when it comes to customer service.  We came here on a whim because my whole family was craving xiao long bao.  We were in town on a Tuesday, and many of the other restaurants were closed.  Fortunately for us, this one was open.  We managed to get seated right away - quite a feat once we saw the line forming shortly after we arrived.  The service was curt and not so efficient - we never did get the rice that we had requested - but they do make up for it in the food qualtiy.  We got their Shanghai chow mein, which were hand-cut thick noodles with generous amounts of meat.  The salt and pepper friend fish was crisp and tasty, though the batter was a little thicker than I prefer.  The shrimp with mixed vegetables had an unexpectedly greasy feel to it, but it was still good.  And of course, the xiao long bao.  Very good; maybe could use a little more broth inside though.

Saw a poor woman have a whole pot of tipped over onto her when one of her children spun the lazy Susan too quickly.  No one from the restaurant came over to help clean up.  Odd.
author: Lee L.

description: Love this place so much!! My favorites are the Shanghai stir fried noodles and their dumplings. It's packed every time we go there for dinner,  but service is quick.
author: J. Y.

description:
Tried the Shanghai liquid filled dumplings for the first time. They were great! Don't forget that the liquid inside is extremely hot and can burn you. Place the dumpling in the vinegar first and let it cool for a minute or two before eating it. 
Get there early if you don't want to wait in line.
author: H. S.

description: Delicious! Authentic! Best items: pea shoots, rice cake stirfry, soup dumplings, wontons in chili oil and chicken wings.
author: Colby O.

description: Dumpling Kitchen is now my go-to place for XLB. Used to be a big fan of Shanghai Dumpling King for a while, but I feel like they have gone downhill in recent visits. After reading many positive reviews on Dumpling Kitchen, as well as reading an article listing the best XLB in San Francisco and seeing Dumpling Kitchen rated as #1, I had to try it. I am very glad that I did! XLB were excellent, very juicy, the skin was thin and delicate, filling was very tasty, etc. Also tried the crab and pork dumplings which were also great. Dry fried chicken wings were awesome as well. Service was spot on, everyone was very friendly, we were seated quick, food came out relatively fast even though they were busy. All in all it was a great experience. Compared to some of the other hole in the wall places I've been to for XLB, Dumpling Kitchen is much bigger, seemed a whole lot cleaner, takes reservations as well as accepts credit cards. Total no brainer, this is my spot for XLB from now on!! Can't wait to go back and try more things!!
author: Nick J.

description:
This is a regular family haunt of ours and while I do think the food is good - nothing spectacular, but good - I have to warn you about the pea sprouts.

Now I get it - pea sprouts are hard to clean.  D likes to remind me of this any time and any where that we order the dish, as I examine each sprout and leaf before tentatively placing it in my mouth.  But regardless of how difficult these veggies are to clean, I expect the dish to arrive critter-free.  When I order pea sprouts, I don't request a sprinkling of bugs, so please don't serve them to me, especially when I'm already paying $14 (yes, most pricey veggie on the menu) for this dish.

Everything else here is a-ok from the XLBs to the potstickers to the chili won tons.  You might just want to proceed with caution with those pea sprouts.
author: Mel T.

description:
We showed up for dinner on a Sunday night and waited about ten minutes.

Dinner for two included:
+Shanghai-style steamed pork dumplings, AKA the XLBs, AKA xiao long bao, AKA ten pieces of deliciousness.
+Shanghai-style pan-fried pork buns, AKA eight pieces of pan-fried buns that were almost identical to the XLBs, AKA still-delicious as take-out.
+Shanghai-style green onion pancake, AKA crispy deliciousness, AKA holy-cow-why-did-we-order-this-we're-too-full, AKA I-can't-stop-eating-this-even-if-I-am-too-full.

Be warned: these three items for two people is incredibly filling. 

Service was fine, food was delicious, prices were excellent.
author: Adena B.

description:
DUMPLINGS!  My kingdom for some good dumplings!

My last meal on earth would be my mom's chive and pork dumplings so this genre of food is near and dear to my heart.

Dumpling Kitchen has a small menu, but so delicious.  Their dumpling skins are really fresh and "fall apart" good.  None of that tough, thick dough skin here!  The dumplings are juicy and hot!  sigh, just writing about it makes me want to get some more....  

The dining room is nice sized, clean and well ventilated.  The bathrooms are "typical" of older Chinese restaurants (kinda grimy).  The wait staff was friendly and didn't mind that I spoke English.  

I took my family of 4 here, had about 4 types of dumplings and a noodle dish and left w enought money to go down to 37 degrees for dessert!
author: Sandy L.

description:
The food was above average but certainly not the best I've ever had. The pork dumplings (most anticipated) was also just good. 

The food came out pretty quickly and service was good. Not much more you can ask for!
author: Henry F.

description:
One of my favorite hidden gems of tasty asian cuisine in sf! Dumplings are always bursting with flavor. I don't go here for anything else but their steamed soup and pan fried dumplings. 

I almost always order their number 1 Shanghai steamed soup dumplings- which are literally clouds of a heavenly pork mixture that seep out their juices in that small pocket of soft dough, when you bite into them, they burst so delicately onto your taste buds and make your day that much better. Amazing. 
Number 5 Panfried pork dumplings are also a must. The balance of textures with the soft, chewy dough, juicy pork filling, and crispy fried dough bottom is truly an experience. Having extra to take home is a blessing because I always eat them all! 

Portions are great for the price. Definitely a place to go on a budget. Avoid busy times and days. Sometimes on those busy days/times they make their dumplings almost constantly especially for their popular items, you might get stuck with dumplings that have been sitting for a while. Go on a day where not that many are in, so you know your dumplings will be steamed/fried to your order and fresh!
author: Aimee A.

description:
I love a great dumpling. Din Tai Fung is the benchmark and while this place comes close, they don't quite match up. I'd like them more if they were more soupy. A few of them busted open before we were able to inhale them. For $7 in the sunset, i just expected more.

Stir fry rice cakes...i guess they arent good if you do not douse them in oil, i thought these were too oily, but every other place serves them just as oily. Not enough pork and too  much veggies. 

Service...is of standard chinese restaurant quality. Don't expect anything more. This was not a factor of my review. 

I'd give the place 3.5 stars
author: Brandon N.

description:
There XLB are legit. I tried both the crab and pork and plain pork dumplings and both are great. 

I especially love the Shanghai style fired rice cake with pork and veggies. It's so simple, but so good!!

I would skip on their dry fried chicken wings, not as good as it looks. 

Their homemade soy bean drink is delicious. I had two cups!
author: Milly H.

description:
This place was such a pleasant surprise! We got the pork belly, which was super legit, the regular xlbs, the crab/pork xlbs, and the shengjianbaos.

The xlbs were soupy and held up all the way to your mouth, the sjbs had great texture and a nice crunch on the bottom, and the pork belly had excellent flavor. Goes so well with some white rice. 

Everything was about as good as you can get in SF, although I think the best place for Shanghainese food in the Bay is still Little Shanghai in San Mateo. But if you live in SF and want a great, cheap Shanghainese food, you won't go wrong here!
author: Diana L.

description: Hole in the wall dumpling place?  Yes please!  Had Shanghai dumplings for the first time.  Be careful, the soup/broth inside is very hot!  They were very flavorful and a perfect item to eat on a cold night.  The potstickers were perfectly pan friend so that the bottom was crispy but the potstickers were still moist.  The Lion Head Soup comes with several GIANT meatballs; not sure how people are supposed to finish that item...but the meat was moist and melted in your mouth, very good.
author: Mary V.

description: Excellent dumplings, excellent service and enough hot oolong tea to keep your cups topped off at all times. The dumplings are tender, juicy and served steaming hot. The Sesame Chicken is not to be missed - tender, thick, juicy strips of white-meat chicken in a delicious sesame-soy coating. The Chinese Fried Dough is a greasy treat that tastes fantastic dipped in a mixture of rice vinegar, soy sauce and chili paste. The Shredded Pork and Leeks have a rich, flavorful sauce with whole cloves of roasted garlic, for you garlic lovers out there. This is a hidden gem that is worth searching out!
author: Anthony N.

description: After getting such hype recommendations from friends, and then reading such hype reviews, I was definitely disappointed. Guys, this is not "authentic" soup dumpling! It doesn't hold a candle to actual street cuisine in Shanghai, and is not even at the caliber of franchises like Ding Tai Feng. The regular boiled dumplings were alright, though.
author: Vick Y.

description: Just come here for dumplings.  Tofu here is only okay.  Price is right and dumplings were good.  Skin could be a bit thinner.  I don't like thick skin cuz it makes me feel like I'm just eating a bun.  Both the fried and steamed dumplings were good.  It's not too tasty but it's juicy.
author: Byron L.

description:
We came here for the xlb's and placed 2 orders, along with an order of Shanghai noodles with peanut sauce.

The xlbs were so so ($6.50 for 10). The skin was thin and the size of the dumplings were average. There was not enough "soup" in each dumpling and some dumplings, which had no hole, didn't even have any soup. The taste was average.

I especially liked the noodle dish here and would definitely come back for it. If you like peanut sauce and spicy, this dish has both (although, I was expecting it to be spicier).

1 hour street parking available in the residential streets. I would probably go somewhere else for their xlb's.
author: Janel Y.

description:
Great quality food at decent prices, and usually no wait for seats!  (I find the food here better than Kingdom of Dumpling, a block away).

Shanghai-style steamed pork dumplings (10pcs) 
Thread roll *steamed or deep-fried (1 roll) 
Pork Preserved Vegetable Fried Rice Cakes
Sweet soy milk

More than enough for 2 people totaling $21.   None of the dumplings were punctured (juicy!), each customer will get their own small vinagar/ginger dipping dish.  The thread roll is yummy when hot (first to come out), this is very filling and is cut into 4 pieces, wrapped in saran wrap (for steaming).  The rice cakes were good too, not too oily.  Very flavorful with the preserved mustard greens and plenty of garlic (will start to get more salty/flavorful towards the bottom of the dish).  The rice cakes are the softer kind than the korean rice cakes.   Sweet soy milk in a glass, a great pairing to the other savory foods.
author: Ju D.

description: This is my favorite dumpling place in the city. The food is great and the staff is very nice. They even closed down for an afternoon to accommodate our wedding rehearsal lunch.
author: Daniel F.

description:
Let's cut to the dumpling chase - the Xiao Long Bao were good.  Pretty big, very juicy, and cooked just right in a bamboo steamer, so they didn't stick.

We got the set dinner ($35-40, I think?), which was more than enough for 3-4 people - yay for leftovers for the twosome!   Knowing the owner, the ladyfriend swapped out the Shanghai-style Drunken Chicken for the Shanghai-style Pan-Fried Pork Buns, which were deliciously ginormous and of course, slightly oily from being fried but not burnt.  The Hot and Sour Soup was decent - not very spicy but packed with stuff.  The Shanghai-style Chow Mein was just ok, although I think this is one of the harder dishes to get right with the fine balance of oil.  The Dry Fried Chicken Wings were really good and definitely comparable to that popular Irving place that shall remain nameless - imitation is the highest form of flattery, right?

You can request different sweetness levels for the hot soy milk for those with and without a sweet tooth.  The Crispy Egg Puffs (with sugar on top!) were really good and irresistible even though we were full.  -_-
author: Kevin W.

description:
Going back today. Hope they are open.   Excited for pork soup dumplings.  Dan Dan noodle.  Lion head and sweet and sour chicken.   Maybe some egg puff donuts in the end.  

This place is the go to spot anytime we happen to be near by
author: F A.

description: Just went for the first time today and really enjoyed lunch here.  Really refreshing to have a Chinese place to go to that has good food along with a (very) good health score.  The guys serving were nice and on top of things.  Only got one thing so haven't explored the menu much, but that said it was good so I will be back.
author: Jesus H.

description:
Come here and you will feast like a king/queen! The boy and I were originally looking for a good dim sum place by the ocean and Dumpling Kitchen came up on Yelp. We went there with high hopes and were not disappointed! 

Our eyes were bigger than our stomachs and so we ordered: 

Pan fried pork buns
Pork dumplings
Seafood dumplings
Lion's head meatballs in soup

Because the portions here are enormous, we got much more food than we bargained for. Everything, every single thing was delicious. I'm not from Shanghai but I've eaten at enough dim sum  and Northern Chinese places with my Chinese-American friends to know what's good and what is not. This place is good.
author: Nene K.

description:
Better than the place up the street, that's for sure. Everything we ordered was good and we'll be back for sure. XLB, fried XLB, normal dumplings, dumplings in chili sauce (I think), some noodle dish and chicken wings. I'd pass on the later two and just stick to dumpling type items.

Not sure why anyone would go to Kingdom of Dumpling - It reminds me too much of Chinatown and that's not a good thing.
author: Con L.

description: I really love this Dummpling Kitchen.Servuce is so quick. Their dumplings were so jucy.
author: LI LI S.

description:
Went here for New Years Day brunch with friends and their kids. We had a group of 13 and there were not too many large tables available, so we got there as soon as they opened.
Food was amazing! Service was exceptional! Orders came out really fast!
Everything we ordered I'd recommend again - green onion pancakes, any of the dumplings, fresh sweet soy milk, egg puffs!
author: Matthew S.

description: My friend had the XLB and the Dumplings in Chili Oil. Both were absolutely fantastic, especially the XLB. Warm and juicy, with a sturdy skin and a very flavorful filling. It's small, so expect a wait on the weekends.
author: Dwayne L.

description: A lot of restaurants in SF are overpriced for mediocre food so I was extremely happy to find this place for my all time favorite dish, xiao long bao! The food tastes great, fair portions, and all at an affordable price! They have the best shanghai steamed dumplings. The soup is flavorful,  the skin isn't chewy or too delicate, and the meat is cooked just right. Their vinegar is also a little sweeter than most places but it compliments the dumplings really well. The soy milk is not too sweet but also not bland making it a delicious beverage to go with your meal. The other dishes also taste pretty good, such as the shanghai noodles. I definitely consider this place a hidden gem.
author: Rachel L.

description: I got xlb dumplings this time and they are the best I've tasted so far! I had Din Tai Fung in Taiwan and I think this place was better ha! Dry fried chicken I still have to give it up to San tung, this place was ok but not as good.
author: Karen T.

description: I live in Austin and from the moment I arrived in San Francisco I wanted Shanghai dumplings.  We combed Yelp to find what we were looking for.  We settled on Dumpling Kitchen, and I'm glad we did!  I went in for the Shanghai dumplings, but didn't stop there.  We had the chili oil pork dumplings.  Yum!  One of the super cute girls who worked there recommended the pan fried pork dumplings.  Super yum!  We also got the cabbage and pork dumplings.  I know, a lot of pork, but so what!  Then we topped off the meal with the egg puffs, which were heaven in the mouth.  I order them early, cause they take 20 minutes.  We were pre warned.  Heaven I tell you!  Also very inexpensive.  Also great friendly service and clean!  I miss dumpling kitchen!
author: Stacie S.

description:
This Dumpling Kitchen is a convenient location for a quick and casual dinner. They serve delicious Shanghai dumplings, braised green beans, green onion pancake, and Shanghai noodles. 

Waiting time is no more than 20 minutes for dinner and food comes out quickly. Don't expect fabulous customer service because that's not what Dumpling Kitchen is about. You come here to get your dumping cravings satisfied.
author: Winnie L.

description:
Dumpling Kitchen trumps Kingdom of Dumplings in just about everything.  I can't go a month without paying this place a visit.  The soup dumplings are the best in town.  There's rarely a wait and the food comes out super quick.  

One thing you may want to know- the portions are fairly large, so order accordingly or prepare for lots of leftovers!
author: Patricia T.

description:
Booyashaka. Dumpling Kitchen is coming off a strong performance in my tummy. 

I'd been craving some chinese food for a week, and after a trip to nearby Stonestown, I was on the Yelp lookout for some nearby chinese food. I found Dumpling Kitchen and decided to give it a try. 

We walk in and the first thing we notice is how loud it is. Whoa. But it was actually primarily due to a loud table of college kids. Durn kids. But every table in the place was occupied, which I took as a good sign. We sit down and with a quick look over the menu, we spot the things we typically like. It's Shanghai food, so you have your xiao long bao, green onion pancakes, stir-fried rice cakes, pan-fried dumplings (sheng jian bao), etc. Although other things on the menu looked very enticing, I stuck to my standards. 

1) xiao long bao: I have to say that these rival any other in the city. Better than Shanghai Dumpling King on Balboa, better than Kingdom of Dumpling up the street on Taraval, better than San Dong on Geary. The skin was soft and delicate, relatively thin, and didn't tear when they were picked up. The filling was very flavorful, extremely juicy (actually living up to the soup dumpling name), and piping hot. Really couldn't find much wrong with these. 

2) Pan-fried bao: I kind of prefer the pan-fried bao to be larger, but these were quite good. The outer dough was crispy on the bottom, and the steamed part was light enough, although it was right at that border of being too dense. Again, the pork filling was excellent, juicy, and hot. I always forget how big a difference the temperature of a dish when it is served makes. Unlike revenge, this is not a dish best served cold. 

3) Shanghai style chow mein: They were good. The noodles were possibly made in house? Not sure. They were large and in charge, thick and chewy. Overall, there wasn't anything particularly special about the chow mein. Though it was good and satisfied my noodle fix. 

4) Five spice tofu and pork: Although I normally looooove any dish that mixes thin pork strips and baked tofu, this one was a bit of a disappointment. The flavor was ok, although it had a hint of some type of flavor (I'd like to guess yellow chives, but I'm not sure) that set it apart from other places. I guess it just kind of seemed like something I make at home. It also contained big strips of onions, green and red bell peppers. Good with some rice, but I'll probably try something else next time. 

So there you go. I was impressed. I would definitely go again. The portions are quite large, and the prices are very reasonable. Service was pretty quick and friendly. Oh yeah, and they give you a small dish of salted peanuts when you sit down. Awesome. Unless you have a peanut allergy. Then it's not awesome, and it's more like anaphylactic shock.
author: Saunders C.

description:
Recommended by many, I had high expectations for the XLB at Dumpling Kitchen. Perhaps I am now a snooty XLB eater but I like my XLB steaming hot, thin skinned and on the dainty side. When the skin is too thick and tough and the dumpling itself is too big, I feel like it starts to taste too chewy and the filly is always really hard. 

As for other dishes (you already know Mr. W. and I wouldn't just order one dish now... right..?) we had: 

the free salted peanuts-- sooo delicious 

Shanghai style chow mein-- a delicious dish of grease and chow mien 

dry fried chicken-- a little too spicy for my taste but Mr. Dubs love it 

Everything we had was decent but nothing (besides the free peanuts) really made me want to tell everyone to check this place out. I was also a little turned off by the slooooow service. Against my will, Mr. W. opted for a second can of soda and it took us 15 minutes to catch our waitress' attention. We were one of the 3 tables that night and she was too preoccupied with the conversation she was having with another waitress. 

I wouldn't say this is my best experience with shanghainese food but I can hardly consider it my worst. I'll probably be back when I'm craving some shanghainese food!
author: Tiffany U.

description: great dumplings and very good soy milk. Im not a huge fan of shanghai dumplings, the steamed dumplings with the 'soup' on the inside, but I do enjoy them from here. I also really like the combination rice cake noodles. theyre rice cakes stir fried with shrimp, chicken and beef. yum. they also serve that chinese burrito wrap here. its chinese donut with dried pork wrapped in sticky rice. so far the only thing I would not suggest getting here is the green onion pancake, only because I like my pancakes to be thin and cripsy and its thick and cakey here. other than that, good, friendly service with good food.
author: Serena L.

description: Amazing dumplings and never too crowded.  It's become a ritual visit whenever we have to move our car for street cleaning, to make the extra drive to come out here :)  Highly recommend the salt/pepper chicken wings, the shrimp/crab dumplings, and traditional pork dumplings - so good!
author: Morgan C.

description: Best dumplings ever! Delicious. The Shanghai dumplings and the spicy dumplings were both wonderful. We also had the string beans, which were excellent. Good quality beans and very tasty sauce. Service was good and friendly.
author: Daniel S.

description:
4.5 stars. 
The latest restaurant on my quest for perfect dumplings, Dumpling Kitchen brought some serious game. My boyfriend and I were seated quickly when we showed up at 5:30 on a Friday night. They quickly served us tea and a small bowl of spiced peanuts.
 We noted with delight that the restaurant charges for take home containers and requests that customers bring their own!! That's where the extra half star comes from.
We were also impressed by the low prices. This restaurant was extremely reasonable for the quality.
We ordered some XLB, the garlic eggplant, and pork dumplings in chili oil. The eggplant came first. It was super delicious. The sauce was spicy and sweet with lots of flavor. The eggplant was cooked perfectly. The portion was HUGE and I ate the rest of it for two different entire lunches after my boyfriend and I had done our best to finish it in the restaurant.
The XLB came next, piping hot. The dumplings had lots of flavor and a decent amount of soup. The meat was tender and fresh, clearly a popular enough item to have been made that day and not frozen. Not one single one of the skins broke. This place is one of my new favorite places to find XLB for the quality and price.
The pork dumplings in chili oil was a comparatively weak point. This dish was a typical set of 12 steamed pork dumplings with a simple sauce.  I would order their regular steamed dumplings like this again, but only after trying some other items like the shanghai buns. For that particular style of dumplings, I'd prefer to go to China Dumpling North on Noriega where it is their specialty. Dumpling Kitchen did these well, but it was clearly not their specialty. 
When we went, the restaurant wasn't particularly busy, so I can't speak to a normal hour, but the service was attentive and responsive to even eye contact. 
I'm looking forward to going back and trying the Shanghai pork buns!
author: Allxie C.

description:
First of all, this is a Cantonese-ran-Shanghainese-style-Dumpling shop. Don't get me wrong, nothing with being Cantonese, I'm Cantonese. It may just tell you how "authentic" the dishes are. Again, don't get me wrong, "authentic" doesn't mean not taste good. The food is decent, but not "authentic". 

We got the pan fried pork buns ($7/10), "Beijing" dumplings ($7/10), potstickers ($7/10), and xiaolongbao ($7/12). 

The tastes were good, fillings of meat and veggie. The skin on everything are on the thin side, the dumpling skin is nothing like the ones next door at Kingdom of Dumpling. But my kid who usually doesn't eat much ate at least 12 pieces of a combo of everything. But we didn't get much of other varieties like green onion pancake, noodles, nor dishes. Perhaps next time we'll try some of the noodles.

All was good, not wow, good enough that if we're in the area again this would be on the list of place to eat but won't drive here specifically nor have any cravings.
author: Lisa Z.

description:
I was here with my son today for lunch.
We were standing at the front door, checking inside threw the window to see too busy or not. It was not too busy so I was ready to get in. 

My son, "Are you sure?"

Me, " Urr, yah. Why?"

My son, "I don't know about this."

Me, "What do you mean by that?"

My son, "Have you been here before?"

Me, "No, this is my 1st."

My son, "So you don't know?"

Me, " That's right! I don't."

My son, " Did you read Yelp reviews about this place?"

Me, "For what?"

My son, " Well, to see the place is good or bad?"

Me, " Oh No, Never, I trust NO ONE but myself."

My son, " Even it says real people real reviews?"

Me, "Hell Yah, Real hip star doofus writing real BS reviews."

My son, " So, you don't know."

Me, "Hey, my favorite son, life is always hit or miss. I know why you are not sure about the place because it doesn't  look clean from out side. But I got to tell you, do not trust your eyes, especially for Chinese, Just trust whats your heart saying, trust your feeling, may the force be with us."

My son, "WTF?"

We went in. Inside is bigger, cleaner than Kingdom of Dumpling.

I had the lunch special menu, the beef and tofu over rice. $7 was a bomb!!!
Really big portion, great MSG flavor, the beef was 'tenderizered' tender, with big cuts of soft tofu.
My son also had the lunch special menu, chicken and broccoli with egg noodle. $7 was another bomb!!! The egg noodle was garlic egg noodle mixed with sesame seeds. The broccoli was crispy, not over cooked, chicken was well done, Thank god, again great MSG flavor.

We shared one order of Beijing-style pork and chive dumplings. 10 for $6, It was good. But we could tell that the KOD has better dumplings.

My son said, "Dad, I want to take a nap."                           

MSG does that.

I might be wrong about it but, it seems like Cantonese chef is trying to imitate Shanghinese dumplings. If so, I think he is doing well. 

Shanghinese is very different Chinese.

http://www.bjstuff.com/forum/topics/why-do-chinese-people-dislike-shanghainese-people

By the way, Service was really good too. 
I'll be back.
author: Nobu K.

description:
DAMN good.  I don't know if it was because me the bf were really hungry, but he thought it was the best food we had all year...and we've had quite a lot of food and expensive food....

Anyway we ordered the xiao lum bao.  He thought it was the best he has had.  In my opinion, the flavor is still better at ZnYs, but it was almost just as good.  Overall, it was much better made with a good skin and it just MELTED In your mouth.  I never broke one, but my bf kept on breaking his when he picked it up.  I wish they put one of those cabbage leaves underneath when they steamed it. 

We ALSO got the beef noodle soup.  I'm still looking for a good spicy beef noodle soup, which I haven't found in SF yet, but this was was def very good.  Big hunks of beef with a good flavor.  The presentation was a little lacking though. When it came, i was a little hesitant if it was going to be good.

We ALSO got the dried fried chicken.  This was good, though it could have been a little more fried and crispy.  Flavor was good. 

We ALSO got this mushroom and chinese greens dish.  This was also very good and i had a lot of flavor.  The only complain was that I wanted all big chinese mushrooms, and it was a medley.

The food was pretty cheap and really good.  Definitely above a lot of other cheap chinese restaurants in the area.
author: Aly A.

description:
One of the best dumpling places that I've been to in the city. Giving it a star off because the appetizers weren't that great and they were a little pricey. Overall though, the food was great and cheap!

My favorite dish was definitely the pan fried pork dumplings; they were perfectly cooked and juicy on the inside with a fried texture on the outside! The XLBs were delicious but unfortunately, a bunch of ours popped. The ones that didn't were pretty damn good!

All-in-all, this place deserves 4.5 stars for great service and cheap/great quality food. Will definitely be coming back here for more!
author: Wilson L.

description:
With Northern Chinese cuisine being Dumpling Kitchen's focus, I didn't quite know what to order. Luckily the group that I came with that day did, and I was happy with what ended up in my tummy.

I assumed we mainly had the specialty dishes, of which xiao long bao cannot be missed. I've never been a huge fan, but these were good. Just be careful when handling them because they are quite fragile. One strong stroke of a utensil to pick it up can easily break the dumpling skin and then you'd lose the treasured soup in it. The filling was very tender and flavorful. I also noticed the filling was just as tender in the vegetable and pork dumpling as well.  

We had three noodle dishes and the Shanghai chow mein and the Shanghai rice cakes were essentially the same thing, except a different noodle was used. I liked the rice cakes more, since it's not everyday I can each rice cakes with a chewy and dense texture. 

The portions are not huge here, which led our group of seven to order around 10 items to satisfy the hunger of two growing boys. Since I'm in the Sunset often when I'm in SF, I'm sure I'll be here again, but the next time I visit, I'll stick with the dumplings as they have quite a selection that I haven't tried yet.
author: Diana C.

description: Fast service and great food, inexpensive. There is a long line always. But we could get in easily around 11 am on Saturday.  Highly recommended.
author: kazue w.

description:
I came here a several times for lunch. This place is always packed every time I have came. I always get the hot soy milk. It is smooth and not too sweet. The Chinese doughnut goes well with the soy milk. I like dunking the salty doughnut into the sweet soy milk and eating it. The Shanghai style steamed pork dumplings are great. The skin nice and thin and filled with juicy pork and broth. The dipping sauce goes well with the dumplings. The Beijing style boiled pork and chive dumplings are also very good. I like the shanghai style chow mein. The noodles are extra thick and have a good chew to them. The noodles are stir fried with some chicken and some other veggies. The fried chicken wings are great. They are fried with peppers and covered in a light sauce.

Make sure you put your name on the waiting list as soon as you get to the restaurant. If your party is small you may have the option to share a table with another party. The food comes out pretty quickly.
author: Alexander L.

description:
Food here is decent. You can get ten pieces of xiao long bao for $7, which is a good deal. I think the xiao long bao places up on Balboa are better though. You can also get dry fried chicken (also ten pieces) here for $8.50. The skin tasted pretty similar to the ones you can get at San Tung, although the meat seemed a bit too soft.

Service could use some work. The staff seems very clumsy. On multiple occasions, one waitress kept dropping teacups from trays as she set up tables. Luckily they didn't shatter, or else there would have been shards everywhere, and there were children running around the restaurant who could have hurt themselves. Additionally, another waitress somehow spilled vinegar all over my friend's pants and just said a simple sorry and walked away. She came back with a small stack of napkins which really didn't help much. We were handed the check before we finished eating, and every few minutes a staff member would walk by to check if we had paid yet.
author: Allen C.

description:
Love the Shanghai dumplings here! The skin is just the right thickness and the filling is juicy and flavorful. Been coming here for years and these are always part of our order.

We also like the pan fried dumplings. They're small buns stuffed with tasty pork filling that are steamed, then pan fried to make the outside crispy.

Can get busy on weekend mornings, buy most weeknights for dinner the wait is 15 minutes or less.
author: Erick L.

description:
Great for groups but make reservations. 

Green onion pancake and soup dumplings are very tasty. Reasonably priced. Quick service.

It is out there though for those not living in the area.
author: Ashley W.

description: We've tried many dumpling places in SF and the greater bay area.  No question Dumpling Kitchen is the best.  The Shanghai Soup dumplings and green beans are favorites.  Service is good.  Be prepared to wait if going on busy Saturday or Sunday late mornings.  Take out is always a good option if you're in a hurry.
author: Cathy H.

description: A friend told me about this place, and I've been back many times, have never had a meal that was not delicious. Everyone I've taken here liked it also.
author: James P.

description:
5 stars just for the xiu lung bao!! It's so perfect and melts in your mouth! unlike other places where the xiu lung bao comes out deflates and juiceless. Dumpling kitchen's is perfect and FULL of juice!

I also heard that the chef used to work as a chef at koi's palace! so that's a plus! 

In addition to their yummy xiu lung bao, their fresh soy milk is to die for! along with their xia yong (fried donut with sugar) even though it wasn't "fresh" it was still great tasting and wasn't oily like we expected out of one that has been sitting around for a while. 

If possible you should come in on the weekdays (it's less packed) on the weekends, the line goes out the door!
author: Jess s.

description:
I'm a dumpling novice living in a dumpling kingdom, and the pan fried Shanghai style dumplings here have been one of my favorites in my dumpling search. The servings -- as mentioned -- are enormous so one entree is enough for three. The Shanghai style noodles definitely make up for the lack of Chow Fun. Three people could order one set of dumplings and entree and walk out spending a total of $15.

I'm not so sure how this sets apart from Kingdom of Dumpling as I haven't been there. I dig the dive atmosphere at Shanghai on Balboa more, but that's just me & my urge to avoid table cloths. Ultimately, if they just turned on music I'd be okay with the atmosphere or if I show up with five friends, the energy would be much better. The price though... it's unbeatable.
author: Jon A.

description:
My regular order that rarely disappoints: 
-xiao long bao
-sang sing bao (panfried pork bun)
-hot sweet soy milk
-vegetarian potstickers
-pork & napa cabbage dumpling

Sometimes, I like to change it up and order the shanghai combo noodles, chili sauce dumpling, and green onion pancakes.
author: Winn D.

description:
This place has the best shanghai dumplings I've ever had, hands down!  Their XLBs are SO DAMN GOOD and even their non-XLB dumplings (ie: their crab and pork dumpling dish) has really tasty broth inside!

The broth inside the dumpling that oozes out when you take your first bite is very flavorful and light.  Also, there is consistency with the soup being inside each and every dumpling I've had.  It's not like most places where the soup had already evaporated by the time you get to the last dumpling in the steam bowl.  I have also taken some left-over dumplings home, microwaved it the next day, and there would still be broth inside!  It's SOOOO awesome!

You also don't leave feeling thirsty as if you consumed a ton of sodium like some places make you feel.  At some places, you can tell there is MSG in the food...and I don't taste it here.  

Their chow mein noodles are the thickest I've had (yeah...yeah...that's what she said) and their Sichaun Style Noodles with Peanut Sauce (Dan Dan Mien style) is my favorite.  It has just the right amount of "gravy" like texture and the flavor is so well-balanced!  I just have to get this dish every time! 

I just love this place!  Will definitely come back over and over again.

You know the food is good when EVERYONE at your table stops talking to eat. 

...Mmmm!
author: Wendy T.

description:
Went here with my family because we wanted to try something new and decided to eat here. This restaurant gets packed during any time of the day, when we arrived we thought we had to wait long because there were a bunch of people outside waiting, however they had a waiting list inside for you to write your name and how many people are with you. After we wrote our name down our wait only ended up to be about 10 minutes which isn't too bad since there were about four groups ahead of us. 
The servers here are quick on their feet because as you sit down they already place your menu, plates, utensils, and tea right in front of you, which I thought was clever because at other certain places they take awhile to give you your tea and rush you as are looking at the menu debating what to get as they keep passing by wondering if you're ready. But at this restaurant they are more prepared and with just a hand signal they are right at your service, they don't keep coming pass your table asking if you're ready or spying on you to see if you're ready. They are patience people but I don't know how they are if this place were to be very packed. 
The food here is delicious we got Shanghai-style steamed pork dumplings which consists of a small soup filling inside along with steamed pork so be careful as you take a bite in this dumpling because the soup could pour out all into your dish and honestly I think it's the best part so don't let that happen; Seafood chow mien which goes well with their chili sauce and is quite yummy except for the fact that it is a bit oily but most noodles if they aren't using too much oil then it wouldn't be as savory as it could be; Beijing- Style boiled pork and chive dumplings was similar to the steamed pork dumpling except that it also had chives and ginger inside which was good but should be devoured first because when it has been out for awhile and starts to cool off it gets a bit dry which i don't like for my dumplings; then last but not least we got Dry braised string beans with rice this is one of the lunch special dishes which is for a good price and the string beans were salty at just the right amount which goes well with the rice and within every bite it just makes you want to crave for more. 

I would recommend this place if you want a place to eat that's quick at their service and waiting to be seated and for food to come out isn't that long.
author: Victoria G.

description:
I need to try more items but we like our favorites so much that we keep ordering the same things. Need to bring another friend so we can expand our choices. We love the steam dumplings, the pan fried pork buns, string beans, thick Shanghai noodles, mushu pork, dry fried chicken wings. 
I took away one star because the pan fried stuff is on the greasier side... but maybe that's why it's so good. It's also a bit on the casual side....but service is always excellent and friendly. The place is clean. Wish they add ice to the water though. I don't like drinking tap water in a plastic cup. I can drink it down if it was icy. There is free hot tea.
Prices are great. I think most if not all items are under $10. Big portions too. We always order more than we can eat. Take out is fast. Call order in and it is ready in 15 minutes.
author: jane f.

description: Food coma inducing. The XLB are incredible. Also loved the braised green beans. Peanut noodles tasted fantastic when they first came out piping hot but were less impressive as the meal progressed. Dry fried chicken wings were good enough. Fried pork buns were delicious but I wish they had baked BBQ pork buns for differentiation. Red bean pancake also on point but again make a small complaint in that I wish they had sesame balls as the vehicle.
author: Lauren H.

description:
Friend took me here to share her local dumpling go-to restaurant. She has three standards that all restaurants have to meet: food quality, price and cleanliness. Kingdom of Dumpling did not meet food quality and cleanliness for her (though I still like it there). 

There were many dishes ordered and the ones that stood out were the shanghai dumplings, pot stickers, peanut noodle and this other noodle soup. All were really good! Shanghai dumplings were yummy! The pot stickers were fried perfectly and the skin was thin. Most places would have thick skins for their pot stickers and the exterior burnt. I was told this restaurant makes their own noodles! Fresh and tasty! 

Service was attentive and very friendly. The food came out in a timely manner. The quantity of shanghai dumplings were more than what  Kingdom of Dumplings gives few blocks up. Though, their fried rice isn't as good as Kingdom's. 

I want to go back soon! I have been craving for more. This restaurant is Alisa Approved =)
author: Alisa M.

description: Dumpling kitchen is my go to place for Xiao long Bao. It also has a good selection of other Cantonese dishes. The Shanghai fried noodles is something we almost always get with the Xiao Long Bao. The fiancé also really like the soy milk. Will certainly keep coming back.
author: Da D.

description: The thick noodle chow mein was fantastic, and all the potstickers and various dumplings we got were pretty good. My only comment is that anyone who has ever had actual XLB (Din Tai Fung, anywhere in Asia, etc) will know that these are really really sub-par. The skin is very thick, making them more of just regular dumplings rather than XLBs. With that said, it's a great place to come if you're expecting American friendly dumplings and Chinese food.
author: Amy Y.

description:
Meh.. 

Don't order the walnut prawns unless you like lemon frosting.. Cuz I kid you not that's what it was. We ordered pick up, and you get the frosting in a small cup. 

I like the crispy puffs though they are super greasy.

The shanghai dumplings are yummy, but your sodium levels will shoot through the roof! 

Green onion pancakes are okay, but my bf loved it. Though he also smothered them in sriracha. 

I tried the peanut noodles with a friend before and it was her favorite, however it wasn't for me.
author: Linda L.

description:
My first visit today and it was very enjoyable.  
The pork belly was very flavorful. I will return again.
author: Mark A.

description: Ok good.  A little bit pricey but also the portions are huge.  Better for a group of 4 than 2.
author: Chris L.

description:
I don't eat dumplings often but would consider coming here if given the chance or choice. We ordered three types of dumplings and a soup, but it was plenty of food:

- xiao long bao=Shanghai-style steamed pork dumplings was $6/10pcs (good, as expected), 
- crab and pork steamed dumplings was $9/8pcs (our favorite), 
- pork dumplings in chili oil was $6/10pcs (unique, but also good),
- Shanghai style spring rolls was $4.50/6pcs,
- sizzling rice soup w/beef & chicken was $6 (just so-so); regular items also on the menu if you prefer entrees on the side.

The inside is typical Chinese mini-restaurant and nothing fancy so don't expect a lot. Parking is not too bad but you may have to circle a couple of times since it is in a residential area in the Outer Sunset - but it's worth a trip out.
author: Peter L.

description: This place is really really really good, I've been here more than 50 times... My favorite dishes are: Pan-Fried Pork Buns, Pork & Cabbage steamed dumplings, shanghai noodles and shanghai spring rolls. If you get these dishes you won't be disappointed! :)
author: Charles M.

description: Ordered the shengjianbao or better known as pan fried dumpling. The filling doesn't have that juicy/soupy and it's a little bit on the dry side. The bottom of the bao also haven't a crisp texture that I had before elsewhere. It tastes more like a steam bao than an actual shenjianbao (pan fried bao). Let's just say I had better ones but it's decent enough. So would I go back again? Maybe....but def won't make out of my way to go there.
author: Cindy L.

description: Not Yank Sing or Din Tai Fung, but also not YS or DTF prices. Cheap, decent dumplings without a ridiculous wait. The wrappers on the XLB pork dumplings looked a bit thick, but tasted fine and, most importantly, kept the soup intact!  The wontons in chili oil had the most meat I've ever seen in a wonton, but, again, tasted good. Would definitely go back.
author: Ivy W.

description:
yummy yummy in my huuuuge tummy!

The overall atmosphere made me feel like I was at home eating and having a conversation with my family; service was friendly & fast like some other Yelpers have mentioned. $21 for two and I will exclaim it is DELICIOUS! We ordered a Shanghai style chow mein, pot stickers, a glass of hot soy milk and of course an order of the xiao long bao. 

Shanghai style chow mein: a little too much foliage covering the noodles, thick noodles were delicious and flavorful.

Pot stickers; the skin/wrap wasn't too think nor too thin, meat was juicy and hot.

Soy Milk: sweet, hot: just the way I love it.

Xiao long bao: one word: perfect; one more word: JUICY!

The bottom line is: This experience was better than the one at Kingdom of Dumpling from the atmosphere to the service and the food. (Kingdom of Dumpling didn't even have Shanghai style chow mein!) You can't go wrong with Dumpling Kitchen!
author: Carol L.

description: By far the best XLB in the Bay! Their salty soy milk is also delicious. Sugar puff and pan fried bun are also a must try. One of the very few Chinese restaurant that has friendly staffs.
author: Raymond L.

description:
I've been coming here every week for the past few months. This place consistently serves the best xiao long bao (soup dumplings) in SF. They also serve some of the best sheng jian bao (panfried dumplings) that I've had.

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description: A little stark on the ambiance, but the food is great. We tried to take some food home but it was so good we couldn't leave even a bite!
author: Lila B.

description: We went there this past Sunday, got there 11:45, about 5 parties in front of us. Wait was not long about 20 mInutes. Ordered food based on other Yelp reviews including crab/pork XLB they came out very sad looking - over steamed, where's the crab?, although flavor was good, onion pancake - bad greasy doughy and flavorless, shanghai style chow main decent, pork pan fried buns -good, pea shoots - good and 1 soy milk - good.  Bill was $54 - a bit pricey. I have had much better. Service was decent.   Glad there is lots of competition which gives me a variety of choices.
author: simone x.

description: OMG let's just say I'm never ever eating at dumpling kitchen again...I got FOOD POISONING from dinner here. I was excited to try this place after work and was so hungry as my last meal that day was breakfast. After eating, I felt so nauseous and threw everything up when I got home. Then I started getting really sharp, painful cramps and cold sweats that I couldn't move nor sleep. Mind you, I don't expect much from Asian restaurants when it comes to cleanliness but this was no coincidence as my friend got sick as well. Maybe this place isn't meant for those with weak stomachs, but tbh the food is only subpar and lacks authenticity. I still prefer kingdom of dumplings's food and never had a problem. One star because the XLBs were the only thing I liked but not enough for me to return and risk my life for.
author: Reggie L.

description:
Despite the very tight / cramped dining room, slow / often terrible service, and chintzy restaurant decor --  this place is amazing. We love to come here for lunch / dinner. The price is right and so is the quality of the food. 

Definitely recommend this place to dumpling lovers.
author: Sara M.

description:
I ordered the following:

Shanghai-style steamed pork dumplings (10pcs)  () $6.00: There was something really wrong with this dish. I felt like the texture of the meat inside was like moist breadcrumbs and the flavor was really off. It had a strong five spice taste to it. I have no idea how this place got such good ratings for their XLB, it wasn't good.. in fact, this is probably the worst XLB I have ever had. Most of the XLB had holes on the bottom before it hit our table and so I received no soup for the 2 out of 4 of the ones I ate. Worse luck ever.

Pork dumplings in chili oil (10pcs) () *Spicy $6.00: Ok, this dish was even WORSE than the XLB I ordered. Dish wasn't even spicy at all! In fact, it was sweet. Who makes dumplings with SWEET NON-SPICY CHILI OIL. ("*spicy" pfft!). The texture of the meat was also not good. Usually when you eat dumplings, it is one chunk wrapped with dough. For this place, the meat inside the dumpling crumbled. CRUMBLED... I have never seen dumplings do that..... smh

Green Onion Pancake: This wasn't bad, but it wasn't great. I like that the onions were there but not too strong for you to leave with an onion breath. Soft yet crispy. 

Shanghai Style Chow Mein: I love thick noodles! This wasn't bad, a bit on the bland side, but overall you get a lot of meat and veggies along with the chow mein. 

Shredded Pork with Veggies: The lady recommended this to us. Not a fan due to the fact that it had no flavor.... not even a saltiness flavor... just bland.

A place well known for their XLB and the day I came it sucked. I wouldn't recommend this place to anyone. The prices here are reasonable, but I can find better places with similar prices for my XLB cravings. I spent about $40 for this whole meal.
author: Erica T.

description: Service was great, food good!  We ordered a couple of dishes we wouldn't again but that's on us - better to explore and decide against than never to venture!
author: Lindsay A.

description:
about 3 years ago, David's kitchen sold his spot on Taraval to Mr & Mrs Li from the awesome dumpling factory store on Noriega, Kingdom of Dumpling. the Li Family quickly turned this location into a great little dumpling and noodle restaurant for authentic Northern style dumplings and noodle dishes. I am a big fan of freshly made dumplings and noodles from any region.  This fairly new restaurant piggy backs the dumpling and noodle theme from the Kingdom of Dumpling restaurant up the street but offers a full varied menu. the usual suspects are still here -  xiao loong baos, green onion pancakes, shanghai style pan fried noodles. but dishes like the Lion's Head meatball and other Shanghai style food fill out a more diverse menu.
Flavors are good. quality of ingredients is high.
JYW likes it here!
author: Jeff W.

description:
So we came here twice within 3 days.. Yea it's that good. We would've kept coming back but I think the staff started to recognize us lol. 
Best Xiao Long Bao in SF! It's perfect. The balance of meat and soup.
I also highly recommend  the pan fried pork dumplings. 
We tried the shanghai chow mein and the clay pot rice. Both were good! The chow mein was slightly undercooked but still good. 
I'm assuming it's a family owned business since it's so small. There's only one girl that really knows how to speak english who will take your order. If you ask any other lady there, she will just yell very loudly in chinese to the girl to come. 
I didn't mind though since the food was so good.
author: Ariel N.

description:
The food at Dumpling Kitchen varies...from "just OK" to "typical" to "really good."  At my last meal there was a real disappointment. I had the dry-fillet fish, lion's head meatballs, sweet and sour chicken, potstickers, and egg puffs.  The fish and chicken were nicely battered with tasty sauces.  They were good, but you could get the same thing at many restaurants.  The potstickers were nice because there was a good, crispy sear on them...however they were very small, therefore not exceptional.  My friend did not like the meatballs because they were very rare (pink) and soft (filler)...however I did like them.  The egg puffs were our big disappointment.  I have had them here before, and they usually arrive piping hot and fresh.  This time it was obvious that they were giving us left-over puffs (from the lunch crowd) that had been re-heated.  They were not fresh and hot, and someone had previously cut them in half (I don't even think the server noticed that they had been cut).

The service is somewhere between minimal and disappointing.  The workers are not friendly or engaging -- clearly their job is just to get the food on the table as fast as possible.  One waitress, and older lady, is exceptionally rude.  One time I placed my order and she responded, "Is that all you are getting?  You need to order more!"  This time, when I ordered the puffs, she said, "Oh no, that takes 20 minutes to make.  Are you sure you want that?"  My friend and I spent about an hour eating and had just finished our puffs when the staff cleared our table...taking our tea cups and tea, so that we could not linger and visit any longer.  They were clearly trying to get us to leave so that they could seat someone else.

The atmosphere is neighborhood "hole-in-the-wall" without any charm.  It is crowded, poorly ventilated, and all the surfaces look worn and greasy.  

I used to love this place, but unfortunately it's popularity has caused the owner and waitstaff to take their customers for granted. Although I have recommended Dumpling Kitchen to many friends in the past, I no longer will.
author: Izzy B.

description:
Food's so good we always forget to take pictures!

Stumbled into this place in January when our favorite wonton soup spot closed early and have been a fan ever since. Delicious every time and very reasonably priced portions big enough to share. Hands down our favorite xiaolongbao  (Shanghai soup dumplings). Definitely recommend the pork & chive dumplings in chile oil and the dry fried chicken wings (just the right sweet / spicy/ garlicky balance).

Better service, fresher tasting, and friendlier than other dumpling places; plus no long wait for tables.
author: Steven B.

description: This place is crazy good it is a great deal and is fast. Honestly, I kinda fear writing this review for fear of more people showing up... But man, this place is the real deal
author: Austin W.

description:
We only usually order two dishes for take out.

DRY FRIED CHICKEN WINGS and MONGOLIAN BEEF!

It's either REALLY good, or ehh, whatever.

Wings are hella saucy! Cheaper than San Tung, but of course isn't as good.
author: Vee 2.

description:
We went to Dumpling Kitchen today because I desperately wanted dim-summy food... dumplings. This was my first Shanghainese restaurant experience (I think)?  We put our names down, and were told 10-15 minutes. A few minutes later we were asked if we were okay with sharing a table. "Sure!" was our answer. We sat with two women, they had ordered a ton of food, so there was no need for any food ordering shame for me.  

We ordered:  
XLB Shanghai-style steamed pork dumplings (10pcs) - they were DELICIOUS!!! Shanghai-style pan-fried pork buns (8pcs) - Meh, would not order these again 
Pork dumplings in chili oil (10pcs) - YUM. Wontons in sesame chili oil. 
Shanghai-style green onion pancake - YUM! Crispy, onions, light, fluffy!!! 
Beijing-style sweet buns (4pcs) - Meh. We ordered steamed but got fried. Even still, just meh.  

This is a good place for 4 or more people to come and dine with portion sizing. We ordered way too much food so that we could try a bunch of things. We'd definitely share a table again, just hopefully not the round table at the back (my hubs had to get up 3 times so the food delivery hand truck could make it to the kitchen). We found parking a long block away, we needed the walk after our meal anyhow.
author: Lani N.

description:
veggie dumpling are great 
walnut prawns are good
author: Stephany L.

description:
When the line is too long at Kingdom of Dumpling this place is a great alternative. Great food!

FYI: They charge $.25 for EACH take out container. I guess you're suppose to bring your own tupperware?!!!
author: Sarah H.

description: The crab soup dumplings were sooooo good. Best soup dumpling spot I've come across in this city!
author: Catherine Y.

description: Definitely a hidden gem of sorts in the Sunset. I found most of the dumplings to ultimately taste the same, which for my friends who love a good soup dumpling was not a problem. For me, I wanted a bit more variety. So while this is not the dim sum place I would prefer, they make an XLB that rivals pretty much any other spot in the city.
author: Jeremy G.

description:
Came here with the family last week. 

The conversation was in Chinese for the most part: 

Waitress: "Are you ready to order?" (no smile and she wasn't making eye contact at this moment)

C: "Yea, Can we get a #1, a #5...."

Waitress: "Can you not tell me the number! Just tell me the name of it."

C: "Okay. Can we order a Xiao Long Bao. Umm...I don't know how to say the rest of it in Chinese."

Waitress: "Just say it in English"

C: "Thread roll - steamed please"

Waitress: "HUH? What is that?"

C: (Points it out on the menu) 

And we just ordered the rest of the items we wanted by pointing it out and trying to read it in chinese. This completely ruined the dinner vibe. 5 minutes later, the waitress went to the table next to ours and she had a smile on her face! And giving them 100X better service. I am so completely confused... I just don't understand this service.

- Xiao Long Bao (XLB) is divine! It's hot, juicy & flavorful! Best XLB on the city! Especially when it's dipped in the vinegar with ginger slivers.

- Thread roll (steamed): I don't recommend. It's just white bread/bun (man tao). But it comes with condensed milk for dipping.

- Shanghai Chow Mein is really good. More tasty if you pour some vinegar. 

I'll definitely come back, but I'll be crossing my fingers hoping that I won't get the same waitress.
author: Jane C.

description:
This is my go-to dumpling joint on a lazy Sunday afternoon.

They serve all afternoon and so you can dine around 3pm, avoiding the lunch rush that occurs at other dumpling restaurants in the area.

Order the Xiao Long Bao! The dumpling skin is a good texture and the filling juicy and tasty.
author: Steph A.

description: REALLY good Shanghai dumpling and green onion pancakes . Had to order another Shanghai dumpling with the gf . Service was okay. Food is good, a must try .
author: Jb R.

description: The place is somewhat small and fills up quick so there maybe a wait for a seat. The salt and pepper chicken is really good and shanghai dumplings as well. The little buns with sweet condensed milk are good also. The green onion pancake was ok, a bit harder than I'm used to. They also have various soy milks; sweet or savory with Chinese fried doughnut. There are a few dumpling houses on Taraval but I like this one the most.
author: Ali F.

description: I arrived at 7:50pm on Monday night and I was immediately seated. Several tables were still empty. After looking at the yelp pics, I just wanted to try the XLB and the Shanghai noodles. I was served my noodles within 2 minutes after my order. The XLB came out within ten minutes. The house tea is typical. The noodles are medium thick; combined with 1 inch pieces of thin chicken, onions, and cabbage. They are pretty bland. I found that the vinegar was the best additive to give them some taste. As for the XLB, they are thick skinned and mostly a slightly less than average amount of juice. The meat is good inside. You have to eat quickly because these guys cool fast. I would rate them average. So I'm impressed with the speed at which the food comes out. I prefer thinner skins and more juice in my XLB. I hope this review helps! Bon Appetit!
author: Jeff K.

description: I'm a big fan of Dumplings in general so I may be biased. I used to come here a lot but it has gotten crowded recently, but it still makes for a good take out place. Pan Fried Pork buns are my favorite here, but also check out the chili wontons and garlic string beans. Great price/value too especially here in the city.
author: Jeff W.

description:
Really enjoyed our Dumpling Kitchen experience. Will definitely go back, but order a bit differently.

What to order:
Xiao Long Bao: best xiao long bao I've had in Boston or in SF. Thin skins, delicious fillings.
Fried Mantou: our son wanted this dish all to himself, especially because of the sweet dipping sauce. Was lucky to sneak a few bites.
Doujiang: sweet soy milk (available hot or cold) - yummy.

Probably wouldn't order the beef noodle soup again (noodles were thin, soup was OK) or the fried pork buns (though these are good, they are too similar to XLB, would order XLB over this).
author: Wendy L.

description:
Definitely a fan of this place! There's a huge selection of food as most chinese restaurants, but everything was so good! There was only 4 of us, but we ordered a feast for 10! We got the: Shanghai dumplings, pork and chive dumplings, fried shanghai dumplings, shanghai rice cakes, and pancake. Everything was really tasty and very affordable. The Shanghai dumplings were perfect! Nice, plump, juice and full of flavor.  It's been a while since I've been there, but I would definitely come back and probably order everything again!

The restaurant is small, so careful in bringing large groups!
author: Diane L.

description:
Steamed, pan friend, chinese pancakes.. All soo good! 

You can choose here or the dumpling place up the street. This building is bigger and provides fans, which is more ideal on those hot days. Or sometimes the other place is too packed, so you can walk down two blocks. 


They provide peanuts as snacks. Their noodles are good as well.
author: Jade F.

description:
This place is delicious! Found my new go-to Shanghainese restaurant.

#1. XLB - was amazing, tastes better than Shanghai Dumpling King. Better eat them hot! Or else the jelly will solidify.
#6. Beijing style boiled pork and chive dumplings - nice and hot, skin was a little thick for my taste (but that's how its supposed to be)
#11. Wonton in house soup - didn't care much for the spinach but dipping those wontons with chili oil in the soup was the best.

10/10 would eat again
author: Gary W.

description:
This place is a stable for us. It is extremely hard to find great soup dumpling places and this is one of those hidden gems. $7 bucks for basket of 10! And they are freaking tasty. You just can't beat that.

They also have wide menu of other dishes that are pretty good. Stir fried shanghai noodles and the mustard green & pork soup noodles are both quite good.

It was closed when we came last Wednesday and we were devastated. We decided to try the other place up on the block "king of dumplings" or whatever. One word - interior!! Their soup dumpling is simply terrible. It is so bad they should just take that off the menu. Their regular dumplings were better but still only alright.

If you have never been here you are missing out.
author: Cheung L.

description: The dumplings are impeccable. I had the xiaolongbao (Shanghai-style steamed pork dumplings) and the pan-fried pork dumplings. Both simply amazing. Has crispy egg puffs for desert, which are like the best homemade donut you've ever had, filled with custard. The only missing star is for the service. I was seated quickly and served courteously, but when I finished eating I wanted to order something else, and I was being ignored. It was during the 2-3 lull, and all the staff were having their own lunch. One of the staff, I think she just brings checks and busses tables, brought me my check, and I told her I actually wanted to order something else, so she disappeared, and I thought she'd send someone over, but nobody came. It took a good 25 minutes for my waiter to finally walk close enough for me to grab his attention, and when I did he didn't stop walking. He just said "check?", and kept going, so I had to sort-of bellow "NO, WAIT" at him. "I'd like to order something else." After he took my order, the food came pretty promptly. Aside from this snafu, which seems an uncommon occurrence here, this was a great experience.
author: Jeremy C.

description:
Came with my bF around 4pm...we were waiting for our pup because we dropped her off at the groomers. We were seated immediately since the restaurant was empty. 

- XLB: they were just ok. the soup wasnt very flavorful ...decent size
- Shanghai style rice cakes: mMm these were good but not as good as my mother's ...too much cabbage too little rice cakes
- Sweet soy milk: tasted a bit watered down
- Chinese fried dough: very crispy and not too oily. tasted great dipped in the soy milk
- Dry Fried Chicken: they were chunks of chicken...the outside was a bit soggy. It wasn't fried at all...when I see/hear "dry fried chicken", I think of San Tung's. These were nothing compared to San Tung. 
- Wontons in chili oil: I didn't like this at all. The chili oil was not spicy. The sauce was a little too thick for my liking. The wonton was mushy like it was old. 

Needless to say, I will not be returning. The service was good...mainly because we were the only ones in there.
author: Serena F.

description:
Dumpling Kitchen has got to be my favorite XLB and dumpling place in the city! I've been here a few times and have not been disappointed by anything I've ordered so far! I could list out everything I've had so far, but you probably don't care, so here's the cliff notes version:

XLBs - LOVE! The skin isn't too thick so be careful how you pick it up. Don't want to be one of those who fail miserably and end up eating it all in pieces - missing out on the fatty soup, no less! Takes skill!!

Shanghai noodles/rice cakes - both tasty and not overly greasy. One of my favorite dishes, so very happy they cook up a good one! Can't go wrong with the braised string beans either. ::DROOL:: Green onion pancakes are more on the fluffly side, so a little different from what I'm used to. Still pretty good though.
