The beef trip cold dish is DELICIOUS! I got an order to go that day, haha. I know - this isn't for everyone, but come on - life is short, so just give it a try! Steamed and pan fried dumplings are both good. Take your pick since they have a pretty good variety.

Egg puffs - YUM YUM YUM and perfect way to end your meal (I like it with the soy milk). Who doesn't like some deep fried goodness covered in sugar?

The place can get pretty busy so I try to go when they first open or a little after the lunch rush hour. Haven't been here for dinner yet, but I'm sure it'd be the same. Parking can be a little painful, but park a little further and I'm sure you'll appreciate the walk back once you finish your meal. They take credit cards, so that's a major plus in my book!
author: Ellen N.

description:
I can't seem to resist going to any eatery with dumpling in the name.  Dumpling Kitchen offers 12 dumpling dishes (potstickers, XLB, wontons, dumplings), cold plates, and Shanghai and Mandarin dishes (Lion's Head meatballs, noodle soups, Shanghai style rice cakes).  They don't have enough dumplings for a place with dumpling in the name.

It's a large space with the look of a typical no frills Chinese restaurant with banquet tables and a shrine.  The lunch special items are generic ($5, $6, 11 AM - 3 PM).  Prices are reasonable.

* XLB (10 pieces, $6): these were decent but on the small, flat side and not juicy enough, the ground pork filling was slightly sweet, with a hint of ginger

* Shanghai style wontons in house broth ($5.50): the pork and veggie wontons had a nice flavor but there was way too much wrapper and not enough filling, the veggie broth is light 

Kingdom of Dumpling has better dumplings and way more dumpling variety as well.
author: Lolia S.

description:
This is my new go-to Chinese food spot in the area.  Yes, it's called Dumpling Kitchen, but a lot of other food here is great, too!  We've never eaten here; we always get it to go.  Often when I walk down to pick up the food there is a line of people waiting to be seated.  Everyone I've interacted with is friendly and helpful.  Food is always ready by the time they say it will be if not earlier.  

We usually get the shanghai dumplings, pot stickers, rice cakes, chicken chow mein, and pork and chive dumplings.  That's way more than enough for 4 people.  It's great piping hot and fresh, but as with most dumplings, it doesn't reheat very well for left overs.
author: ROB L.

description:
A little birdy told me that the owner/chef at Dumpling Kitchen used to be the chef at Koi Palace, so I was definitely excited to give this place a try. 

We had a party of 5 and came on Saturday around 8PM. The place was pretty packed and the food on everyone's table looked delicious. The menu is very extensive so it was pretty hard to choose what to order because we wanted to try everything. As far as I can remember, we ordered the following:

-2 orders of XLBs -- soupy and very delicious!
-Pan-fried Potstickers -- good!
-Steamed pork and cabbage dumplings -- I was a bit bummed when the dumplings came out looking identical as the potstickers, but nonetheless it was good
-Wontons in chili oil -- not really spicy
-Spicy cow stomach -- tasteless and not spicy at all (not recommended)
-Sizzling Rice Soup w/ chicken -- bland and not recommended
-Beijing-style noodle in black bean sauce -- the noodles didnt really go well with this dish and there wasnt enough sauce.
-Dry-braised string beans -- lacking something I couldnt quite make out.. but still good.
-Spinach w/ garlic - yummy
-Walnut Prawns - VERY GOOD!

I wanted to try their Shanghai noodles but they messed up on our order and it never came. The service here was efficient but you can tell that they were a bit scattered and chaotic because of how busy they were. Plates were coming to our table when we didnt order them though we would have gladly taken them if it hadnt gone to their correct tables :) 

We received 10% off on our bill so the total was about $75.00. A bit improving is needed but I'm optimistic that this establishment will remain in good business for years to come.
author: M W.

description: Delicious!! The dumplings were fresh made, delicate tasting and the servings size was good. Clean, efficient and service wasn't too abrupt.
author: Gale D.

description: Excellent dumplings at a fair price.  The service was fast and courteous.  The place can get crowded, but it is worth the wait.  Way cheaper than some "fancy" dumpling joints  I would highly recommend this place to folks.
author: Cat H.

description:
Love the XLB, I could happily gobble up one serving of 10 pieces all by myself. Food is very reasonable, in laws loved the family style menu options. What a great deal! The option for 2-3 people served us 4 easily with leftovers. 

A must go to place whenever we're in town. Parking can be a pain but it's conveniently located on the MUNI route.
author: Jen D.

description:
Restaurant not to be confused with Kingdom of Dumplings 2 1/2 blocks east which always has a line.  Want good dumplings and don't want to wait for a table?  Come here.  The food was pleasantly good.  Ordered various types of dumplings including the XLB.  Ample amount of soup broth in each XLB.  

Dumplings all very fresh tasting, and good proportion of meat and thin skin wrappers.

Noteworthy - the stir fried Shanghai rice cakes.  Called rice cakes, but to me, they're more like thick flat noodles.  The noodles are shaped like little surfboards.  Very very good. Not too starchy. Can't recall the last time I've eaten this type of noodles.

Service very efficient and the food comes out quickly.

Minor con - the Chinese donut was very egg custardy, but too oily.
author: Shirley N.

description:
Recommend:
Shanghai Dumplings
Pan-fried Pork Dumpling Buns (my favorite of the dumplings)
Potstickers
Wonton in Chili Oil
Shanghai Chow Mein (I always order this)
Noodles in Peanut Sauce (OK)

All these dishes are around $7-9 each.

They get really busy on weekends and meal times, so expect a wait if you're going at those times.
author: Derek M.

description: Decided to give this place a try after having a great experience at Kingdom of Dumplings. The atmosphere here is definitely better compared to KOD but the food is not as tasty. With that said, we ordered the Shanghai dumplings, the wontons in chili oil, the green onion pancakes and the steamed pork bun. Although they were not as good as KOD, they did offer a more generous portion of food for just about the same price, and for that reason, I have to give this place a 4 star.
author: Marco M.

description: Amazing soup dumplings. Green beans, dry wings, steam buns... All of it top notch - a full step above any other xiao ling bao shops you'll find.
author: Hunter H.

description:
I'm always down to try dumpling places because I'm on a mission to find the best dumplings in the city!  Sadly I have to say that dumplings here are not the mouth-watering-juicy-soft-dumplings that I wished for.  Nonetheless I've still been here a couple of times.   Dumplings are okay.  Most of the dishes are okay.  

Tables and dishes are a bit dirty.  I've found scraps of food on my cups and plates more than once.  

If you want decent dumplings then this place might be good for you.  If you want "great" dumplings than I advise you to keep looking and let me know when you find a place.
author: Shirley T.

description: Mediocre food. The first two choices in the menu are ok, but that's all...
author: Creasy Q.

description: The Shanghai Dumplings were sooo good, Nice and juicy! The fried version was only so so.  The green onion pancake was perfect and not only at all.  I am looking forward to my next meal there!
author: Anna K.

description: Dumplings #1 and 2 are ok. Green onion pancake is not authentic at all.  The 5 spice beef noodle soup is so so.  Not memorable at all in my opinion.
author: Chris C.

description: Finally found a place not too far from my house and the wait isn't bad for some XLB. It's juicy and the skin doesn't break, but it's not too tough. It's not the best I ever had, but it is satisfying enough. I love their pork and crab XLB, but there needs to be a bit more crab. The green onion pancakes are fluffy and good flavor. The rice cakes are not oily and they don't stick together. I need to come with more people so I can try other things. The service is fast and friendly. Prices are reasonable and portions are decent.
author: Karen H.

description: I'm a big fan of XLB here. The skin is thin and the soup is tasty. Also I want to note that the other dishes here really good! Try the Shanghai sticky rice cake, pea sprouts, and the normal dumplings.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
I'm surprised that I haven't written a review for this place, but then again I'm not surprised since I'm getting older, but that's besides the point. Dumpling Kitchen is another one of our Asian go-to's especially when we're craving soup dumplings or sizzling rice soup! When we both caught the flu, sizzling rice soup was a game changer :) Clean and comforting, yet super hearty with the bits of shrimp, oyster mushrooms, peas, etc. It definitely hits the spot.

Other worthy mentionables:
- black bean noodles
- pan fried pork dumplings

TIP: they do take out orders for those times you don't want so share cooties with the rest of the world when you're not feeling well. Or when your boyfriend has to make it home in time to watch baseball playoffs
author: Kristen C.

description:
On 10/8/10, I passed by on the L Taraval and was surprised to see the previous Han Geong sign replaced with Dumpling Kitchen.  I'm not sure if this is a change of ownership, but the menu is completely different, and there is a Grand Opening 10% coupon available on their website that expires 10/27/10: http://www.letseat.at/dumplingkitchensf/coupons

[Update] I emailed Dumpling Kitchen on 10/9/10 and received this response on 10/10/10:  The old owner decided to sell the restaurant and go on vacation. We specialize in Shanghai dumplings, potstickers, and all types of noodles, dinner dishes, and set meals.

I'm curious as to why the owner renamed this place Dumpling Kitchen when there is Kingdom of DUMPLING (fka David's KITCHEN) up a block or two.  Now I have to try this place so consider this my placeholder review.
author: Pam L.

description:
Kingdom of Dumpling had a line and we were hungry! We found this place on Yelp and gave it a try. We were seated within 15-20minutes of waiting. They give you salted peanuts as a little appetizer. We ordered the xiao long bao, zha jiang mien, stir-fry green beans and the hot oil wontons. I must have seen every table order 1-2 orders of the xiao long bao! It was good and I think it tastes better than Shanghai Dumpling King's. The soup to meat ratio was perfect. The soup wasn't overly starchy and the outer layer was just right. When the zha jiang mien came to our table, I didn't expect the portions to be so big! We had to bring it home as leftovers. The noodles were the right texture and the sauce was good. I would've preferred if there was a bit more sauce though... The green beans were your average green beans...you can't really mess that one up. The hot oil wontons were nothing special...

I might come back next time and try their wings and the fried puffs!
author: Jay Z.

description: This place is a great example of the "food chain" at work. Hipsters move into the hood. Disposable income, hate to, or don't know how to cook, (especially Shanghainese food,) Join other ABC's that being tired of grandmas choy, and out on a date, or with friends, will get their next meal from Yelp, plus canto families from the nearby hood that are looking for something mythical (Shanghainese noodles/dumplings famous among Chinese folks,) and different from Cantonese food (of which the sunset has lots) and can also walk there from their homes, and you have an instant line. People see the line,they get influenced, (line=must be good!) and they Yelp it's goodness. Then people read it on Yelp and create more of a line. Equals more stars. Self fulfilling prophecy. Never mind that it's just okay. (Too expensive for what you get. The dumplings are good but Shandong Deluxes down the street are better and cheaper.) And what's up with the soggy deep fried fish? Everybody, (even Panda Express) knows how to deep fry something and still keep it crispy even with sauce on top. (It's called baking soda, yo!) The Shanghainese rice cakes and noodles were bland, and the onion pancake tasted like cardboard. But I felt "privileged to be there" and to drop $60, once I saw all the hipsters, 20 something daters, and all the Cantonese families who go crazy over anything Shanghainese regardless. Got seated! Scored! Yessss!!
author: George F.

description:
I'm recently become a fan of shanghainese dumplings and when I heard about this place, I just HAD to try it!

This place has been compared to Kingdom of Dumpling just a few blocks up and I have to admit, they may be similar, but both places definitely have their wins. Dumpling Kitchen wins for the size because there are plenty of tables here and also tables for groups of 4 or more (1star).

 I looked over the menu and though Kingdom of Dumpling has more variety of dumplings, Dumpling Kitchen serves something that Kingdom does not, pan fried pork buns (~$5 for 8 pieces)! I first tried it in San Jose and have been dying to find something like it in SF and luckily Kitchen has it! It is a cross between pork bun and XLB. The one I had in SJ was soupy and I was disappointed that it was less soupy here, but nonetheless still good! It's topped with sesame seeds and green onions and you lose yourself for a second just smelling it as it is served on your table. 

We also ordered the crab and pork dumpling ($9 for 8 pieces) which we could have done without. I didn't taste much crab but I will disagree with other yelpers who said the skin was mushy and broke easily. 

The green onion pancake was delicious! It was different from Kingdom of Dumpling and the portion is HUGE for $3.60. It was served on a dinner entree plate. The pancake was fried to golden brown perfection . Another plus, you can actually taste the green onion. 

Lastly, we tried the beef stew egg noodle soup. This was by far one of the best I've ever had. I'm all about the soup and their soup was ON POINT. So much beefy flavor goodness I couldn't get enough of it. The noodles were also good and fresh. ($7?)

Will definitely be back to get my dumpling fix!
author: Connie C.

description:
Came here on a nice midafternoon, no line at all and got seated immediately. 

I must say, their xiao long bao's ARE FREAKING AMAZING!! Also their pan fried pork buns ARE FREAKING AMAZING AS WELL. I think I almost like their pan fried pork buns the best...

The food here is top notch quality, served fresh and steaming hot. Service is the typical apathetic chinese type, but hey, it ain't bad.  Honestly I recommend this place if you're around Sunset/Parkside.
author: Austin R.

description: The xiao long baos are yummy here, but the service isn't good. The place is super small and cramped. I came here with a group of 4 total, 2 ordered their soy drinks cold. We ended up being served the hot version. So we ordered, and I ordered the green onion pancake, some dumplings, and some kind of chow mein dish. We got the dumplings and chow mein, but the green onion pancake never came out. When we asked the waiters for it, they didn't even know we ordered it or they forgot. So we had to wait even longer for the pancake. When the pancake came out, it was a little burnt and very dry. They overdone the pancake, not worth waiting for :( . I give this 3 stars only for the good soup dumplings.
author: Katie F.

description:
A party of 4 ordered 2 pork xiaolongbao (20 in total), 1 you tiao with 2 soy milk, and 1 wontons in chili oil. 

- You tiao (fried dough) was a big no-no. I was imagining something more crispy outside and flaky and fluffy inside. Their rendition was hard inside out and dipping the fried dough into soy milk didn't really help. 
- Soy milk was great, on the other hand! Soy milk you order at Chinese restaurants isn't anything like "Silk"; it's not sweet at all and sometimes, if you are unlucky, you might get weirdly seasoned soy milk -- either too salty or too tofu-y. Dumpling Kitchen's had the perfect seasoning! Note: It comes out hot. 
- The main event xiaolongbao wasn't the best I've ever had, but was definitely better than what you'd get at a typical dim sum place. I thought dumplings could have had more soup, but otherwise, they were great. The dumpling skin was soft and chewy and the seasoning was good. A complaint: They didn't give us ginger to go with the vinegar dipping sauce! (The crunchiness of ginger adds so much to the dish!)
- Wontons in chili oil were good. The sauce had peanut butter taste to it, which enriched the flavor of the dish.

I wasn't amazed by this place, but this is definitely an acceptable place for xiaolongbao cravings.
author: Wonhee P.

description: The soup filled dumplings were pretty good but nothing to write home about, even with a lowered Chinese food standards in SF. Fried rice were good. Definitely more Hong Kong style than shanghainese.
author: Nora X.

description:
If you compare this place to the other competing soup dumpling establishments in the city, Dumpling Kitchen is by far the best place to get your XLB fix. 

The venue itself is bigger than Kingdom of Dumpling and Shanghai Dumpling King which means that you won't have to worry about showing up early or wait in the cold outside for 30-40 minutes to secure a seat for your party. I've been here almost a dozen times with an average wait time of 3 minutes. It's also right off the L line, so getting to this location isn't such an excursion. 

The dumplings themselves are superb. I've had dumplings from all over the world. We'll, just China, Taiwan, and Hong Kong, but the dumplings here are pretty comparable to the dumplings I've had overseas, including the flagship location of Ding Tai Feng (which is extremely overrated). The skin on each individual dumpling is thin, but extremely chewy. The stuffing they use tastes fresh and savory. The soup is PIPING hot right off the basket. Freshness is the key word here and this place gets it right every single time. 

The other items on the menu are pretty standard. I usually get the fried string beans (), braised pork with sour vegetables, the stir fried rice cakes, and fried sugar pea vegetables. Those dishes are good and intended to accentuate the flavor of the soup dumplings themselves. Personally, as long as these side dishes don't differ too much than what you're accustomed to, then it's okay and doesn't affect my 5 star rating even if they're not crazy amazing. 

Perhaps the biggest reason why I gave this place a 5 star rating instead of a 4 (which is already really good), is because the waiters don't pressure me into buying their overhyped, overrated egg puffs. I laud them for that. It's annoying when Chinese restaurants try to push Americanized dishes towards their non-Asian or Americanized looking Chinese patrons.
author: Vince C.

description: Dumpling Kitchen is the best place for Xiao Long Bao in SF, that I have found! There are some other places nearby but they are not nearly as good as Dumpling Kitchen. My partner and I travel over an hour to get there just to have a few trays of xiao long bao. The broth is flavorful and the dumpling skin is not too thick, just right. Other favorite dishes include the pork and chive dumpling, pea sprouts with garlic, and green onion pancake. Food is not greasy, it is fresh and just the right amount of oil, steam, etc. Service is quick. Servers are not overly friendly, but also not rude. I will keep coming back again and again for the xiao long bao, and look forward to trying other new dishes as well.
author: Lizzy A.

description:
The more places I try the pickier I get with my dumplings. I appreciated that the dumplings here are good sized and taste really fresh... but it's just... not as good as other places I have tried especially around this area. 

Shanghai-style steamed pork dumplings (10pcs) - good, but just doesn't pack the flavor as other XLB does (:ahem: Kingdom of Dumpling)
Steamed pork and napa cabbage dumplings (10pcs) - a bit mediocre, almost a little too doughy. I did like enjoy the insides. 
Shanghai-style green onion pancake - "A-OK" however, pretty heavy. I like my onion pancake light, layered and fabulous, this wasn't. 

This was my first time trying Hot Soy Milk... :) good stuff and a good way of topping it all off! I wouldn't mind coming back again, but maybe trying something other than the dumplings? (As weird as that sounds)
author: Tracy Joy K.

description:
I came here a few weeks ago for a family dinner. There was about 10 of us. We ordered a lot of stuff but I don't remember what everything was. I only remember a few of the dishes which were green onion pancake, xiao long bao, don don mien, lion head meat balls, deep fried sweet buns, this red bean paste thingy (don't remember what they're called) and the crispy egg puffs. 

The green onion pancake were different from the kind i normally eat but it was still pretty good. The xiao long bao and don don mien were really good but the noodle wasn't that spicy. The lion head meat balls were huge. I didn't really like em that much because theres ginger in it and I don't really like the taste of ginger. The deep fried sweet buns were pretty good tastes like all the other places' I've been to. The red bean paste thing and the crispy egg puffs were delicious. I'm tempted to make a trip out there just for those alone. I need to find a place in my area that has the crispy egg puffs. 

I would definitely come back but with less people so I'd get a smaller table because this place is pretty small and the tables are really close to one another. While I was eating the table next to mine had like 5 kids. About 2 or 3 of those kids decided to use this restaurant as a playground. They kept running around their table and kept bumping into my chair.
author: Stephanie L.

description: Truly excellent dumplings; nice thin (but firm) skins with flavorful insides.  Modest ambiance and efficient service make this a fine place to gorge with fellow dumpling lovers.
author: Peter H.

description: Terrible service. Better food can be found nearby. Sunday late afternoon, restaurant just cleared out from several large parties, so it wasn't busy.  Placed order for a dumplings, chicken wings, beef with green beans. 20 minutes after ordering, we ask how our order is doing since we noticed other parties seated later getting their food after about 5 minutes. Server tells us he FORGOT to put the order in, tells us he'll get it in right away. Two dishes come out, after finishing them, ask about the chicken wings 15 minutes later. He comes back to tell us, sorry I didn't put them in the order. Again. After doing this with our initial order. That was it. This place doesn't care, the servers, the back of the house, no one cares. They get enough neighborhood regulars it seems like they do fine, but they clearly just want to crank out mediocre food as fast as they can and dick around in the back.
author: PJ B.

description: I have been coming to dumpling kitchen with my friends for a few years now. I recommend the xiao long bao and shanghai stir fry thick noodles. The dumplings are juicy and the noodles are cooked just right. We always get these two items along with items. They have a pretty good variety of little dishes you can choose from.
author: Lory M.

description:
Quite happy with the food here, I've heard a few good things about this place and thought to check it out.

Xiao Long Bao (10 pieces) for $7 was really good. The top knot was a bit too thick, but this isn't hong kong. The soup inside was really tasty, better than Shanghai dumpling king. The wonton noodle soup was really tasty as well.

The service was pretty good for an asian place, I wasn't rushed and I was checked up on several times during my meal. 

Pros:
- Great food
- Normal prices
- Decent service


Cons:
- none
author: Kevin L.

description: We live in the San Francisco East Bay and  heard about this restaurant from some friends. We ordered the Shanghai  dumplings, pig stomach and chicken dish, beef chow mein, preserved vegetables-soup noodles and green onion cakes.  Dumplings, chow mein and soup noodles are first rate; great ingredients, fresh, and very tasty!!!  The stomach-chicken dish was very good.  The noodles were "al dente" and tasted very good.  The green onions were only "OK;" I probably won't order these again.   The service was actually "good." I definitely would recommend this place to our friends.
author: Franklin W.

description: I enjoyed their pan fried pot stickers and stir fried rice cakes but their green onion pancakes (bland) and shanghai pork dumpling (bland) was not what I expected.  I'll probably try a different filling for the dumpling instead.  It was a busy night but the staff was still helpful.  They have a lot of choices on their menu so I'll be back to try them.
author: Jennifer P.

description: oh hell ya. Dumplings and everything is good here. Service is fast. Food comes out fast. Food, in my case, disappears fast.  I agree with the other yelpers. XLB. Green Onion Pancake. Cabbage and Pork dumpling. The chinese spinach. All very tasty.  Price is reasonable and they open pretty late for a dumpling place.  If you get there at 9pm, they will still sit you.
author: Kelly C.

description: If you want decor, don't go here. If you want delicious food, don't go anywhere else. Salt and pepper fish fillet, salt and pepper chicken wings, and potstickers were all to die for. Will definitely be going again. Only regret is that I didn't have enough room to finish all my food.
author: Megan R.

description:
BEST shanghai dumplings in San Francisco! 

TRUST ME! It's affordable and family friendly. Love mom & pop shops!
author: Sandy L.

description:
We got there before there was a line. It took about 5 minutes to seat us. Pretty good for larger groups. 

We started with light and not greasy onion pancake. Then added their famous XLB. I don't think those were amazing, but they are pretty good for the Bay area. We then moved onto simple and filling noodle, napa and chicken soup. We saw a lot of others order this so we were eager to try.  

Would go back here again.
author: Winny F.

description:
Awesome dumplings! They were pretty amazing, the portions are pretty good too so you might want to take that into consideration when you order. Those little dumplings will fill up your stomach pretty quickly...
We had a few different types of dumplings here and they were all good. The fried ones are better than the steamed ones, at least for me. This place was pretty crowded when we came here for lunch. We had to wait for about 15 minutes, but it was worth it.
author: Long H.

description:
Me : babe I lost big
Her : how much?
Me : more than two paychecks.
Her : damn ravens huh? Come on let's go eat.

So we end up here somewhere close to her work. After a very disappointing weekend, one of my best friends took me to get some grub and comfort. She orders the xlb, spinach, and black bean noodle. Spinach was cooked fast so that it still had a nice crunch. Black bean noodles not bad, al dente but the minced meat and sauce ended up at the bottom. She comforts me then proceeded to put a xlb in my mouth. Yummy. Hot, steamy and chewy . Can't put a finger on what was in the meat but had a nice flavor. After that I felt like a champ. This is what happens when you have good friends and food. Ho bao ah!
author: Q L.

description:
After reading the review my buddy Jason G. and recommended by a coworker who is considered a foodie, I had to try this place. As you may know, there are quite a number of a dumpling houses in the Sunset District so I am pretty critical when it comes to my dumps. 

My girl and I ordered the following: 

#1 Shanghai style pork dumplings  
 - They were exceptionally good. We both received our own ginger  vinegar plates. The wrap was thin and soup was piping hot inside! 
 4 stars

#6. Beijing Style boiled pork and chive dumplings
 - Like the Xiao Long Bao, they were exceptionally good. Nice and hot  with good flavor.
 4 stars

#12 Wonton in Chile oil
 - Not really a fan. I could taste the flour from the wrap. It wasn't spicy at  all but a little sweet. I even tasted some peanut sauce in it.
 2 stars

#15 Beijing style sweet buns
 -  Fried Man Tao with condensed milk. What else can I say? Fried foods  are always good.
 3 stars 

#26 Sizzling Rice Soup
 - This was the worst sizzling rice soup I tasted.  It was EXTREMELY bland.  The shrimp, beef, and chicken was chopped up into tiny pieces. It  reminded me of baby food or when a parent chops to feed their kid.  The sizzling rice turned into mush right away. It was raining and cold   last nite so I was kinda upset the soup wasn't better on a cold day. 
1.5 stars 

#68 Dry fried chicken wings
 - They tried very hard to imitate the best dry fried chicken wings on  planet earth and failed. They are getting there. Sauce is decent but  wings were not really dry fried. Overall , eeehhhhh.......
2 stars

Not on the menu but posted on the wall we ordered sweet and salty soy milk with Chinese donuts. The sweet is something you can buy in a gallon bottle from Golden Gate soy Milk Company. The salty soy milk was quite delicious. They added some sliced Chinese donuts and chili oil. Not bad at all... I do recommend the salty soy milk

With the amount of food I ordered, the bill was $44.60 which is not bad at all considering I had lunch and dinner for the next day. The staff was very catering and attentive, aside from the fact one of the waitress forgot who a teapot belongs to and asked every table. Overall the dumplings were decent but the other dishes can use some TLC (or at least the stuff I ordered). 

I will definitely come back to try some other dishes such as the braised lions head meatballs and Braised Pork Trotter. I'll give this dining experience 3 star this time, but things may change. I will continue my quest for FABULOUS DUMPLINGS IN THE BAY!!!!!!!
author: Scott L.

description:
We arrived at 11:30 on a Sunday, hungry for dim sum, and we were seated immediately. The dumplings do not disappoint! Their Shanghai-style steamed pork buns satisfy our craving for Joe's Shanghai in New York City! Their fried pork buns are also super delicious.

The hot and sour soup had a weird texture (very thick, almost gelatinous), but the flavor was good. And you get a HUGE bowl that is more than enough for two to share.

We'll definitely be back for more!
author: Jane T.

description:
I don't understand how this place can have four stars. 

We ordered: 
- pork/crab soup dumplings
- wonton soup
- green onion pancake
- stir-fried noodles

The pork/crab dumplings were good, but the rest, not so much. The wonton soup was bland, the noodles nothing special, and the pancake just terrible. Service was above average. 

Not worth the wait.
author: germ i.

description:
Stumbled upon this place while in the area for work. 
We ordered take out... DELICIOUS. 

We had the XLB, the Pork Dumplings, the Pot Stickers, the Green Onion Pancake, the Salt and Pepper Tofu, and the Salt and Pepper Fish Filet. 

Everything was Excellent! The dumplings were ALL soupy, not just the XLBs. The green onion pancake was good even as left overs. The fish and the tofu were extremely tasty, with just enough garlic and spice to make them as addicting as they come. 

I highly recommend this place!
author: Ping N.

description: I've had a chance to try a lot of different noodle houses and xiao long bao shops now. This place is by far the best! Its consistently delicious.
author: Kevin C.

description: My go to place when I am wanting some xiao long baos. I remember my family found this place maybe two years back and it is to this day our favorite place for some fixing for xlb. This place is CHEAP and it is GOOD. I have to say that people line up outside for some morning yum cha here and this place has what you want including soy milk, the fried doughnuts, shanghai rice cooks or thick long noodles and dumplings of all sorts. Go for all the dumplings they have because they are worth it and are fresh and juicy!
author: Angela S.

description: Sunday morning XLB goodness. One order of XLB, sweet vinegar spareribs, shanghai noodles, and green onion pancakes for two. We ordered way too much food, but the food was delicious! I don't normally eat pork, but I will eat plates of the sweet vinegar spareribs. Their hot soy milk complimented our meal. Get the sweet vinegar spareribs, you won't regret it.
author: Sandy W.

description:
The food was very good and the portions very big. 
I probably ordered more than I should have but that's okay because now I have delicious leftovers waiting for me.
author: Sawyer F.

description: I've only tried a handful of places in the city, but so far, this is our go to for XLB. Not up to par with Din Tai Fung, but also without the wait and prices of DTF. The sheng jiang bao are so-so, as are the red bean desserts, but overall it's a solid meal.
author: roger t.

description:
I recently came here with my friend and didn't know what to expect besides dumplings! We ordered the Shanghai dumplings, pan fried pork bao, and noodle soup with park and mustard greens. 

The Shanghai dumplings were sooo good! I love how the soup is so flavorful once you take a bite and of course drink it from the spoon, Chinese style! As for the pan fried pork bao, it was also good because they didn't cover it with too much bao layers. So I did not feel as bloated, also that crisp on the bottom along with the soup inside just makes it solid. As for the noodle soup, it was not bad. However it was hard to finish the noodle soup since they give so much noodles! You would either need a big party, huge appetite, or just stuff yourself to death. lol

As for service, the waitresses were very attentive so they will know when you finished a dish or tea. Hopefully you will receive the same service as I experienced since I know Chinese service is a hit or miss.

I definitely recommend this place for dumpling lovers and anyone who is hasn't ever tried Shanghai dumplings. I can see why it's so crowded!
author: Victor Q.

description:
+Restaurant's clean compared to your average chinese restaurant.
+ Good XLB..... but NOT the best in the city (I'd prefer Kingdom of Dumpling a few  blocks up) BUT there wasn't a wait at this restaurant and the staff was nice.
+ Cheap compared to kingdom of dumpling
+ Good for groups! they have a bunch of normal chinese-banquet-style roundtables 
+ Good green onion pancake (not the best)

- Do not get the beijing dumpling! Flavorless and bland. Tasted boiled and overcooked. 
- not much "dumpling" action; just the XLB with pork or the special crab with chili oil so don't expect as much as selection as other places
 

This restaurant had an extensive menu so if you're JUST craving XLB + chinese food, then this would be a good choice.
author: Patricia K.

description: Solid, no nonsense dim sum restaurant with popular favorites that are well executed and priced right.  We had the xlb, eggplant in garlic sauce and shanghai-style chow mein with chicken.  Everything was very good.  We'll be back.
author: E G.

description:
Ate here Nov. 16, 2012.

This place was pretty darn good!!

SHANGHAI DUMPLINGS = so juicy and flavorful!!  4.5 stars

WONTONS IN CHILI OIL = eh, nothing to write home about! 3 stars!

SIZZLING RICE SOUP = not bad but nothing special! 3.5 stars!

SHANGHAI RICE CAKE = get this w/ the mustard green instead of cabbage! OOOooo my! so tasty!!! 4.5 stars!!!

This place is solid! You shouldn't be disappointed. Good food w/o breaking the bank!
author: Victor C.

description:
I'll be honest, I was a little hesitant about whether or not to write a review for this place, since I didn't want to hike up the number of Yelp reviews for this awesome place and then have it become one of those "over hyped" restaurants like many others in SF. Selfishly I also wanted to keep this somewhat of a hidden gem to myself!

You know this place is legit when it's smack dab in the middle of the Sunset (aka lots of Asian people) and always has throngs of Chinese families waiting in line at any given time.

The xiaolongbao and dumplings are both really good, although the real showstopper for me was the scallion pancakes - these were very savory and flavorful, and had a light and airy consistency. The cucumber and 5-spice beef cold dishes are also a must.
author: Lena R.

description: The green onion pancakes were my favorite. Also loved the beijing style boiled dumplings. We live 50 minutes away but will definitely be back.
author: Amit B.

description: By far the best dumplings I've ever had. This place is amazing and FAST. My boyfriend and I will definitely be back.
author: Nicole V.

description:
Came here with some friends on a Thursday for some lunch, and noticed it was pretty packed. I would say I had a pretty enjoyable meal for my first time and service was okay. Sadily the tea was made from a teabag, which surprised me.

We ordered a bunch of different plates to try. My quick rundown the Shanghai dumplings were superb, pan fried pork buns were meh, panfried potstickers meh, the chili dumplings were pretty good, green onion pancakes interesting and quite enjoyable, fried chicken wings were my favorite and absolutely delicious and tasty. Most of the dumplings we had tasted like they had the same filling.
author: Tony C.

description: Frankly, I'm surprised this is not 5-star. Their dumpling is really well made. We ordered a bunch of food and ended up being $11 per person. Would love to come back.
author: Andrew W.

description: I love dumplings so much....I could eat 50 in one sitting.  I especially love shanghai dumplings and this is my go to local place when I'm having a craving. All my friends know, as I always make them eat here with me.  I always get the soup dumplings and pot stickers - solid favorites! The skin is chewy, and there's a good amount of soup in each dumpling. I really liked their dan dan noodles (noodles in peanut sauce) - chewy noodles to slurp with a thick, spicy peanut sauce with pork - yum! Pretty good braised green beans as well. Not a huge fan of their dried fried chicken wings or salt and pepper chicken.  Can't wait to go back and try other dishes esp their clay pots, they looked great!
author: Janelle H.

description: Wonderful wonton soup and shanghai style dumplings (number 1 and 11)! Very filling for two and the price is absolutely awesome! Great dinner atmosphere.
author: Julie O.

description:
I had to come and try this place after finding out there was a new restaurant that had shanghai dumplings.
Came here for lunch and it was pretty empty, but it's understandable since it's still pretty new.  We ordered the vegetarian goose and smoked fish, both were a bit on the bland side but still good.  The shanghai dumplings that I was really looking forward to was a let down.  The skin of the dumpling was really good, but the meat and the soup inside was the disappointing portion.  I didn't like the taste of it and it was too sweet.  The redeeming dish was the pork dumpling in chili oil.  It was awesome!  Not too spicy and the dumpling itself was delicious with its own juices inside.
I will definitely be coming back for the pork dumplings in chili oil again, and try other dishes as well.
author: Karen L.

description:
I looove Kingdom of Dumpling and when I heard a rival restaurant opened down the block, I had to give them a try.  8pm on a Sunday night and every seat in the house was almost full.  Luckily it was just my boyfriend and me so we got the last two seat table in the back.  

We got and order of the xiao long bao, (of course), green onion pancake, and general chicken, (my bf has to always get this at a new restaurant).  

I definitely liked the flavor of the pork in the xlb, in fact I thought it was delicious.  But, I had a problem with the skin.  About 4 out of 10 of the dumpling skins were already broken or broke as we struggled to pull them off the bed of lettuce they sat on.  We're not expert on xlb eating but we're not novices either and we've never had a problem picking them up.  

The green onion pancake was not what I expected; I'm not a fan.  I love green onion pancakes and how they're flaky and crunchy and chewy in all the right places.  Their version was more cake-like and hollow in the middle.  Again, not a fan.

The general chicken was good and the vinegar in the sauce definitely stung my eyes as I took a pic of it for Yelp.  It came with a ring of broccoli surrounding it which was a nice and simple touch to a regular meat dish.  

I'm sure we'll be back.  I would of course try to get a seat up the block at Kingdom of Dumpling first.  But you know there are those days you just don't feel like waiting for a table.  And this place is much better for a large group.  And before I forget, the staff was super nice and on top of things.
author: Rosalind S.

description:
Came here with a buddy after hearing good reviews.  We ordered the XLB and then some more typical "American-style" dishes... fried rice, chicken, beef, etc.

The XLB were great!  Lots of flavor and were definitely the highlight of the meal.  The other items were also very good and the portions were huge, but we'd probably order more dumplings instead next time.

Service was functional and nothing more.  All in all, the food was great and it was a good value.  I look forward to returning!
author: Ryan S.

description:
My mom raved about this restaurant, and to be honest, I don't remember how she found it, but I'm glad she did! 

We came here for lunch and we ordered the XLB's. Delicious! 

I also ordered a lunch special and paid extra to get chow mein with something else....it was really tasty as well. 

The restaurant was clean and everything was really good. 

I tried it after trying Kingdom of Dumpling and while, at the time, I thought KoD was delish...this definitely trumps it. 

Hipster hole-in-wall places that become famous and popular -- aren't hipster or hole-in-the-wall anymore...then they just become dumpy and "touristy." 

Dumpling Kitchen is bigger and has less of a wait.
author: Alison N.

description: I really like this place and been dying to try it. I finally did and oh my god best dumplings ever!! Xiao lin Bao are to die for!! They are a must get with their green onion pancake! The potstickers were succulent and delicious. The best thing is that the prices are amazing!! Yes extremely affordable for what you get. The portions are big and you get way more bang for your buck.
author: Nadia N.

description: Went to Dumpling Kitchen for dim sum and was very impressed by the quality of the food. The green onion pancakes were unlike I've ever had: light and fluffy  with that great braised green onion flavor. The pancakes went well with the twice cooked pork belly which is like bacon cooked with green onions.  The soup dumplings were excellent as were the potstickers.  Basically all of the food rocks.  The decor is nothing special but who cares if the food is outstanding.
author: Scott A.

description:
The bf and I went back to this restaurant tonight (Sunday), and it was pretty busy.  However, we were seated pretty quickly.  All of the wait staff was very nice, attentive, and fast!  I don't think I've gotten better service from a Chinese restaurant.  All of them seem genuinely happy to have us there. 

We ordered only three items, and the food arrived very quickly.  The hot and sour soup was really, really tasty.  It tasted like it was made from scratch.  The sauteed pea sprouts are as expected (the reason why I wanted to come here in the first place), very tasty.  The pork and vegetable dumplings were also very well-seasoned.

This place is definitely much, much beter than Kingdom of Dumplings!
author: William L.

description: My husband and I LoVe this place! We got the vegetarian pot stickers and pork and cabbage dumplings and shared. It was only $16 and we left full and happy! We went back the next night it was so good!
author: Jennifer T.

description:
Oh yes!  Another winner in the Sunset for great dumplings!  I really prefer this place rather than Kingdom of Dumpling that's two blocks away.  Dumpling Kitchen is more spacious, accommodating to large parties, cleaner, and a much better value.  Most of all, their food is delicious!  You can't go wrong!

You would think they only serve dumplings but their menu is very extensive (144 items!)  Dishes include various specialty dumplings and pot stickers; cold plates and appetizers; numerous mu shu options; soups; noodles and rice dishes; a variety of vegetable, pork, beef, and chicken preparations; and seafood.

My favorites include:

* Shanghai-Style Steamed Pork Soup Dumplings (10 pcs) $6.50 -  What I would have to say is their signature dish!  Ten plump pork dumplings served in the warm bamboo steamer that burst with a mouthful of soup when you take a bite.  The texture and thinness of the noodle wrapped around the generous pork filling is perfect!  Complemented with the dipping sauce . . .  FABULOUS!  AND what a bargain!  Ten dumplings for only $6.50!

* Beijing-Style Boiled Pork and Chive Dumplings (10 pcs)  $6.50 and
* Steamed Pork and Napa Cabbage Dumplings (10 pcs)  $6.50 -  Good sized dumplings with flavorful and generous amounts of filling.  The dumplings are more oblong shaped than round, and some tend to stick together when served.  But a couple of more stirs while they're boiling in the hot water would help to separate them. 

* Shanghai-Style Chow Mein  ($7.00) -  A tasty blend of wok-fried thick, chewy noodles tossed with plenty of veggies.  Generous portions and not greasy at all!

* Dry-Braised String Beans ($7.00) -  Quite good!  Delicious, slightly crunchy string beans dry fried with flavorful seasoning.
 
* Mu Shu Pork ($7.95) -  Six light and thin flour pancakes served with a large heap of mu shu pork (vegetables, bamboo shoots, mushrooms, eggs, and pork sauteed in a delicious sauce).  Spread the hoisin sauce on to your pancake, add a few spoonfuls of mu shu pork, wrap it up like a burrito, and you're ready to go . . . HEAVEN!  The texture of the pancake wasn't quite stretchy and elastic enough as it fell apart, but that's ok since the yummy taste of the mu shu pork made up for it!
 
* Crispy Egg Puffs (3 pcs)  $3.50 -  A nice dessert to end your meal (when it's available and you don't have to wait too long for it to be prepared).  It's not really crispy as the title suggests, but lightly deep fried.  You get three hollow egg puffs, a little larger than the size of an orange, topped with granulated sugar.  The dough is chewy, and with the little bit of sugar, it's DELICIOUS!

They also offer lunch specials from 11AM - 3PM which consist of various rice plates ranging from $5.50 - $6.50.  

The service is quite efficient but could be a little more friendly.  However this is typical with many Chinese restaurants.  There is also ample parking so it's convenient.  Dumpling Kitchen has become a frequent stop for my weekend lunches.  A delicious meal and a great value!
author: Karen L.

description: Favorite dumpling spot in the city. XLB is better that Shanghai Dumpling King and better value than Yank Sing. Service is nothing special but it's fast and at least respectful. If the other chinese dishes we're a little better this place would be perfect.
author: Anthony D.

description:
I'm giving a "5 star" on an Asian food scale!

FYI, Translation of restaurant's chinese name: literally "#1 dumpling king". how did that become "Dumpling Kitchen"? I guess the worse the name of the restaurant, the better the food!

Highlight dish:
Anyway, LOVED the XLB here! the meat is juicy and marinated with a touch of sugar- best price I've seen: $6.50 for 10.

Other entrees:
- chili oil dumplings: to DIE FOR! minced garlic on a chili oil/vinegar sauce mix. ended up using this sauce on everything! these dumplings were juicy too!

- pan fried dumplings: standard. i preferred the boiled dumplings though. depends on your personal preference

- Tried the Shanghai noodles, Westlake minced beef soup, braised tofu, garlic  eggplant dishes- all of which were of generous sizes, low on salt (we had to add a bit more ourselves). definitely not the highlights of my visits. Each entree was about $7:cheap but would recommend that you stick to their dumplings.

Appetizers:
- deep fried dough (you tiao) - classic
- soymilk - perfect with the you tiao

Service:
GREAT! and I don't mean just "great" for an asian restaurant. they were truly attentive and prompt. Very pleasant dining experience on the Friday night that we went.

Had tons of leftover. great prices! we feasted and left with full bellies!
author: Lina C.

description: This is, hands down, my favorite restaurant in SF, and that's saying a lot. It's a total hole in the wall, but the soup dumplings here are perfect and so is the sliced beef and cucumber salad. I would eat here every day if only it were closer...
author: Jia H.

description:
Shanghai Dumpling?! Let's go to the dumpling kitchen. 

The place is packed during prime dinner hours. Lucky me, I get off work by 4pm every day, so I get in before the rush.  My favorite is the shanghai dumpling, but I have ordered the chicken wings, mapow tofu, fried fish, deep fried man tao with condensed milk, peanut noodles and corn dumplings. 

Everything is tasty and I have no complaints. Def recommend for a dumpling night out!
author: Chanel L.

description:
I love this place. Their dumplings are incredible. I especially like the Shanghai pork dumplings, though, there's a large variety to choose from. Their other food is good also. I've had chow mein and several other dishes, all of which are great. For the price, it can't be beat. I'm not sure you'd get a better dumpling if you paid twice as much. In fact, I'm pretty sure it would be worse. And then you'd feel like a sucker, and no one wants that. 

It's roomy and the staff is super nice. If your choosing between this place and the one down the street, Kingdom of Dumpling, I think it is, pick this place. You won't be disappointed.
author: Elias A.

description: Dumplings are good but this review is solely because for whatever reason they charged for to-go boxes. We ate at the restaurant and did not finish all our food. They didn't even bother giving a bag on top of that because at that point if they're charging $1 for boxes, you might as well charge me for a bag, though according to http://www.sfenvironment.org/article/prevent-waste/checkout-bag-ordinance you're not supposed to be charged for a doggy bag. So please look over your bill before paying.
author: Eugenia G.

description:
This is my go-to dumpling restaurant in the city. Not too crowded, decent amount of tables to sit, and the food is great.

We always order the XLBs, potstickers, pork dumplings, chicken wings, rice cake noodles. Been coming back for years, and will continue to do so. 

I would just advise not to get their pan fried onion cake - it's thicker and less flavorful than other places would normally make it.
author: Jon L.

description:
Funny enough, I came here right after a meal at Kingdom of Dumplings. Boyfriend and I was on a dumpling hunt and wanted to try different dumplings from different restaurants to see if there are any places better than Shanghai Dumpling King.

The waitress was very attentive, but I'm wonder if it's because there were only 3 occupied tables (including us). Since we already had dumplings before this, we only ordered two baskets of dumplings ($6/10) and that was only split among my boyfriend and our other guy friend. I only tasted one and it was nothing special. There were soup and the skin was thin enough to contain the soup, but the meat were smushy and I tasted some pepper too. It certainly does not scream FRESH to me.

We also ordered the sugar puff (egg puff), it was decent but I think the ones at SDK was better. I do love my sweets though so it's hard to complain. Overall, I probably wouldn't come back unless the SDK or Kingdom of Dumpling are both out of seats and I did not want to wait in line at all. One thing that this place has over the other two is this place has more spacious seatings.
author: Elaine Y.

description: My favorite dumpling place in SF! I can't remember the name of the dish, but #1 on the menu is really good!
author: Viggo W.

description: Bunking in a friend's place and didn't wanna head too far out for dinner. We decided to try this place, seeing that the reviews of the food were decent. Don't expect much of a decor or an ambience, but the xiao long baos were pretty good, though I wished the soup that leaks out on the first bite was hot, instead it was lukewarm. Had the pan fried dumplings, but I would surely give that a miss the next time round. Try the pork belly with preserved vegetables; juiciness of the belly fats is HOLYMOLLY good!
author: Ann Hui Y.

description:
Dumpling Kitchen is my new go-to restaurant.

Everything on the menu has been satisfying so far, and the restaurant is able to accommodate large parties.

Some of my favorites include the following:

Green onion pancake that is so light and airy, yet full of substance, that always leaves you wondering if you have ordered enough.

XLB that has thick enough skin to withstand the pressures of chopstick-lifting and spoon depositing, while keeping its treasure of hot soup and flavorful fillings safe before it enters your mouth.

Beijing style boiled pork and chive dumplings that have an irresistible char on their bottoms that have dramatically changed my expectations for dumplings everywhere else.
author: Andrew M.

description:
It wouldn't surprise me if you've completely passed this place up while driving down taraval. Isolated from the other restaurants in a tiny location, Dumpling Kitchen hardly stands out among the random stores littered on this street. Do yourself a favor though and stop by for some delicious (and decently priced) dumplings.

Price-wise Dumpling kitchen might not initially wow you but in terms of value, you'd be hard pressed to find a better deal. Whereas most places give you half a dozen dumplings for similar prices, you get about 10 delicious and moist dumplings at a reasonable price. I've been to a few different dumpling places but in terms of price, flavor, and ease of travel (free street parking everywhere) this is by far my favorite place.

Don't expect the cleanest place though as I've encountered some issues with dirty utensils before. It's expected but still not pleasant. Also, the service is what you'd expect with a friendly waitress and lackluster help throughout your meal. 

Dumpling Kitchen is my favorite place for dumplings in the city. I'm sure with some more searching I could find a better quality or finer tasting place, but in terms of experience I love Dumpling Kitchen. 

(order the shanghai style soup dumplings and pan-fried pork buns. Thank me later.)
author: James D.

description: This is not the swankiest place, but it's exactly what it says it is and every bit of it. The staff is super sweet and helpful, the food is beyond amazing and even if pundit know what to order, someone will recommend something and lead you well. Lovely crowd and amazing food!
author: SIlver O.

description: My friend and I got lost while searching for another restaurant, and we stumbled upon this hidden gem. Overall, a great dumpling house! Clean tables, excellent service, and wonderful food. I believe you're supposed to order a la carte, but two dishes were enough for both me and my friend. We ordered pork Xiao Long Bao and pork Potstickers... They were so good! I can't wait to come back with a larger group and order more varieties of dim sum.
author: Christie K.

description: This is my favourite place for value to eat xlb I could just inhale all the dumplings they put out if I could. Affordable, some of the best I've tried for the price. The pork belly too is highly recommended. All just delicious.
author: Andrew L.

description: This place was delicious. I went with about 5 other people and we got something like 9 or 10 dishes. All of them were gone by the time dinner was done - we definitely did well! A few winners were the noodles and (surprisingly) the vegetarian pot stickers. The only thing we were disappointed by was we ordered the pork belly but I think it got lost in translation or forgotten because it never came. That was okay because ordered so much, but we would have liked to have tried it. When all was said and done, it wasn't really that expensive! I would definitely go back.
author: Rachel N.

description: Probably one of the best XLB in the bay area. The XLB has a balanced taste with the right amount of dough to meat ratio. The spicy wonton is another delicious dish I would recommend to everyone.
author: Hau N.

description: Worst service ever!! We came in on Friday evening, plenty of open table, we got seated immediately. Ordered our food and food were served quite fast. The customers started coming around 7pm, and starting to get busy. While we're still chewing our food, the waitress already gave us our bill and started cleaning up our table. "Hold on, can't you see we're still eating". Anyway, we got so disappointed!!  We ended up asking for to go boxes and packed the food home. The dumplings were ok. Dry-fried chicken was not that good compared to the restaurant on Irving. The noodles were too soft because of over cooked. And the clay pot salted meat rice didn't taste good at all. First time eating there, and would be our last time!!
author: Wanda Y.

description: Pretty tasty!!! So the XLB at Kingdom of Dumpling are a little better, but marginal at best. Dumpling Kitchen does not have lines, is bigger (seats more people) and has more variety/options! Love the raw fried buns (buns that are pan fried until cooked, no boiling), pot stickers were delicious, crispy and juicy, loved the shanghai pan fried flat noodles. Yum!  My only non-fav is the onion bun, too toughy for me, but I guess it is healthier. Love it here, will definitely return!
author: Vanessa K.

description: Might get hate mail for this but the XLB at dumpling kitchen is way better than the same item at Din Tai Fung.  The filling/soup has this fatty umami flavor that knocks others out of the ballpark.  To give some more reference, I'm not even normally a fan of this style dumpling, but dumpling kitchen's XLB is now one of my favorite dishes of any cuisine.  Haven't really tried anything else there so I can't comment on the rest of the menu.
author: Prashant C.

description:
Been here only once so far (July '12) but would like to come back as the food was delicious! Get ready for an experience in carbohydrate-loading: noodles, dim sum, etc ensures a restful after meal nap.

Ordered: shanghai dumplings, black bean sauce noodles, and some other stuff I don't recall but were good.

Prices were cheap/fair.

What really BUGGED me was the poor service by one of the older waitresses; while  serving the soup she accidentally spilled a glass of water all over my side of the table and said nothing. Then to resolve the issue she piled on a bunch of napkins and walked away. She didn't even come back to clean up or replace anything. I had to flag down another person to clean up. Although a trivial thing, it was indeed a blemish on my first overall experience of this place.

Be back again hopefully soon (for a different waitress!).
author: Danny H.

description: Awesome dumplings. I go to this place now because Dumpling King is just too small and too crowded. Can go wrong with their crab or pork xiao loung bao - delightful and delicious. Their Shanghai fried nian gao is pretty awesome. The Sheng jian bao and pot stickers taste almost the same, so I'll be sure to order just one or the other next time. The green onion pancake is deep fried and not pan fried, so I won't order that again either. Red chili wontons were okay, but I've had better. All of these negatives drop the star off in my book. Would definitely give the dumplings 5 stars though. They stand up to any other dumpling place I've been, including din tai fung!
author: Alton Y.

description:
This is a great go-to place when you're feeling too lazy to make your own xiao long bao (XLB). When I come, I don't even bother to look at the menu to know what to order. XLB!! A tip to my friends, removing the XLB from the steamer onto your spoon requires great balance, precision, and hand-eye coordination of chopsticks and spoon. Master it, my friends.

Besides that, the tian tian (jia jia?) mien aka the pan-friend noodles is an excellent choice for spicy seekers. Vegetables are a little on the salty side for my taste.

For dessert, the steamed rolls with condensed milk is mysteriously soft and moist. Try it!
author: Tiffany C.

description: Kingdom of Dumpling wasn't open yet and I was really craving some XLB for breakfast, so I found this place on Yelp. So happy I did because they were incredible. Really some of the best I've had in a while. I want them now.
author: Jessie M.

description:
Pan fried pork buns!! Delicious little nuggets of flavorful soupy pork wrapped in a perfectly doughy skin and pan fried to perfection! I could eat a million of these!! 

The xiao long bao (which we originally came to snack on) were a pleasant surprise. These little parcels came pretty close to my favorite ones (Shanghai House), mostly b/c of the surprising extra kick of ginger. Downside - they were a little too sticky on the outside. I picked one of them up with my chopsticks, placed it on my soup spoon and it wouldn't disconnect from the sticks. Mreh? Whatever. At $7 for 10 (pretty much anything on the dumpling menu), I'll deal with the mess. YUUMM.
author: Karena Q.

description: Best xiao long bao and boiled dumplings in San francisco. Better than Kingdom of Dumpling (by a hair) and better than Shanghai Dumpling King (by a lot). Also, huge portions. El fin.
author: Nancy Y.

description:
I love XLB so I decided to try Dumpling Kitchen after my friend texted me a pic of their XLB this weekend.

I ordered the XLB and pan fried potstickers.  The XLB is good, great pricing, but I prefer Shanghai dumpling shop in Millbrae.  Potstickers from San Tung are my favorite, but the ones here remind me Ling Lings from Costco.

Overall, I might come back if I'm in the area.  There is no wait and it's bigger than Kingdom of Dumpling.  Prices are not too bad either.
author: Chrissy M.

description: In my book, this is the best dumpling place in the city. The dumpling skins are made in the right consistency, but not too fragile.
author: Thomas L.

description: Delicious and cheap dim sum....so glad I stumbled across this place! Filled with local families and curious tourists, but I got seated right away and the service was great. I've also done take-out here several times...the dim sum servings are huge, so take note if you're eating by yourself!
author: Kate E.

description:
It's just Soooo Good. That day I ordered vegetable dumplings, they are so natural, unlike some dumplings in chinatown, their vegetable fills are green and fresh, with green bean noodles inside, I felt satisfied but light after finished them.
I never review any restaurant before, but this truly impressed me lots. I'll definitely travel 34 mins from home to try other things very soon.
author: Crystal Y.

description: I am addicted to this place.  The green beans!  The pea sprouts and any kind of their rice stick noddles.  The lions head soup was crazy amount of food - for like 6-8 people and huge fresh dumplings.  everything is super fresh.   I would order here twice a week if my husband let me!
author: karen h.

description: Everything was delicious the dumplings, the Shanghai noodles, and the fresh vegetables. We will definitely come back for more.
author: Rick M.

description: Really good dumplings (the type that have soup in them). Homemade food and friendly staff. Very cozy, low key ambiance. Some of the other popular items like the pan fried onion cake and noodles weren't that exciting for me. Again, wish I could give a half star to make it 3.5 stars.
author: Nora Y.

description:
Green Onion Pancake!  I love it here!  I could eat the whole plate myself but that would just be rude.  It's got a nice crispy crunch outside, soft fluffy inside, and packed with flavor.  

I've had a variety of dumplings here and have found them all to be deliciously devoured.  The Xiao Long Bao is good and everything's pretty cheap.  The hot soy milk is pretty good too.  I'm not a huge soy milk person but my friend really loves it.

Not sure what more to say, but if you want dumplings stop here and also order a pancake!
author: Stephanie C.

description: I was wondering what to eat for lunch Tuesday. Weather was sunny but a little bit chilly. I remembered I haven't had dumplings for a long time so I decided to pay Dumpling Kitchen a visit. Started off with a glass of warm soy milk and complimentary roasted peanuts. Ordered a dumpling called xiao long bao which was warm with juicy soup in the middle. When you eat be careful because the soup inside is very hot. The way to eat is to bite a hole on the top of the dumpling to drink the soup then eat the dumpling. The rice cake noodles dish was chewy with shredded pork and veges. I also ordered a sweet rice roll for dessert later. All for about $24 and there was leftovers for to take home.
author: Viv T.

description: I am by no means an expert on Asian cuisine but BY GOD THESE WERE THE BEST FREAKIN' PORK DUMPLINGS I'VE EVER TASTED!!! Light, perfectly stuffed, even with a delicious broth INSIDE the dumpling! And parents; my picky children (one child only eats plain buttered pasta when we go out) LOVED these!!! Woot woot! We ordered take out and looking forward to checking out more of the menu with the family!
author: Joanna B.

description: Good place to go for some dumplings they sure are delicious.  The staff there is very friendly and if you get there early there won't be that long of a wait.  The dumplings are delicious I recommend the Shanghai dumplings I think they are the number one on the list.  Recommended for families
author: Danny C.

description:
I liked the dumplings!  Tasty thin skin, with lots of flavorful soupiness

I wasn't a fan of their Sichuan style noodle.
author: Jennifer L.

description: You MUST try the pan-fried pork dumplings. They are just as everyone else raves about, and the pork belly was to DIE for. Super tender and juicy and flavorful. The quality and the taste of the food will really exceed your expectations. Sure, the service is lacking a little (I had to ask for water because they didn't bring out any even when we were halfway through our food), but they bring out your food fast even on relatively busy nights and if you flag them down they will attend to your needs. This restaurant rivals all other Chinese restaurants out there. Probably my favorite place to get Chinese food now.
author: Andrea F.

description: I would say the best Shanghai soup dumplings in the city. The soup has a sweetness and it's not greasy. The dumplings in the chili oil is also a good choice. The leeks with pork belly has a very nice wok flavor. The food here is amazing and so affordable. There will be leftovers and you can enjoy the goodness later!
author: Eve C.

description:
Dumpling kitchen is one of my top favorite restaurants in Sf. Their dumplings (#1) is awesome, juicy and flavorful, green onion pancake is soo much better than most places and quantity is plenty to go around, soymilk is warm and savory, but i don't like the savory soymilk, just the regular soymilk. The spicy peanut noodles are the BOMB! Trust me, it's flavorful and yummy. I tried the rice roll cake thing, but it's one of my least favorite dish. The fried spring roll is essentially eggrolls, very yummy! Warning: the pan fried shanghai buns are meant for more than 2 people, it's very filling, and there's 10! Well, try it out, you'll enjoy this place like me~
hb
author: Hao B.

description: The star is for the good Shanghai buns. Everything else was horrible. They gave me horrible service and I said I wanted the egg puffs after I ate and they gave them to me before the buns came out. I told him I didn't want them until after I ate. So he brought them out, cold and I said I wanted them fresh and he brought out partially heated up. The staff was eating in the middle of my visit at an other table and yelling, it was pretty annoying.
author: Rosy C.

description: Din Tai Fung, eat your heart out.  I totally wish there was a Dumpling Kitchen in orange county so that I wouldn't have to settle for mediocre shanghai dumplings.  A friend from sf recommended this place a few years ago and I will never forget that first bite.  I have never been able to forget Dumpling Kitchen from that moment on.  So I had to take my friends from orange county to try this place on our SF trip about two months ago.  Since we aren't from the area it took us a while to figure out how to here.  2 hours and 24 minutes to be precise and it was worth every minute of it.
author: Uyen P.

description: So amazing. The dumplings were out of this world and the general chicken is incredible. I've gone here four times now and it's been a pleasure every time!
author: Cecilia A.

description: We just had the wonton soup and a plate of green beans, but they were both amazing! My sister and I ducked in to this place on a super stormy day so that hot soup was really comforting. :) service was quick and friendly.
author: Jade C.

description: The Shanghai dumplings were worth the flight from San Diego. The chow beef fun was great. My friend brags about this place and it lived up.
author: Janine D.

description:
This has some of the best Chinese food in San Francisco.  I've been in China, and this is very rustic and homely (not the genericized, greasy stuff nor the super fancy "fusion" style).  It's definitely not the best, considering all the expensive and fancy Chinese restaurants, but the bang for the buck and authenticity is where this place wins.

I had two dumplings:  the Xiao Long Bao (looks like a tiny pork bun) and a standard steamed pork dumpling.  These were really good, even though we originally ordered a fried pork dumpling and they gave us the steamed one instead.  I also had the hot-sour soup, which was underseasoned but had really good flavor.  We had the seafood stir fried flat noodles (this isn't the "fun" style, but more like flat ovals, which is a particular style in Southern China).  These were pretty legit too.  I've had them in Hong Kong and China and I don't recall too many places outside that area that makes noodles in this style correctly.

Well, enough about the food.  The yelp reviews seem to already say the same good stuff about the food.  The reason I didn't give it 5 stars was the crappy service.  First, as mentioned above, they got our order wrong (they gave us steamed dumplings instead of pot stickers).  The place was really slow and we were the waitress's only table.  When we brought up the mistake, she brought the manager over.  The manager asked us what the problem was, and we said there was a mistake.  The waitress then comes out of the kitchen and starts laughing and says "Oh my, you're right.  I wrote it down correctly but pushed the wrong button on the computer" (but she said it in Cantonese).  So, she brought out the manager because she thought we were lying or something?

The other thing is that was kind of weird was that we ordered about 8 things with a group of 4.  EVERYTHING came out the same time.  When the fourth item came out, we told the waitress to slow down the kitchen as we couldn't catch up and didn't have space on our tiny table.  Despite that request, the remainder of the food still came out one by one and our table was just cluttered.

And, for some reason, they took away our tea kettle without us noticing (maybe because the table was running out of space because of all the food they were trying to squeeze in)!  And you call yourself a Chinese restaurant?  YOU DON'T TAKE AWAY A CHINAMAN'S TEA!  That's like walking into a house without taking off your shoes!  Ai-ya!

Anyways, it most likely was that the waitress was untrained because my mom has been here before and she said she didn't have any of the problems.  So in summary, awesome authentic food but staff needs to be trained better.  I'll most likely come back again and hopefully it'll be flawless and I'll change my review.
author: Alan C.

description:
My personal benchmark for XLB dumplings is the Rincon location of Yank Sing. The skins are thin, which I prefer.  Because they are expensive at YS, I am always on the search for an equal to or better than XLB for less.  I checked out Dumpling Kitchen because of the reviews.  I found the XLB to be sweet and the vinegar did not cut the sweetness.  The skins were nice and thin, though.  But the sweetness was a killer for me.  My search continues.  Good thing there are a lot of dumpling places!

ps--I also got the wontons in red oil.  Just ok.
author: Amber B.

description:
How could I forget to check-in or write a review after coming here more than 5 times?  The Wo Tie or fried dumplings are awesome: Slightly juicy as you bite into each dumpling with perfect crisp skin at the bottom and moist at the top. Each dumpling is dainty, served just like in HK, Singapore or China; not the usual gargantuan pieces with thick chewy skin.
How about Xiao Long Bao? Of course bursting with soupy juices as you drop it into your mouth. YUUUM!
The onion pancake is so bread-like, light, and fully onionly fragrant!  Beef Sichuan style are immersed in wok-aroma; mark of a chef who stir fries over high heat! The same wok-aroma in their Shanghai stir-fried noodles. And the smoked fish: chilled and sweet; the perfect appetizer!
Will definitely come for more and eat the rest of the menu; love this place!!!
author: Sheue L.

description: Food was quick and tasty. However, wonton soup was extremely under seasoned, green beans were yummy along with the Kung pao chicken, pot stickers and shrimp chow mein. Service was underwhelming. If ur looking for delish food and poor service this is the place for u.
author: Irene P.

description: They have such amazing food there! Great Shanghai soup dumplings, but their best thing is the pan fried dumplings! Nice crispy bottom, not too bready, and still has some juice flowing from it when you bite in. Simply delicious
author: Tim F.

description: Found hair in the Mui shu chicken!! yuck!  They've gone down hill. Their dumpling used to be a lot better. probably won't be coming back here again. Service not that great either. If you're non Asian, you get so much better of a service than us Asians! Racist......
author: Alyce l.

description:
MMmmmmm!!!! This right here is PERFECT warm-yourself-from-head-to-toe-on-a-cold-night dim sum. Because that's pretty much all I've ordered from them is the dim sum but boy, it left me reeling with delicious everything. 

My boyfriend loves the crab and pork steamed dumplings the best, they are more expensive and you get less but they are a flavor knockout!  

Anything else here that says dumplings on the dim sum menu, I can give two thumbs up to, and I would give more if only I had more thumbs. The pork and chive dumplings are tender and perfect. The shanghai steamed pork dumplings are creamy and cooked just right. The pork dumplings in chili oil, boy, that combination has been around for ages but it makes my eyes roll around in my head with how they play off each other so well. The green onion pancake is so unexpectedly tasty! Perfect for sopping up the delicious meat juices that run out of your moist dumplings when you bite into 'em. 

 Also? Do not pass up the Lion's Head Meatballs. I've not had the ones in the soup but i have had them served over the bed of spinach, and while I found the spinach unremarkable. I can say hands down this is the most impressive meatball I've ever had the pleasure of having in my mouth. Aside from being huge, like whoa, they are omg omg omg so good. I am drooling up a storm right now. 


I guess be wary that the temperature can be kinda weird in here, they've got fans going a lot of the time so if you get cold easily bring a jacket....and also there's the muni going by all the time right outside which shakes EVERYTHING in the place, that along with it being crowded and pretty noisy frequently means you're probably not going to have a silent meal but the hustle and bustle can be very pleasant. Dumpling Kitchen! I will return forever!!!
author: Jessica W.

description:
this is an affordable restaurant with good dim sum. one downside during my expeeience was the xiao long bao when it came out to my party had barely any soup in it. maybe the soup drained from the bottom. could be fixed by steaming the dumplings on a lettuce leaf.

 flavor was good and I had better elsewhere hence docking a star. their pan fried version of it was really good and made up for it. other dishes they had were alright like one of their noodle soup dishes. 

wait isn't too bad and the ambiance is somewhat homey but in the end all that matters is that the food is delicious and the dining environment is kept to a good cleanliness score.

all in all good for the price you are paying for in a city like San Francisco.
author: Myk S.

description:
Sunday Brunch with no wait for fresh streamed dumplings. No complaints, but not a wow factor. If you are looking for a quick fix of dumplings, this is the place to go.

* Pork dumplings in chili oil (10pcs) $6 (3 of 5) It is ok. Fresh boiled dumplings served with chili oil. I do like it better than Millbrae's Shanghai Dumpling Shop, because this place doesn't dunk the dumplings in a chili + peanut based sauce.
* Shanghai-style steamed pork dumplings (10pcs)  $6 (4 of 5) Not bad, but not super juicy either. But probably my most favorite dish during the brunch.
* Steamed pork and napa cabbage dumplings (10pcs) $6 (3 of 5) Dumpling shaped like gzoya and steamed. Fresh, but I rather have the Shanghai-style steamed pork dumplings if I am going to be at this Shanghai place.
* Thread roll steamed or deep-fried (1 roll) $2 (3 of 5) Chinese donut with pork shred wrapped in stick rice. This roll makes you very full, so don't order to many.
* Pork Preserved Vegetable Fried Rice Cakes $6.95 (3 of 5) They cooked the dish without soy sauce, so it was not as salty as I like and came out looking super white. I prefer the darker coloring when cooking rice cakes.

This place is local and rather affordable, but if you have the time and patience, I rather be going to Kingdom of Dumpling (few blocks up).
author: Janice T.

description: Came here for lunch. Had their dumplings and noodle soup. The food was great but nothing mind blowing. There may be some better places out there especially for soup dumplings. Recommended though.
author: Garett N.

description:
This place is super legit!!

The service may not be the best, and downright awkward sometimes, but really, the food makes up for it.

Do try the dry fried chicken wings, as they are rock solid!

I really don't think you can go wrong with anything on their dumpling menu, but then again I only got 2 of the dumplings. Pot stickers are awesome, and the beijing style chive dumplings legit as well.
