Salt and pepper fried fish was just ok, the batter leaves a bit of a weird grainy after-taste, but the mounds of fried garlic on top put it over the top.

Pros: Good, traditional food. Comfort food!

Cons: Service seemed a bit awkward, not the cleanest place, but not as dirty as some make it out to be.
author: David H.

description:
I came here with some friends who heard some good things about this place. We came on a Friday night and was pleasantly surprised to see there was no wait for a table, although the restaurant is fairly busy. (Protip: They don't accept reservations for under 5 people.) The restaurant had a lot of families - which means of course, lots of little kids too, so it you're not a kid-person, watch out! The food here was brought out very quicky, and service was not bad for a Chinese restaurant. Of course, I came here with Chinese people which might have helped.....

Most of the food is fairly mediocre. We got the family style meal for 3-4 people, plus an extra order of the crab and pork dumplings. The dumplings were very good! I kept on breaking mine, and my friend commented that the skin was good and thin. The rest of the food was definitely not as good. It tended to be a bit bland and just didn't taste very good in general (as I said, mediocre .... at best). If I come again, I think we'll only be ordering dumplings next time. 

4 stars because the food was priced appropriately ... and for the dumplings. If they didn't serve the dumplings here, it'd probably be knocked down to a 2.5 stars.
author: Lena Y.

description:
These guys have the best XLB dumplings. We tried the sesame chicken there and also the chicken with seasonal vegitables and they were both excellent. 

The service was good (not the perfect but close) hence the 4 stars. 

Prices are reasonable, great over all.
author: Brenda T.

description:
probably my first and last time here. 

food wasn't anything special--ordered beef chow mein, pork dumplings in chili sauce, and sweet and sour chicken over fried rice. so our food didn't come out on time and when it did, the chow mein was kind of cold, the pork dumplings had a weird, rancid after taste, and received plain rice instead of fried. 

our waiter seemed completely out of it and not very hospitable. asking for water appeared to be a hassle. they also sat us next to their store room and were in and out of it.
author: lib c.

description:
The second time I've tried their stuff and it's GREAT! The prices are reasonable, the service is pretty fast, and the portions are fairly generous (important in my book).

The xiao long baos are delicious, as well as the potstickers. I also liked the noodles in black bean sauce! I loved how big the green onion pancakes were but they were a bit too doughy and fluffy for my tastes (I like them really thin and crispy). Some other goodies: the spicy cow stomach and the Shanghai style rice cakes.

It's a bit far away from the other businesses on Taraval but there's parking around and the L runs right along!
author: Cynthia Y.

description:
This is one of my favorite joint for food. Great food. I have tried about 10-12 items on the menu so far and all of them were delicious. If I were in town more often, I would have tried out the whole menu by now.

This is a place where you'd want to bring 2-3 friends if you plan to try out a few items, the servings are big. I have introduced several of my buddies to this place and one of them even became a regular.
author: Alan L.

description:
I ordered takeout once from here and have yet to dine in, but the even as takeout the dumplings were tasty!

I ordered the soup dumplings (Shanghai-style steamed pork dumplings on their menu) and the pan fried pork buns. I had never had nor seen the pan fried buns before and I have to admit, they give soup dumplings a run for their money. They were soft and plump with a good amount of filling and even a bit of soup inside! Yum!

The soup dumplings were good as well, and held up even though I didn't get to eat them right away. Very soupy, but the meat could have a little more flavor.

Out of the dumplings I've tried in San Francisco these are good, but still come in second behind Shanghai Dumpling King.
author: Annaliese D.

description:
As you walk into a Chinese restaurant and see mostly Chinese,  you know you've come to the right place!
Unlike Kingdom of Dumpling which is 2 blocks away with much better reviews on yelp, Dumpling Kitchen is much brighter and more room. As a matter of fact, Kingdom of Dumpling has 70% customers of other race as we walked in and we know  this place is for Americans. 
Back to Dumpling Kitchen, food is great and price reasonable. Shanghai Xiao Lung Bao is the best in town and very juicy with good smell, way better than Shaihai Dumpling King on Balboa in the Richmond which also is another place has 60% customers are other race.
author: Spike P.

description: Great pot stickers.  And super love their dry fried chicken wings and seafood chow mein. Try them ... you won't be disappointed.
author: Rebecca L.

description:
This place is better than KINGDOM OF DUMPLING!

More variety in terms of food (not dumpling) but all you really need to get is the Shanghai Dumplings here - they are juicy, hot, and the bomb!

Here are the other items I usually get that is really good:

1. Black Bean Sauce/Meat Noodles
2. Sun-Jean-Bao (Pork-bun, juicy, crispy bottom)
3. Dry-fried Chicken/ or Fish
4. Walnut Prawns.
author: Gwen K.

description: This place was awesome! No complaints. Being Taiwanese, I've had the best (din tai fung, etc). I'm not saying this matches it, but it's as good as any place I've had in NorCal.
author: Tommy Y.

description:
Thought the place was pretty good. Food tasted fresh and not too fried.

We didn't get a chance to try the dumplings though, so I"d definitely want to return to try them!
author: Lauren E.

description: I moved here from NYC where I was spoiled by the likes of Joe Shanghai, Shanghai Café & everywhere you go in Flushing.  Food was good, but the XLBs will always be in the shadows of my hometown favorites.
author: Trish M.

description: Large portions. We got the shanghai dumplings, green beans and mushroom tofu dish. Tofu dish was overwhelmingly tofu and not what i expected. The gravy was a little clumpy and gelatinous... Maybe a bit to much corn starch. A little bit hike in the wall-ish. Line out the door on a Friday night.
author: Kathleen T.

description:
The only thing I can do is reiterate what others have said, because it's true: 

1. The XLB are excellent. Nice and juicy.
2. The pan fried pork buns and potstickers are legit. The pan frying makes them crispy and different from other restaurants. 
3. The bok choy with garlic is good. The portions were enough to feed our group of 5. I liked that the dish included roasted garlic cloves (I'm a garlic lover so I appreciate things like that)

The staff was attentive and regularly stopped by to clear empty plates. Just make sure you input the right address into your GPS and don't accidentally go to Kingdom of Dumpling on the next block.

My tummy gives Dumpling Kitchen...4 Stars!
author: Allan L.

description:
I've been here a couples times before and it used to be decent enough for me to come back again.  So here we were today to celebrate my son's very 1st birthday with his grandparents.
    I don't know if it's because we came on a Saturday night so service was pretty awful.  I made a reservation for 6pm. We got there on time, sat down, ordered quickly, food came and we started eating. Okay so at approximately 6:24pm (yes, i looked at the time) halfway through our dinner, one of the server, an older lady in her forties came to our table and asked if we needed boxes for the rest of the food that's on our table. We told her we were still working on it and continued eating. She walked away and comes back with to-go boxes and the bill and started clearing our table. We're thinking wtf...?? Okay whatever, it's my son's bday don't wanna ruin the evening. I asked for the cake that I brought in when we got seated. They brought out the cake still in the box. I asked for plates and forks and this other waiter guy asked "and forks!?" like it was too much to ask for.  I said "yes".  Wtf kind of attitude was that?! Anyways, as we were lighting the "1" shaped candle these busboys or whatever were standing there chitchatting that they still had to wait for us to light the candle, sing happy birthday, blah blah blah before they can clean up our table.  Like seriously? You guys had to say it right behind us like we couldn't hear or maybe they just didn't gave a damn. 
   Overall, the food was nothing to rave about.  I thought it was average.  For that quality I can go elsewhere without such horrible, not kid-friendly service.  My mom did told the younger lady in the front counter that they were rude. As if they cared.  Quickest dine-out dinner we've ever had. Didn't mean that in a good way. Will not be back, ever. Good luck with your potty-mouth bussers that walks around casually cursing at each other. Do not bring your kids here if you do not want to expose them to profanity.
author: Phi P.

description: I drive up and down Taravel all the time but have never noticed this place until I mentioned to my best friend I was craving xlb for lunch. This was one of her favorites so we decided to check it out with another friend. The lxb were hot and soupy. The fried potstickers were flavorful and not overly oily. The shanghai style chow mein which usually has too much oil was perfect and you could really smell the "wok hay" as soon as it was put down on the table. And the dan dan noodles. Oh man probably my favorite dish that day, I don't know how they do it but it was sweet, spicy and almost creamy at the same time. We also had 2 glasses of fresh cold soy milk. Lunch for 3 with tax and tip came out just under $30. Would definitely come back again.
author: Sarah L.

description:
Okay I had to try this place... its so close to my work.  This place is much larger  than the Kingdom of Dumpling place a few blocks up.  The servers were really nice and were very helpful setting up the table for us with two highchairs. 

 We ordered: Green ontion Pancakes (Loved the texture, very light and airy with green onions throughout) Steamed Xiao Long Bao, the pan fried version of Xiao Long Bao (was definetly my fave- kinda like a pot sticker outside and with a soft yummy meat inside, Fried Rice, and won ton mein (my husbands fave).

Prices weren't bad.  Large Portions. Will def come back to try out more dumplings.
author: Sheenie L.

description:
This place is literally a hole in the wall but man is it good!

Apparently this place has won countless awards and you can tell. The food is so fresh and the plates are adequately portioned. There are two cooks and one of them is a teenager I think. You can tell off the bat that all of the recipes are homemade. The place is really small, seats about 10 and there are always groups waiting outside to be seated. Their location is not fancy by any means. All of this is forgotten once you start eating and realize that you are eating award winning food. The waitresses are friendly and attentive. There are countless Chinese spots up and down Taraval but this is the one everyone goes to so that is saying a lot.

 I'd highly recommend this place.
author: Javier G.

description: Closest soup dumplings that I've had since NYC's Joes Shanghai dumplings! There was enough soup liquid in the dumplings than most joints in the bay area.
author: T L.

description:
dumplings where a 4 star, but all the other food was just Okay at best. I went with a group of people and got the biggest family meal option. I think it was like 110 bucks. which was really cheap for the amount of food that we got. but i would have preferred to have gotten better quality over the amount of food. 

If you like dumpling u should go here b/c they are very good. 

FYI: its a hole in the wall, parking is hard to find. very small restaurant, food comes out fast.
author: Henry C.

description: Went for the first time with family and the dumplings did not disappoint! It's a fairly small place with not to many tables, but each one was full! Love their dumplings and would definitely come back even though they raised their prices
author: Jennifer Y.

description:
I always order take-out and I'm never the one paying so this is based on food only!

Their potstickers are really some of the best in the neighborhood.  The skin is really thin and light and the meat inside is perfectly packed.  I can devour these like crack.  I bet they taste a hell of a lot better fresh though because they always have this weird taste after I pick them up (maybe too much oil)?

Their jya jya mien (sp?) is also good but I just don't care for the cucumbers.  Other locations put more stuff in their noodles like tofu and veggies and stuff.

All in all pretty good and pretty affordable.  I gotta try dining in one of the days because I'm sure eating it fresh makes all the difference.
author: Kimiko Q.

description: Dumplings are really good here.  There might be a little bit of a wait, but worth it.
author: Matthew P.

description:
My friend and I came here after a long hike and ordered shanghai bao, seafood bao, pot stickers and onion pancake. It was pretty fulfilling and the food was very traditional. Although the pancake wasn't what i expected it was still very interesting and delicious. The bao was pretty soupy and flavorful.

We also all got a glass of soymilk which reminds me of home when I use to drink warm soymilk. I think if you like traditional chinese food it's a good place to try.
author: Pin X.

description: Nothing like finding a new restaurant just by chance and leaving so satisfied wanting more and more.  A little far from where I live but whenever I get a chance, I am there!  415, baby!!!  Clean, delicious and not expensive!  You really can't ask for more...maybe some better music.
author: Dan S.

description:
Vegetarians: Try the the fried green onion pancakes. They're crunchy, flavorful, and addictive, serving the same purpose that tortilla chips do at a good Mexican restaurant: To incite fights over who gets to eat the last one.    

I also like the salty green beans, stir-fried with garlic. And don't miss the vegetarian fried potstickers and veggie steamed dumplings -- both are stuffed with savory minced greens, and served with a brown vinegary dipping sauce.

Save room for dessert. The light and airy egg puffs, generously sprinkled with granulated sugar, are fantastic.

I wouldn't go out of my way to order the veggie chow mein or vegetarian noodle soup. They're fine and they get the job done (the chow mein is appropriately greasy and keeps in the fridge for days).  But there's nothing special about those dishes.
author: angela n.

description:
Found my new Xiao Long Bao place. Shanghai House used to be my favorite, but the wait and inconsistency on the xlb has made me less and less of fan. Thank god my in-laws showed me this place.

Came here for lunch with my in-laws and the place wasn't too packed. Here's what we got:
1. XLB - so good. The skin is nice and thin and there was soup in every piece I ate. Some places make the skin too thick so it's really chewy, but Dumpling Kitchen has got it down. 
2. Pan Fried Pork buns - awesome. 
3. Onion Pancake - hands down one of the best onion pancakes I've had. Nice and fluffy and yet crispy at the same time. Great flavor.
4. Shanghai noodles - very good and I love noodles. 

The XLB are a little bit more than the other places I've been, but I think it's only a $0.50 difference so whatever. For another $0.50 I'd rather eat here any day.
author: Lang T.

description:
Maybe this place doesn't compare to the crazy 800+ reviews from Kingdom dumpling down the street...but trust me when i say...the XLB are hands down tasty here.  Mind you..i haven't tried that restaurant..but I have heard from very good friends who live in SF as well as a friends mother (Who know's her XLB :)) Say that this place is good for it..

For those who haven't tried this decadent dumpling...you have to try it.  Get the orginal pork ones.  One order yields 10 for about $6.  Super great price.  Must be eaten with a bit of their ginger and red vinegar.  

I came here a couple weeks ago just to try it out.  Comes pretty close to Ding Tai Fung of SoCAL.  :) Skin is just right and not too thick...there was soup sitting inside every last dumpling...I also love their Egg puffs too.... Soft..fluffy...and just the right amount of sugar.

I will be coming back.  It is my fav. and only place for my XLB (XIao Long Ba0) cravings!!

Hope this review help those in search of great tasting dumplings.
author: Trang K.

description:
I do not understand why this place has such high ratings.  The dumplings are not very soupy and the meat is bland. We ordered the Red Chili Oil Wontons, Pork Dumplings, a noodle dish, and string beans.

the red chili wontons was not spicy and tasted like it had peanut sauce in it... not the correct way of making it.

the dumplings were not that great and kind of dry.  the skin was thick.

the noodles were bland and had no flavor.

the string beans were also bland and had no flavor. 

the food came out very fast.. like way too fast.
author: Jtina K.

description:
The place is not always consist with its xiao long bao, but I still enjoy the food here. I went here today and it was a little disappointing. My parents and I ordered the crab and pork xiao long bao, Shanghai noodles, shanghai style pan fried dumplings, and the pork and chive dumplings. 

I expected the xiao long bao to have lots of soup because of last time, but it was so dry. It was still tasty, but I really wish there was more soup. Everything else was good and we finished everything. Some days are better than others, but I still really enjoy the food here. 

Service is okay. You get what you want, just don't expect a smile. Waiting for the weekends can be rough, since it can be pretty cold, but on a Friday afternoon is great. Was no wait at all.
author: Jasmine W.

description:
Dumpling Kitchen is pretty damn good...

came here last weekend and ordered up a storm

the XLB (soup dumplings) were perfect...had both the crab and pork dumplings and the flavors, textures, and even the dipping sauce were ideal...

also ordered the pork belly with preserved vegetables...just the way i liked it BUT the pork belly was too fat...instead of a 70/30 ratio of meat to fat, it was more like a 20/80, which is a bit to "rich" for my blood...

pan fried potstickers were solid...very meaty...im not a huge fan of potstickers that have alot of veggies in the stuffing...these were perfect, and not TOO oily either...

other than that, the turn around time for the food was super quick, and the service was actually pretty good too...will definitely come back to try some other dishes soon...great hangover food...
author: Kyu L.

description: They have very good Siu Lo Bao. Hot and juicy. However, other than that there is noting good here. The sauce of Tan Tan noodles is like glue.  Red bean cake is not crispy.  Overall, food are mediocre.
author: J L.

description: I'm very hesitant to write this (I don't want to have to wait in a line around the corner at this special little gem)...I truly cannot add much to the rave reviews of this place! The dumplings are out of this freaking world!!! Seriously, these folks must be from another planet, to serve such good food. Hot, flavorful, served quickly, with a smile. We have tried other dishes; dry fried shrimp, Kung Pao beef, etc. all quite good, but don't forget the name of the restaurant "Dumpling Kitchen", Order The Dumplings! Plenty filling, fantastic flavor, extremely satisfying and very reasonably priced. After dinner take a walk down to the beach, then catch the L train back home.
author: Doug W.

description: Dumplings were delicious. Beef with mixed vegetables was good too. Veggies were steamed, not a lot of grease like most Chinese restaurants. Tea was good. Customer service was good. Seating area was quiet on a Saturday afternoon. Will come back here for sure.
author: Hugh M.

description:
Had a hankering for some XLBs and didn't want to risk waiting at SDK. 

We headed over before the noon lunch rush and we were immediately seated. We decided to try XLB, 5 spice beef soup and Beijing style dumplings. 

The food came out at a good pace. The soup was first out and it was different than I've had at other places. The soup base was chicken broth instead of the usual beef broth. The flavor was lighter and the beef pieces in the soup were mostly tendon and not really beef. Our XLBs came out next and they were hot and juicy. I was pretty full after this but we had one more dish. Our dumplings came out and they were steamed then pan fried and when i bit into one the center was still raw! Eeewww raw pork! They took back the dish and made us a new plate but we had to wait a good 15-20 min (at least that's what it felt like). 

Anyways, I thought the place was just okay but I'm willing to go back and give it another try. The service was pretty good here and the staff was pretty friendly!
author: Julie F.

description:
Delightfully YUMMY! Came here because Kingdom of Dumplings was busy and glad we did.

Crab & pork Shanghai dumplings were DELISH - Must try!  I preferred this one more than the regular Shanghai Dumplings.

#119 - Fried Chicken Wings - Must Order...so yummy with a kicker sauce! 10x times better than that thick crusted, yucky and overrated chicken wings @ San Tung.

Green onion pancake - Not your typical thin version. Thicker yet airy with the right amount of sodium and you could definitely taste the green onions; not bad.

Definitely will return with friends & family to try other stuff!
author: Katy N.

description:
Small room with poor ventilation and lots of steamy dumplings = HOT HOT HOT. However, the food is so good that it's worth it to sweat a little.

We were a group of 4 and we ordered 10 items. We had to eat fast so that there was room to put all our dishes down since the table was so small. The waiters kept looking at us funny as if we were crazy to order so much.

- Xiao Long Bao and Pan Fried Pork Buns were really good as expected
- Pork Dumplings in Chili oil! Yesss!
- Green Onion Pancake was okay - this was the thick version where we prefer the light flaky version - I dipped mine in my soy milk
- Sweet Soy Milk (Warm and Cold) was exactly what we expected
- Chinese Donut was good, crispy and not too oily
- Steamed Sweet Buns with Condensed Milk was good - It was a good palate cleanser after I ate a ton of salty dishes (eat while warm)
- Dry Fried Chicken was okay.. not the right crispiness and a little dry - will need to do the wing version next time.
- Shanghai style Stir Fried Rice Cakes had the perfect texture! Not too chewy or too soft and lots of flavor
- I forgot what kind of veggies we ordered but they were green, garlicy, and good!

We all left extremely full and happy. The only thing we did not finish were the onion pancakes and the rice cakes.
author: A. Z.

description:
Pretty impressed. My new go-to for xlb in SF.

Xiao long bao - 4/5
Shanghai fried noodles - 4/5
Shanghai Fried pork dumplings - sheng jian bao - 4/5

This place beats Kingdom of Dumpling for me for Xiao long bao. The skin was the right texture and thickness (just thin enough so that it wouldn't break apart when you pick it up and there is no thick top where they seal it). Plenty of flavorful juices inside and the meat had good flavor. 

One thing that didn't make it perfect was that I prefer the meat inside to be a little less soft but it was still delicious and satisfying overall.

The fried noodles were good and tasted like they usually do.

As for the sheng jian bao, we were at first hesitant to order them since most places either have the wrong meat to bun ratio (way too much bun) which results in the deconstruction of the bao to counter it. Also they are usually massive. Looking at the tables who ordered it, they were a lot smaller than I've seen. These had a good ratio of bun to meat and the bun part was thin and moist.

I still think Koi in a Daly City has the best xlb I've had near SF but Dumpling Kitchen comes close.
author: Amy H.

description:
My friend and I came on a Wednesday to try it, only to find that it was closed.

So my mom, cousin and I dropped by a few days ago to taste test.

We ordered the shanghai dumplings (10 for $6.50). They were pretty juicy and just average.

Next came the pork with preserved vegetable stir fried rice cake ($8.00).
Also not that much flavor and just alright.

The dish that came next looked delicious but was not very spectacular. 
Braised lions head meatball (4 for $9.00). These huge meatballs made of pork and covered in some brown sauce with some greens on the bottom. Honestly the "choy" at the bottom of the dish has more flavor than the meatballs. 

I wish I could have liked this place better but really, I couldn't. I usually eat a lot and I spent more time eating white rice than eating the dishes in front of me. That's not usually a good sign.
author: Wilson T.

description: I had been craving dumplings for over a week. Found this place on yelp and decided to check it out with a friend. We ordered the XLB's, veggie potstickers, dry fried wings and tofu. All of it was amazing. We could barely finish our meal but it was so good. Also was super cheap. 30 bucks for all of it. I would return.
author: Nia R.

description:
I'm glad there are a few more of these dumpling shops closer to where I live. Balboa or San Mateo used to be my places to go if you wanted some XLB.

And as of late the two places on Balboa just aren't cutting it.

Anyways though, after coming here a couple times I can say this place is pretty good. So here are the few items I usually order

XLB - either pork or crab..I say stick with the pork. Lots of tasty soup that will burn your lips and tongue if you decided to bite into them immediately. And the skin isnt too thick.

Pan Fried Buns - Its almost like an XLB but its more like a bun. Crunchy on the bottom where they have been pan fried. Soft buns with a crunchy bottom with juicy meat.

Drunk Chicken - simple dish with no complaints

Green Beans - another simple dish that can't be messed up.

Potstickers - huge potstickers, quite flavorful with a nice crunch.

Green Onion Pancake - crunchy outside with a nice soft inside.

Some of the dishes are quite big and you probably wont need to order too much unless you plan on bringing stuff home. Overall this restaurant is very good and I'm very glad to have it quite close to where I live..

Oh forgot to mention they do have soymilk which isnt too shabby either.
author: phillip w.

description: Just went back tonight and had their pot stickers--surprisingly good!
author: C L.

description: Aw man, more and more people are finding out about this place and the wait for dinner is starting to get longer! Shanghai dumplings, black bean noodles, and egg puffs are our staples and are perfect for these chilly evenings. Skip the red bean pancakes and get the green onion pancakes instead.
author: Cheryl Q.

description:
LOVE LOVE LOVE this place! The service is as good as it gets for a standard traditional chinese restaurant. The dumplins are TO DIE FOR! Its so good and there's never a wait. Its way better on so many different levels than Kingdom of Dumpling in my opinion, such as...its cleaner, not stuffy, cheaper and food tastes better.
Hands down my favorite Chinese restaurant.
author: tee c.

description:
02.06.11

Late lunch with the parents.  Xiao long bao (10 for $6, awesome deal).  Shanghai style chow mein, extra spicy ($6.50).  Dry braised string bean with rice ($5, but the beans were not in season and old, so we essentially wasted $5).  Drunken dumpling dessert (drenched in rice wine).

Good alternative if Kingdom of Dumpling is packed (like it was yesterday).

Total damage for three: $28
author: Jenny L.

description: Great shanghainese food. I highly recommended their pan fried pork bun 生煎包. Must eat when they are still hot from the kitchen. The bun is very juicy and tasty. Price are very reasonable, too.
author: Katherine L.

description:
dumpling kitchen looks plain on the outside. inside are cream walls and functional stitched pics.

sampling: 
appetitizer: salted peanuts (free) nice
-shanghai-style steamed pork dumplings(10/6)    4.5 stars
some dumplings leaked. hot soup within, skin thin
tender, tasty meat
-beijing style pork & chives dumplings (10/6)   
 kind of doughy, some leakers, 
came in broth caused by leakage
meat bland                                                                      3 stars

-shanghai style green onion pancake (3.60)
doughy, undercooked                                   1 star,

foodnotes:
-server almost gave me potstickers instead of xlb.
-foods not even made
-menu leans shanghaiese, generic chinese dishes also present.

chinese lessons                          mandarin
beijing style  dumplings     bei jing shiu jiao
author: Victor G.

description: Yum!!  I think this is our new favorite place to have Shanghainese dumplings in SF.  It's definitely a lot more spacious than the other restaurants that we been to.  The dumplings are juicy and tasty.  We ordered the soup dumplings, pan fried pork dumplings, black bean sauce noodles, and a rice roll.  The rice roll wasn't what we were expecting but the hubby absolutely loved it.  It was a chinese donut wrapped in sticky rice with pork sung inside.  He devoured it.  We also got the egg puffs for dessert.  It's a big puffed doughnut covered in sugar.  It's so fluffy and airy and good.  We got here early and it was pretty empty... maybe another table or two, but by the time we left, there was a group of people waiting for a table.  We will definitely be back again.
author: Kymberli C.

description:
?????????????? 

This was what I was thinking as I bit into my XL bao and found no soup. Hmmmm....not a good first impression. 

I had this bookmarked for quite some time and finally ventured in. Overall, I WAS excited about trying their XL baos until I bit into one. Every dumpling was dry. Where the hell was the soup? 

Ordered the Shanghai pan fried bun and mom made a comment saying it tasted like a soggy char sui bao and then pan fried.....Okkkkk....place isn't winning points with mom.... 

We also had a bowl of soup noodles. I can't remember what we ordered so that might be a clue as to what I thought of it. It just wasn't memorable. Sad eh? 

I can't say that I would return to Dumpling Kitchen. I found it really disappointing.
author: Cris H.

description: I love this place! Everytime i'm in San Francisco, I want to come here.  The service is not always good but the food makes up for it. Their soup dumplings are great but I think their fried bottom dumplings are even better! The chicken wings and the shanghai chowmein is also delicious!
author: Jo-Ann L.

description:
The best thing about going around town with a local is the great food finds on and off the tourist-y path.  And for something like Chinese soup dumplings, it works out very well.

Awesome soup dumplings.  You're not exactly pouring out spoonfuls of broth when you open these, but the dumplings are big and there's enough soup to soak through the meat filling for moist, savory, flavorful awesomeness.  This place also has the best scallion pancake I've ever had, perfectly chewy, not too greasy, and the perfect amount of scallions.  Other awesome dishes include some good udon-like noodles in brown sauce, noodle soups, and sauteed veggies.  Wish I can tell you what exactly I ordered, but my Cantonese friend did the ordering, and he did a great job of doing so.
author: Enigmajic O.

description:
We've eatten here several times and even ordered take out and I love this place!  This place is #2 on my list of *bay area's best dumplings* (#1 is a place off 25th in San Mateo).  

Must haves: 
 - shanghai steamed dumplings (the juice BURSTS in your mouth)
 - pot stickers (the filling is juicy and tasty and the skin is thin - perfect!)
 - pan fried pork buns (OMG .. so good!)
 - jai jen mien (made with thinner noodles ... tho the portion size for this noodle dish is small)
 - pan fried rice cakes (yum!)
 - fried egg puffs (fluffy, eggY and sweet)

I recommend this *dumpling* house if you're in the city.
author: elaine i.

description:
The xia long bao (Shanghai dumplings here are delicious.  And a great deal to at 10 for $6.50).  Also tried the crab and pork version (8 for $9.50) and truthfully, the difference in taste was minimal (doesn't justify the much higher prices).

The Shanghai chow mein was just ok - the noodles were too thick and the dish didn't have too much flavor.

And the green onion pancake was very disappointing ... just a lot of starch with no taste at all.

Best to stick with dumplings here.
author: F. P.

description: Feast: hot and sour soup, crab/pork XLBs, wings, and seafood rice cake. Good stuff, good price (about $40ish for it all with tip).
author: Maximillian M.

description: Wow, this place is delicious. I'm no foodie but I can tell the ingredients are very fresh and authentic. We ordered numerous dumplings (the pork and chive were my favorite) and then the chicken wings were really crispy and well seasoned. I will definitely be back.
author: Sami B.

description:
This is the place for xiao long bao.  Their chef was actually the one who made the dumplings for the fancier dim sum house in Daly City.

Really a mom and pop comfort food place.  Highly recommended!
author: M Y.

description:
++A Tale of Two Dumplings++

Dumpling Kitchen vs Kingdom of Dumpling

Separated by only a quick jaunt down the block, these two restaurants both boast Dumplings to their names. Which restaurant shall reign supreme?

First off, this is what I've tried at Dumpling Kitchen.
------------------------
+ XLBs are pretty juicy and tasty.

+ Shanghai Style pan-fried pork buns are delicious. The dough is moist and the pork filling is good. I wish they could of pan-fried the bottom just a tad longer to give a more crispy bottom to give a nice contrast to the rest of the bun.

+ Green onion pancake is a lot different compared to the others I have tried. This one is made very thin, almost wafer like. The top of the pancake is wavy due to the dough bubbling up while being fried. This one is not as oily since it has less dough to absorb the oil.

+ The pork and napa cabbage dumpling was a little off. First they were wrapped like a potsticker in a siu gow like wrapper. The filling tasted like they put too much white pepper.

+ The wonton noodle soup was just okay. The wontons were good but I didn't really enjoy the broth or the noodles.
------------------------

Kingdom of Dumpling has a way better variety and quality of dumplings. The only two dishes I really enjoyed at DK are the XLBs and the Pan-fried pork buns.

I also prefer KoD's noodle soups because their broth is more flavorful and they offer more fresh green vegetables and mushrooms. 

Also, KoD has a mean hot sauce which I really dig while DK provides the basic vinegar, soy sauce, hot sauce combination that you find in almost all Asian restaurants.

The only drawback to KoD is that it is a hole in the wall, so it does get packed quite easily. You do feel like you are eating inside of a kitchen over their. 

But overall, I'd stick with Kingdom of Dumpling to get your dumpling fix but Dumpling Kitchen is a decent alternative if you can't stand the wait when KoD is packed.

++Result++

KoD with a K.O. over DK in the 3rd round.
author: Sam T.

description:
There has been so many different restaurants that have been in this location that I don't even recall their names..............until now.

Dumpling Kitchen have definitely etched their signature into San Francisco's sunset district to be the top dumpling houses in the Sunset.  Is it the best I have ever had...........No.  It's reasonable, the food comes out hot and fresh, the service is great, the price is cheap, timing was good.  I really had a great overall dining experience here today.

West lake soup..........very good

XLB..........good....not awesome.  the dough could be a tad less doughy

spicy wonton...........great

vegeterian goose.....kinda small, bland, and a little cold

postickers.........needed a bit more char on the bottom but still good

spicy beef noodle soup.......wasn't spicy, just tasted like beef noodle soup.  noodles could use a little work but the beef was good and tender

black bean sauce noodles.........I don't think it was even black.  It was good.............again the noodle was lacking that bite.  Sauce was good.

This restaurant definitely has potential.  Menu is very elaborative and have a ton of other foods that I would love to try.
author: jason g.

description:
There's a lot of dumpling restaurants in SF and everyone swears by each of them sch as SDK or Kingdom of Dumpling. But in my opinion Dumpling Kitchen trumps them both.

Hidden along the streets of Taraval, sits this awesome place. Setup and furniture is you typical chinese restaurant, but the real pluses come from the menu itself. Their Xiao Long Bao comes in 10 pieces as opposed to 5-6 with other restaurants and come at roughly the same price ($6). XLB's were juicy and delicious and for once didn't scorch the inside of my mouth so that's always a plus! We also ordered a couple of different items, green onion pancakes,  Dry Fried chicken wings, and crispy egg puffs. Pancakes were fluffy and yummy, crispy egg puffs were light, sweet and a nice way to end the meal, dry fried chicken wings however weren't so hot. In reality the wings were covered in soo much sauce, so much that they were difficult to pick up with chopsticks and was unnecessarily messy, however that's the only blemish from Dumpling Kitchen.

In terms of service, I have no complaints, overall they're friendly and attentive. The restaurant itself has ample seating for a variety of groups and parking around the area isn't too bad but remember it is in a residential area.

Overall I think this will be the dumpling restaurant we go to until said otherwise, and I'm sure you'll agree with me!
author: Ryan C.

description: Should be a 5 stars restaurant, however minus 1 star due to the taste of crispy chicken has changed. Friendly hostess but not the servers. Must try the SLB - very very very good.
author: kerokeroppi L.

description: No wait, good XLB, good shanghai food.. can't complain! Portions are huge here too! So that's a plus.
author: Stephanie C.

description: The Shanghai steamed pork dumplings were what my family came for and they were super delicious. We also ordered the shanghai chow mein, chinese doughnut, soy milk, and other dumplings. This place has a long wait but the food is very worth it. The service is a typical chinese restaurant but the place gets packed so come early.
author: Jason L.

description:
So after I came here last week... My experience was so different that I have to update my review. They've raised their prices... $7.50 for 10 xiao long baos. And the dumplings itself are different now. The meat inside now contain a lot of fat and there isn't much juice in it as before (which is my favorite part). 

As for the shanghai chow mein, it was good but pretty salty. 

Won't be coming back here for a while... Used to be my favorite shanghai dumpling place!
author: Grace S.

description:
Dumplings were good but i had better from Shanghai Dumplings. Their wontons in chili oil was .... a little weird tasting. The fried buns were... eck too filling and rather plain. The one thing that was good were the stir fried rice cakes. Deep fried sugar puffs were way too greasy. 

Service was average, like any other Chinese places; we did get seated pretty quick. They did come fast with your check and to go boxes. Place is clean. 

Not much that was memorable. It is your average place for some dumplings and a quick lunch. Overall, just get the dumplings and stir fried rice cakes.
author: Jules D.

description: Good place to get your fix, the parking can be a challenge but hey it's the sunset..The food comes out pretty quick and hot..Good for families
author: jonathan h.

description: Rating doesn't change because this place is really the real deal. Just a tip for better service, make sure to come more than an hour before closing. Unless we just caught our waitress on a bad night. She probably just wanted to close the kitchen out soon and lacked the patience for our indecision. Sorry!! Also, stay away from the green onion pancake - unless you like your pancake on the bready side. Probably the only bad thing I have eaten here!
author: Lisa H.

description: The pork dumplings and the crab/pork dumplings here are pretty tasty. I'm giving it 3 stars because the skin on the dumplings are very thick. It's not worth driving all the way to SF for unless you live in SF. I would suggest finding something in your area and avoid coming here unless you have a major craving for soup dumplings
author: Annie T.

description:
Went here with a buddy last night after realizing Kingdom of Dumpling was closed and I'll probably be back.  The food was good and CHEAP.

The XLB were on par with Kingdom of Dumpling but maybe not quiiiiiite as good.  You get 10 for $6.50 which seems to be a pretty awesome deal.  Also tried the Crab & Pork XLB which were also tasty, a nice change from standard pork dumplings.  Spicy wontons were good although I prefer them with some additional seasoning on top instead of just the spicy oil.  Pan fried pork dumplings were great, but we received them last and were already full so only had 2 of the 10.  Bok choy w/ garlic? eh, it was what you'd expect but they should either chop the garlic or cook the cloves for longer.

Overall, a great place for dumplings at a great price.

-1 star for the vinegar being watered down / weak and not enough ginger in the dipping sauce.
author: Niall H.

description:
Sooooooooo good!

We ordered take out last night and it was ready in 15 minutes. We got mapo tofu, dry fried chicken wings, and sesame chicken. I recommend them all! The sauces were delish :)
author: Brittany B.

description:
What seemed like a sunny afternoon in half of SF, turned out to be a dismal foggy blanket in the sunset.  And what better way to warm up the soul and scarf down some food delight at Dumpling Kitchen.  My sisters and I along with the nephew went to town on this joint feasting on almost every category on their menu.  The place fits probably up to 10 tables with 1 or 2 fitting large size parties.  Waitresses were very accommodating, but the food overall had its ups and downs.  For those that only care about the XLBs, they were pretty good except for somewhat of a thick skin.  Flavor was there though.

-Soy Milk - delicious.  not too sweet, not too bland, and very little grain at the bottom
-Spicy Cow Stomach - excellent.  perfectly tender and flavored with chili and sesame sauce around celery and peanuts
-Pan Fried Onion Cakes - ehhh.  could skip this next time
-Shanghai Stir Fried Noodles - ok, noodles were a bit chewy, and the flavor wasn't fully there
-Shanghai Dumplings (xlb) - pretty good, except for the thick skin
-Preserved Veg Pork Noodle Soup - soup was good, noodles i'd prefer to be thicker
-Dry Fried Chicken Wings - almost a take on San Tung's but not spicy and still relatively good.

Bill came out to be $40 for 3.5 people.  NOT too shabby!
author: Vincent K.

description: Yum!  Almost as good as Joe's Shanghai in NYC. Great xiao long bao and shanghainese noodles.  Tasty staples!
author: Alex S.

description: Really good food. I was craving xiao long bao and my boyfriend wanted to order other things. We ended ordering to much food and we couldn't finish it. We didn't think the dishes would be that big but it was quite a lot. It wasn't expensive either.
author: Aimee M.

description: Liked this place, decent soup dumplings
author: Jon L.

description:
This is the third restaurant at this address in recent memory.  Hopefully this place fares better than its predecessors.

-XLB - original, soupy and done well
-crab and pork steamed dumplings - tasty, sweet and a must
-shanghai-style pan-fried pork buns - a little doughy for my taste
-wontons in chili oil - not spicy enough
-shanghai-style drunken chicken - typical, can't really go wrong
-shanghai-style stir-fried rice cakes - better than expected, if you're into thick noodles, thats what she said

Not a bad alternative if Kingdom of Dumpling is packed.
author: Dennis L.

description: Preetty good + cheap as dumplins
author: Blake N.

description:
Yay, I'm a fan of Dumpling Kitchen! A couple of friends and I were in the mood for Shanghai soup dumplings and when the popular restaurant that first came to mind was crowded on a Sunday afternoon, we settled for Dumpling Kitchen. And by no means was it settling, as the food and service were great! 

Here's what we ordered: 

Shanghai pork dumplings - YUM! The filling and soup were very tasty, and soup's temperature wasn't scalding hot. The dumpling casing was exactly how I like into super doughy, and more like a pot sticker. I'd definitely order it again! 

Dumplings in chili sauce - Couldn't decide on the other dumpling to try, and since my dining companions and I all favor spicy foods, opted for this. Glad we did! The dumplings were a perfect size, filling filled with seemingly good ingredients and well balanced in flavor. The chili sauce the dumplings were swimming brought them over...I may have had more than my share of dish. 

Beef with mixed vegetables - Sounds boring, but we all enjoyed it immensely. Again, the ingredients were good quality, veggies (baby bok choy, carrots and maybe another that I have already forgotten) beef cooked well in a not too salty brown sauce. 

Black bean sauce noodles -We were expecting jajangmyun-like (Korean noodles) noodles, but wasn't the case at all. The noodles were al dente, sauce was more a meat sauce that tasted slightly like black bean, and thinly sliced cucumbers brought a nice freshness and texture to the dish. The entire ordered was devoured! 

The restaurant is actually pretty spacious. The service was fairly quick and attentive. One server seemed out of it, but at least another picked up her "slack" so we were well taken care of at all times. I'd go again, and wouldn't be surprised if it's with the same two dining companions...and soon!
author: Marie B.

description: their dumplings are perfect. so plump and perfect on the inside. I live doors away from this place, so if I'm not in the mood to make ill just get an order of those and some fried rice and I'm good to go!
author: Juan Carlos S.

description: My wife and i went to have lunch their today.  It was one of the routine places for us to have lunch. We ordered a beef noodle, pork buns and soy milk. Unfornately, they added a bug in our buns and we complained to the owner.  They didn't apoligize and said, "it was hot these few days". I assume it's ok to them to have insect in their food.  NOT A PLACE TO GO AGAIN!
author: E L.

description: I like them! :) Their pan fried dumplings with veggies are good. I'll hit this place up if I'm in the area. Their soup dumplings are pretty good. I think their skin isn't amazingly 5 stars, but I definitely appreciate their pan fried dumplings!
author: Vicki T.

description:
It was a Sunday afternoon and my boyfriend and I were in the mood to try something new. We were thinking of dumplings. Driving down the streets, we noticed Dumpling Kingdom. Actually we were looking for Dumpling King, but since this one showed up first, we decided to give it a try.

At first glance, we noticed there were a lot of people waiting outside for a table. We put down our names and the wait wasn't too long since the rest of the customers were large parties. We noticed that the restaurant was a bit small. 

After we sat down, we took a look at the menu and decided on three items. We ordered Shanghai-style steamed pork dumplings (10 pieces), Five-spice beef stew noodles, and  Pork with Sichuan pickled mustard noodle soup. 

The dumplings came out first, followed by the five-spice beef stew noodles and Pork with Sichuan pickled mustard noodle soup. The dumplings were tasty and I liked it. 10 pieces was quite a lot for only two people. The beef stew was a bit spicy but not to the point where my nose was running and I couldn't handle it. Some of the meat was a bit tough and hard to chew. There was a good amount of noodles and plenty of flavor. We were unable to finish the last noodle dish due to the portions of the noodle soups. However of the amount we tried, I was satisfied. I liked the pork and enjoyed the noodles.

I would come back to this place again. I would also like to try out some of the other dumpling places in the area to see what the difference is.
author: Doris W.

description:
4 stars for the dumplings, and xiaolongbao.

3 stars for vege goose, chicken wings, and black bean sauce noodles.

price is reasonable
author: Danielle A.

description: loved this spot for the soup dumplings and Chinese bacon !!
author: Micah W.

description: Dumpling was just ok.  My Shu pork was just ok.  The salt n pepper seemed to be prep by deep frying chicken wings and sprinkling on some salt.  Ok the salted wings were literally wings with salt so I got what I ordered, but did it have to be so ordinary?  I mean create a wing that would knock me off my feet, u know?
author: T. C.

description: Food is pretty good for the price and the service is quick. I'd suggest the dumplings and the fried rice cakes.
author: Chelsea L.

description:
Came here for the first time tonight with a group of 4.  We got there pretty late, around 9:15 (they close at 9:30), but they were friendly and welcomed us.  We ordered a total of 5 dishes:

shanghai soup dumplings
pork and napa cabbage dumplings
shanghai rice cakes
lions head meatballs
chicken wings and drumettes

I have to say that every dish was very good.  The soup dumplings could have used a little more soup, but the filling was tasty and it was actually one of the better XLB places that I've had in the Sunset.  The Shanghai rice cakes were also delicious, it was the favorite dish of two of my friends.  It has just the right mixture of meat, veggies, and sauce.  I also really liked the chicken wings.  It's sweeter and wetter than San Tung's because it's a different style, but it was still delicious.  

The service was friendly and we got a 10% off because of the grand opening.  I'm happy that this place opened up so close to my home.  I think I prefer it over Kingdom of Dumplings because it has a little bit more variety. The price of the dishes is pretty reasonable too. I'm happy to give it a solid 4 stars.
author: Tyler C.

description:
I'm a Big, Big fan of this type of food so unless you mess it up bigtime, then you should get at least a 4 on the Yelp scale.  It's been open for about 2 weeks now but even on a rainy day, they were pretty packed for a Sunday afternoon.  

I think the one thing that makes this place really unique are their version of hand pulled noodles.  Usually, hand pulled noodles at any and every other place I've tried them are thicker.  This place they are thin and look like just regular non hand pulled noodles.  But my mom did ask the waitress just to confirm and she did indeed confirm that they make it a little different here.  Can't say they were out of this world but they were good nonetheless.  

We ordered a couple of lunch special rice plates as well but I would say skip those if you are here as their dumplings and noodle dishes are the star of the show.  The Lionhead Meatball was pretty good too and they had some cold appetizers I liked.  So I think the only thing to really avoid are rice plates as they are nothing special here.    

At this point, they are giving a 10% discount and not sure it'll last but I am assuming it's a first month Grand Opening Special.  Supposedly, the chef is formerly of Koi Palace so if you are into that place, you should definitely try it here, especially since the prices are more than fair....  Unlike Koi.......
author: Mark W.

description:
Love this place!  Came here 2 times in one week.  This is now my absolute favorite place for shanghai dumplings. 

Must haves:

-Shanghai-style dumplings
-Dry-fried chicken wings and drumsticks
-Shanghai-style chow mein
-Sweet vinegar spareribs
-Crispy egg puffs (AMAZING!)

The restaurant is clean, the staff is attentive, the food is great!  Parking is difficult in this area, so give yourself some extra time to find parking.
author: Stella C.

description:
Came here a few times, their dumplings are always good. Their chow mein are a  little salty but their fried rice is just right. 

I enjoyed the Shanghai dumplings and dumplings with the chives. 

The wait time is not too bad, at most 20 mins from my past experiences at around 
7-7:30pm

Service is good and the food comes relatively quick.
author: James T.

description: The cabbage dumplings taste very good and fresh. This is our favorite, almost order every time. Good and fast service.
author: Li Z.

description: You must get the Shanghai dumplings here. It is a must get dish. The other dishes they serve are all delicious much like other Chinese restaurants.
author: Jack L.

description: This place has very good dumplings. So-so everything else. Price is decent. But it's is hard to be full with just the shanghai dumplings. It needs some noddles with dumplings too.
author: Michael Q.

description: The dumplings here are delicious. This is my go-to place if I'm craving good-quality steamed dumplings. The employees here are cool and do a great job. Don't let the look of the restaurant fool you. This is a great place. I hope this is helpful.
author: Kyle D.

description: Either I've been eating food overly high in salt content and I've gotten used to it or this place just has really bland food. Green beans, bland. Xiao long bao, bland. We did the set meal and added a few dishes. Nothing really stood out to me except for their sugared donut pastry at the end which I almost passed on because it looked like it would immediately induce diabetes... Good thing the boyfriend insisted that I try some because it was actually really good.. The rest of the food I can't recommend... All I have to say is I'm Shanghainese and the xiao long bao did not live up to standards.
author: Lily Z.

description:
I came here on a Saturday night and the restaurant was full except for 2 large family tables. My boyfriend and I were next in line for a table, and the restaurant offered to seat us earlier at one of the large family tables where we would share with another small party. I didn't mind but other parties seemed like they did. My boyfriend and I ended up eating at the large table of 8 alone, but hey, more space for us right?

I haven't eaten at a Shanghainese restaurant since I was a kid. Therefore I couldn't pass up green onion pancakes and hot sweet soymilk! I wanted to go for the fried doughnuts too, but my health conscious side wouldn't allow it. The green onion pancakes were done just right! Not too salty, and fluffly- unlike the ones you can just get at a supermarket and fry at home. The soymilk was a great addition to the meal as well. We also ordered regular xiao long bao, crab xiao long bao, and garlic vegetables. The xiao long baos were delicious and soupy! I agreed with another reviewer that they could be hotter but they were the best ones I've had in the area. The crab xiao long bao's tasted fattier, but I liked them even more than the regular. 

Next time I come here, I will definitely get the xiao long bao (either regular or crab)! I want to try their other dumplings, and their shredded pork rice balls with the sweet soymilk- would bring back old breakfast memories. 

A lot of reviewers compare this place to Kingdom of Dumpling a few blocks away. I've never had the XLB there, but I do think the ambience and service at Dumpling Kitchen is more welcoming.
author: Grace S.

description:
This location, once best known as the "Han Goeng" Chinese restaurant suddenly closed one day to emerge to my surprise and dismay as "Dumpling Kitchen".   I drove by it multiple times and tried to ignore the fact that I had lost one of my favorite eateries.  That said, the other day, I cast aside my sadness to begrudgingly visit the new tenant "Dumpling Kitchen"- but only at the suggestion of my sweet mom-in-law!

Once inside, I found the decor largely the same as the old Han Goeng, but missing the fish tanks - now sealed behind a block of walnut veneer. Hey, no big deal, remember - this is a REAL Chinese restaurant, where the focus is on the food - NOT the surroundings! =)

Once seated, we pulled the usual stuff off the menu  (dumplings, XLBs, potstickers, shanghai pork buns, etc.), as if we were visiting Kingdom of Dumpling.   Once our order arrived, I was more than surprised at seeing and tasting the absolutely terrific shanghai pork buns. They were perfectly fried with a evenly-browned, ever so slightly burnt bottom.  The same treatment goes for their potstickers, which were also delectable, as the meat inside was still very juicy as you bite into them. For this, and the Shanghai pork buns, I will keep coming back again and again!  THE BEST I've ever had - and the driving reason behind this five-star rating.  The Shanghai Pork buns imho, I consider MUCH better than the starchier, less fried renditions I've tasted elsewhere.   Not even in the same league. Not even close.  The XLBs here were terrific as well. Very juicy, with perfect chewy tender skin that you bite through to reveal the very juicy insides.. YUM!

That said, I wasn't quite as impressed with their dumplings, as I prefer the ones from KOD that wear a thicker skin and a rounder not-so-fun-gor shape.   Either way, I WILL return to Dumpling Kitchen.  Can't wait to go back for the Shanghai Pork Buns and Potstickers!
author: Harry W.

description:
High five Dumpling Kitchen! Super great dumplings! Three of us ordered 5 plates to share and stuffed ourselves for $25! We got-

1. Shanghai-style steamed pork dumplings (10pcs) XLB way to be!
4. Shanghai-style pan-fried pork buns (8pcs) 
8. Steamed pork and napa cabbage dumplings (10pcs) 
13. Shanghai-style green onion pancake 
15. Beijing-style sweet buns *steamed or deep-fried (4pcs) -Fried for sure!

-and everything was on point! These guys know whats up!!! As we were leaving the restaurant I wanted to press rewind and do it again! I'm soooo stoked on this place!
author: Thomas F.

description: Very underwhelming soup dumplings ( I'm shanghainese so the bar is high). Other dishes are mediocre as well. Scallion pancakes didn't have enough scallions.
author: V W.

description:
Hubby and I are craving for some XLB  and Shanghai dumpling kings on Balboa was closed for vacation. After reading the reviews on yelp we decided to go to the closes one in the Sunset. 

Here is what we ordered:

-Vegetarian Goose ($5) : more on the dry side and it's kind of bland. 

-Green Onion Pancake ($3.60): Maybe it's Shanghai Style, it's fluffier and bigger  than many other places and we can taste a bit of sweetness in it.  Hubby loves it.

-Steamed Pork and Cabbage dumplings($6): We both love the thin skin with more meat than cabbage filling but  prefer a little more seasoning on the fillings. 

-Xiao Long Bao ($6): Very close to Shanghai Dumpling King in seasoning and texture, but not as juicy.


Under $25 dinner for two with left overs for late night snack and save the drive to Richmond when we are starving, will go back.
author: Pearl H.

description: It is a very descent shanghai restaurant of the area.  The xiao long bao is very good...  The braise pork belly, half fat and and tender meat really melt in the mouth ( be warn... it is really good but very fat!) The preserve vegetable make a perfect combination to this dish.  It is a dish to share to avoid overkill of calories and fat intake, but is really a great dish.  They make it quite perfectly and it has to be accompany with some white rice.  I like that it is not too crowded.
author: Z G.

description: Good, tasty dumpling house everything u could want in a dumpling house XLB are very tasty and so our there other dumplings there pan fried pork bun are unlike many pork buns I have had before and tasted like little dumplings with that texture and doughiness that make BBQ pork buns so good but they are tasty and I had leftovers and when I heated them up they were still super tasty which isn't always the case. Bok choi and garlic was pretty boring but all of the dumplings we ordered were good not as light of a wanton skin as some other places I have been to such as din tai flung but really easy to eat and I some times like a little more wan-tan skin with my dumplings, holds together well, less likely to pop your precious XLB. Tasty if your in the area and needy for good dumplings go here it's GOOD.
author: Noah L.

description: In town for a short visit, saw good reviews at Yelp, we decided to try it out. Though there was a line, food was above average, service was ok (which I dont usualy mind that much). Everything seemed good till I checked my credit card statement. They changed the total amount I signed on the receipt, which is an act of FRAUD. Therefore, I decided to write a review on this business even though I am not a big reviewer. I immediately filed a fraud claim with my credit card company, the company said they will monitor this business closely. BEWARE of this business!
author: Krystal V.

description: I love the dim sum from this place.  We ordered the steamed pork and Napa cabbage dumplings, won ton soup, vegetarian dumplings and egg puffs.  Ale were very good.  I can't wait to return to get my egg puff fix.
author: Carb Q.

description:
I've been here twice. My first time here, I was amazed by it. Not only did they have cheap onion pancakes for $3, they had xiao lung baos for $6! My boyfriend and I ended up over ordering since everything on the menu was so cheap. 

Their dumplings were nice and juicy and didn't break when you picked them up with the chopstick... the only complaint I had was tha the pork inside was too mushy... It didn't have a nice consistency compared to well-- Ding Tai Fung. I enjoyed their onion pancake, but it doesn't look or taste like the traditional kind you have in mind. It's puffy and really light. I can't describe it... The potstickers weren't special and I think it could have been a bit more crispy. The beef noodle stew had bland noodles and the beef was chewy.

My family came again and we ordered almost the same dishes because I 
wanted them to try it. I think they would have given it a 2-stars.  


The thing I would give an A+ to is the hot soymilk and the sugar egg donuts (the name of the dish totally slipped my mind at the moment). I looove fresh soymilk. Mmmm... $1.50! Totally worth it. Maybe even 2 cups! The donuts were hot and fresh and a nice dessert. More sugar please.
author: Rosanne L.

description:
My mom was having a birthday dinner and she is ridiculously picky.  She's the type of lady who ONLY eats Chinese food, but not just any Chinese food because it has got to be from her region of China. Surprisingly she loves Shanghai dumplings and fell in love with the one on Balboa. They were on vacation so we decided to try this place.  

The Shanghai dumplings here were so mouthwatering juicy that I'm still thinking about it!  It was a clear favorite, while the crab dumplings were eh.  They had pan-fried pork buns, which was outstanding.  It was the perfect amount of bun and meat that I gobbled it all down.  The Shanghai chow mein and snow peas with garlic were so good that I tasted the wok it was made in.  I'm not even sure how to describe that, but my parents call it wok air.  Your stove has to heat up really high to get the wok to cook your food a certain way, which we can't do at home.  My mom talks about that a lot so its ingrained in me to think that way when I eat.

The family favorite is the Lion Head Soup because of the house broth with vegetables and clear noodles.  It's not the lion head that we like though it does give it some flavor... we're a vegetable inclined kind of family so we noticed how absolutely amazing this soup is.  It is delicious. My mom was a happy camper and thus we shall be back!!!
author: Amy L.

description: Found this place through yelp. The dumplings were wonderfully delicious - hot and juicy. Salt and pepper chicken wings were crispy and flavorful. Hot and sour soup was exactly that. I was not too impressed with sizzling rice soup. It was lukewarm and has no flavor at all. I would com back again and try other dishes on the menu.
author: Rose O.

description: Love the dumplings, esp. Shanghai style. We always stop here while visiting the city. Another favorite is the egg puff - soooo good. There's always a long wait so we try to come a bit after peak lunch hour.
author: Rohini J.

description:
-1 star for stereotypical asian ass service. when the older lady brought out me and my girlfriends food she said nothing to us and gave us no smile or any form of happiness and then when we said thank you instead of saying something nice or any type of word or noise she just said nothing.

That out of the way, the food was really good. Ordered the shanghai style steam pork dumplings (perfect taste, comparable to kingdom of dumpling). Then some spicy dumpling that i forgot the name of that was good too, then the green onion pancake which was good. It was like crispy and warm and shit. lol These food descriptions are soo shitty bc I ate here like 3 weeks ago and am writing this review now. JUST TRUST THAT THEY WERE GOOD.


So summary, 4 stars for the food.
author: George S.

description: This place got some really good XLB for cheap. I also like their pan fried buns and shanghai noodles. The pan fried dishes are salty, probably from the MSG.  Overall, it's good place for food and the price is reasonable.
author: Alex Z.

description:
Went for a second visit, this time weekend lunch. I'm sticking with the three stars. The soup in the XLBs had a higher grease content than the last time (though it's nothing compared to the melted fat disaster that was my experience at Joe's Shanghai in NYC's Chinatown several weeks ago).  Where Dumpling Kitchen kind of missed were the other two items I ordered: five spice beef noodle soup and pot stickers.

The noodle soup was wrong on two fronts: 1. The beef stew was tough. 2. The restaurant used Cantonese egg noodles instead of the expected wheat flour noodles. The item on the menu has an image of a chili pepper next to it, but the heat was negligible.

Pot Stickers: A failure in my mind. They came out with a noticeable green filling seen through the wrapper. The problem is Dumpling Kitchen uses Shanghai Bok Choy instead of cabbage (either napa or regular) mixed in with the meet.  What were they thinking?  I wish someone had warned me because I would not have ordered the pot stickers had I known.
author: Eating Sleeping T.

description:
Some of the best soup dumplings I've ever had.  The food was excellent as was the service.  The fried pork buns were fun and something I've never has before. They were fantastic with a little chili sauce. And the shanghai rice noodles? Ridiculously good.  The portion was huge, but the two of us considered ordering another round of this dish.  

The only thing i didn't like was the dumplings in chili sauce.  These didn't have much heat to them and were basically just sitting in a pool of vinegar which I hated.  I also wanted some broiled green beans which they didn't offer as an appetizer. BUMMER!  I'll have to go to Shanghai Dumpling King for these.  

If you have leftovers, a woman will come to your table and package it for you.  This was like dinner and a show.  She had this insane skill where she could hold two giant spoons in one hand and perfectly wrangle slippery noodles and delicate pot stickers into the to-go boxes.  She was truly amazing.  

Overall, everything was fresh, delicious, and reasonable priced.
author: Jordan F.

description: Great stir fried rice cakes and very good Xiao long bao. Probably some of the best in the city, definitely better than shanghai dumpling king in the Richmond. Cucumber salad was simple and delicious.
author: Katherine W.

description: I've got no idea why people have rated it so high. In my case I think the service is very bad - the waitress was not helpful at all. The food is really average and we will never go back again.
author: Mark M.

description: This place has the best Dumplings I've EVER tasted. Probably the illest Chinese spot I've ever been too as well. As authentic as you can get. I almost don't want to leave this review becuz I don't want anyone elapse to discover it!
author: Will D.

description:
I don't really like to review Chinese restaurants, but if I do, it's something to say about it. I came here twice with family and both times were quite delicious! It's really not much to look at from the inside out and some of the waitresses might be a little blunt and honest to you, but I think this is slowly growing to be one of my preferred choice for Shanghai food!

Among the great choices are the Xiao Long Bao, San Jin Bao and Preserved Vegetables and Meat Noodle Soup. All of these are my personal favorites and only a handful of places do it right! The Xiao Long Bao had a juicy meat center with flavor-explosive soup and all that with a dumpling skin that doesn't break easily! The San Jin Bao was done with a crispy bottom, soft exterior and a meat-in-your-mouth meaty core! The noodle soup was like comfort food to me and it was perfect for chilly weather! I don't know how else to describe it, but to have you try it! 

I can think of the Shanghai Dumpling in Millbrae that could do the same quality of food, but Dumpling Kitchen is much easier to get to. Parking might be a hassle, but if you don't mind walking, parking on the residential street shouldn't be too bad. Service is okay, but don't expect much: it's a Chinese restaurant.
author: Jeremy L.

description: Ma Po Tofu sucks!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  I came here with a few friends after spending an amazing day in the city/sausalito and the headlands.  We all had high hopes for this place, like a fool I passed up getting eggplant in garlic sauce for veggie ma po tofu, major mistake, it was hecka oily, lacked flavor and had thousands of black pepper balls in there that were so annoying to chew on.  My friends said their food was just avg.  I will not be coming back to this place.
author: Maninderpal M.

description: Xlb! Green onion pancakes! Fried chicken wings!  Great service...Better than San Tung.
author: cipote w.

description: I have to say, it's been a long time since I've had good Shanghainese xiao long bao. In fact, that last time was in Shanghai's cheng huang miao bazaar. Believe it or not, Dumpling Kitchen's xiao long baos actually blow those out of the water. Well, not entirely. The crab-meat infused xiao long baos are still WAY better back overseas, but the normal ones they serve in Dumpling Kitchen are spot on. Give this place a shot, you won't regret it.
author: Thankie S.

description: XLB, pan fried pork buns, and green onion pancake were amazing! However,   Other dishes which we ordered at the same time weren't professional.
author: Ting L.

description: Delicious! Sizzling rice soup, steamed sweet buns, Shanghai and Beijing style pork dumplings, really good and great value.
author: L B.

description: Great pan fried dumplings.  Very good pea sprouts in broth.  Excellent wontons.
author: Di Yin L.

description: The dumplings here are pretty decent. I got the pan fried variety. Filling was standard porky goodness, but would have liked more of a crisp brown bottom. They started to fall apart when I picked them up with my 'sticks- making them more difficult to eat than they should have been. I survived to tell my tale though.
author: Anthony R.

description:
I really liked their XLB! It's juicy and tastes like the ones I've had in Asia.  The skin is perfect and so is the meat inside. Nothing soggy.  We had their soupy noodle items and the noodles are great too!

Pan Fried buns were also tasty!  
We had a great experience dining here and will def. come back!
author: AhLin C.

description:
4.0 Stars

Mom, Happy Mother's Day! What can I say, I'm a motherlover!

Our extended family decided to have a Mother's Day lunch at Dumpling Kitchen and they were accommodating to provide us a reservation. We brought along my grandparents and the reservation ensured they got seated quickly so they wouldn't have to stand a long time waiting for a table.

Dumpling Kitchen offers an extensive menu aside from just serving dumplings. We decided to share everything family style and I got to try a lot of different items.

Shanghai-style Steamed Pork Dumplings
*10 Pieces.
*These original Xia Long Bao (XLB) dumplings were amazingly juicy and tasty. They were my favorite out of all the dumplings we tried.
*The skin/wrapper wasn't super thick and was nice and thin.

Crab and Pork Steamed Dumplings
*8 Pieces.
*I didn't find anything special about these dumplings because I could barely taste any crab flavor. I've had similar dumplings at other places and I could taste a sweeter flavor in the meat filling.
*It costs more and there are less dumplings in this order. I would've ordered another round of the Shanghai-style Steamed Pork Dumplings instead.

Shanghai-style Pan-Fried Pork Buns
*8 Pieces.
*Delicious and crispy! The bun surrounding the meat was soft and doughy and the bottom is seared to perfection. 
*I would recommend ordering this dish.

Pork Dumplings in Chili Oil (10pcs) 
*10 Pieces.
*These were typical steamed pork dumplings swimming in a light chili oil. I didn't taste anything extremely spicy with the sauce.

Lion Head meatballs with vegetable in house broth
*4 Pieces.
*The meatballs are HUGE. Imagine them being the size of a clenched fist.  The meatballs themselves are really moist and juicy.
*The broth is pretty light and is accompanied with vermicelli noodles and various vegetables like spinach, carrots, and mushrooms. 

Shanghai-style Stir-Fried Rice Cakes
*There was a good amount of pork and veggies, but I found this dish overall pretty oily and bland.
*I would recommend passing on this dish.

Crispy Egg Puffs (3pcs) 
*3 Pieces.
*The Crispy Eff puffs were a great way to end the meal with something sweet. These puff pastries were coated in sugar and were nice and airy on the inside.
*They weren't exactly the freshest because they weren't piping hot when they arrived at our table. There were still crispy though and that's a good sign.

It's great to have found a new Shanghai dumpling restaurant in the Sunset. My favorite dishes of the meal were the juicy Shanghai-style Steamed Pork Dumplings and the crispy Shanghai-style Pan-Fried Pork Buns. I highly recommend the dumpling dishes at Dumpling Kitchen. The other items were more on the lackluster side.

== A MUST TRY! ==
author: Jason H.

description: Ordered chive, pork and Shanghai dumplings along with an order the ground beef noodle soup.  The dumplings are just okay and I wouldn't necessarily go out of my way to eat there.  But the soup wasn't soup but a rather gooey combination of a noodle gravy with ground meat.  I'd pass on that. So it's okay.
author: Stefan L.

description:
Friendly Service!

At first we ordered the pan fried rice cake but instead they gave us the shanghai noodles.  The owner came out to apologize to us and comp'd us on free dessert!

Apparently, the owner is the brother of the folks at Shanghai Dumpling King at Balboa St.  Many of the menu items are comparable/better!

You can't really beat 10 juicy XLB's for $6!.  I recommend the stir fry rice cake/noodles as you can taste the "wok air" there.

If you live in the DC/Sunset area and don't want to trek out to the Richmond for XLB's.  This is definitely my 1st pick!
author: Annie C.

description: Just came here with my parents for lunch. We ordered shanghai style steamed dumplings (10 pcs),  pan fried potstickers, thread roll (fried), and salty soy milk. Everything was really good. But I have to say I've had better dumplings elsewhere. The skin was really soft but it was really dry. But that won't stop me from going there again.
author: Christina K.

description:
Since the first month it has been opened, my parents have been coming here every single day for weeks! The Shanghai Dumplings are D-E-L-I-C-I-O-U-S. The meat is succulent, the skin is soft and tender, and the hot steamy broth comes spilling out the moment you take your first bite. Other dishes such as the Lion Head Soup is super tasty and loaded with fresh vegetables. The Pan Fried Dumplings are great as well, although the skin texture is a little too thick for my liking. The chicken wings are pretty good, although it could be crispier. 

Every other dishes are delicious, made with homemade quality, and definitely hits the spot for a satisfying belly-rubbing meal.
author: Denise W.

description: Huge portions.  You definitely get your money's worth here.  It gets crowded during peak hours, so I usually sneak in for an early dinner or late lunch.  Don't come here if you're into atmosphere.  This is your typical brightly lit Chinese restaurant where you come strictly for the food, which is excellent.  Lots of Chinese customers who know a good deal when they see one eat here.
author: Robert C.

description: Pan fried pork buns, Shanghai dumplings , Shanghai chow mein were all on point! The pan-fried pork buns had a slight crisp on the bottom, which made them extra delicious! The shanghai dumplings were perfect, when you bite into them, the soup spills right out! And the shanghai chow mein were made with thick noodles, MY FAVORITE! I would recommend any of these items!
author: Mable J.

description: First time there. We went at 5 PM and we were the first ones there. We had number 1, number 68 and the fried fish. The fried fish was sole with a light dusting of seasoned flour. The fish was so fresh and so good. Number 1 was 10 pork dumplings. They were also so good. And number 68 was a chicken, spinach noodle soup which was sort of plain but also so good. I would go back there and I highly recommend it.
author: Clark S.

description: Dumpling Kitchen's XLB are very good, but their other dumplings not as good. This is the opposite of our experience at Kingdom of Dumpling, up the street, so we can choose where to go based on what we want to eat. Their onion pancake is nice, more breadlike than others. Shanghai noodles was good.
author: Bruce C.

description: Prices aren't bad for what one is getting. The only problem is that one must know what to order, not everything taste that great.
author: M C.

description: Yummiest Shanghai dumplings ever. Also at the top of the list, the Beijing style pork and chive dumpling with chili oil. obsessed with these at the moment. oh yes, cheap too!
author: Cat R.

description:
My go to dumpling place! This is the best xiao long bao dumpling in the city! They also have enough variety of other dumplings that I don't have to always get the shanghai dumplings every time but it's so hard to resist! They used to have pigs ear :( but their stir fry green beans and boy choy are also good for veggie options. Soy milk is a favorite of the parents. I usually get to go but come to eat sometimes...usually can get a table but my family are early eaters so about 5:30 is not crowded yet. 

Definite must try!!
author: Nikkie P.
