description:
As much as I am weary to say it... and Ryry hates that I say it... I think KOD has some good competition!

The menu here is more extensive -more chicken, beef, veggie and more to choose from. They have mapo tofu which is off the hook! I was in complete tofu heaven last night! It has just the right amount of spice, saltiness, sweetness... YUM. As a matter of fact, going to have the leftovers for lunch soon - can't wait!

Now.. onto the food... this is what we got:

* crab and pork dumplings - a little bit sweet, a little gingery, the meat was smooth... totally delectable. I could have had another order all to myself... :)
* XLB - again, smooth meat (versus a little bit lumpy and with more texture like KOD)... a little too sweet for my taste. 
* wontons in chilli oil - pretty good. the wonton skin was a little tough and there were too many ginger pieces for my taste but good overall.
* mapo tofu - of course! it's what I get at every Chinese restaurant and this, my friends, is something I'd come back for again and again!
* bean curd salad - thought it's be like the bean curd salad at KOD but it is not.. they use the sweetened tofu with dark skin for this salad and a lot of celery... which I didn't care for. 

Dumpling Kitchen is bigger in restaurant size, too. The staff is very nice. The restaurant is bright and clean. So... if KOD is crowded or you want to try something new and tasty, Dumpling Kitchen is a great alternative! 

It was only the two of us... otherwise we'd have gotten the potstickers, the strings beans, more dumplings... but this just means we'll have to go back soon and try more! Can't wait! :D ...so happy!.
author: Christine C.

description:
I came here not too long ago with a few dining buddies.  We started off our meal with a warm glass of soy milk.  It was smooth and quite tasty.  We had a saucy noodle dish, chow fun, crab & pork XLB, XLB, Lion Head Meatball and a plate of pickled cucumbers.

Although the food came out very quick, it was quite underwhelming.  The lion head was good, but was cold on the inside and had a slight tint of pink to it.  The XLB were quite subpar.  You can taste that the quality of the meat is a little subpar.

The most outrageous thing was the portions.  We ordered a saucy noodle and did not have enough to fill 7 bowls!  Everyone only had about a bite of noodles.

I am definitely going back down the street to Kingdom of Dumplings.
author: E C.

description:
Came here again for dinner with my family and was quite disappointed. 

They ran out of soy milk.

The honey walnut shrimp was loaded with mayo and didn't have much flavor. 

Their chicken & corn soup was pretty gross.

The lady taking our order was so busy telling us she got our order that she dint take our order for chow mein down. 

The salt and pepper fish fillet was just ok. 

The stir-fry rice cakes was good. 

Guess we're not coming here often anymore.
author: Mai H.

description:
Four Words:  PAN. FRIED. PORK. BUNS.  (PFPB)

Get them here.  We have tried other dumpling shops and places, but this is the place for PAN FRIED PORK BUNS.  They are delicious because you have to wait for them.  They take 15 minutes, but are worth it!  Crispy and brown on the bottom, and nice and juicy inside.  8 pieces for about 6 dollars!  Their XLB is pretty good, too!  =)
author: Ali and Nick G.

description: First time trying dumplings and I loved them! Honestly, everything We ordered was so good. Tried many different things. Only downside was that i almost felt like I was rubbing elbows with the next table. Ordered green onion pancakes, cabbage and beef dumplings, bbq pork friend rice, beef chow mein, sweet and sour soup, all was great!
author: Vanessa M.

description: SORRY, but you definitely left me in disappointment.  I do not know what happened but those XLBs were not tasty like the last visit.  Oh, where am I going to find a good XLB place that's near by? Not going to give it another try because my friend who also went with me went back and said the food was not as good.  What a shame.
author: Ann L.

description: This place was awesome.  Much nicer inside than Kingdom of Dumpling.  All the dumpling and buns we ordered were excellent, as were the green beans and green onion pancake.
author: Chris A.

description: Their lunch menu is great. So much food, but very affordable. Their Dumpling is B+.
author: Ryosuke K.

description:
this was a recent find while scouring the 'net for new places to have dumplings and XLBs. been here three times now and only made it past the first page of the menu on the last visit (all the dumpling-related goods are on page one, hehe). 

aside from XLBs, definitely try the Lion's Head meatballs...very tasty and huge portions. pea sprouts were tender and yummy also. 

skip the won tons in chili oil...not authentic or spicy. 

parking can be hard in this 'hood and if you show up at prime dinner time, there might be a wait.
author: Jill L.

description: frequent this place often.  everything is great.  shanghai dumplings probably top notch in the city.  their potstickers are even fill with maybe the same broth as the shanghai dumplings and explode with flavor and juicyness.  great servers, very friendly and nice.  get there sweet homemade soy milk and dip some fried "chinese donuts" into it or the onion pancake, umami...
author: Kevin L.

description:
came here for lunch today with my mom & sister - must say the portion is huge & well worth the price 
we had a order of spinach with garlic - we are being good with eating veggies

ordered the crab, pork & chives, and a reg. Shanghai dumplings along with pan fried pot stickers - everything was good - the dumpling skins were thin & non-doughy and fresh 

we had the eggs puffs for dessert - nice, crispy & hot

we finished everything except for 1/2 order of the pot stickers ;) oink - this is the kind of place you need to come with more people so you can try a variety of dishes

my min now likes dumplings more than dim sum - less greasy as most of the dumplings are steamed
author: Mia C.

description:
Gotta write another review for this place to knock my initial rating of 4 stars to the 3.5 stars it deserves.

High: For two tables of ~20 total diners from seat to out the door took an hour on a Saturday night. So service is quick.

Lows: Some dishes seem to disappoint.

Shanghai-style stir-fried rice cakes were bland and oily.

Sweet vinegar spare ribs were so dry it practically fell apart like chalk.

Walnut prawns swim in mayonnaise. Be prepared to gain 5lbs on mayo alone.

If I'm feeling for a XLB fix and too lazy to make a farther drive, then I'll be back.
author: Eric L.

description: yummy dumplings! xiao long bao is super good!
author: Tiff W.

description: Yum.  Probably one of the better xiao long bao places in the Bay Area.  The skins of the dumplings are quite thin and the pork broth tasty.  A bit greasy, but that's not uncommon.  Their dim sum dishes are also good (sticky rice with fried dough and pork, fried doughnut).  I wasn't a huge fan of the green onion pancake - it's not the light and flaky kind, but rather looks like green onion naan.  Chili wontons were okay - I thought they weren't nearly spicy enough.  Came early on a Saturday so were seated immediately, but by the time we left there was definitely a wait.  I think we will definitely be back!
author: Michelle C.

description: So far the dumplings are delicious. The skin is not too thick and still able to contain the juices in. The deep fried bread roll with condensed milk is a winner too. This will be my go to stop for dumplings from now on!
author: c h.

description:
the flavors in the xlb and dumps were balanced but not excitingly. 

-1 star because their xlb and dumpling peels seemed to be from the grocery store. you'd think they would make their own.
-1 star for liberal use of MSG.
 
the place was packed on a sunday afternoon at 2 pm so thet must have a loyal following.
author: S F.

description: Food was decent (3 stars) but the place is filthy. Table needed a scrub down. Table cloth needs to be replaced. Dinnerware been through years of abuse. XLB was decent.  Whoever reviewed this place as the best have not experienced enough XLB.
author: Thanh L.

description: not as great as i expected
author: Long C.

description:
what a pleasant treat to find this place! the exterior of this restaurant does not do this place justice. but hey, should you ever judge a book by its cover? 

i came here knowing full well that it'll be a dumpling place. i am anticipating something like san tung or kingdom of dumpling. to my surprise, the serving sizes are much more generous!

starters:
-(cold appetizer) soft tofu with preserved egg --this was a delicious mountain of exactly what it's called. i was most surprised at the serving size! it could easily serve a table of 10 with everyone getting a decent portion.

-green onion pancake --this was kind of thick for my liking, almost bread-like. i typically like my green onion pancakes more thin and crispy.

entree:
-xiao long bao (shanghai soup dumplings) --these were fresh and filled with a perfect combo of meat to soup. 

-pan-fried shanghai dumplings --i usually pass on this as i think it would be too thick and bun-like, but to my surprise, the exterior was made up of a thin layer of the bread and pan-fried perfectly. like the xiao long bao, this had some soup in it as well, keeping the meat moist. i enjoyed this one very much.

-steamed pork and napa cabbage dumpling --now these are the kind of dumplings i like! the skin is not too thick and the shape is that of a potsticker. these dumplings were flavorful and juicy. each bite was yum-o! 

-soybean milk --don't forget to ask for sugar (unless you prefer it as is--bland). it was freshly boiled and paired well with my meal.

i would highly recommend this place to people. they have a handful of large tables (good for large groups) and a good amount of smaller tables. it may not look big on the outside, but is pretty spacious inside. the staff is friendly and helpful. of course i'd come here again.
author: Lorraine C.

description:
For a sister restaurant to Shanghai Dumping King in the Richmond district, I have to say it's about the same. 

This new restaurant is not as patron friendly and personal as original restaurant. I know it's still new but at least try! 

The waitresses don't seem to know what they're doing or even where they're going. One waitress fumbled around with our table's teapot from table to table before realizing the teapot was ours. The maître d' looked like a girl in high school, and it took her a few minutes to find a table for four people! The restaurant wasn't even packed! Very unprofessionally dressed staff and questionable waiting services. 

Luckily, the food deserved some redemption but not all. For a Shanghai restaurant it is expected to have warm soybean milk, which they didn't have. What a disappointment. Everything came out in a timely fashion as expected. The Shanghai dumping was fresh but tasted rather dry for my liking, the onion pancake wasn't crunchy but dry and baked like bread, everything else was fine and okay.   

***Recommended: N/A

**Highlights: N/A

*Low points: Unprofessionally dressed staff and waiting services
author: Amy C.

description: Pretty decent dumplings overall.  The XLBs were pretty plain, but the pan-fried dumplings and other ones (I tried a little bit of everything) were overall decent, if not excellent.  I don't want to jump to conclusions, but given the sheer quantity of dumpling shops in the neighborhood, I figure this place to be pretty middle-of-the-road.
author: Josh Q.

description:
who knew XLB's are still good for take out?  they are!

chicken chow mein wasn't bad either, albeit slightly oily.
author: Josie M.

description: Not sure what all the "rage" is with this restaurant & their food.  Service is at best mediocre and I guess I'm not really into Shanghinese cuisine?  XLB is good, nothing extraordinary about - same-o, same-0 anywhere else.  Somebody tell me what's good about this place (rhetorical question) - Looks better than it tastes...experience it for yourself - good luck!
author: Athena C.

description:
again, thru the gates of CLEAN. . .

We were late becoz of the rainy conditions/  Sorries JOHN-  We will initiate you at our next convention there!

Eyes bigger than the stomach, (just the 2 of us) ordering with total abandon and pre-culinary boners, SL Bao, Lion Head meatballs in House broth, Shacha beef, Mushu Pork, Pan-fried dumplings, Col. Tso's Chicken, Green onion Pancakes, and the glorious Golden Crispy Egg Puffs, PLUS one order to go.  

Whether the reason that we were early of the cusp or the chef was in an u"ber generous mood, we distinctly had enough for 2 more robusto eaters = 2 tubs of meatball soup and the larger half of all the other entre'es.

[Uncle Robert, please FW the pic by gmail so I can attach to this./ THX WOK HAY]

Aloha,

C
author: Clifford L.

description: Came here with my BFF for a late lunch last weekend.  We both LOVE soup dumplings and usually go to Kingdom of Noodle or Shanghai House but we decided to be adventurous and try this place.  The soup dumplings were awesome!! So flavorful and rich...We also ordered the steamed dumplings with pork and cabbage, which were delicious! BUT our favorite dish was definitely the stir fried rice cakes. We LOVE rice cakes but we're always hesitant to order them.  We saw that a few other tables had ordered them so we figured it must have been good and they were amazing.  Just the right amount of meat, sauce and grease. Both of the dumplings we ordered had lots of ginger flavor, but not big chunks of it, which I loved. Definitely coming back!!
author: Jen D.

description: The dumplings were soft, juicy and super tasty! Best I've had in the Outter Sunset area so far. Four star because it was a little overcooked (I had the Beijing style boiled dumplings)
author: Mengeskhan K.

description:
4 stars because they serve one of the best XLB in the area. XLB have plenty of soup and the broth is good unlike in some other places which the broth can be slightly too sweet.

I live right next to this restaurant so I have tried a lot of their food before. One of the best dish that I like is the wontons in chili oil. I really like how they mix peanut sauce in the chilli oil since I love peanut sauce. Another dish that I always order is the sichuan style noodle. It is served with a lot of chili oil and minced pork. Oily it is but I like my food spicy! 

Their dumplings are JUICY and they are FOR SURE BETTER than those in kingdom of dumplings.I don't know what's the hype about that place since their dumplings are super dry. No juice or whatsoever and beneath the dumpling skin you would find a chuck of meat.That's it. For the real Chinese dumpling experiences please walk a few blocks down and have it here instead.

The dish that I do not enjoy is probably the beef noodle soup. Maybe they messed up my order or something but the beef in the noodle is soooooo chewy. I could barely eat the meat and I ended up throwing half of them away.

Friendly services. I keep coming back.
author: Ris L.

description: the only reason for 4 stars instead of 5s is that menu online has outdated prices. Everything is about $2 more expensive than version shown online.
author: Paul W.

description: Solid food and great service! This place has inexpensive Chinese food. I really enjoyed their xiao long bao, stir fried rice cakes, and  beef stew noodle soup. The onion pancakes were too oily for me. My friends also go shanghai pan fried potstickers which they said tasted too spicy because of pepper in the filling. They also go a rice roll, which is sticky rice with a Chinese donut inside and pork sung (dry pork meat). They said it tasted how they expected it to taste which to me mean it was ok. I really think it's great how fast food comes out. I left my scarf and they ran out the door to chase me down and get it back to me. I really appreciated the extra gesture!!! I would definitely come back.
author: Annie P.

description:
returned a couple more times,

xlb still really satisfying, and you always crave more!

the pan fried dumpling...its pan fried really well, but the inside is alright.

tried the dry fried chicken wings? kinda resembled...soy sauce chicken wings..just slightly better, but no san tung wings.

dumpling or wonton in chili oil is a pass for me.

also tried the fat noodles, pretty good ( i love all noodles, can't complain)
veggie dishes are good, some a bit oily.

five spice sliced beef- not bad, a bit thickly sliced.

just reviewing this i want to go back for more dumplings!
author: Christine M.

description:
when the white folks overcrowd the "new hot spot" aka kingdom of dumpling up the street and you cant get a table anymore, a new place is bound to open. thats just how it is in sf.  

im happy and very glad to see that dumpling kitchen isnt a cheap knockoff but rather a place worth a visit or three on its on merit. 

i wont even bother with the comparisons. you can figure out for yourself which place is the "best" xlb... shanghai kingdom of dumpling kitchen, you pick....... i really hate that term... the best. how do you quantify what the best is? saying something is the best assumes "your" qualifications of what the best is applies to all..... 

nevermind...

so back in the parkside hood, we drove by and noticed, hey, look a new place. a quick check on yelp mobile and we gave it a try.

good, cheap, soul warming food. whats not to like? 

well actually, i REALLY didnt like their twice cooked pork belly. the meat itself tasted like it was steamed then stir fried giving it a lifeless texture. i believe that they burnt a lot of pepper seeds and it had the consistency of burnt rocks in the dish. a real disappointment. 

the drunken chicken was odd to me. there isnt anything really wrong with it, but cold chicken? its just an odd thing for me. plus, i think you might want to  avoid this dish because you will get freaked out about the red bloodyish bone marrow from the cut chicken bones. 

those two were probably the only real disappoints from my two meals here so far. 

the good? 

i loved the shanghai chowmein. nothing fancy at all, but i loved this. the fatty, what i presume to be in house noodles were gold. the simple preperation of this dish reminded me that simple things can be a great thing.

an off menu item i have no business trying to repeat the name... it was a texture party dish that i loved. sticky rice roll, with fried chinese donut and shredded dried pork. awesome. 

the xlb, hell, i might not know what a good xlb is, but i know what i liked.  i think i inhaled at least a sixer last time. 

the best part about this place? your wallet will thank you. enough food for 3-4 people, about 30-40 plus plus tax and tip (minus drinks.. note no abc license at time of review)

ill be by again
author: Euge L.

description: MmmmmMMM the soup dumpling skins here are pretty good.  It's not Din Tai Fung, but it's the best one I've had in the city thus far.  I am a fan of their Shanghai Stir Fried rice cakes and their chive dumplings as well.  The prices are very reasonable.  The place is clean as well! I went on a weekday so it wasn't crowded at all, but i do recall having to wait out the door years ago...perhaps that was a weekend? I can't recall.  I'm definitely going back!!
author: Jen P.

description: I love this place. I asked that my Hot and Sour soup be made without bamboo shoots and they took it out. I love vinegar too and they always bring me some when I need it. Excellent food and service all around.
author: Wendy L.

description:
You must order the Green Onion Pancake! I've never had one like it, and it has been the est I have ever had so far. It was light and crispy, yet moist, very light breadlike in the center. You must try it!
Other great things here are the noodles which seem to be made fresh, the noodle soups are great! I will have to try the drunken chicken next time, a lot of tables around had order it. Prices are reasonable and the atmosphere is generic Chinese restaurant, but it's warm and friendly.
Service is a plus as well.
But if you come order the Green onion pancake!
author: Sheena L.

description: I heart this place!!! So good and friendly and cozy. This place has the BEST Shanghai dumplings I have ever had! The runner up is the crab and pork dumplings.
author: Bobbie M.

description: Their dumplings and potstickers are pretty good! Combination stir fried rice cake was ok as well as their soy milk (tasted a bit watered down).
author: Rosanna T.

description: One of our regular spots! Awesome dumplings. Almost everything I have tried on the menu is good! Here is a favorite of mine that I don't see people ordering enough....Lions Head Meatballs. SOO good. Gotta shout out my friend Sunny for showing me this place. Love it.
author: Jake S.

description: My family and I came here for the xiao long baos, since one of our relatives recommended this place. The food tasted decent but I was disappointed about the xiao long bao. The skin was rather thick, but the pork was nicely marinated and the soup within it was tasty. The Dou miao was pretty good - hint of garlic without overpowering the taste of the dou miao. We also ordered seafood chow mein, with tasted pretty good. Overall, the food was ok. I eat there again if I was in the neighborhood.
author: Lisa L.

description:
- XLB (Shanghai-Style Steamed Pork Dumplings): the good thing was that they offered more dumplings per order (10) than the place up the street that offers 6 per order.  There was a lot of soup in each dumpling and the XLB didn't pop the second I picked one up.  However, the XLB lacked flavor... it was just average to me.
- Dry fried chicken (boneless): had a nice tangy flavor to it, but was completely soggy.  When I think of dry fried chicken, I immediately imagine the crunchy, honey goodness of San Tung's chicken.......I was sorely mistaken.  Think more like Panda Express, minus the delicious fast food flavor, and chewed up a few times and then served.
- Shanghai-style chow mein: reallly disappointing and flavorless.  The noodles were overcooked and soggy, and they didn't have a nice al-dente bite to it.
- Crispy egg puffs: delicious!!!! It's a cross between those small egg puffs served at the Asian dessert houses, and those fist-sized cream puffs (minus the cream).  There's a lot of white sugar on top, but you can easily shake it off if there's too much for your taste.  Most importantly, it is NOT greasy like Chinese donuts. I like. I approve.

Overall, for a place that calls itself Dumpling Kitchen, I would expect the dumplings to crawl in my mouth and die (in a good way).  The prices were really cheap and the egg puffs were delicious, and maybe the other dumplings are better (but then they should move them up to #1 on the menu instead of the XLB)..... I will not be returning.
author: Betty W.

description: This was my first experience of dim sum-loved it! I got the XLB and they were absolutely delicious. Also got hot and sour soup which was fantastic and the waitress was very sweet. Definitely am coming back!
author: Chloe A.

description: Superb food at a very good price. This is by far my favorite restaurant.
author: hol a.

description: the food is outstanding! tastes extremely fresh - 5 of us ordered maybe 7 plates. got my grub on and was so thankful not to have that sluggish full feeling afterward. it is definitely a functional place - you're in there to eat good, authentic food; no other frills here. will definitely return if I'm ever back in san fran area.
author: Jazmin L.

description: I'm so glad my friend introduced me to Dumpling Kitchen.  Their chow mein noodles are thick and delicious!  What amazes me are their Shanghai-Style steamed pork dumplings!!  It's cheap and yummy!  I really appreciate their fast service, and I will have to bring my parents and other friends to this place!
author: Steph S.

description:
I've been to place for several times already.  Although I haven't tried every single thing on the menu, but I like all of the dishes that I've ordered from this place.

Love its green onion pancake!!

Service is okay..Interior can be improved..but like the food from this restaurant=)
author: A L.

description: Ordered take out last night because I heard from a friend that food is good here. I ordered noodles and shao long bows. Most delicious dinner ever! Will have to come here again and try other entrees.
author: Liz C.

description:
4 Stars.... and well deserved for one thing so far : The Fried Pork Buns. Yes, Ive tried these all over the Bay Area, and this one tops it as far as this item goes. The bottom is fried lightly, just enough to give it that potato chip crunch but not overdone one bit. The skin is not too doughy, so the bun doesn't overwhem. What can I say, the pork inside is very reminisent of a XLB ( sew long bao ); it has a bit of the soup inside to go along with the pork.THAT, my friend, is extremely rare and even if these are not supposed to have a tad of soup, it should now!

I would come back here just for this item, which says a lot as I don't usually go out of my way just to eat a specific item. 

The rest of the items were ok, mediocore at best. However them Chicken Wangs look mighty delish! Looked similiar to San Tung.
author: Marcus H.

description: Dumpling Kitchen provides decent Chinese food at affordable prices.  I went with some friends and we ordered the xiao long bao, pan fried pork buns, clay pot rice, and green onion pancake along with some hot soy milk.  The soy milk reminded me a lot of home in SoCal and it tasted very fresh and was very good with our meal.  With the 4 of us, we were very satisfied and it only cost $10-$11 a person which is very reasonable.  I will say the green onion pancake was not the best that I've had and my friend mentioned that one of the chefs who makes it used to work for Koi Palace so its supposed to be similar.  Other than that, I had a good time and I enjoyed the food with good company.
author: Lawrence E.

description:
This place is awwwwweeeeeeeeeesommmee!!!

I read Cat C.'s review on this place and found out that this was the "better" version of Kingdom of Dumpling (service AND atmosphere), so I was beyond ready to try this place.

I went with my parents and boyfriend..we ordered XLBs (of course), red bean pancake, chow mein, chive dumplings, spicy won ton, egg rolls, egg puffs, AND a to go order of chow mein for $50 (including tax and tip).  
XLBs=loved them!, full of flavor, dough wasnt too chew for me, and it came with 10 dumplings
Red Bean pancake= They didnt skimp on the red bean, which I like, cuz some restaurants tend to do that.  The pancake portion was a little too thick for me though, but I would order them again nonetheless
Chow Mein: there was ooodles of noodles in this dish PLUS chicken, beef, and shrimp.  you def. get a bang for your buck with this dish.  The only thing is it was a little to salty for me
Chive dumplings: these are pretty tasty, must try if you're a chive fan
Spicy wonton: beware! if your palette doesnt enjoy spicy food, it may be too spicy for you!  I enjoyed these, i think they put some chili oil on top of regular won tons
Egg rolls: This dish came with about 6 rolls and crispy, but not TOO oily.  I enjoyed this dish as well
Egg puffs: OMG delish!!  they were fresh and melting in my mouth!  i loved these...i think they're better than koi palace!

OVERALL, you must try this place.. great prices and great food.
author: Kristen T.

description: Delicious. I haven't had such great shanghai rice cakes in a long, long time. The dumplings were great and I loved the rice clay pot too. We didn't have enough people to get a big variety so I will update later when I can recommends more.
author: Gwenn G.

description: Dumpling kitchen is my go-to for dumplings in San Francisco. The restaurant has that typical chinese dim sum vibe and look to it. It seats about 40 people or so, and this place is popular so expect to wait to get seated. Service is also pretty standard for an asian restaurant meaning they're a little rough around the edges, and they want you in and out as soon as possible but that's to be expected. More importantly, the food is spot on here. The dumplings are great, and so are the entrees. I usually get an order of the soup dumplings, and then get an entree or two to share. I'll definitely be back.
author: Ken C.

description: Dumplings were amazing. Pork and crab, and pan fried pork. Chow mein is pretty good, stir fry tofu was great but  a bit spicy. Overall worth it, especially because of the price point, cheap. :)
author: Antonio I.

description: Had a wonderful dinner here!  The fact that they take reservations was very helpful for our party of 8.  The food was served incredibly fast and everything was delicious. We particularly liked the crab & pork dumplings, vegetarian dumplings, green onion pancakes, and shredded pork & tofu.  Service was friendly and the place was clean.
author: Cardinal S.

description: This place is pretty good/cheap for dumplings and other dishes =] everything tasted pretty good. I can't seem to find anything wrong with this place; this place doesn't fall short of a typical hole-in-the-wall chinese restaurant but it's still pretty good! Parking would be my only issue with this place; it can be difficult to find close spots at times but most of the time you can find a spot just around the corner.
author: Greg H.

description: This place has good food and very reasonable prices. I get the pan fried potstickers everytime...soo delicious!!
author: Kristin M.

description:
Was told that a new shanghai dumpling place that was going to be opened in the sunset. Now this place is only a few blocks away from the other dumpling place, so I wanted to see how this compares.

Came here tonight to try it..I believe this is their first opening weekend. We were greeted and seated immediately. The place was packed for a grand opening! We looked around to see what everyone was ordering before making a decision. 

We decided to order Shanghai-style steamed pork dumplings (10 pieces for $6), Shanghai-style pan fried buns (8 pieces for $5.50), Wontons in chili oil (10 pieces for $5.50), and Noodles in peanut sauce ($6). The shanghai dumplings were tasty, but there wasn't a lot of soup in the dumplings. Probably because they steam it on parchment paper or some kind of paper- so it sticks and when you try to pick up the dumpling it rips a little and the soup spills out. Other places steam on a piece of cabbage/napa cabbage...and that seems to work really well. So, the reason why we ordered the shanghai pan fried buns was because we saw every table ordering it! I'm glad we did, because these were basically pan-fried shanghai dumplings! These were really delicious, juicy and flavorful! The wontons in chili oil were really good as well - it was more of a chili-soy sauce, and not dunked in oil (which is good). The noodles in peanut sauce was spicy, but while it was tasty, I felt the noodles wasn't the right type of noodles. 

Overall, there were lots of hits, and a couple of misses. Next time I do want to try the green onion pancake and the shanghai-style chow mein. Those seem to be a favorite of the restaurant as well! I also did notice that they has the dried fried chicken wings, and the black bean sauce noodles that I also want to try.  Service was a little spotty and some of my food came out slowly, but again this is the first weekend, so hopefully any kinks will be worked out. Also 10% off - either because of their Grand Opening Special..or they really liked me! =P Overall the prices are cheap, food is good, and the restaurant is clean. We will be back!
author: Betty S.

description: Deeeelicious soup dumplings! The best I've eaten so far. We tried the pan fried and the steamed versions, and both were delectable. The soup inside isn't so hot that when you bite into the dumpling, it burns your mouth. It's important for my taste buds to function so I can enjoy the rest of my meal, like their black bean noodles (Zha Jiang Mian). The sauce is thick and not too salty, and the noodles are chewy. I've been here twice already and will still be coming back!
author: Katherine T.

description:
01.27.14 with 4 others

ate here for dinner because i was craving dumplings.. ordered the XLB, the crab and pork and pot stickers. all three were good.

we also had a couple other dishes that do not need to be mentioned and some dried fried chicken, these did not compare to san tung like other reviewers mentioned. these were sweeter and not as crunchy.

eh..debatable if we are to go back..

the service was okay, and if you do not finish and get to go box 25 cents. 
since when do places charge for to go boxes?
author: Jay R.

description:
Great food and both cheap and clean!   

Everyone fully enjoyed the meal.    The xiao long boa (Shanghai Dumplings) were definitely as tasty and the noodle more delicate and noodleee.  The dry fried chicken wings were superb!  The Do Miao (Pea sprouts) were fresh and tender and salted and garlicked just right.   We especially loved the spicy wontons.   It was a great place for conversation.

We went here because Kingdom of Dumpling was full with quite a wait.  One family member felt we should go there more often, while another family member still loves the down home and welcoming atmosphere of Kingdom of Dumplings (its eastern neighbor up the block}.
author: Debbie L.

description: xiao long bao here is the best in the city that i've tried so far. the rest of the dumplings and pot stickers offered are all tasty but I prefer yummy dumplings (ie the ones available at king of noodle or kingdom of dumpling). the sweet buns are extraordinarily delicious and a must-have. not a fan of their soup noodles but the stir-fried noodles are pretty good, although I will probably go dumplings-only the next time I head here.
author: Sherman L.

description: This is a hidden gem in the outer Sunset. My parents and I came here and ordered a pre-set menu that included shanghai dumplings, chicken wings, drunken chicken, soup, shanghai chow mein and these delicious egg puffs for dessert. We were stuffed! Everything was delicious, and the best part? All for $35 including tip!! I came here the following week with a friend and had another delicious and big meal all for $20 including tip. Where can you find a place this cheap and good in the city anymore? The dumplings are one of the best in SF. Service is friendly and fast.
author: Cee J.

description:
Love, love, love this place. The green beans and garlic were crisp and bright and flavorful. The veges and mushrooms were loaded with three or four different types of mushrooms and lots of non-onion veges. 

The dumplings were amazing too...what really stood out for me were the vegetarian potstickers. They were filled with spinach, bok choi and other chopped veges. Not pureed into an unrecognizable paste but just chopped and cooked and stuffed. 

I'll definitely make the trip out there for their tasty bites...
author: Steve P.

description:
I noticed this new dumpling shop while riding the L on my way home. DUMPLING shop?! How could I resist? It's so close to Kingdom of Dumpling too, so I was curious to see how it compares. 

I love dumpling shops so I really wanted to like this place, but it just left me going eh...
1. The food
Shanghai XLB-- they were decent if you don't try to compare these soup dumplings to other places (or Kingdom of Dumpling a few blocks down). The wrappers were a tad too mushy (steamed too long?) and the filling was extra gingery, which I liked.
Drunken chicken-- good.
Potstickers-- not crispy on the bottom. they could have been cooked a little longer, but our food was taking SO long that they started to rush...but i'll explain that in part 2.
Rice cakes w/ pork and pickled veggies-- just ok; I've had better, and it just tasted like a lot of black pepper and some extra salty spots
Beijing style pork dumplings-- not good; I expected these to be the best dumplings ever after waiting 40 minutes for them and since the restaurant name has "dumpling" in it! The dumpling wrappers were mushy (probably boiled too long) and the filling also too mushy (my mom said too much water mixed in the meat)
...these 5 ok dishes took a total of 40 minutes for it to arrive! which brings me to 

2. Service
The servers(probably the owner/chef's wife and daughter) were nice and very apologetic, but it really didn't make up for how long it took our food to come out! After we ordered, the XLB came out in 5 mins--thats fast. Then nothing for a good 10 minutes. After my parents complained, they bring out the drunken chicken...which is a dish that is already pre-cooked!  I timed the meal; we didn't get the last dish, the dumplings that my boyfriend deemed "the worst dumplings ever," until 40 mins after we ordered. Which might be fine if I were eating a 3-course meal at a French restaurant! But when I eat Chinese, I expect the dishes to come out all at once or one closely after the other! They gave us the 10% off (that other yelpers found from their coupon online) to make up for the service.

Maybe I'll try this place again for takeout in a few months, when they get their act together, and have improved their dumplings, because like I said, I really want to like a dumpling place. Also, they do serve a lot of dishes like dry fried chicken and similar types of dishes they serve at San Tung. Maybe those are good and I'll try them as takeout, but I won't have high expectations. Plus the servers were really nice and apologized profusely. Oh and the prices are pretty cheap, but that doesn't really matter when it's just so-so food.
author: Jessie C.

description: Went there because i saw all of these high ratings, but neither their steamed bao nor dumplings were good. The lady put her thumb inside the cold dish when she served us and i don't even wanna describe the details about her nails. Definitely black list.
author: Lulu W.

description: love the crab and pork dumplings and egg puffs! other entrees that i've tried were not  extraordinary but they were still pretty good :)
author: V B.

description: prefer kingdom of dumpling.  but good price here.  the XLB had thin wrapper, medium juice so only missing the amazing meaty/juice flavor.  same with the beijing pork and chive dumplings -- not that bursting chive flavor I like.
author: Rob C.

description: Five big stars - the winner of my XLB tasting thus far, though we have not yet been to shanghai dumpling king. but these were awesome, and so were the pork dumplings in hot oil, and those doughnuts - oh, those doughnuts! and in the added bonus category, the restaurant is pretty nice, the bathroom is clean and the wait staff doesnt give you a huge attitude for being white. all-around win.
author: Erica W.

description: The dumplings aren't quite as good as the Kingdoms - down the street - but they are still 4 Stars Good! What's better, the wait is far shorter, service is nicer, and it's not a cramped tiny room - like the Kingdom (again, just down the street).
author: David S.

description: Was excited to try, but meh. Not anything on ding tai fung. Vinegar too sweet, everything was too salty. Not worth the half an hour drive.
author: Jessica L.

description:
recommendations:
 - pan fried bun (green onion, white sesame outside and dough is soft but little sweet)
 - xlb (the best XLB so far in whole bay area and is cheap). I will update it in Oct to see DTF is better
 - kitchen staff are Cantonese (not Shanghainese), not sure about their dishes.
author: Way L.

description: So it turns out that my daughter my daughter moved in right next door to this place the other day.  She actually shares a wall with them and tells me that most of the time when the windows are open it smells awesome in the apartment.  This could be good or bad because she could end up not even being able to smell all that goodness after a while because she'll get so used to it. The good news is that she'll get to eat there whenever she wants.  My wife and I were visiting SF over the weekend so of course we had to try this place.  You walk in the door and you are immediately hit by great smelling Chinese food.  This is a small place that seats maybe 25 or 30 people so we had to wait but not too long because we went kind of late on Saturday night.  We ordered pot stickers that were absolutely perfectly cooked, and we shared an order an order of Eggplant in Garlic Sauce which had a huge depth of flavor, the Chicken in Black Bean Sauce which I felt was very lack luster and also an order of Shanghai Noodles that were great.  As we looked around the restaurant we saw dishes come out of the kitchen that looked and smelled amazing. The service was very good as the wait staff all seemed to help each other out and we had 3 different people at least bring out our dishes, fill our waters and generally just answer questions.  The place was clean and nicely decorated too.  The one major down side for me though was how hot it was inside.  The front door was wide open but it didn't help much unless the MUNI went speeding by out on Taraval and it would create a breeze inside.  All in all though this is a very good restaurant and I recommend it highly.  I like too that it's kind of off the beaten path so you shouldn't have to wait too long for a table.  I'm sure the next time in town I'll be back!
author: Mike G.

description: Came here for Dumpling and Pot Stickers! All time favorite : ) juicy juicy
author: Rachel L.

description: This is pretty much one of the best places for me in San Francisco for Shanghai Dumplings.  Yank Sing's dumplings are good but way way overpriced.  Pork with preserved vegetable noodle soup and and their Sichuan-style noodle in peanut sauce were also very delicious.  I definitely would recommend this place to anyone who likes Shanghai dumplings.
author: B F.

description: On 1/15/12, I took my son and daughter there for dumplings. We had three different kinds of dumplings. My son threw up 6 times that same nite. My daughter had diarrhea and I vomited on 1/17/12 morning.  Our nightmare with contaminated meat  causing viral gastroenteritis. Sorry, not going back whatsoever.
author: Paulette T.

description:
It is a kitchen
A place where dumplings are made
And they are awesome

But that's just the tip
Of the Chinese food iceberg --
Try the chow mein, man
author: Balboa C.

description: good little place, reasonably priced, and authentic. a goto for comfort Chinese foods and worth the trek.
author: Charles L.

description: I came here earlier this week to try out the new kid on the block. Their "xiao long bao" (Shanghai style dumplings) were pretty tasty. I made the mistake of choosing item #2, the one supposedly with crab meat ($9 for 8 pieces) instead of the regular #1 ($6 for 10 pieces). Personally I could not identify the crab meat which I was supposedly paying extra for. I will not order that one again. Their hot and sour soup was tasty also.
author: H K.

description: A family restaurant that serves your regular northern Chinese fare. Comes with complimentary peanuts, which are fun to munch on. Their potstickers, shanghai dumplings, and pan-fried pork buns are delicious. Friends and family always get this every time we go there. I would also recommend the Shanghai Chiu-Chow Mien.
author: Ruby L.

description:
i'm debating if i should give this place 1 star or 2? Why the struggle? well, because it had something good and of course, lots o bads. let's start with the goods- dumplings. we ordered XLB and the pan fried potstickers. they are both pretty good, but the dumpling place on Balboa is better, IMO. another pro is that they have a 10% discount(offer expires 10/31/10) off your total bill, which is always a good thing. 

now, the bads - first, the shanghai chowmein, it's hard..they probably didn't cook it long enough but the flavor is ok. The fried rice is a-ok but i've had much better else where. then it gets worse..the soup. we ordered westlake beef soup. it came out with diced carrots in it. that was a complete turn off for me. and then the taste? bland and thick. worst westlake soup i've had. but the worst part wasn't even the food, it was the service! my god, the waitress who took my order was slow, and kept asking me to repeat the order. i had to point out the number of the order on the menu before she took it down. ugh!!! AND throughout the whole night, they kept messing up our order, giving us someone else's food. you can totally tell the waitresses are very inexperience.
author: Bon T.

description: They closed 30 minutes before their listed time & were rude when we expressed surprise that their Yelp hours didn't match their actual store hours.
author: Roger D.

description: I was planning to take my family to Parkside Tavern for brunch but they didn't open until later so I took them across the street to dumpling kitchen instead. It was my first time trying this place and their dumplings were surprisingly good. I ordered the xiao long bao and potstickers--both had soup filling and really thin skin. A thin skin that doesn't break is the ultimate testament of a good dumpling. It's rare to find places that can do it right and I'm glad I can add Dumpling Kitchen to my list of good dumpling restaurants.
author: Eric L.

description: I should preface this by saying I'm not a huge fan of dumplings, but everyone else seems to be so who am I to stand in the way?  I thought the dumplings here were just okay.  The Shanghai soup dumplings were a bit too greasy (the soup, anyway).  The scallion pancake was yummy but not a "typical" scallion pancake like I'm used to.  My favorite part was the eggy dessert puffs.
author: B. Y.

description: Delicious shanghai dumpling and fried egg puff "sa yung"! One of the best dumpling and egg puff places I've been to.  The soup oozes out when you bite into the dumpling.  I can't wait to come back again.
author: Vee C.

description: The food is delicious and adequately price and appropriately located. Cheers.
author: Cove C.

description: This place is really hit or miss the last year or so.  When it first opened, I thought the food was great for XLB and other stuff but I'm not sure if they changed Chef or something because the last couple of time, food has been awful!!  If the food isn't burned from the wok then it's super salty and oily.   The girl who runs the place from the register is really nice but food here has gone down hill big time.  If you like burned, oily or super salty food then this is your place.  I have tried XLB all over the bay area and LA but not sure what happen to this place but food just plain sucks now here.  I was raving about this place for XLB in the Sunset and even took friends and family here .... let just say they weren't impress.
author: Guess G.

description: Had dinner at Dumpling Kitchen with my fiance, and the peanuts that they serve as a free appetizer had RAT FEACES in it. I have had dinner there for many years, and this is the first time it's this bad.  To not have good ventilation it's just a breeding ground for bugs and bacteria.  Those wall fans they use just circulate heat in the restaurant.  I would not recommend this place for a meal, but if you happen to be there be sure to check your food.
author: Jonathan W.

description: We came here for an early dinner and were seated right away, but by the end of our dinner the restaurant was packed.  We weren't that hungry but wanted to eat dinner before leaving the city.  We ordered a few things to share.  The xiao long baos, pan fried pork baos, the black bean sauce noodles, the rice roll with the donut and pork sung in the middle, and egg puffs for dessert.  This place is probably the best out of all the XLB places we have tried in San Francisco.  The XLBs were super juicy and the skin was a good consistency and they had a lot of flavor.  The black bean sauce noodles were very different from all the other places I have ever tried it, but it was still good.  The pan fried buns were really flavorful and tasty, even the leftovers that we took home.  The rice roll with the chinese donut and pork sung was very different from anything I've had.  It wasn't what I expected when I ordered it, but turned out to be very good and I would definitely order it again.  The service is fast and efficient.  I would definitely come back here again.
author: Gordon C.

description:
I ate at this Dumpling Kitchen several times already.  So far so good.
I recommended the Shanghai-style chow main, pork with preserved vegetable sitr-fried rice cakes, Shanghai-style steamed pork  dumplings,pea sprouts with garlic, Lion's head meatballs in house broth and the original soymilk.  
Pea sprouts plate is a little expensive $11.00.  
Very easy to find a parking space around the restaurant.
author: Jr D.

description: My first Yelp review....    Just stopped in to this place. Dumplings seemed like they would satisfy my lunchtime cravings, but I ordered a rice plate. It was pretty good and not too oily - which is what you get with sesame chicken a lot of the time. The noticeable thing was HUGE portions...  I usually just eat it all up, but knew right away I'd be taking half back to the office for tomorrow's lunch.
author: Robert B.

description: Prices are average.  I ordered potstickers and pork cabbage dumplings which turned out to be the same practically except the potstickers were fried and included green onion.  Both were first class.  The pan fried pork buns were really, really good.  And the person who took my order and settled my bill gave great service, I was pleased and a little shocked.  In a good way.
author: Mitchell M.

description: I have never had anything so disgusting as what i had here. we ordered the sour pickle vegetable cold dish and it was actually sweet rather than sour. ordered their steamed soup dumpling which tasted like it was steamed from frozen dumplings. We also ordered two noodle dishes. JaJiang Noodle which was a black bean sauced noodle but it did not have black bean sauce in it and then there was the dan dan noodle which should have been a dry noodle mixed with sesame paste, vinegar, crushed peanuts and soy sauce topped with hot chili oil but that was not what we got. Both noodles were served with this slurry of corn starch paste over it. It was beyond disgusting. My recommendation is to STAY AWAY FROM THIS PLACE!!!!
author: Gail K.

description: One of my favorite spots for Chinese food, except service is not as well service as elsewhere.  Very small restaurant, but ambiance is fine.
author: Michelle K.

description:
Only come here if you don't wanna spend that much money and Kingdom of Dumpling is too full. (Or if Kod's owner totally creeps you out, which he would if you had any idea what he's saying.) 
The xiao long baos here are more oily and less "pure" tasting than the ones at KoD, but you get almost twice the amount for about the same price. The pork and chive dumplings aren't as chivey as at KoD either. DK has pretty good noodles in their noodle soups, but their Shanghai style rice cakes are only standard. The lion's head meatballs with spinach were pretty good, but needed more ginger and less salty sauce. Otherwise, they were well seasoned and very tender. 
+0.5 stars for better service and atmosphere than KoD
-0.5 stars for really sweet vinegar dumpling sauce
These restaurants are literally within 5 minutes of each other on foot, so unless you're really that concerned about quantity over quality, you've no excuse not to go to KoD for your dumpling fix instead.
author: Skye L.

description: Clean, Cheap eats ... what more can you ask for?!  Great food.  Place was not too busy and restaurant seem very clean and service was above average.
author: Chris L.

description: No class of small business knows how to hop on a fad more than the SF Chinese restaurant owner.  When tapioca or "boba" tea became popular, you had more than two dozen new specialty boba shops.  When Pinkberry popularized tart frozen yogurt,  another dozen new businesses.  One of the latest fads is "dumpling" houses.  This is just one of those places looking to cash in.  The restaurant while serving a decent selection of dumplings does not do any of them all that interesting.  In fact, I would say that the cooked dishes are the highlights here if not a tad on the greasy side.  If you are really interested in having traditional Chinese dumplings, the best are the Sandong style.  Yes, many other regional cuisines also serve dumplings but Sandong dumplings are the standard-bearer.  My mom actually makes the best Sandong dumplings but unfortunately you just can't get mom's food on demand.  Your best choice in the City is still Kingdom of Dumplings and Santung Restaurant.
author: Laurence H.

description:
Good food at a reasonable price. Quantity for price is lacking. So not much value for the money.

Dumpling is the specialty, there are other special dishes also.

Please note the food has MSG so if you are allergic, it can give you headaches.

The food is average in quantity but food tasted pretty good.

4/5 for food.
4/5 for service.

Since I'm allergic to MSG, I probably will not go back. 

Had to take Advil for the intense headaches afterwards.
author: W. L.

description: This place is a staple for me.  I'll probably come here on average once every 2-3 weeks and they've never disappointed.  Service is fast, they accommodate large groups, and the xiao long baos (both steamed and pan fried) are delicious. While Kingdom of Dumpling up the street is probably a bit tastier, Dumpling Kitchen is definitely a good alternative if the wait is too long.
author: Stephen C.

description: This place isn't bad and the prices aren't either.  Been here multiple times.  Came with my roomie and she had her bike and they let her store her bike inside since she didn't have a lock yet so that was nice of them.  I usually just eat dumplings when I'm here.  Nothing superb or anything but they're still good.
author: Hwan L.

description: My family has been coming here for the siu long bao for awhile now, which have been consistent: juicy and steamed well. I've long loved their potstickers, as well as their Shanghai-style fried noodles with savory soy milk. The family style vibe makes it a comfortable place to come visit, but really, what bothers me is how the place gets when crowded. The food quality slips, and people rudely like to just sit down at empty seats despite the fact that there is a list of people waiting. I was also shocked one day to have had a plate of potstickers set on the table and then promptly snatched away again AFTER I had touched one with my  chopsticks. It was promptly given to the next table over, which I think was because the lady thought we didn't order it, but regardless, you should never just take a plate and give it to someone else. It's a health hazard, and it's just not something someone is going to eat after seeing that.
author: Travis L.

description: typical chinese setting restaurant, but the dumplings are amazing!  the shanghai dumpling and pot stickers are flavorful and very juicy, a must order! other items are pretty good as well and havent tried anything to spit out.
author: Def J.

description: Pork dumplings, pot stickers, pan fried pork buns are great! Soymilk, Chinese fried donut are good also!
author: Gourmet King Z.

description: great quality food, good atmosphere and very nice pricing.  just be prepared to wait as they are very popular due to what I stated above.  They do a good job of moving people through so the wait is never really long.
author: Justin H.

description:
I've lived nearby my entire life and I'm amazed I've only recently discovered Dumpling Kitchen. A predominantly non-Cantonese restaurant, the food was superb! I vastly enjoyed their exquisite #1 Shanghai-style steamed pork dumplings (xiao long bao, XLB), #5 Shanghai-style pan-fried pork buns, #7 Beijing-style boiled pork and chive dumplings and #45 Shanghai-style chow mein. The XLBs had a thin wrapping encasing the prized and substantive juices and were served with a ginger-vinegar sauce. I was surprised the pan-fried pork buns were just as juicy as the XLBs. I thought they were going to be like the Cantonese barbecued pork steamed buns, but their pork buns were more like dumplings with a light, BREADY (not similar to the XLB's) wrapping. The pork and chive dumplings were also high quality and packed with meat; I only wished they served some kind of house dipping sauce. The Shanghai-style chow mein, consisting of thick noodles, minced pork, the green stalk of scallions, onions and carrots, was flavorful and filling.

Two of DK's menu items were unremarkable: #14 green onion pancake and #19 Chinese fried dough (Chinese donut). Their #14 isn't what I expected: it was non-flaky, somewhat bland but with subtle notes of green onion (needed some salt and pepper), and more similar to American-style pancakes. But I must say the pancake was huge and is good if you want to eat bread. Their Chinese fried dough lacked the airiness, flakiness and holes that I usually find in Chinese donuts eaten with congee.

Not only is their food satisfying, their service is top-notch fast and friendly. I was impressed when they boxed up our leftovers for us, unlike most if not all Cantonese restaurants in The City!
author: Cliff W.

description: Ok, I live in the burbs so called me spoiled when I go to SF for some food.  I am very spoiled since I have had food such as this at an SF restaurant.  They are obviously well known for their dumpling.  We got the pork dumpling and the vegetable dumpling.  We also got beef noodles with some large noodles that I've never had before at any other restaurant, and some tofu with vegetables.  All the food came out quick.  The dumplings especially the pork dumpling was delicious and well made.  It was crunchy on the bottom and came with a nice special sauce.  The noodles were well done as well and all in all, everything was fabulous. Their service was good on the day we were here, we had ran out of tea and lifted the lid and immediately it was filled.  But then again we came when it was a later lunch, around 2:30pm.  We got to see the staff eat their lunch and they still brought us the check relatively quick even though most of them were eating.  I enjoyed this place and will be back after I check out the other dumpling place down the street to compare.
author: Eating And Living Well U.

description: dude. this place is WAY cheaper than kingdom of dumpling. and there's way more seating. that said.. the food is not necessarily as good. but it's still a damn valiant effort. i fucking love the pan-fried soup dumplings here. don't touch mine. i will stab you.
author: Ben T.

description: Fell in love with this place first time our family tried it and come often. Good food, clean environment, and reasonable pricing. Pot stickers, dumpling, shanghai noodles, fish head soups are all delicous (fresh tasting but not too salty or MSG flavor).  Spicy chicken wings and fish filet taste just right.  Also, we always order soy milk and it tastes good cold or hot.  They also serve the chinese sugar donuts that kids would love.
author: Annie L.

description: The Shanghai Steam Pork Dumplings are very good. Not as good as Din Tai Fung in Beijing but it is a lot closer. I also had the Pork Belly with Leeks which was also very good. This restaurant has jumped to the top of my list of places to eat in the city
author: arthur t.

description: warm restaurant and great food.   i was craving some soul warming won ton soup and it hit the spot. the potstickers were stellar =) great find
author: Mimi X.

description: Hmmm well i have been here twice so far and probably will go back. The xiao long bao, the prize of shanghai restaurants was very very average, it seemed like the microwaved it though because the outside looked dry but the inside was relatively hot and there was nos team coming out of it. The hot and sour soup, drunken chicken, shanghai style rice cakes were all very good, but the daddy of entree's came in the form of the dried fried chicken (i think thats the english name). OOOOH MANNNN it was pretty freaking bomb. But yeah the service is kinda iffy you can defenitely tell that these people are new to owning a restaurant, they tend to forget things but they are very very friendly. overall a pretty decent experience maybe it'll get better next time
author: Preston L.

description: The skin texture of the Xiao Long Bao was not too thick and the meat was fairly tasty but the best is still Joe's Shanghai in New York. Sorry, but I am forever a fan to Joe's when it comes to XLB. The egg puffs at DK was so heavenly!  It's nice and airy with lots of egg flavor and granulated sugar sprinkled on top (traditional chinese style, not the powdered sugar)!!  and each puff was huge!  The Shanghainese pan fried bun is good but my husband wasn't a fan (said the meat was a little to mushy for him and made the bun a little soggy). The thin fried green onion pan cake wasn't as greasy as other places but wish it was packed with more onion. We also ordered the stir fried string beans and my son scarfed it up (he's very pick about his string beans). And you've got to try their soy milk, I definitely loved it!!  Just the right amount of sweetness, smooth and very fresh.  I'd go back and try the other stuff like the jia jia mein in the future  ...
author: Sassy G.

description: I went to this restaurant few times, seems like their cooking is going down hill, today I had potstickers and onion pancakes,  the pancakes were not quite done, the potstickers taste different( in the bad side). the price still okay.
author: Alex S.

description: we ordered the crab meat xlb, it was all dried up, there was no soup.  got the shanghai rice roll, that was good since the donut inside was crispy.  shanghai noodle was ok and the beijing dumpling had very thick wrapper.
author: Luxuriouskin L.

description: this place is literally a hole in the wall. you can pass by it and not even notice it. lol. but the dumplings are soo good. especially when you dip them in their soy sauce and their hot sauce. yummy! the place is a little dirty but what can you expect from a restaurant that looks like this one lol.
author: Cindy Q.
